urn:contentItem:5S8P-4YH1-DY0W-40DH-00000-00Stocks In Positive Territory Today After Industrial And Technology Stocks Help To Pull It Up; President Trump's Trade Team Travels To Beijing To Talk About The Trade Relationship With China; Report Released By NBC News Says Michael Cohen Was Being Wiretapped By Federal Investigators; Group Of Republicans Wrote A Letter To Personally Nominate President Trump For The Nobel Peace Prize; CBS Now Under Fire After Report From 'The Washington Post' Says That The Media Company Knew About Former Anchor Charlie Rose's Harassment Incidents As Far Back As 1986; NBC's Report About Federal Officials Wiretapping Michael Cohen's Phone Is Confusing People Because Of Their Different Version Of Stories; Senator Marco Rubio Now Taking Back His Previous Comments About Tax Cuts, Saying It Did Indeed Help American Families; Twitter's Stock Is Slightly Down After They Issued A Warning To Their 330 Million Users About A Glitch That Has Now Exposed A Substantial Number Of Users' Passwords2018-05-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks In Positive Territory Today After Industrial And Technology Stocks Help To Pull It Up; President Trump's Trade Team Travels To Beijing To Talk About The Trade Relationship With China; Report Released By NBC News Says Michael Cohen Was Being Wiretapped By Federal Investigators; Group Of Republicans Wrote A Letter To Personally Nominate President Trump For The Nobel Peace Prize; CBS Now Under Fire After Report From 'The Washington Post' Says That The Media Company Knew About Former Anchor Charlie Rose's Harassment Incidents As Far Back As 1986; NBC's Report About Federal Officials Wiretapping Michael Cohen's Phone Is Confusing People Because Of Their Different Version Of Stories; Senator Marco Rubio Now Taking Back His Previous Comments About Tax Cuts, Saying It Did Indeed Help American Families; Twitter's Stock Is Slightly Down After They Issued A Warning To Their 330 Million Users About A Glitch That Has Now Exposed A Substantial Number Of Users' PasswordsLanhamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Look at this. We are on the down side, and then that's a big time, 29 of 30 Dow stocks are in the red.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It could be more of the trade fears, China does cheat in trade and we need a bear relationship with that.

STEVE MNUCHIN, UNITED STATES TREASURY SECRETARY: I'm cautiously optimistic about the meetings. I don't really want to predict what's going to happen or what's not going to happen. We're going to go over there and we are going to have a very frank discussion.

These are issues that President Trump has been focused on for over the last year, and hopefully we'll make significant progress.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN LAYFIELD, FBN HOST: A massive 180, the Dow closing slightly higher, erasing earlier losses of nearly 400 points. With technology and industrial stocks leading the turn around, the market watching the U.S.-China trade talks closely, which are now underway.

Our U.S. trade delegation arriving in Beijing led by Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin.

Politics, money, we got you covered. I'm John Layfield. I'm in for Liz MacDonald. The Evening Edit starts now.

The Dow ending five points higher to 23,930. The day's volatile swings reflecting uncertainty over the trade meetings between the U.S. and China that begins today in Beijing.

With me now is Nicole Petallides live from the floor of New York Stock Exchange. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, John. So what you saw was the market that was down about 400 points, turned and finished in the green. We can see it right there with that chart that moved into green late in the day. We could thank some of those industrials like Boeing and 3M.

So there is the look. The S&P 500 and NASDAQ tough weren't able to squeeze out those gains but not too far off that unchanged line. Here are winners and losers as I noted, Boeing was a big mover and that's heavily weighted in the Dow, up 2 percent. Nike and G.E. coming under pressure.

Apple, you know, Apple had a great week up about nine percent announcing that share buyback after their quarterly numbers. Take a look up. It's up 100 -- it's at 176.89. But again, up about 9 percent this week.

Tesla on the other hand, the analysts are saying they've never heard a call like this one, in fact that Elon Musk saying that he was bored, that they were killing him with the questions, they call it bizarre and unorthodox as he interrupted analysts who were asking about profits for the company. The stock finished down 5.5 percent.

Twitter right at the closing bell we heard from Twitter that in fact, they had a glitch that your passwords may have been unmasked and they are urging everybody to change your password. Stocks finished down 1 percent.

And CBS just was on the conference call since 4.30 for the last half hour at least is the conference call the stock did beat the street for the company. But we were listening for anything else. Viacom, they said they will not be speaking about Viacom, anything Charlie Rose they have not acknowledged it, the conference call is still going on, but it was a great quarter for CBS. Back to you.

LAYFIELD: Elon Musk conference call was a must-listen, it was wild.

PETALLIDES: Wild.

LAYFIELD: We're going to have more on that later. Nicole, thank you very much.

PETALLIDES: Thank you.

LAYFIELD: President Trump praising his relationship with Chinese President Xi Jinping as the U.S. team arrives for two days in trade talks.

With me now is Connell McShane in Beijing, China with the latest. Connell?

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hey, there, John. Mnuchin is getting set for the second and the final day of his talks with counterparts from China, and he's brought along a large contingent from United States, a team of rivals some are calling it.

In addition to the treasury secretary, and commerce secretary Wilbur Ross here, the trade rep, Robert Lighthizer, Ambassador Brandstad, economic advisor Larry Kudlow, and Peter Navarro all are on hand. That group already holding talks at a place called the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse, which is used often as a meeting place for foreign dignitaries.

Now, it's not clear how much can really be accomplished. Just over the course of a couple of days, there is some concern building though, that the tensions over trade dragged on and nothing has accomplished. A growing anti-American sentiment will build up here in China that could cause real problems for American companies.

There are stories swirling about China cutting back on buying U.S. soybeans so that would kind be an example of that. We found out about it ourselves on a visit we took to a local food market here in Beijing, we found out about worries building about supply disruptions.

With the help of our translator, I spoke to one of the merchants there about fish that she was selling here that was brought in from the Boston area.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: Is she worried at all that the supply might go down as that conflict continues?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I'll ask her?

(FOREIGN LANGUAGE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: She said, yes, I really have this kind of concern, and maybe two weeks ago, there were some, yes, there was a period, a short period that kind of lacked a little bit of the supply.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCSHANE: So similar comments that you heard there, to what we see many times from farmers and others back in United States. So with these talks we have day one in book, as we get set for day two, we're hoping to get some sort of an update from Secretary Mnuchin or somebody else in the U.S. delegation before they all fly black on Friday evening.

With that, from here in Beijing, John, back to you in New York.

LAYFIELD: Well, thank you, Connell. It's 5 o'clock in the morning in Beijing right now, so please go to bed. Great work. Thank you.

Sign of progress, Switzerland UBS is now testing China's promise to allow foreign owned banks saying today it's seeking control of its joint venture in China, but upping its stake in the business to 51 percent. It would be the first financial firm to take advantage of Beijing's decision to relax investment rules on foreign banks.

UBS stock ending the day in the green to a little more than $16 a share.

Joining me now is former deputy assistance to George W. Bush, Brad Blakeman. Brad, this seems like a step in the right direction. You were with the Bush administration who last tried steel tariffs. They ended up most those administration officials admitted that it was a mistake.

We first started to go after China. We started to go after them with steel tariffs. Once again, we import about 2.2 percent of steel from China. That's not the real issue. The real issue is theft of intellectual property and there's one belt -- one road in this trip where they're loading up these countries around the world with too much debt that they can handle, and a need for China to expand their global dominance right now. How do you deal with the real issues specifically the theft of intellectual property?

BRAD BLAKEMAN, FORMER PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH'S DEPUTY ASSISTANT: We got to hold China's feet to the fire, they know what they are doing, they are a country of makers, takers and fakers. And it's unacceptable. If they want to be a first world country, they have to stop acting like a third world country.

The president is only asking for them to respect our ownership of things that we own and not to take it, not to fake it and not to make it. So I think carrots and sticks are makes trade effective. Right now we're using sticks. And by sending our big guns over there it's not to start a war, it's to prevent one from happening.

When America is at our best, when we stand on principle, when we stood on principle with China we have an effect with North Korea. We have to do the same thing for things that are absolutely in our interest to protect jobs here at home.

LAYFIELD: Brad, what can really be done? You know, President Xi over there, you know, he's a forever chairman right now, be he is still is having a hard time with this made in China 2025. He's got a terrible problem with a coastal economy, the bifurcation of the rich and the poor over there. They have 260 percent right now debt to GDP that they just reported.

He's in a bind himself, with this own Chinese media saying don't give in to, quote, "the bullying tactics of President Trump." It seems like he can't back down. It seems like the Trump guys can't back down. It seems like what we're getting out of this is probably just window dressing like we got with some of the tariffs on the South Korean deal that really didn't meter that much. The quotas did, the tariffs didn't. Do you expect something substantive?

BLAKEMAN: Yes.

LAYFIELD: To come out of this China meeting.

BLAKEMAN: I do, but I don't think it's going to come right away. This is - - this is a breaking of the ice. We've sent the best and brightest there, they know that they speak to the president, President Xi knows that, and this is going to be a long process, but China has got to change their behavior.

We're not going to be extorted anymore and we're not going to be taken advantage of. It's not in China's interest, it's not in the United States' interest to have a trade war, and we've got to use every tool in the tool box to make the Chinese understand that it's going to be business as usual.

A deal is only as good as it is for both parties if one party thinks they are getting a raw deal then it's going to be honored in the breach. Stand on principle, China will find an accommodation, we'll compromise, and we'll be much better off dealing with China out of strength than out of weakness.

LAYFIELD: How can we deal with the amount of strength, what is the main thing we can do that to deal with theft of intellectual property in what China is trying to do in the global scenario right now.

BLAKEMAN: We can punish China directly. We can punish the companies in the private sector of China. There is a lot that we can do, and we can also use the clout of our business sector. Apple would love us to start sticking up for their intellectual property.

There are other companies that do business with China who have been the victims of theft. So, yes, we've got to stick with the American companies. We've got to stand up for them. We've got to protect our property. And we got to punish China when they act in our -- when they act -- I would say as criminals, in stealing property that doesn't belong to them.

LAYFIELD: China is reportedly ordering a recording ban on the Mnuchin led trade talks. Isn't this part of the problem?

BLAKEMAN: Yes.

LAYFIELD: I mean, they control the media. It's a dictatorship effectively, President Xi is there forever. They control this and they have not been honest with their dealings, same as North Korea. How do you know that we can get a deal, and they will adhere to this deal?

Because when you have Chinese companies right now that are listed, they have listed assets that don't exist. And there is no recourse for investors that have invested in these Chinese companies, they are able to lie and have no follow-up. How do you handle that?

BLAKEMAN: Well, first of all, with regard to their own media, it doesn't matter what they control their media inside their country, what matters is what the rest of the world does, that's where the leverage comes in. The United States should not go alone with their tax on China. There are thousands of companies that are outside our borders in friendly nations to us, and allies who should join us in putting the screws to China.

And guess what? China will back down. They don't want their people to know what they are doing, that's fine. As long as we know what they are doing, and we can verify the concessions that they'll make.

LAYFIELD: Brad, thank you very much for your time. I appreciate it. That's going to be very interesting on the next couple of days--

BLAKEMAN: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- on what the Trump administration can get done with the Chinese officials.

BLAKEMAN: Pleasure.

LAYFIELD: Social media company Twitter just warning its 330 million users a glitch has now exposed. Substantial number of user's password. It's stocks is now down slightly afterhours. Coming up, we have the details and the developing story.

A new report accusing Disney on CBS of knowing about former anchor Charlie Rose's sexual harassment and doing nothing about them. Coming up, we have the details.

Plus, the embattled media company just reporting after the bell. We're monitoring the CEO's earnings conference call for any response.

But first, NBC reporting federal investigators wire tapped the phone of President Trump's personal attorney Michael Cohen, and at least one of his phone calls was with White House was intercepted.

My next guest is an attorney who says that's not legal. Harmeet Dhillon joins me next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LAYFIELD: And now this, NBC reporting federal investigators wiretapped the phone of President Trump's former personal attorney Michael Cohen. And at least one of his calls with the White House was intercepted.

According to report, the wiretap was in place leading up to the raids on Cohen's home and offices last month. And it's unknown if President Trump was heard in the wiretaps, this according to two anonymous sources.

Giuliani telling now the Daily Beast he doesn't think Michael Cohen was wiretapped because it would be highly.

With me now is attorney Harmeet Dhillon. Harmeet, this appears to me to be one of the biggest messes I've seen in recent political history. You've got Mr. Cohen who says that he was not paid back. He stands by that.

Now you have Mayor Giuliani come out last night and say he was. You have President Trump saying that he did pay him. President -- or Mayor Giuliani comes out and says that he did but President Trump didn't know about it and didn't know about what it was for.

You also have Mayor Giuliani coming out saying that this wiretap was illegal because of the attorney-client privilege and also if you are wiretapping and the president is on the call, you have to notify the White House.

Was this illegal if this wiretap did in fact exist?

HARMEET DHILLON, ATTORNEY: Well, I think it's too early to say whether or not it is illegal, at least for me, I don't know all the details. But what we do have is this coming in the setting of evidence that that same people involved in this DOJ investigation have sought warrants to wiretap people through the FISA court that were not truthful with the court about all the circumstances.

And it's, you know, really the same sort of group of high level FBI and DOJ individuals who have been involved in getting this particular set of search warrants.

And we've already known, for example, that Michael Cohen's e-mails have been intercepted, so it's not surprising that there is a wiretap order as well. The real question is, what was the court told in order to get the subpoena in order to get that wiretap, in order to get that warrant, rather. And we don't know that.

But it is true that courts generally require the prosecutors to take great care and not to intercept attorney-client communication unless there is already evidence of an attorney-client exception relating to a crime, and that has not been allege yet in this case.

So if it is true that the president or somebody close to the president on his behalf communications with his lawyer had been intercepted that is a very serious matter.

LAYFIELD: NBC News this breaking news has just released a report that they, in fact, did not listen to the calls. I'm not sure if they said whether the wiretap was still in existence or not but NBC at least saying they did not listen to those calls. That's the newest report.

And it's just a new web that's being built right now. This whole thing is just crazy to me. Now it seems to me with plausible deniability that the Trump administration whether true or not has to at least say that they paid back Mr. Cohen because if not that looks like a campaign finance violation which is a violation of the federal law. Is that correct?

DHILLON: Well, I think Rudy Giuliani already has addressed this issue. And you know, some people have said maybe he went on Hannity show last night, and had a slip of the tongue. No, I think Rudy Giuliani knows exactly what he is doing and that was thought out carefully. You know, obviously when you are making a payment like this to settle a disputed claim, which I do as a lawyer on behalf of my clients all the time, you know, you don't want to be talking about it publicly. And so, that's one point.

And so now they have to do it because of all of the storm of controversy around it. But number two, it's entirely plausible that somebody of the net worth of the president would not know the details of settlements like this. And I'm sure isn't necessarily the only settlement. He's been affiliated with Michael Cohen for many years.

And so, you know, surrounding here for somebody who is very wealthy this amount of money I know it may seem like a lot to most Americans, but in the grand scheme of things, people who are this wealthy routinely are shaken down, routinely are approached with these types of threats and routinely make the calculation that regardless of the merits of these types of claims it is better economically and better for their peace of mind and their family's sake to resolve them privately.

So, we know that Stormy Daniels is not a person who can be trusted because she breached that agreement so that has to be put in the context of the rest of the people--

(CROSSTALK)

LAYFIELD: Yes. But who can be trusted between Michael Cohen and Rudy Giuliani, because one of them is lying. Look, I can understand the argument that President Trump if he did in fact spend $100 million on his campaign didn't know about a $130,000 payment.

But if you are lawyer, and you said that you made, and I have no reason to doubt that, payment on behalf of your client. If you're making a payment of $130,000 on behalf of your client it may not mean something to a person with a $100 million who does this regularly when people try to sue him for crazy things, much less some more egregious things like this.

But if the porn star that involves the president of United States you know for a fact whether you did this or not and Michael Cohen has denied it. So somebody is lying here, it's either Michael Cohen or Rudy Giuliani. I mean, if you are lawyer here, wouldn't you know you made this payment?

DHILLON: No, so first of all, I would reject the characterization that somebody must be lying, I would probably if I were taken depositions I would ask quite a follow-up questions.

And so the way that Rudy Giuliani described this was that there were payments made in the form of retainers of some amount every month, I think he said $35,000. So that's different than a check for $130,000 being written to Michael Cohen to reimburse him but that is inconsistent with reimbursements having been made. So, again--

(CROSSTALK)

LAYFIELD: I'm talking -- I'm talking about -- wait a minute--

DHILLON: -- we're talking with lawyers here.

LAYFIELD: I'm talking about -- I don't mean to interrupt you, I apologize. I'm talking about Michael Cohen's payment to Stormy Daniels, that was the one that Michael Cohen says, he was not reimbursed for, wouldn't Michael Cohen know this?

Now the president may not because he is a very wealthy man and there's a lot of these things with very wealthy people. But wouldn't Michael Cohen know for sure? Because Michael Cohen says he was not reimbursed, Mayor Giuliani said he was. There's a problem there.

DHILLON: Well, I just addressed that, so I think that, you know, there is a difference between getting $130,000 check, that is a direct, you know, exact account and retainer payments, which is how Giuliani describe it.

So, you know, again, you are dealing with lawyers here, and I'm sure the language was thought about very carefully before each of these two gentlemen got into the details.

And you know, it is always awkward when you are a lawyer being asked to describe the details of your interaction with your client. Lawyers tried to be very circumspect about that. And so, you know, I mean, any lawyer would be put in a very difficult position to answer those questions.

So, without some further follow up on, I don't think anyone can conclude that there was a lie told here on by either of them.

LAYFIELD: I understand, but again, I wasn't talking about the retainer to Michael Cohen. There was not a retainer paid to a porn star. I can pretty much guarantee you that.

I do want to follow up a little bit on the NBC story. The NBC story was that, now they are walking back claims that they indeed listened to these phone calls. But to go forward now, you have special counsel Robert Mueller filing a request for 70 subpoenas in the eastern District of Virginia in the case of former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort.

Where does this go from here? This seems like a never ending investigation. And one of the reasons it seems never ending is because Mr. Mueller is just not letting go out, like a good investigator would do, but we don't know if it's an actual witch-hunt or if there is something here. What do you think this means this 70 subpoenas?

DHILLON: Well, first with the 70 subpoenas, we don't know what it means because the story just broke a few minutes ago. I've seen the cover page of the request by the special prosecutor. But generally speaking you have to get a court to issue a subpoena for a trial appearance.

And the date indicated is that the prosecutor wants people individuals to come to court in a date in July to testify at a trial. It also says there is a reference in the news reports about 35 sets of subpoenas, so it could be that there is a request for two separate hearing dates, it's not clear from the papers that have been published so far.

And with respect to so-called they are walking back the wiretapping claims who are they? You know, we don't know who they are? We don't know where these leaks are coming from? And we don't know why the people are saying that they didn't do what they weren't supposed to do because they've been caught out in doing it.

But you know, I would need a lot more information and so should your viewers before you reach any conclusion about whether the calls were simply monitored as to a call occurred versus the contents of the call being listened to and who was on the other side of that call at the White House. I think these are all questions that we don't know as yet.

LAYFIELD: That's right. And that's the problem with this entire mess, there's so many reports there's so many allegations that you don't know what is fact, especially because Mr. Mueller himself is not letting any information out until he wants to.

Harmeet, thank you very much for your time. I appreciate you coming on tonight. Coming up-

(CROSSTALK)

DHILLON: My pleasure.

LAYFIELD: -- North Korea may release its three U.S. hostages at any moment, President Trump hinting at it this moment.

My next guest has signed a letter formally nominating Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts. Republican Tennessee Congressman Marsha Blackburn joins me next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LAYFIELD: But in light of all other positive elements between the U.S. and North Korea, three Tennessee Republicans now signing a letter formally nominating President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize.

My next guest is one of those nominating him. Joining me now, Republican Tennessee Congressman, Marsha Blackburn. And I've got to say this, congressman because my mom is watching, you were ask to be called you congressman, my mother will think I'm disrespectful if I say that instead of congresswoman.

REP. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R), TENNEESEE: Your mother will know that you are using the correct title for the job.

LAYFIELD: Out of respect I will adhere to all your wish and I'm glad to know that I'm actually correct with my grammar. Being from Texas--

(CROSSTALK)

BLACKBURN: Grammatically correct.

LAYFIELD: -- being from Texas that doesn't happen very often.

So I want to ask you about this Nobel Peace Prize nomination.

BLACKBURN: Sure.

LAYFIELD: Look, you've had some conflict with the Nobel Peace Prize. There was a lot of people that was very polarizing, when President Obama was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize after only two months into office, you had Mahatma Gandhi was never given Nobel Peace Prize.

BLACKBURN: Right.

LAYFIELD: Yasser Arafat was given the Nobel Peace Prize.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

It seems like this organization does not have a lot of credibility when it comes at least to the Nobel Peace Prize not the physics prize but the Nobel Peace Prize. Why would you think it's so important for the president to be nominated, and I would assume win this Nobel Peace Prize?

BLACKBURN: One of the things that I think is significant is that President Moon of South Korea is who originally said, he thought that the president should receive the Nobel Peace Prize.

If this is a president who because of his accomplishment and actions, and the fact that he is leading through strength if he is able to bring an end to the Korean conflict and resolve this and have an irrevocable and complete denuclearization of the Korean peninsula, that is quite an achievement.

And I think this would be something people around the globe would say the president's peace through strength is paying a dividend, this is something that should have been done long ago, getting Kim Jong-un to the negotiating table so that you are going to resolve this and make certain that it is a complete process. That's noteworthy.

LAYFIELD: A few months ago, if you have said that the denuclearization was on table in North Korea, I think people would have called you crazy. I agree with you that if something like happens it's certainly worthy of the Nobel Peace Prize.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

LAYFIELD: I want to go to you a little further about both about Facebook but also to the story that just broke from NBC News and sources now to the story of wiretapping of Michael Cohen who is President Trump's attorney.

Sources are now saying federal investigators were monitoring calls but not listening to calls, so they're saying he was under surveillance but his phone calls were not recorded as reported by NBC News.

Everybody was quick to believe NBC News but now they are retracting it.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

LAYFIELD: This entire investigation, and all of this mess that is going on. You have Michael Cohen saying one thing, Mayor Giuliani saying something completely different.

BLACKBURN: Yes. And let me tell you something. When I'm talking to Tennesseans what they will tell me is that they know there's Democrats and the liberal press are out to get President Trump.

They voted for President Trump and he was elected so that he would go drain the swamp, that is what they want to see happen. And all of this talk and hubbub doesn't do one thing. To create one more job or put one more paycheck in the pipeline for Tennesseans and that's what Tennesseans are wanting to see.

They wants to see more tax cuts, they want more of an economic recovery, they like what is happening. They want to see the talks with North Korea succeed, the actions against the new axis of evil, Russia and Iran and China, and North Korea. They want to see action there so that we do achieve some peace. They want to see the military rebuild.

And these are things that Donald Trump is accomplishing. This is something they want to see more of. And quite frankly they're not paying a whole lot of attention to all of these different investigations that are the hype of the day.

LAYFIELD: Congressman, switching gears a little bit, you know, Mr. Zuckerberg on Capitol Hill. And you took him to task over Facebook and their privacy.

BLACKBURN: Right.

LAYFIELD: You proposed a BROWSER Act which you mentioned to Mr. Zuckerberg which he didn't know about at the time.

But earlier in 2017, the FCC had the Obama era act which you voted against was a 100 percent partisan, Republicans voting against it, and what it did was it allowed third parties of information to be sold to from the telecoms, you voted against that but then you enacted a bill, the BROWSER Act, which you're the lead sponsor on which basically put that back in place but it just added to edge providers, which are Facebook and Google, and things like that.

Why would you vote against that bill and make it the Wild West instead of amending that bill and adding others to it?

BLACKBURN: Well, I would take issue with your term the Wild West, because what had happened with the net neutrality roles entitles to and the rate classification at the internet all was a part of that. What you need is one set of rules with one privacy regulator for the entire internet eco system.

And what big tech wanted to do was to carve themselves out so that they did not have to abide by any privacy rules. And as we have seen, this is something that is not fair, and it is not right, and it certainly is a violation of your privacy rights.

When you talk about this edge providers, which are your social media providers, YouTube, Google, Twitter, there is a problem with them and their data mining policies, they go in, they snoop around your post, they view your videos, then they coalesce and sell the information from your data, the information from your data, to those that are wanting to advertise to you, that's why you have pop ups and that's why you have so much spam.

And this is something that we need one set of privacy rules that stem for the BROWSER Act. Facebook and the other social media outlets need to get their act together on protecting people's privacy.

LAYFIELD: Congressman, I don't mean to cut you off, I only have few seconds left, but when you put a picture on Facebook -- and I'm sorry, we got only 30 seconds left. Congressman, I apologize to you. Thank you very much for your time, and good luck in the--

(CROSSTALK)

BLACKBURN: Absolutely, any time. Thank you.

LAYFIELD: -- BROWSER Act.

CBS under fire. A new report from the Washington Post accusing the media company of being well-aware of former anchor Charlie Rose's harassment incidents as far back as 1986.

CBS is reporting an earning beat after the bell. We're monitoring the CEO's earnings conference call for any response.

The Federalist Britt McHenry isn't surprised; she is here to react after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LAYFIELD: NBC issuing this update that a story on the feds wiretapping Trump attorney, Michael Cohen. Now, they're saying he was surveilled and that phone calls were not recorded.

NBC issuing this statement, editor's note today, "Earlier today, NBC News reported that there was a wiretap on the phones of Michael Cohen. President Trump's long-time personal attorney citing two separate sources with knowledge of the legal proceeding involving Cohen. But three senior U.S. officials now dispute that. Saying that the monitoring of Cohen's phones were limited to a log of calls, known as a pin register, not a wiretap where investigators can actually listen to calls."

Stay tuned, I'm sure there will be another report soon saying that there were calls that were listened to or not listened to and nobody listened to. I mean, this is nuts. It's accusation thirsty here, we are in New York City.

A new report from the Washington Post accused the CBS and there were allegations of knowing about Charlie Rose's harassment incidents as far back as 1986. And as recently as April of last year, and the company's managers doing nothing about it.

This, as an additional 27 men -- women say Rose sexually harassed them. Charlie Rose, on the other hand, denouncing the Washington Post news story, telling the newspaper, quote, "Your story is unfair and inaccurate."

CBS stock shares in the green after hours following an earnings beat.

Joining me now, Britt McHenry with The Federalist. Britt, the world has gone crazy. It's accusation thirsty. Before we get to Charlie Rose what do you make of this NBC? You've got Michael Cohen saying one thing, Mayor Rudy Giuliani saying another.

They're saying calls were listened to, calls were surveilled, calls were not listened to. This world is gone nuts. What do you make of this NBC fiasco?

BRITT MCHENRY, CONTRIBUTOR, THE FEDERALIST: Well, what we're witnessing is a discrediting of the media, and no one is doing that to the media other than themselves. This is why people are losing faith in what they should be going to know about what's going on in the world.

The phrase fake news can easily be applied when several media outlets are in such a rush to denounce President Trump that they're making egregious errors. A pin register is different from a wiretap listening to every single word being made on a phone call. It's a log as you mentioned.

And to make that kind of a report, and then just say, sorry, we didn't really mean that. That is what is going to lose the faith of your viewers of your readers, and honestly it's only going to help the president in his 2020 run.

LAYFIELD: Britt, I don't mean to cut you off, but the difference between a pin register and a wiretap, that's not a mistake and conflating the two are confusing the two, right?

MCHENRY: They are two separate things. To rush to judgment, as we saw with ABC News back in December, with CNN when they reported on Donald Trump, Jr. and WikiLeaks they had the completely wrong dates. These aren't little errors of mispronunciation of a word here and there, these are conflating facts and it's irresponsible journalism, and they need to do more to the public in my opinion than just issue a press release apologizing. They need to really take action on improving their work.

LAYFIELD: Wikipedia is not 100 percent correct use as much as school kids who don't want to read encyclopedias, they do all their homework on Wikipedia.

Now to Charlie -- I want to go back to Charlie Rose, CBS News saying it had no human resources complaints about Mr. Rose. Also saying in a statement, quote, "Since we terminated Charlie Rose we were to strengthen existing systems to ensure a safe environment where everyone can do their best work. Some of the actions we have taken have been reported publicly, some have not. We offer employees discretion and fairness, and we take swift action when we learn of unacceptable behavior." Swift action?

MCHENRY: Swift action. Some of these allegations dated back to 1986 the year that I was born, 31 years ago. Now granted, there was a different culture, hopefully everything we've witnessed in past year will improve the workplace culture in media.

But to Charlie Rose was going after the Washington Post. They had 107 women that they spoke to, you mean to tell you 107 records of firsthand accounts other things that they've heard that that means nothing? You know, 14 women at CBS, I believe. There is something there. CBS finally handled it, but it was too late, and I think it's wrong to say we swiftly handled this when you could go back 31 years that there were these allegations.

LAYFIELD: Britt, thank you for making me feel very old right now.

MCHENRY: Hey, my birthday is coming up, so I'm getting old too.

LAYFIELD: No, you are not. And I want to get to you about the ESPN losses.

MCHENRY: Yes.

LAYFIELD: But news is so crazy that we don't have much time. Thank you very much, Brit, for your time.

MCHENRY: Thank you.

LAYFIELD: Social media company Twitter just warning its 330 users a glitch has now exposed a substantial number of user's passwords. We have the details.

But first, Marco Rubio doing a 180, recently criticizing Trump's tax cuts, now walking back his comments. We have them.

My next guest is a Florida small business owner who recently sincerely thanked President Trump for these tax cuts. Irina Vilarino speaks out after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Florida Republican Senator Marco Rubio doing a 180, recently criticizing Trump's tax cut, now he is walking back his comments. Saying quote, "Overall, the Republican tax cut has been good for Americans that is why I voted for it but it could have been even better for American workers and their families."

Rubio originally blasting the tax law, saying that there is no evidence whatsoever that money from corporation has been massively poured back into the American worker.

My next guest is a Cuban-American small business owner who recently sincerely thanked President Trump for these tax cuts. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IRINA VILARINO, CUBAN-AMERICAN BUSINESS OWNER: Coming from a country that promise everything and only delivered misery, I knew that eight years of promoting appeasement, apologizes and entitlement was taking us down a path of no return.

Government helps small businesses by letting us do our job and getting out of the way by unleashing the American spirit.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I think the politicians are being beaten today.

VILARINO: Thank you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Irina, welcome to the show. Is Rubio right to change his stance? Are these tax cuts -- you run a small business in Miami, a restaurant, have they affected you?

VILARINO: Certainly they have. They have affected us in many ways. And to err is human. And I think that once people realize that prove is in the pudding and the results are coming in they are right to understand and correct their mistakes, I think that that's wise.

To continue saying that something is not working when clearly it is, well, I wouldn't think that's too smart of anybody. So I think that it's wise for Senator Rubio to correct his stance on the tax cuts and to join in and participate in what we're seeing in the economy right now.

LAYFIELD: Are you an incorporated company? So the corporate tax cut that affected you the most? Or are you an LLC so it was a personal tax cut that affected you the most?

VILARINO: We have both, corporate and LLC's.

LAYFIELD: And that percentage gain that you had that if it's a corporate tax cut, it can go from something around 35 to 21 percent, what have you done with that money? Have you hired more people, have you invested in your restaurant, have you done more marketing, what have you done with that money?

VILARINO: Well, we're definitely investing in our restaurant, but we've also increased our hourly wage for our current employees, and in order to obtain new employees we have to increase our hourly wage because there's a huge demand in labor market right now. So in order to stay competitive and hire good people you have to increase your salaries which is what we've seen.

We've seen an approximate increase of about 20 percent in many cases in a very short time. And so, we're seeing that this has caused a demand in the labor market in order to retain our employees and to gain new ones we had to compete with for those employees.

LAYFIELD: In the political crazy world that we're in right now, everybody is trying to gain an edge. And so you have people who voted against tax cut saying it didn't had any effect, you have people that voted for it that said it did.

Senator Rubio just changed what he said I guess to clarify or correct his quote. What would you say to these people who say that the tax cut have no effects, and the people like Ms. Pelosi who said these are just crumbs that these bonuses that were given out. What would you say to these people who say tax cuts had no effect?

VILARINO: I would say that they are out of touch with every day Americans with lower level employees that rely on paycheck to paycheck. And that they should really go out and talk to people.

And we're not, you know, common Americans we're not worried about the Russian collusion story. We had so much of that. We're really interested -- maybe if they would have left, you know, left it to the side and focus on what the president wants to do, which is better our economy, things would be even better than they are right now.

They've already gone much better but they could be -- they could even be even better. So imagine that.

So, I was just talking to customers today where they were telling me they own a housing cabinet business. And in this year alone their sales have increased $3 million in four months. That's -- so that's significant. I don't that sounds like bread crumbs.

For these people to go out and hire more people because they have more demands for their products is significant for our economy. So I think that Mrs. Pelosi is out of touch, and she would do a great justice to the American people if she would really stop hijacking every initiative the president has.

LAYFIELD: Irina, thank you for coming on the show and good luck to your restaurant. I look forward to visiting your restaurant when I'm down in Miami.

VILARINO: Absolutely. We look forward to having you.

LAYFIELD: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LAYFIELD: Social media company Twitter just warning its 330 million users a glitch has now exposed a substantial number of user's passwords. Its stock is now down slightly afterhours. Coming up, we have the details.

Twitter support tweeting out, quote, "We recently found a bug that stored password unmasked in an internal log. We fixed the bug and have no indication of a breach or a misuse by anyone. As a precaution, consider changing your password on all services where you've used this password before."

No kidding, Twitter stock down only slightly afterhours.

But what's great about this is old bulls and bears buddy, the reasons I do TV. Jonas Max Ferris of Maxfund.com editor and co-founder, and Kadina Group president Gary B. Smith.

Age before beauty, so I'm going to start with you, Gary B. So, Gary, look, these tech stocks, they have been up 28 percent, we're talking about Facebook, Amazon, Google, they are absolutely on fire. Does this data breach, does anything derail this tech landslide going on right now?

GARY B. SMITH, PRESIDENT, KADINA GROUP: It does not, John, and here is the reason why. First of all, I just -- as a matter of fact just before we went on air I tried to sign on to Twitter, and I got that, you know, the whole gobbledygook, this and that. And you know what I did? I did like a millions of other Twitter users. I said skip and move on.

My password is in 27 different locations, I'm sure it's the same password throughout except for some exceptions. And people are just going to say, this happened again. I mean, if this happens you know, almost every day it seems. Maybe it was target at one time, there's been these other sites.

I think this is a big nothing. I think tech is where it's at. I mean, you got robotics, you got self-driving cars, you got artificial intelligence, we've moved away from an industrial society, we're now a tech society, that is still where I put my money.

LAYFIELD: And about what I said there with beauty before age because I want to be Gary B when I grow up because he is a scratch golfer, it's just everything you want to be in life.

Jonas, the tech onslaught that's going on right now, you have bifurcated markets, the tech stocks are on fire, the rest of the market not so much. Does this continue?

JONAS MAX FERRIS, MAXFUNDS.COM EDITOR: I don't think it does continue. And this is just the very -- the Twitter is not the hottest stock in the world. And I will say, first of all, everyone is not reading 27-page terms of service that always comes it keeps throwing you but they are suspicious of them now more than they ever have been.

And I think people are getting less happy about the amount of information these companies have. It's not only their -- I mean, it's their fault that they log the passwords to appear as text somewhere on their own servers. It wasn't hacked they don't think.

I do think there is too much information given to these companies, people are questioning the business model of collecting more and more and more information on you, just to put ads between you and content, often content that you created and your friends created. So, I think the boom is open, the growth era for these stocks were a little ahead of ourselves. So, I would say focus more on boring value stocks for little while and so they can--

(CROSSTALK)

LAYFIELD: Nothing boring about making money. Gary B and Jonas, nothing boring about you too, guys. Thank you very much both of you. It's the highlight of my week. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LAYFIELD: Big day tomorrow, jobs day. Our own Maria Bartiromo will break down the numbers with expert analysis. It all starts at 8.30 a.m. Eastern Time on Mornings with Maria right here on Fox Business.

Thank you for watching. Charles Payne, my pal is here now with Making Money. Charles, take it away.

END

<xhtml:span id="h4" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... lot of these younger people; they don't understand exactly how much <xhtml:span class="hit">regulation</xhtml:span> . It just curtails everything, especially start-ups. BARTIROMO: Yes. SHEFFIELD: Because ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h5" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... have these at massive economies of scale to deal with the <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> compliance....</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h6" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... are going to continue moving. And you've got the rollback and <xhtml:span class="hit">regulations</xhtml:span> that have not hit the banks yet. KELLY: Yes. I think ...</xhtml:span>

<xhtml:span id="h7" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... under Dodd-Frank, right? We had over 22,000 pages of rules and <xhtml:span class="hit">regulations</xhtml:span> from a basket of agencies -- you know, hold them down. ...</xhtml:span>
