urn:contentItem:5RFF-GFF1-DY0W-42RB-00000-00Stocks In Record Territory Again; Republicans Object To Treatment Of Homeland Security Secretary; Bitcoin Plunges2018-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks In Record Territory Again; Republicans Object To Treatment Of Homeland Security Secretary; Bitcoin PlungesLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you, Happy Wednesday, everyone. Good morning, I am Maria Bartiromo. Wednesday, January 17th your top stories right now, 6:00 a.m. on the east coast. Record territory again, Dow industrials touching 26,000 yesterday and end of the day below the milestone marking the second highest close in history. Could volatility be on the way back. President Trump praised the recent record run for stocks.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We've enacted massive tax cuts. You seen what's happening. I have to tell you far beyond our expectations we've made a tremendous amount of progress in a very short period of time, when you look at what has gone on with employment, look at what's gone on with the stock market. Hard time recognizing work We have created now almost $8 trillion worth of value just in the stock market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And this morning we have gains in to show you. Take a look. Dow industrials expected to be up better then 100 points. S&P 500 and the Nasdaq also in positive territory.

Check the European indices this Wednesday morning, and we see a weakness on yields of that selloff yesterday from the highs. The FT 100 down 15, CAC Quarante in Paris down eight points, and the DAX index down 1/4 of a percent, 27 points lower.

In Asia overnight stocks closed mixed, as you see the Shanghai and Hang Seng up, Nikkei average and the Kospi were lower. Call it the crypto crash. Bitcoin plunging as much as 25 percent yesterday, it is not sitting just above 10,000. Why one legendary is saying he's not going anywhere near this craze. An amazing move.

Shocking footage out of Baltimore. Police engaged in a shootout. In a robbery early at a 7 Eleven. The latest as they hunt for the suspects, Coming up.

More winter weather a slamming of the United States. Hundreds of flights canceled in the south as the threat moves north. What you need to know this morning coming up. One thing is for sure. Not as bad as it is in Russia. The shocking temperatures that are causing eyelashes to freeze. Plus, is it the end of General Electric as we know it? The major challenges that could lead to the breakup of this American staple? Big story there, although stories coming up this morning.

Joining me to talk all about it, Bold founder, Carrie Sheffield is here.

Benchmark managing partner Kevin Kelly and beyond sport, global ambassador Fox News contributor, John Layfield. Great to see you. On Earl there

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see you, very interesting stuff with GE, this 100-year-old company is actually getting a chance for a reset, or is this company going to break up?

BARTIROMO: If you're a long-term GE shareholder, this is a sad day.

LAYFIELD: I did just buy it recently for $18 thinking there is value there at the bottom. I hope it's not a falling night.

BARTIROMO: And your thinking maybe unlocks shareholder value. Good morning to you, Kevin.

KEVIN KELLY, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: The problem there is GE was actually was to have thrown in the kitchen sink, when they actually did the restructuring and they found these more problems. $6 billion worth of problems, when they are doing 20 billion of asset sales, that is pretty significant. There is more to come with GE, if they could not find this there is a lot more under the surface.

BARTIROMO: You are on the other side of the trade.

KELLY: So was the market. Look at the reaction yesterday.

CARRIE SHEFFIELD: I hope you're wrong.

BARTIROMO: There is a lot to talk about in business as well as politics. Did everybody catch the press conference yesterday about the president's health?

KELLY: Yes, yes.

SHEFFIELD: 30 out of 30.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN HOST: Stable genius.

BARTIROMO: while I am watching it, I was just astounded at the stupidity of the questions. I mean come dentures?

KELLY: The last president was a smoker and a drinker. This one isn't bad at all.

CARRIE SHEFFIELD, FOUNDER, BOLD: He's got to lose 15 pounds and do more exercise.

BARTIROMO: I was embarrassed by the questions from the media. I really was. Coming up this morning White House director of legislative affairs Mark Short it is with us this morning.

Former CKE Restaurant CEO and America First Policy Advisor, Andy Puzder is here.

Former Trump campaign manager and Avenue Strategies partner, Corey Lewandowski joins with us. Plus, Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

And Dr. Mike, Dr. Mikhail Varshavski, is here, aka in dr. Mike. You don't want to miss a moment of it. Do stay with us.

We kick it off with this top story. Markets in record territory again. The DOW topping 26,000. President Trump weighed in on the record highs from Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) in

TRUMP: The stock market is way up again today setting the record literally all the time. I'm telling you we have a long way to go. And had the other side gotten in, the market would have gone down 50 percent from where it was. 50 percent from where it was. Remember that. It was stagnant, and it was going down.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: It's a big number. 50 percent, Kevin Kelly. I do think we are seeing this kind of success because of the president's policy.

KELLY: It totally is because of the policy. The only reason the economy can do well is if monetary policy and fiscal policies are working to the benefit of the people and that is what is happening. Every Federal Reserve governor begging for fiscal policies. The economy was hampered by oppressive rules and regulations from are doing m an alphabet soup of agencies including Obamacare, you name it and all of a sudden, a new administration comes in enacts fiscal policies and Federal Reserve governors are over the moon.

Great, we can raise three times next year, maybe even more.

BARTIROMO: Is this potential government shut down one of the threats to the market rally the clock is ticking on Capitol Hill just days to avert a government shutdown set for Friday? House leaders propose a short-term funding bill that would fund this government and for four more weeks while allowing more time for stalled negotiations over what to do on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, the DACA program? Is this the kind of event should we see a government shutdown the takes this market down, John?

LAYFIELD: I think it will definitely take it down, it will take down the Republican Party. There is no doubt about that. Seven government shut downs since the budget and appropriation acts of 1976, all have been ideological differences between the Republicans and Democrats.

In no case has there been one party controlled on both sides of congress and the White House in a government shutdown. This is suicide for the Republican party. For the market yes, I think it goes down.

BARTIROMO: I have to push back on that. Yesterday I was watching the show. I had a cold. I still have a little bit and I heard Dagen say look back at all of the government shutdowns that we have seen, you know what, the world goes on. And not only that, but I feel like people are increasingly upset with the obstructionism out there. I think they will blame the Democrats.

SHEFFIELD: I think they will because of with got Democrats like Heidi Heitkamp, Joe Manchin. The nine Democratic senators that were elected in states that Trump won. Including five where he won by double digits.

The obstructionism by the part of Democrats because the Republicans are wanting to make a deal, they don't want to shut down the government this is the insistence by the Democrats to say we need a clean DACA bill, though which makes no sense because that's what we've been trying to do. This is why the Republican establishment lost because they were not willing to be comprehensive and focus on the border first and that's what people are fed up. That's why you see a disconnect, I think you see almost a sequestration between let Congress be the juvenile children, and we will be the adults in the market.

KELLY: Real quick on this, I don't think the market does go down and I don't think it will have any impact on it, in one of the reasons why only in government does the government shutdown, not shutdown. The government won't shutdown, the markets are not worried about it, I think you're also going to see Democrats seeing through to the 30th which is the state of the union. They will not want to shut down the government until they see what the president actually lays out because they have elections in 2018.

BARTIROMO: I want to shut down the government but Kevin at the end of the day the other side we want a government shutdown. The Democrats. They would like that.

KELLY: Certain Democrats don't want to do their because they are running for reelection in 2018, and they want to show they are actually working with this administration to benefit constituents.

BARTIROMO: Who is that? You are so positive. I mean who, which Democrat? Do you have a name? And who is that that is working with Republicans?

KELLY: So here is how it plays out in here is how the market is viewing it. They are viewing that Democrats will come along when they need to and work with Republicans, state tax reform, whatever they need to do. Especially there is no incentive for Democrats to work with Republicans because they were shooting themselves in the foot repeatedly time after time last year. Look at health care. It blew up in their faces. No one is pushing back on Democrats, especially constituents.

BARTIROMO: This is why think that if they don't want to come to the table, into the proper funding for the border wall and make sure that the military is funded properly, I would say the Republicans will say fine, the government shuts down. Which is why I think people blamed the Dems.

LAYFIELD: I just completely disagree, I see it otherwise. We are looking at the tallest Lilliputian here, so it is sort of like neither party is very good. OK. But the Republicans are in charge of everything right now. This is never happened in the history of our country that someone has shut down, when one party controls everything. I think the Republicans will get the blame. But now when you understand your dealing with the least worse in this case, so who is going to come out the worst on this? Because both parties are trying to have a 13 percent approval rating which is less than people who believe in alien abductions. So, it is within the crazy factor.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, the Homeland Security Secretary says President Trump used tough language on immigration during a White House meeting last week though she denied hearing a particular vulgarity during testimony that turned testy before the senate judiciary committee yesterday. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The president Trump used this word, or a substantially similar word to describe certain countries.

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY, UNITED STATES: I did not hear that word used, no, sir.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is not a question, anything similar to that described in certain countries?

NIELSEN: The conversation was very impassioned. I don't dispute that the president was using tough language, others in the room were also using tough language.

REP: CORY BOOKER, (D) NEW JERSEY: When Dick Durbin called me, I had tears of rage when I heard about his experience in that meeting. For you not to feel that hurt and that pain and to dismiss some of the questions of my colleagues, saying I have already answered that line of questions, with tens of millions of Americans are hurting right now because of what they're worried about what happened in the White House. That's unacceptable to me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Does Corey Booker not think that everyone knows that was just a performance because he wants to run for president? The way he spoke with the secretary of homeland security to me was unacceptable. As a professional women, were you as outraged as I was?

SHEFFIELD: With all that man-splaning? As the feminists would say. It was incredibly condescending. And you are absolutely right. This is his platform where he wants to lead the mantle of the resistance against Trump.

I got news for the Democrats. If you want to actually do something different, i.e., win in 2018 and 2020, you have to do something different. Because they tried this in 2016, they tried to be racially divisive, try to divide us on whatever gender, however you want to slice and dice it, the identity politics. The left is not learning any different here.

And in terms of immigration, they want to focus on language and instead of policy. What you're doing matters a lot more and what the president said in terms of immigration based on substance and merit. It is what we should be focusing on. The fact of the matter is the National Academy of Sciences has reported a 58 percent of immigrants are on some form of public welfare.

Basically, what's happening is middle-class Americans are taking their paychecks and subsidizing immigrants taking more than they are putting into the system. That's reality and however you want to slice it, politics is about the allocation of resources. It is about hard choices. And Cory Booker is just being emotional.

BARTIROMO: No, he's putting on a show because he wants to run for president.

LAYFIELD: I think you probably is. I certainly can't assign motives to Mr. Booker. But when you talk about nomenclature you're exactly right. It doesn't compare to deeds.

In the slums of Cape Town, that huge shantytown just outside of Cape Town, last month I was in some soccer magic bus down the slums of Mumbai, I am going to Haiti in a couple of months to visit the same sports programs there.

People are not doing anything to help these places. I don't agree with this term being used of that indeed was used, it is just alleged right now. Not taking away from the fact that we have places like this, the ninth ward down in New Orleans. We found out it was just as bad as Haiti after Hurricane Katrina.

We have places in our own country in our Third World countries inside our country. We are not doing anything about these inner cities. We argue over what we call them. I think this is a total distraction.

BARTIROMO: Why does anybody sitting on that panel there think that is a license to rip into somebody? I'm talking about the way Cory Booker spoke to the homeland security secretary. I thought it was disgusting.

KELLY: Because it was a public hearing. You see the difference between how they act in their private hearings were nothing gets out, nothing actually gets done. In public hearings really use it as a platform for themselves.

That's all it was whether it was Dick Durbin doubling down or Corey Booker putting on this sideshow.

BARTIROMO: Incredible. We will keep talking about. Will take a break and when we come back, police in Baltimore on the hunt for two suspects after brazen shoot at a 7 Eleven overnight. Details on the robbery that led to the gunfire.

Then bitcoin selloff this morning, the crypto currency plunging as governments move to regulate. Is the meteoric rise over? Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Two suspects on the run after an exchange of gunfire with Baltimore police. Cheryl Casone with the details. Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right, Maria. Good morning. This shootout happening at a 7 Eleven in downtown Baltimore. The pair were trying to rob a store when police showed up and a gun battle ensued. The two suspects shooting at police were able to get away when officers took cover to protect themselves. Shots ringing out with the robber and officers just feet apart from each other. Baltimore police say it's an absolute blessing that an officer was not shot in this exchange.

Another winter storm warning hitting parts of the northeast all the way south to the gulf coast. Snow, sleet, freezing rain. Parts of Texas are dealing with frozen rain. Forecaster warning about dangerous travel conditions throughout the entire swath of the storm. Hundreds of flights already canceled across the United States.

And the thermometer has been plunging in Russia down to minus 62 degrees. So cold there it is freezing people's eyelashes and luckily for us they are taking pictures of their frozen eyelashes. Beautiful but yes more than 60 degrees to the negative.

General Electric considering breaking itself apart, for problems with the GE Capital Unit prompted a reevaluation of the strategy. The company would book a $6.2 billion charge in the fourth quarter related to its insurance operations. They need to set aside 15 billion over seven years to bolster insurance results. GE shares down about 40 percent from a year ago. Big story, Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: Exciting story. The said one was the most valuable company of any company. You bought the stock recently because you see value, you're saying absolutely you are not touching it right now.

KELLY: just to get back on that point. One of the reasons why I want to touch it is because they expect to command multiple evaluation of their peers, like Honeywell and other companies that are operating efficiently but with better management. Why would they deserve that?

Their breakup value, sum of the parts is less than their share price right now. So, this is very optimistic where they are trading. They have ongoing concerns when it comes to management. They just announced somebody new in Europe.

This whole thing where there is smoke there is fire, and they were supposed to get rid of it a couple weeks ago and didn't work out. And here we are today.

M: Let me just point out to Bob Nardelli was a regular on this program called it. He said you know what at some point this company may there will consider breaking up. He said on WALL STREET WEEK, a couple weeks ago we will bring the soundbite later on.

LAYFIELD: We have healthcare to windmills, you have a company that is incredibly diverse, they used to say how the economy goes GE goes, I think now you are not seeing that anymore. This is just the biggest shakeup since you had JP Morgan take the company from Thomas Edison. I think they have a chance for a reset. I think Flannery has a chance to throw everything out. And I think that is what he is doing right now. You can get all the bad news front loaded in the next couple weeks.

KELLY: Charlie Gasparino said in November there might be a breakup, too.

SHEFFIELD: I just wonder what role policy and taxes, because they moved to Boston, but before that they were in Connecticut were they were battling this enormous tax burden, regulatory burden. If they had been in a different state, what might be different?

M: They moved to Massachusetts because of that, you are right. You also have to look at leadership. Jeff Immelt took over the week of September 11 by the way, 2001, and that was a hardship for sure. But the decisions that he made obviously were bad decisions.

LAYFIELD: You have $31 billion in unfunded pension liabilities. You have $83 billion in cash and cash overseas that completely changes the balance sheet with this repatriation.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will take a break when we come back. All eyes on earnings. Bank of America, Goldman Sachs reported before the bell this morning. How markets react after see sawing yesterday. As you see both stocks are trading up.

Meanwhile, giant fireball lighting up the night sky it can be seen from six states. Scientists explain that a meteor was the reason for the extraordinary experience. Got to see this. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures indicating another rally. This market will not quit. Dow industrials up 133 points right now. Nasdaq expected to be up about 26. Futures indicating a big rally. Markets of course extending the record run after the Dow briefly crossed 26,000 yesterday for the first time ever. The shortest 1000-point move ever. From 25-26000. Big banks reporting earnings continuing the last couple days. We await numbers this morning from Bank of America and Goldman Sachs.

Want to bring in capitalistpig.com founder, Fox News contributor Jonathan Hoenig. Good to see you. Op-ed in the journal today. Stocks are headed for a fall. That is from Marty Feldstein what is your take on this?

JONATHAN HOENIG, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: We are still in a bull market. New highs yesterday so many big stocks are of new highs. This is the basic reality of the markets that trends tend to persist. I first fell in love with you many years ago during the 90s bull market in you remember up to five, six years, it went up 100 percent in 1999.

I do think there are indicators that the pendulum has swung from greed, from fear all the way to greed, mostly the average investor is at the highest-level stock exposure since 2000. We herd you send stocks right now.

It's a good time to argue for lower than normal exposure.

BARTIROMO: That was a real moment in time of the 90s. Thank you for that by the way. Then, pushing stocks because they have a.com at the end of it, today we are seeing buying the stocks because the fundamentals. The real story. Earnings growth 23 percent in 2018 because of this tax plan.

KELLY: Yes, the difference was that back then it was about eyeballs. How many eyeballs are you getting now. Now it's about revenue earnings and you are saying that come through. It's fascinating if you think about previously the past few years, we were in an earnings recession that's the biggest issue we had and now companies are actually doing exceptionally well, operating margins are at their highest levels. They are hiring. We see the tailwind of the monetary policy finally pulled through. Now we have fiscal policy taken hold and the global growth story that is actually lending credence to all large multinational corporations.

HOENIG: Can I just kind of that really quickly. I think this time it isn't different. Back then it was .com. Now it's block chain. Add block chain to your name, this companies me 200 times in public trading. He talked about stocks, they are not publicly traded. All the block chain companies, all the press releases.

KELLY: Yes, so we are not in the S&P 500, so you look at your exposure, the long block chains are not indicative of the nature of today's markets.

HOENIG: But it's not pushing the stock market higher, the stock market if you look at the Dow Jones industrial average.

KELLY: The 30 largest companies, none of them are block chain companies.

BARTIROMO: IBM talking about.

KELLY: Yes, they have exposure to the block chain hyper ledger, but it is not driving the revenues. Just using it and deploying it. Using technology to foster.

BARTIROMO: Block chain or bitcoin, could it be bitcoin that is the thing that is the thing that takes this market down. Look what happened yesterday. Plunge more than 25 percent at one point yesterday.

This is no surprise to a lot of people out there. It is now sitting as you can see out 10,000. Legendary investor T. Boone Pickens slammed the crypto craze, the Twitter user asked for his thoughts on the crypto currency, and he said at 89 years old, anything with the word crypt in it, it is a real turnoff for me.

SHEFFIELD: I love it, the thing is, as far as whether it will be a drag on the market, the fact that we have a spike in stocks meanwhile simultaneously the drop in the crypto currency. Thank God right now, it seems like it's isolated and it will not have a larger impact like you said on fundamentals. I don't think bitcoin is baked into the fundamentals about this point.

BARTIROMO: But sometimes when you lose money in one area you sell whatever you can sell. And so sometimes that triggers the selloff because you try to make up your gains in another area and, so you sell what you can sell.

HOENIG: The great recession started with a problem in subprime and now was the nature of the beast. You can make the argument that bitcoin is the canary in the coal mine. The liquidity indicator. They would've never existed in 2008 and 2009. It has taken a big ball market. Ultimately have another leg up. People are very bearish on on bitcoin right now. But that is the canary in the coal mine, it will leave the rest of risk assets down.

SHEFFIELD: But it is not integrated the way subprime mortgages were. On these other layers on top of it. You have systemic risk but --

LAYFIELD: One thing integrated in the market his inflation. You look at a copper it is up 31 percent. I know you follow commodities. Oil is at $65. China imported deflation a long time. Now looks like they are exporting inflation. Is that your biggest worry right now?

HOENIG: I will spare you my opinions and give you my position. The platinum metals you mentioned copper, but now is a good time to have platinum, Palladium, rhodium. I think those are good place right now, because you want to take things that are counter to the S&P 500. You want to find alternative assets that are doing well. So, I think those are once look at.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for stopping by. Really good to see you.

More hacking by North Korea. The United States accusing the regime of crypto currency tax and South Korea, similar to the massive cyber attack on Sony pictures. A surge of excitement as power returns to one Puerto Rico school, the heartwarming video, the reality and struggles that the island still faces this morning. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, January 17th, your top stories right now 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast. The rising North Korea threat, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson warning a military option could be on the table if Kim Jong-un does not choose negotiations.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REX TILLERSON, SECRETARY OF STATE: With respect to whether Americans should be concerned about a war with North Korea, I think it's -- we all need to be very sober and clear eyed that that threat is growing and if North Korea is not -- does not choose the pathway of engagement, discussion, negotiation, then they themselves will trigger an option.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: More on that and new concerns this morning over the regime's ties to cyber attacks on crypto currency. Earnings season in focus on Wall Street. Several big banks reporting ahead of the open this morning, including Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, we will bring you the numbers as soon as they hit the tape, and check those stocks.

Markets this morning, looking good, futures pointing to another rally at the start of trading this morning, we are now at the highs of the morning with the Dow industrials up 145 points, the NASDAQ up 28 points. We're looking a strength this morning, for the S&P 500, after a wild session on Wall Street yesterday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rallied all the way up to 26,000 cracking yet another new milestone. But then, toward the end of the day, erase the games as the session wore on.

We saw some real volatility. Checking the overseas action this morning, as you see, the markets are looking lower. And the FT 100 is down 14 points, the CAC Quarante and the DAX Index also weaker, on the heels of that, we close for Wall Street yesterday. In Asia overnight, stocks were mixed, Shanghai composite up a quarter of a percent, as well as the Hang Seng in Hong Kong.

Celgene, eyeing a second deal in as many weeks. The Wall Street Journal this morning reporting the biotech company is in talks to acquire Juno Therapeutics. The stock is soaring on the news. Check it out. Juno Therapeutics up, 50 percent in the pre-market this morning. A major milestone for one school on Puerto Rico, kids erupting in cheers as the power comes back on after three months of no power, the heart-warming video, coming up.

Plus, lighting up the night, a meteor shooting across the sky, so powerful it triggered a small earthquake. We will bring it to you, coming up. But first, this top story this half an hour, crypto hacked, a U.S. cyber security firm has identified a North Korean hacking outfit as the hackers behind the latest crypto currency attacks in South Korea. This is the same group responsible for the Sony hacks at the end of last year. Joining us right now is Endgame CEO, Nate Fick, Nate, good to see you. Thanks so much for weighing in this morning.

NATE FICK, CEO OF ENDGAME: Hi, Maria, good morning.

BARTIROMO: So, how vulnerable is this crypto currency to hack?

FICK: Look, we live in a world that's increasingly digitally connected. We're connecting a billion things to the internet every quarter, including increasingly now, currencies and cars and other things that we hadn't previously thought of as digital. So, there's exposure there, obviously. And when you talk about war with a place like North Korea and the United States, you're talking about a potential war between a strong country and a weak country. And the cyber capabilities can we weapons for the weak. They're cheap and easy to develop.

KELLY: Here's my biggest issue, it's Kevin Kelly, I see all these things coming out in North Korea and I'm like, how is the regime like this able to get due anything possible, such as come up with the WannaCry, such as develop nuclear weapons. And the only thing coming in to my head is that they're enabled by China.

I see, you know, North Korea as a proxy for China to develop things, figure out how they can actually come up with the tax, they can place blame. You know, what is your take on that that North Korea's being enabled by China, especially in the cyber security realm because we've seen these attacks happen, but the only way North Korea gets internet is through China.

FICK: Well, look, one of the realities of cyber security is that defense is really hard, but attacking is pretty easy. And think about the attacks, even here on the United States that have been launched by, you know, a kid and his parents' basement.

So, the reality is that the barriers to entry to this, kind of, high-end cyber capability are falling. And it's likely that North Korea's getting outside help. But, it's also not beyond the realm of possibility that a handful of people relatively well-equipped can do these themselves.

LAYFIELD: Nate, this is John Layfield, this appears to be their only option, right? I mean, they don't have the gas, little gasoline to invade South Korea. They don't have any money. So their only option out there is to either be a cyber-terrorist or develop nuclear weapons. Isn't that right? This is a matter just of self-survival.

FICK: There's a great book about the Vietnam War, called The War of the Flea, that makes this point. That in asymmetrical conflicts, conflicts between the strong and the weak. These are the sorts of things the weak adversary does. Cyber security, cyber capabilities are cheap and easy to develop, so yes, I agree with you. You go to the low end of the spectrum and develop these kinds of capabilities, or you go to the high-end of the spectrum, the nuclear end, to try to deter the United States.

CARRIE SHEFFIELD, FOUNDER, BOLD GLOBAL MEDIA: Well, and this is Carrie Sheffield, so, there was elections in South Korea last year and word on the street is that the new leader they have there, he is not as pro-western as some of his predecessors.

What's your assessment of that? There's even talk that he wants to reopen the case on industrial conflicts, which by my mind, would allow millions of dollars to flow into North Korea, to the point we said earlier, that would allow the North Koreans to have access to more capital which means that they could do more damage.

FICK: I think there's a reality that the South Koreans have to live next door to North Korea and are probably going to be a little bit more, you know, potentially pragmatic or even accommodationist, then the United States can be across the Pacific Ocean. BARTIROMO: Right. And you're absolutely right. I mean you're basically being held hostage and running the government every two weeks.

BARTIROMO: That's a pretty incredible number actually. But you're also facing a group where they would prefer the government to shut down because they don't want the legislative agenda to get executed, isn't that right?

But again, this is no way to run a government. We continue to do this every couple of weeks.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SHORT: The administration submitted a budget in February of 2017 and here we are again in mid-January without funding for 2018, much less beginning in 2019.

BARTIROMO: Well, let's talk about the broader agenda -- Marc. This is the -- an anniversary week for the President, the first year in office under his belt. What are the priorities for '18?

BARTIROMO: All the while, Democrats have been saying that they want infrastructure. Reports say that the President will actually present an infrastructure plan during the State of the Union. Do you have plans to tout an infrastructure plan for the State of the Union?

SHORT: There are plans for that. The President has a plan in place; it's a matter of timing. We will continue to have conversations with Congress. We have a lot of plans to begin the year. But to your point, Democrats will have to make a case as to why not -- not one of them voted for tax relief that now 2.1 million Americans now -- 2.1 million workers have either received a bonus or a pay increase since the tax release -- since the tax package was passed just a couple of weeks ago.

SHORT: That's a great question -- Maria. I think the reality is that on the border security, keep in mind in 2006 most Democrats voted for the Secure Fence Act that would have funded the wall including Chuck Schumer.

In 2013, over $40 billion was in the Democrat plan on part of their Dream Act to provide border security. So they have been willing to vote for it before. The only difference now is that Donald Trump is president.

WILLIAMS: Founders Fund. Founders Fund, right?

WILLIAMS: Mark Cuban is one of our investors. So again, there's a diverse group of investors across the political spectrum. What we focused on is building what we believe will be one of the best business of our generation, again, so more people can invest. That's a testament to Goldman.

BARTIROMO: So Tell me where the growth comes from at Cadre in the coming five years.

WILLIAMS: Sure. So, first and foremost we want to make sure that we're expanding nationally, right? With real estate opportunities. When I started the company, it's primarily based out of New York. We've been able to expand and grow into multiple markets. You know, we have a billion in assets on our platform right now. We're going to probably double that over the next 12 months here in the U.S. Over time we want to do is expand internationally and then explore opportunities across asset classes, right? Real estate is a quality asset class to invest in but it's not the only asset class we think more people should be able to invest in or that our investors invest in. So maybe there's an opportunity for infrastructure or natural resources or timber and oil, private equity, a lot of these verticals are historically have been opaque and challenging for people to access, we want to change.

BARTIROMO: Real quick. Where are the best opportunities right now for real estate in the country? Geographically speaking or even sector speaking, where do you find value?

WILLIAMS: So we find a lot of value in a few sectors. First, multifamily, right? We believe that people always need somewhere to live and we're focused on cash tax -- adjusted in the second yield, right? So we want to make sure that people can invest in quality opportunities that are existing asset in and around gateway markets. So we focus on a lot of multifamily across our portfolio. We actually think there is a lot of quality opportunities in the office sector as well. We like office because again you can buy their pretty good basis today given there's so many quality operating partners bring us skills.

BARTIROMO: Do you avoid high-tax states?

WILLIAMS: So, we focus first -- look, this is --

BARTIROMO: No. Because tax law changes.

WILLIAMS: It's a hundred percent something we focus on in terms of just overall returns to our investors. I think the beauty of real estate, right? Is the largest asset class in the world also the most imperfect, so there's always bound to the inefficiencies. So like stocks, you get a good management team that can find opportunities. So for us, it's really about micro-level investing. We overlay the macros well.

BARTIROMO: Are you going to take the company public soon?

WILLIAMS: I think we'll focus on this year, the following year. Like I told our team all the time, we do the right thing, we focus on value to our users, to our customers. I think we'll trancede NASDAQ -- exceed rather, anyone's expectations and IPO, who knows.

BARTIROMO: At some point?

WILLIAMS: Potentially, yes.

BARTIROMO: Ryan, it's good to have you on the program.

WILLIAMS: Thank you for having me. Appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Congratulations on that huge injection from Goldman.

WILLIAMS: Thank you, Maria, appreciate it.

BARTIROMO: We will take a break. The impact of President Trump's tax plan on wineries in California coming up. How the industry is cashing in big time with the new reforms. And then Goldman Sachs reporting earnings four quarter earnings this morning beating earnings and revenue expectations. We break down those numbers, the stock still lower this morning by a fraction. Stay with us.

LEIF SHIRAS, TENNIS CHANNEL COMMENTATOR: Welcome back to another Tennis Channel Court report. A special presentation for Fox Business. I'm Leif Shiras. The 2018 edition of the Australian Open reached the second round Wednesday in Melbourne with some of the biggest names in the sport in action. U.S. Open champion Rafael Nadal continued his quest for a second straight major title with a routine victory over Leonardo Mayer. Rafa moved on to face Damir Dzumhur in the third round. Elsewhere, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga had to dig deep and use all his experience to see off the challenge off next-gen Denis Shapovalov. The French then was 5-2 down in deciding fifth set before pulling off the win 7-5 after over 3-1/2 hours on court. And don't forget Tennis Channel's live coverage from Melbourne continues Wednesday at 6 p.m. Eastern.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, January 17th. Your top stories right now 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. Wall Street in record territory again, the Dow Industrials yesterday cracked another all-time high and milestone of 26,000 stocks came off of the highs however and closed lower erasing all of the games and then some closing down about 10 points on the Dow. President Trump touting this market's record run.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We've enacted massive tax cuts, you've seen it, you've seen what's happening. I have to tell you that far beyond our expectations we have made a tremendous amount of progress in a very, very short period of time. When you look at what's gone on with the employment, when you look at what has gone on with the stock market, we have created now almost $8 trillion worth of value just in the stock market.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Checking the action this morning, we are an hour away from the open and the markets are back in record territory once again. Dow Industrials up 96 points this morning, a third of a percent high. This is off of the highs of the morning but nonetheless look at that a very strong opening for stocks about an hour. In Europe this morning, stocks are lower FTSE 100 and the DAX Index down about a quarter of a percent of piece. The CAC Quarante in Paris is also down fractionally. In Asia overnight, stocks closed mixed as you see, Hang Seng index and the Shanghai were higher. Financial earnings in focus, Bank of America reporting mixed results for the fourth quarter Goldman Sachs hurt by weak trading at a $4 billion hit from tax reform. Call it crypto crash, Bitcoin sold off trading near $10,000 now after new concerns over government regulation. The end of era for General Electric could be at hand, the company eyes are breakup as it struggles to shore up business, the stock continues to trade down another 2-1/2 percent right now.

McKayla Maroney no longer has to worry about a nondisclosure agreement she signed about the abuse she faced at the hands of Dr. Larry Nassar. USA Gymnastics will not pursue a fine if she speaks out but two celebrities also stepped up with an offer to pay. Plus the Super Bowl just over two weeks away and we have the first look at ticket prices, the lowest ticket price get this $950. Good luck getting it with that price meanwhile.

All that coming up but first this nearly 100 days of record closes on the Dow since President Trump's election. Listen to what FedEx CEO Frederick Smith told Stuart Varney about his tax reform. And how it's boosting optimism for the bottom line.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FREDERICK SMITH, CEO, FEDEX: The market is reflecting growth around the world which of course we see, we serve 220 countries nobody sees the global economy the way we do. And it's pretty well synced up and you have a better situation for business with the reduction and regulations and most importantly this tax bill.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is America First Policies policy advisory and former CKE restaurants CEO, Andy Puzder. Andy, good to see you.

ANDY PUZDER, CEO, CKE RESTAURANTS: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So how would you characterize where things are right now? We know that the market has been trading on real fundamentals, people are also expecting four percent economic growth this year. What can you tell us in terms of what you're seeing?

PUZDER: Look. I think it's spectacular. This is the most booming economy that I can ever remember experiencing and I, you know, I was 30 years old in my 30s during the Reagan years. This -- the energy here is incredible, the business optimism that and you hear a lot about the big companies in optimistic there. I've got friends who are franchisees, you know, small business owners that were with our company and other companies and they're talking about building. They used to talk about how can I build? How can I afford to pay for healthcare? How can I afford to pay this minimum rate wage increases? Now they're worried about competing for sites, they're worried about competing for real estate because there is so much demand. So I think -- I think we will see four percent next year and I think we are going to see wage growth.

BARTIROMO: You know what if the conversation Kevin has changed from how am I going to pay for all the lawyers and the compliance officers that I need to keep up with regulation to how am I going to grow? Where am I going to invest for growth?

KELLY: Yes. I think Andy is bringing up a great point because -- and one of the reasons why we're seeing this is because of the current tax environment right. It was harder for U.S. corporations to invest in the United States than it was for foreign corporations, right? And we saw that happen precipitously with deals ever coming in from overseas and the tax environment wasn't beneficial, are you seeing -- and I am curious Andy, are the guys talking about -- pass-through entities, the deductions, what is the main emphasis for them to invest and deploy their capital into the U.S. here?

PUZDER: Well, you invest when you believe your business is going to go up and that you can make a profit. Another if your costs are down enough that you can make a significant enough profit that you're willing to risk your wealth, you're willing to risk your time and what they are seeing is regulatory costs down, tax costs down, optimism very high, so they're anticipating growth. So this isn't rocket science, if people think they can make money, they will invest in growth. And what we had during the Obama years was people -- they didn't believe they could make money so growth held GDP down now we're seeing more investment, even before the tax bill we've seen an increase in investment which is what the GDP to three percent. Now we're going to see really I think very, very substantial investment. The big problem for small businesses is the Dodd-Frank. Because it killed a lot of the community banks but there are lenders out there and they will continue to look for money and build as long as they believe they can make money at it.

CARRIE SHEFFIELD, FOUNDER, BOLD: Andy, in addition (INAUDIBLE) what are you seeing on regulatory side because I know for example on the labor side there was this big Obama era regulation around to an employer mandate and all this sort of regulation. Are you seeing released in this while in addition to tax reform?

PUZDER: Absolutely it's both joining employer and minimum wage. Now wages are going up because of competition but they're not being forced up to where you're reducing the profitability. These companies are actually competing for employees with growth. And joining employer was a very, very fearful thing for small business particularly franchise businesses because it looked like the franchisors, the larger companies are going to end up controlling their labor costs. Well, that is not franchising at that point you are a subsidiary of the big company and entrepreneurs don't want that. Now that trade is gone, so people are very excited as I said we're seeing - - we're seeing a lot of building.

LAYFIELD: We talked about the investment that you had. Morgan Stanley plan index just said that 2007 -- since 2007 the biggest CapEx spending has happened mainly since President Trump and the perception of business current administration, low-interest rates, people already building a lot of CapEx. Do you see a lot of extra CapEx being spent -- being built with this repatriation? I call it repatriation money, I just don't think we're going to see a lot of CapEx because we already -- you've already seen a lot of it.

PUZDER: Well, I -- you know we ever really have seen the money come back yet so you are not seeing it I think you will see it going forward. But the big -- you know, where I see, you know, look, I would get same numbers everybody else looks at. The Bureau of Labor Statistics you look and see how much money, if the census period when you look at whether GDP has gone up and you look at -- they see -- whether it is because people invested or not and they have been saying during the Obama administration, people weren't investing kept GDP down. The last two quarters, the investment has gone up. So this -- again, it's not rocket science if you --

BARTIROMO: But do they have to --

PUZDER: You get investment.

BARTIROMO: Do they have to bring the money back? And I was surprised that a 15-1/2 repatriation rate, we were talking 10 percent, we were talking eight percent 15-1/2 percent is -- do they have to bring the money back at this point?

PUZDER: I don't think they have to bring the money back but I think they will want to bring it back, people want to build and invest in the United States.

BARTIROMO: And they will at 15-1/2 percent you think?

PUZDER: Yes. Well, I mean if you're in Germany and you can invest in the United States without a tax penalty, you could your bring money here to invest if you make money in Germany and you pay higher than 15 percent, you're not going to bring back competitive with Germany. So I think we will see investment, I -- we just haven't seen it yet.

BARTIROMO: By the way, I was speaking to one investment pro this week. And he said to me that he spoke with a lot of the companies that they own, this private equity guy. And he said that in Europe, they are saying you know what we were planning on investing in Europe but we are going to switch those plans and we're going to invest in America because of this tax plan. This is actually changing behavior across the world.

PUZDER: Well, in Japan, Germany, China and they've all expressed distress at the fact that we passed this tax bill. That's a good thing for us, that's something we want in the United States.

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: We're competitive before, right? If you looked at the worldwide averages was that 22-1/2 percent, we reached 35, we already complete disadvantage I mean that's the thing. So now they're freaking out, they're trying to figure out if you look at -- if you look at the U.K. they are at 20 percent, they are looking to go to 17-1/2 percent.

PUZDER: We were the fastest runner on the track. We were running with leg weights, we just took them off.

BARTIROMO: Andy, are you going to go back to the White House?

PUZDER: Look political -- I am glad you asked that. They ran an article claiming that I was getting an offer from the White House. I told them that I hadn't heard anything about it, they called friends of mine and all of them said they heard nothing about it. I talked to friends in the White House who heard nothing about it, they just made this up basically to reraise the salacious allegations from my divorce 30 years ago. They try and raise from whatever they can I, you know, it's -- I don't know. But there was nothing, I have no discussions about going back but if the president ask me to mow the lawn, I would mow the lawn. Whatever is going to make this administration work, I'm happy to help but right now I'm focused on doing it as a private citizen and enjoying myself. I think I am having -- my wife said, you know, I would like to see you be a secretary of labor would have been great, it would be good for the country but aren't we really having a lot more fun? That, you know, she's kind of right. BARTIROMO: You must have an opinion about the 18 states that just raised the minimum wage.

PUZDER: Well, as long as they don't -- the key with the minimum wage is not to raise it above where competition has driven it. And I think what we've seen with Wal-Mart going to $11 an hour in a lot -- in a lot of -- in a major sections of the country that will set the minimum wage, competition will set it. If you want the best employees, if you are running a muffler shop or a restaurant, you're competing with Wal-Mart for those employees. And if you want the best you're going to have to meet their price. So if the minimum wage goes from 7.50 to 8.50 to 9.50 at this point it really doesn't matter much.

The economy is growing at such a pace, the competition is outstripping government and really government -- when government sets those rates the only thing the federal government can do is set the lowest possible rate because if you don't then places that are economically distressed like let's say Birmingham or Memphis, Tennessee if you drive them to $15 an hour you hurt them you don't help anybody. So you can't set it to what you got, what you got in Seattle or San Francisco you have to set it low. Competition drives it, it's kind of like a tide that drives to where the tide goes and Wal-Mart has just taken a big step in moving to 11. And I think people should be excited about that, President Obama wanted 10-10, Wal-Mart went to 11. Let's praise them.

(CROSSTALK)

SHEFFIELD: If you were labor secretary, what would have been the very first thing you would have done in office? What would be your top priority?

PUZDER: Well, the first thing I would have done was try and get people in there to help run the department. They're still the person that I wanted to have my number two it's the same person that Alex Acosta wants his number two. And, you know, I thought the person would be approved by mayor -- and they're still not approved.

SHEFFIELD: Wow.

PUZDER: So you really -- you got -- you go into -- you go into this agency and you've got people that are right then and there, you've got resistance within your agency. And it's not like a private business where you can start firing people and bring everybody in line.

(CROSSTALK)

PUZDER: But I would have worked on joint employer, the overtime regulation you know really focused on things that drive jobs.

BARTIROMO: Andy, great to have you on the show.

PUZDER: Great to be here, Maria. Thank you. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Andy Puzder joining us there. We will be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BOB NARDELLI, FOUNDER, XLR-8: I hope that -- you know, I hope the swan song here isn't, you know, pushed down 28,000 corporate people, put them into businesses, move them out, sell the final three, and then all of a sudden G.E. goes away of Westinghouse. It would be a terrible -- a terrible saga for a legacy company.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, unfortunately, that is the conversation. That was G.E.'s former transportation CEO Bob Nardelli on the company possibly breaking up. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with more details there. Nic, the stock is lower this morning.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Good morning, Maria. Again, to the downside. I mean, this is a stock of legacy company as he said. This is one of our oldest conglomerates, 125-year-old company and it's down again. Down two percent. First of all, they're suffering yet from yesterday's headlines of the $6.2-billion charge in G.E. Capital. The company has had a new CEO in place. They've been slashing the dividends, selling off assets, but the breakup has been back on the table, the talk that Flannery may have been really orchestrating this for some time. And then, it may be difficult because of pensions and debt structure but that it can be done, that it won't be completely broken up as we noted 300,000 employees under the umbrella there. So, a name that's been under pressure for the last year, at least.

Taking a look at some of the banks, Goldman Sachs out with its numbers, have beat the estimates of $4.4-billion charge related to Trump's tax reform did push the company to first-quarter loss. You can see Goldman Sachs down one percent this morning. Did well on its revenue, the banking revenue, IPOs underwriting. And then there's a look at Bank of America which is slightly higher. They did beat on the net profit slump on the adjusted income beat. So, there's the banks for you, Maria. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Nic, thank you so much. Nicole is on the floor. Meanwhile, an unhealthy response to a clean bill of health. Mainstream media reporters on the attack yesterday, poking and prodding at President Trump's physical exam report, asking the White House doctor outrageous questions. It was incredible.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Does the President wear dentures?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Are you ruling out things like early onset Alzheimer's, are you looking at dementia-like symptoms.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Is there anything you're keeping from us for privacy reason?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He's weight, I think he's a 239, right? That's -- it seems just shy of obesity.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It is, yes.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You're confident of that number and did you do any measurement?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: (INAUDIBLE) where the president appears to slur his words while giving an address. Did you look into what the cause of that might have been at all?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What a charade. "VARNEY & COMPANY" host, Stuart Varney now with his thoughts. Stu, I tweeted out in the middle of it yesterday. No words. I -- it was just incredible.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: It was a disgrace. That's what it is.

BARTIROMO: It was a disgrace.

VARNEY: I mean, when you got a White House press corps asking the president's doctor about dementia, obesity, how much sleep does he get? How about his eating of ice cream, how much golf does he play? I think they delivered a black eye to themselves.

BARTIROMO: Me too.

VARNEY: I thought they looked just ridiculous quite frankly. Childish, petulant, and ever eager to have a go at President Trump. Do you really think that they would ask anything like those questions to President Obama's doctor who was the same doctor as President Trump?

BARTIROMO: Who smoked, right? He was a -- he was a big smoker, by the way.

VARNEY: Yes. That's right. They never asked that question, certainly not. Oh, when did you quit, Mr. President? That's what they would have said. I think it was a distraction from what's going on in the economy and the markets. And I've got Eric Trump on this program about 50 minutes away. He's going to sit right next to me. I'm going to ask him what do you feel like when your dad's mental health is questioned? I'll ask him.

BARTIROMO: Incredible. I'm going to be watching that interview, Stu, for sure. All in the face of the doctor repeatedly saying the president is in excellent health.

VARNEY: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: But they wanted more. They kept prodding. It was incredible.

VARNEY: Yes. Ridiculous!

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in 10 minutes, Stu. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Devastating news from the college football world. Jared Max with the story. Jared?

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: Maria, Tyler Hilinksi, 21-year-old quarterback for the Washington State Cougars college football team is dead from an apparent suicide. A statement from Cougar's head coach Mike Leach, reads, "We are deeply saddened to hear of the news of Tyler's passing. He was an incredible young man. Everyone who had the privilege of knowing him was better for it. The entire WSU community mourns as thoughts and prayers go out to his family." When Hilinski did not show up to practice yesterday, officers went to his apartment to check on his welfare.

Hilinski's body was found, a gunshot wound to his headed and accompanying suicide note, Tyler's younger brother, Ryan, said in a statement, "We, as a family, are in complete shock and disarray. Tyler was the kid that put a smile on everybody's face when they were down, especially his family, we will mourn the loss of Tyler for some time but celebrate the way he lived his life every single day." Tomorrow marks three weeks since Hilinski started the holiday bowl for Washington State, and he was expected to be their starting quarterback next season.

Sentencing on seven counts of sexual assault again yesterday for former U.S. gymnastics doctor Larry Nassar among his many victims, McKayla Maroney who in 2016 signed a nondisclosure agreement. She received this as part of a $1.25-million settlement from USA Gymnastics. Now, the NDA said Maroney could not share details about her about abuse at the hands of Nassar. Well, yesterday, USA Gymnastics said it would not find her if she speaks out. Meanwhile, model Chrissy Teigen tweeted support for Maroney, saying the entire principal of this should be fought. An NDA to stay quiet about the serial monster with over 140 accusers. But I would be absolutely honored to pay this fine for you. Actress Kristen Bell also said that she would help pay any fine.

You're going to have to pay a big-time cost if you want to attend Super Bowl LII, February 4th in Minneapolis. According to Yahoo! Sports, the face value of Super Bowl tickets begins at $950, goes all the way to 5,000. Of course, these are face value prices. The cheapest tickets on StubHub right now $4500 and that's for the $950 ticket, so about three to four times as somebody a broker told Yahoo! Sports, if the Vikings win Sunday, a lot of folks in Minnesota are going to be selling their fishing boats next week.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you. It's such a horrible story about the suicide. Jared's sports reports on Fox News headlines 24/7 or Sirius XM 115. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Carrie Sheffield, Kevin Kelly, John Layfield, great show.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Awful cold (INAUDIBLE) It's great to be here.

SHEFFIELD: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: It is cold.

SHEFFIELD: Yes, we had a nice, warm start to the morning.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day everybody.

SHEFFIELD: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: That'll do it for us. We'll see you tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stuart.

VARNEY: Yes, it does. Maria, thank you very much indeed. Yes, we are going to make another run at 26,000 on the Dow.
