urn:contentItem:3TS5-5030-009B-G2C0-00000-00Stock Slide Worsens; Stopping the Selling; NATO: Kosovo Response1998-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR WITH LOU DOBBS 18:30 pm ETBusinessSHOW98100100V19Stock Slide Worsens; Stopping the Selling; NATO: Kosovo ResponseLou Dobbs, Kelli Arena, Rhonda Schaffler, Bill Dorman, Jamie McIntyre, Richard Roth, John King, Bob Franken, Allan Dodds Frank

Global financial markets continue their stunning decline. Plus, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin blames a herd mentally for the battering of global markets and broadly outlines a new plan to head off with global recession. Also, there are warnings of possible military action to end the slaughter of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. And, author David Reiff discusses his latest book which chronicles the fall of Bosnia and the world's efforts to deal with.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

ANNOUNCER: From CNN's New York headquarters, the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR WITH LOU DOBBS.

LOU DOBBS, HOST: Good evening.

Global financial markets today continued their stunning decline. The Dow Jones Industrials fell another 210 points, bringing the two- day loss to a staggering 437 points. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin today blamed a herd mentality for the battering of global markets and broadly outlined a new plan to head off a global recession. And in Washington, warnings of possible military action to end the slaughter of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.

We begin tonight on Wall Street where stocks fell precipitously for the second day. The Dow tumbled 210 points, down 2-1/2 percent. The Nasdaq fell nearly 5 percent in its fourth biggest point less ever. A staggering $600 billion of market value has been erased in the past two days as the world's economic crisis continues to pound Wall Street.

Rhonda Schaffler covered today's events from the New York Stock Exchange, joins me now live from the CNNfn Newsroom with a report.

Rhonda.

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Lou, for the first time ever, the Dow has dropped 200 points two days in a row, and like yesterday, this sell-off was global. Stock markets from Asia to Europe to Latin America fell sharply, deepening investors' fears of a world slipping dangerously close to recession. The Dow Industrials today lost 210 points, closing at 7,632. The selling was even steeper on the Nasdaq where the market took out some big-name tech stocks. The Nasdaq plummeted nearly 5 percent, closing at 1,612.

And once again, the winner in all of this was the U.S. bond market. When investors flocked to the stability of this government- backed security, it gained 1-1/4 points, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, falling to another all-time low, today closing at 4.87 percent.

Lou, back to you.

DOBBS: Rhonda, thank you. Rhonda Schaffler. Well, as global stocks were tumbling today, the chairman of the Federal Reserve acknowledged just how fragile world markets have become. In congressional testimony, Alan Greenspan said the failure of a single hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management, could have resulted in severe widespread and prolonged disruptions to financial market activity. In New York today, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said global financial reforms are urgently needed to end the crisis.

Allan Dodds Frank reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERT RUBIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: In the short term, the international community has worked aggressively to limit the damage from what is in some ways probably the most serious financial crisis of the past 50 years.

ALLAN DODDS FRANK, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): But the Treasury secretary said the work so far is not nearly enough to stem what he called vast and systemic disruptions in global markets. He said the United States will push governments, international institutions, and private lenders to be more open and more careful in their financial dealings.

R. RUBIN: Both the concrete steps and the proposals for further work will basically deal with three areas: improving transparency, strengthening national financial systems, especially in emerging markets and developing countries, and improving response to international crisis, including appropriate private-sector involvement.

FRANK: The Treasury secretary urged the International Monetary Fund to pressure countries that fail to take tough reform measures. To make those reforms stick without setting off social unrest, he said, the international community also must have a social safety net.

Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan was addressing one piece of the puzzle: the need for government involvement in the rescue of a hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management.

ALAN GREENSPAN, FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD CHAIRMAN: The plight of LTCM might scarcely have caused a ripple in financial markets or among financial regulators 18 months ago, but in current circumstances, it was judged to warrant attention.

FRANK (on camera): The first test of the new U.S. resolve to bolster countries that adopt economic reform may come within the week in Brazil, and the Treasury secretary said the United States and other countries are ready to help Brazil fend off economic contagion from other emerging markets.

Allan Dodds Frank, CNN Financial News, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE) DOBBS: We'll have much more later on the global economic crisis. Ahead, complete coverage of the market losses, both on Wall Street and around the world, analysis of Alan Greenspan's congressional testimony on hedge funds, and my guests tonight are the secretary of the Treasury, Robert Rubin, and we'll be joined by one of the nation's most prominent hedge fund managers Leon Cooperman of Omega Advisers.

In Washington this afternoon, House Democrats met in private hoping to settle on a strategy in the battle over ground rules for impeachment hearings. Democrats are pushing for rules that would limit the hearings in both scope and duration, but Republicans appear content to follow the precedent of Watergate for a more open-ended format.

Bob Franken has the story from Capitol Hill.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BOB FRANKEN, CNN CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): They're meeting now. Both Republicans and Democrats huddling in a series of closed sessions. The House Democrats are trying to hammer out their alternative to the Watergate model rules for an impeachment inquiry favored by the Republican leader of the Judiciary Committee Henry Hyde.

SEN. JOHN CONYERS (D-MI), JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: This is a little bit more than a chess game.

FRANKEN: Actually, it is a chess game right now. Democrats say their package won't be completed today but that the highlights have already been publicly discussed. They want a strict time limit imposed on the investigation instead of the open-ended schedule contemplated by the Republicans.

CONYERS: We're talking four to six weeks or -- you know, we're talking about a reasonable period of time that we would negotiate.

FRANKEN: They also want to restrict the investigation to the Lewinsky matter. Republicans want to leave the proceedings open. In an attempt to limit the scope, Democrats have written a letter to Republicans asking that independent counsel Ken Starr let them know if he has any further information that might apply to impeachment. If there are no such referrals, they wrote, then the committee can easily confine the scope and duration of the review. But Republicans are resisting any talk of limiting the investigation.

REP. BOB GOODLATTE (R-VA), JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: We must follow the truth wherever it leads and get an expeditious review of the process -- of the matter and an expeditious resolution of the matter but not under some arbitrary time line that does not make any sense for us to follow.

FRANKEN: Still to be decided: whether to put forth a Democratic- backed motion of censure against President Clinton as an alternative to an impeachment investigation. That is a sensitive subject for Democrats. CONYERS: Members come up to me -- none of -- I haven't seen any today that have said it, but I've been getting it all last week, that this would be a highly regarded method and an alternative. So it is still under contemplation.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANKEN: Democrats are going to hold a news conference tomorrow morning to announce the specifics of their counterproposal. Remember: The Republicans are in the majority. It's up to them to decide exactly what the rules will be. The only thing Democrats can do is complain, if they want to, that the Republicans are being too partisan and see how that plays with the public.

Lou.

DOBBS: Bob, as it now appears then, the Watergate hearings will be the structure for these hearings, should they come about?

FRANKEN: Probably so. Now the Republicans probably will negotiate some. Democrats, for instance, will propose a specific time line, and Republicans might decide that they can come up with some sort of acceptable compromise. But, yes, Watergate is the model.

DOBBS: Bob Franken reporting from Capitol Hill. Thank you.

Well, while Congress debates the ground rules, the White House is quietly lobbying Democrats to stand by the president and to vote against impeachment hearings, and CNN has learned that the lobbying is surprisingly aggressive. Both the president and his wife, despite their diminished political capital within their own party, are trying to play hardball.

John King has our report from the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JOHN KING, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A show of Democratic unity on the issues as the White House lobbies aggressively for a similar show of support in the impeachment debate.

MIKE MCCURRY, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: What we're trying to do is put forward the most powerful and persuasive argument we can put forward that will convince members of the House that an inquiry is not warranted.

KING: The first lady is among those making the case to House Democrats in recent days, and CNN has learned she's playing a little political hardball. Several sources say the first lady is casting the investigation as a political vendetta against her husband and arguing that Democrats have an obligation to vote against an impeachment inquiry. Two of these sources describe the first lady's pitch as adamant and say it includes a blunt message that the White House will be reluctant to offer campaign help to Democrats who support an inquiry, but early estimates suggest 50 or more Democrats might vote yes. SEN. JOSEPH LIEBERMAN (D), CONNECTICUT: But the hard fact is that there is no quick end in sight. The president by his own words is not going to resign, and the House by its leaders' own words is going to move forward with a formal impeachment inquiry.

KING: The president is steering clear of the impeachment debate in public but using his events to make the case the Republican Congress isn't paying attention to the things that matter most.

WILLIAM J. CLINTON, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: And yet no issue has suffered more from misplaced priorities and partisan pursuits than American's public schools.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KING: There is, of course, considerable irony in the first lady's role defending her husband. In the last impeachment debate a quarter century ago, young Hillary Rodham worked for House Judiciary Committee Democrats building the impeachment case against Richard Nixon.

Lou.

DOBBS: John, thank you. John King reporting from the White House.

Also in Washington today, opening statements in the corruption trial of former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy. Espy is accused of taking illegal gifts, of lying about it, and then trying to get a friend to cover up for him. Espy allegedly accepted $35,000 worth of travel, sports tickets, luggage, and other goods from businesses regulated by his department. Prosecutors call Espy a "super sports fan" who was chronically short of money. Espy pleaded not guilty to those changes last year. The trial is expected to last at least six weeks.

Coming up next on the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR, the Clinton administration's national security team today goes to Capitol Hill trying to lay the groundwork for military action in Kosovo.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Western powers could be on the brink of military intervention in Kosovo. The United Nations Security Council is meeting at this hour in emergency session. International efforts to stop the unrest took on new urgency this week after reports of two separate Serb massacres of ethnic Albanians. In one attack, 12 men were killed. In another, 18 people, including women and children, were mutilated. Serbs deny they had anything to do with those massacres and, today, they invited international experts to look into the alleged attacks.

Richard Roth is at the United Nations and has an update on today's emergency meeting.

Richard. RICHARD ROTH, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Lou, the U.N. Security Council has been meeting for about two hours. It's expected to break momentarily. The Council is expected to issue a press statement -- thus, it's not an official document regarding the Kosovo situation -- and there is likely to be no talk of any military force to be used now or in the near future.

The Council is expected to condemn the atrocities that you referred to in Kosovo and also to call on the Belgrade government to identify and punish those responsible. However, the Security Council is on record as saying further measures may be taken against Serbia or perhaps the Kosovo Liberation Army, but, once again, with China and Russia not willing to sign on at this point to any document calling for force, we're at least several days away from further legal diplomatic authorization of any NATO air strikes.

Lou.

DOBBS: Richard, thank you. Richard Roth reporting from the United Nations.

The Clinton administration today sent its national security team to brief Capitol Hill on the Kosovo situation. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, Defense Secretary William Cohen, and National Security Adviser Sandy Berger telling senators about alleged Serb atrocities against ethnic Albanians. They laid out what Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic should do to avoid military action against his forces.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIAM COHEN, DEFENSE SECRETARY: There are several things he must do. He must pull back his armed forces. He must pull back the police. He must allow the NGOs -- the nongovernmental organizations and agencies to provide humanitarian relief. He must allow for the displaced persons to return to their homes and then sit down and seek a diplomatic solution to the conflict.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Also today, the State Department warned Americans not to travel to Serbia or Montenegro. A possible indication that military action is imminent.

NATO's top decision makers have completed their plans for possible air strikes against Serb forces. NATO has been working for months on plans to intervene in Kosovo.

Military affairs correspondent Jamie McIntyre reports on what NATO Has in mind if, in fact, it should act.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JAMIE MCINTYRE, CNN MILITARY AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Sources say NATO's attacks begin with cruise missile strikes from U.S. ships and possibly B-52 bombers to disable Yugoslav air defenses. That would pave the way for an escalating bombing campaign by NATO warplanes, if President Slobodan Milosevic doesn't capitulate.

KEVIN BACON, PENTAGON SPOKESMAN: Unless he immediately begins to meet the demands that the international community have made that -- he faces the possibility of a very punishing military strike.

MCINTYRE: NATO officials say Milosevic has only a matter of days to order an end to the killing of civilians in Kosovo and allow the return of hundreds of thousands of refugees to their homes.

JAMES RUBIN, STATE DEPARTMENT SPOKESMAN: It is not going to be enough for him to simply play cat and mouse with the international community.

MCINTYRE: Sources say, while NATO will make a show of participation by all 16 of its member nations, plans call for up to 80 percent of the bombing to be done by U.S. planes. The United States has some 40 F-16s at Aviano Air Base in Northern Italy, another 15 F- 18s and F-14s on the aircraft carrier Eisenhower currently on a port call in Greece, and the U.S. has additional strike aircraft in Germany, England, and Turkey which could be moved to forward bases in Italy to beef up the NATO strike force.

Sources say the bombing would not be limited to the Kosovo province, that all of Serbia proper is fair game. Targets have been selected to minimize risks to pilots and civilians while crimping Milosevic's military forces. Sources say the targets could include command headquarters, communications centers, and military installations.

BACON: If military action is called for, the purpose would be to degrade Milosevic's ability to continue his attacks and reduce his will to continue those attacks as well.

MCINTYRE: So far, there has been no order by the Pentagon to move any planes or cut short the carrier's port call, a sign that military action, while closer, is not yet imminent.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MCINTYRE: And if NATO succeeds in imposing a cease-fire either by force or the threat of force, it leads to another NATO option that no one here much wants to talk about: a possible midwinter deployment of 10s of thousands of NATO troops to keep the peace in an open-ended Bosnia-style deployment.

Lou.

DOBBS: Jamie, thank you. Jamie McIntyre reporting from the Pentagon.

Former U.N. weapons inspector Scott Ritter received a warning from his former boss for speaking out on the subject of Iraq. Richard Butler wrote Ritter a letter admonishing him for violating the secrecy clause of his United Nations employment contract. Ritter resigned in protest in August, accusing the United Nations of failing to deal firmly with Iraq's refusal to cooperate with weapons inspectors. A belated acknowledgement from the Israeli government tonight that an LL (ph) cargo plane that crashed in Amsterdam in 1992 was, in fact, carrying a chemical used to make nerve gas, but the Israeli government insists the chemical was nontoxic and it was not to be used to make sarin nerve gas. The 1992 LL crash killed 47 people.

Coming up next on the NEWS HOUR, a scathing indictment of the West in action in the Balkans. My guest tonight, a journalist, an author whose latest book chronicles the fall of Bosnia and the world's efforts to deal with. David Reiff is next. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Serbs began action against ethnic Albanian separatists in February. Since then, more than 700 people have been killed, hundreds of thousands driven from their homes. Word of last week's massacre once again prompted Western nations to take notice of the crisis in the Balkans.

My guest tonight says air strikes against Serb forces will only aggravate the situation. He is the author of "Slaughterhouse: Bosnia and the Failure of the West."

David Reiff, good to have you with us on the NEWS HOUR.

DAVID REIFF, AUTHOR: Thank you.

DOBBS: At this point, with NATO, the United Nations discussing and focusing upon Kosovo and what could be, it seems, military action very soon, do you think that they are taking a proper course?

REIFF: I think that if they imagined a policy for Kosovo, one that would include not just the military action they're contemplating now but some kind of outcome afterwards, a political outcome, military strikes might form part of it, but they have no idea what they're going to do.

DOBBS: Well, the Clinton administration has obviously focused on the human suffering. Is it your judgment that that could be, in fact, alleviated by taking action, particularly military air strikes?

REIFF: I'd have to tell you I don't understand the humanitarian justification. It's true there's a lot of suffering in Kosovo. It's also true there's much more suffering in a place like Sudan or Sierra Leone or a lot of other places we all could name.

DOBBS: Where there are plenty of refugees.

REIFF: Where there are plenty of refugees. In South Sudan, people are starving to death as we're having this conversation. The reason to intervene in Kosovo surely is political. It's surely one -- a question of European stability. It's about saying Milosevic is a troublemaker. He has been since the breakup of Yugoslavia the problem in the Balkans. There are other villains as well, but he's been the problem. We have to do something, but to strike, launch military strikes, make war on Serbia just for a humanitarian basis seems to me grandstanding.

DOBBS: Milosevic has been singularly successful in holding the United Nations and the United States and NATO at bay. Is he, in your judgment, that remarkable a leader, or is he confronting a group of powers who simply have not, as you have said, come forward with an objective that allows them to be effective?

REIFF: I think it's more the latter than the former. Milosevic is a clever guy and a shrewd politician, but he's also a fairly typical, central casting thug. We don't know what we want. This is sound byte diplomacy, to use the famous putdown of Mrs. Albright. This is a wish list. This isn't a serious policy. Again, Kosovo is legally a part of Yugoslavia. Do we want independence for Kosovo? Is that what we want these bombs to do when the -- Mr. Bacon from the Defense Department says we're going to degrade Milosevic's military capability? What's the goal? Nobody's enunciated that. And what's the legal basis?

DOBBS: What should, in your judgment, the Clinton administration do?

REIFF: I think the first thing the Clinton administration needs to do is work out some kind of coherent policy with the NATO allies for what they want the long-term future of Kosovo to be. The possibilities are obviously the status quo, a return to the autonomy Milosevic took away from the Kosovo Albanians, or independence.

DOBBS: Milosevic says that he's willing to talk about that.

REIFF: Well, Milosevic is a famous liar, and without backing some of this up by at least the threat of force, we're not going to get anywhere, but the point is we're putting the car before the horse here. We don't have a policy. We're threatening military force in advance of a clearly enunciated policy. That's why people keep coming back to this humanitarian business, because they can't think of anything else. They talk about the suffering. The suffering exists, but it's not the basis for making war on Serbia.

DOBBS: And those who would suggest that NATO is not entirely the correct framework, that it is a matter, in point of fact, for Italy, for France, and for Germany, even with its new government, to take leadership roles in this instance?

REIFF: Well, I think it would certainly be better if the Europeans would take the lead, but since they failed to take the lead in Bosnia, it seems hard for me to imagine they'll do it in Kosovo. Frankly, Europe is an economic unit, but it's not a political unit yet, whatever people talk about it at this moment.

DOBBS: David Reiff, thanks for being here.

REIFF: Thank you.

DOBBS: Well, next on the NEWS HOUR, a very frightening secret report requested by Winston Churchill discovered after more than 50 years. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: In London, a document has surfaced offering new evidence that the Cold War could have begun as a very hot war. A 29-page plan. It was code-named Operation Unthinkable. It was drawn up at the request of Winston Churchill, and it called for a coordinated surprise attack on the Soviet Union. The plan came in the days after Germany's surrender in 1945 when an uneasy peace existed between the Anglo- American forces and the Soviet allies. The hypothetical attack, which would have been led by 47 British and American divisions, was discovered in a public records office and, of course, never used.

Coming up next, the second half of the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Another brutal, punishing day on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrials today dropped 210 points, putting the two-day loss at more than 400 points on the Dow. The Nasdaq Composite today tumbled almost five percent. The damage similar to yesterday's, and so was the trigger.

Rhonda Schaffler has report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SCHAFFLER (voice-over): Worries about a global economic slowdown and it's impact on corporate profits prompted investors to unload stocks and, once again, snap up Treasury bonds.

TODD EBERHARD, EBERHARD INVESTMENT ASSOCIATES: Concerns about a recession, possibly, for the U.S. economy, corporate profits certainly are a concern, interest rates are a concern. A 4.89-percent long bond is very low, but the answer I love to give people is at least you'll make 4.89 percent if you buy that, as opposed to possibly losing a lot of money if you're in the market in certain places.

SCHAFFLER: The Dow's almost 2.7-percent loss wasn't as steep as the losses among big-tech stocks, which dragged the Nasdaq composite down 4.8 percent. Among the Nasdaq stocks taking the biggest beating: Microsoft down $6, Dell and Cisco Systems down more than $4, Yahoo! down more than $16.50, Amazon.com plunging $9 a share. Financial stocks were also hit hard on fears about hedge fund exposure and weakening earnings. Profits for major banks are expected to be off more than 40 percent in the third quarter. Wells Fargo plunged 11- 3/4, Merril Lynch losing about 2-1/2, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter shedding more than three, Chase Manhattan down 2-13/32, Citicorp off 4-3/4.

With the same reasons weighing on the market, few expect a turnaround any time soon.

LARRY WACHTEL, PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES: I think the 7400 level will probably be tested in the next week or so. And I think, if it is violated, probably that could create a washout that would finally put a period to this thing -- finally bring on the capitulation that we haven't had up till now.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SCHAFFLER: The last two days marked the steepest back-to-back selloffs on Wall Street in over a month. The latest damage leaves the Dow Jones industrial average off 3-1/2 percent for the year, and investors are wary of October and its history, from the crash of '29 and '87, to last year's dizzying selloff -- Lou.

DOBBS: Rhonda, thank you.

Well, taking a closer look at the markets: the Dow Jones tumbling 210 points, tonight at 7632.53. Volume today, almost 900 million shares, declining issues beating advancers by a better than three-to- one margin.

And even worse day on the Nasdaq. That index fell 81 points, losing almost five percent: tonight at 1612.33. Volume there 856 million shares. The Nasdaq is still, however, up 2-1/2 percent so far this year; down 20 percent from its record, however.

The S&P 500 index also down sharply today. Down almost 31 points, losing three percent.

A global sell-off today slammed markets all around the world, beginning in Tokyo, where the Nikkei fell to a 12-year low. The skid in the German market wiped out all of the gains of the year; Frankfurt's market plummeted 5.5 percent. The Dax has now dropped a stunning 30 percent in six weeks. Paris off five percent. Battered bank shares in London; that index down more than three percent.

Declining bank stocks and fears of a credit crunch also pounded markets in Latin America. Brazil off almost 10 percent. Argentina down almost 8 percent. Mexico fell five percent. Chile down just over one percent.

Another rally, another record in the bond market, however. Continued volatility in global markets again making U.S. treasuries the investment of choice. The 30-year issue followed yesterday's better-than-two-point surge with a gain today of 1-8/32. The yield tonight at 4.87 percent; that the lowest level ever for the bond. It's dropped more than a full percentage point this year.

Despite record-low interest rates, a business credit crunch does threaten the economy. The Federal Reserve Board reported today the nations' banks, concerned and faced with financial turmoil, are squeezing credit for industry and commerce.

Bill Dorman has the report from Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BILL DORMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): It's becoming harder for big companies to borrow money. The Federal Reserve conducted a special survey of 54 banks about two weeks ago to judge the impact of recent financial turbulence on the bank loan market. The finding: shrinking demand for corporate loans to buy new factory equipment; a troubling indicator for future business conditions.

LAWRENCE CHIMERINE, ECONOMIC STRATEGY INSTITUTE: It not only suggests a slowdown in the economy, but clearly the risk of a recession some time in the next 12 months is higher now, by far, than it's been at any time since this expansion began.

DORMAN: Manufacturing is also slowing, falling for the fourth month in a row. The survey of purchasing managers show further declines in exports to Asia. And it's not just factories getting hit by trouble from overseas; farmers are suffering from tumbling crop prices. Concerns about the U.S. economy are even surfacing at the World Bank, where officials worry that information about bank loans to problem economies may amount to less than full disclosure.

JAMES WOLFENSOHN, PRESIDENT, WORLD BANK GROUP: I woke up one day to find that over $60 billion had been loaned by Western banks to private companies in Indonesia. That was an awakening, because it didn't show up in any of the statistics that I was aware of.

DORMAN: Other troubling statistics are plentiful, from warnings about corporate earnings, to a decline in corporate capital spending plans.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

One bright statistic remains domestic consumer spending, along with continued low unemployment, but as the stock market continues to slide, any corresponding fall in consumer confidence would come at a steep cost to this economy -- Lou.

DOBBS: Bill, thank you. Bill Dorman reporting from Washington.

Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan today played defense on Capitol Hill. To a very skeptical House Banking Committee, he was forced to explain the Fed's involvement in last week's $3.5 billion takeover of Long- Term Capital Management, the hedge fund. Greenspan also argued against direct regulation of the hedge fund industry.

From Washington, Kelli Arena who with a report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KELLI ARENA, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): The Fed- orchestrated rescue of Long-Term Capital has lawmakers at odds with the Federal Reserve.

REP. BERNARD SANDERS (I), VERMONT: Not when family farmers get in trouble, not when small business people get in trouble, not when poor people get in trouble, but I guess to get government assistance or the help of the Feds, you've got to be a multi-billionaire gambler.

ARENA: But the Fed didn't use taxpayer dollars, and Alan Greenspan defended the privately-financed takeover.

ALAN GREENSPAN, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD: Had the failure of LTCM triggered the seizing up of markets, substantial damage could have been inflicted on many market participants, including some not directly involved with the firm, and could have potentially impaired the economies of many nations, including our own.

ARENA: Some lawmakers were clearly frustrated.

REP. CAROLYN MALONEY (D), NEW YORK: What kind of banking system do we have where major financial institutions have no idea as to the financial condition or balance sheet of the borrower they're extending credit to?

ARENA: There are about 4,000 hedge funds controlling hundreds of billions of dollars in investments for wealthy individuals. But Greenspan argues government regulation would result in big funds moving abroad, making them even harder to monitor. In addition, no regulation is foolproof.

GREENSPAN: But they make mistakes. They're human beings. And I think they will continue to do so. And I know of no set of supervisory actions we can take that will prevent people from making dumb mistakes. I know of no piece of legislation that can be passed by the Congress which would require us to prevent them from making dumb mistakes.

ARENA: But other market regulators suggested a more aggressive approach, in cooperation with international partners.

BROOKSLEY BORN, COMMODITY FUTURES TRADING COMM.: I do think transparency, disclosure, availability of information, is very important.

ARENA (on camera): Arguments over regulating hedge funds will continue on several fronts: not only on Capitol Hill, but within the G-7, and as part of the president's working group on financial markets.

Kelli Arena, CNN Financial News, Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOBBS: Coming up next on MONEYLINE: one of the legends of the hedge fund industry, Leon Cooperman of Omega. But first, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin will map out a solution to the world's financial crisis. He's my guest next on MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: In tonight's "MONEYLINE Focus": the global economic crisis. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin today warned that this is in some ways, the worst economic crisis in 50 years. A crisis, that the secretary has a plan to deal with. Secretary Rubin joins me now. Good to have you with us.

R. RUBIN: Good to be with you Lou.

DOBBS: An international framework, a new approach -- give us if you will, some sense of what needs to be done immediately. R. RUBIN: Well, let me break this into two pieces. We have been over the course of now, a little bit more than a year, very intensely focused on dealing with the crisis that's in front of us, through a whole range of measures. We have also been, at the same time focused, on building an architecture on the kinds of changes we are going to need if we are going to have a global financial system that really works for the 21st century. One grounded in a market based economy, but at the same time dealing with the kinds of problems that can develop in markets.

DOBBS: The IMF, World Bank, G-7 -- institutions with a great tradition and history, -- what more needs to be done institutionally?

R. RUBIN: I think there's a great deal that is going to have to happen if we're going to have what we need five, 10, 15 years from now. The IMF, clearly is going to have to become far more transparent, more accountable. I believe there will have to be a review of the kinds of programs and policies that they follow. Although, I think that they have on balance done a good job in the face of extraordinarily complex situations over the course of the past year.

I think, Lou, there is going to have to be a very intense focus on how to provide incentives for developing countries to put in place sound financial systems and banking systems. And for the industrial country, financial institutions to much more rigorously focus on risks in their credit extension and provision of portfolio capitol.

DOBBS: Is there anything to the idea that this global financial crisis is providing something of a ring out for those countries, particularly emerging countries, that have resisted transparency, that have resisted regulation -- that there is or should be at least a clear cut understanding now on the part of the leaderships of those countries that they are going to have to move to meet market demands for transparency, for stability, and for security?

R. RUBIN: I think one of the clear -- I think you are onto something very important. I think one of the clear lessons of this past year is that countries that have economic policy regimes that are unsound will pay a very heavy price in the global financial markets. But unfortunately, what is also happening now is that just as investors and creditors probably were careless because of sustained good times when capital flowed in, they're now, in effect, withdrawing -- in a sense with a herd mentality.

So the countries that have had very good reform programs and reform regimes are being affected by a kind of contagion. That's one of the things that we're all focusing on trying to limit to the extent possible. DOBBS: Specifically in Latin America, Brazil -- I would think would be foremost in your outlook. Brazil, President Cardoso in an election this Sunday -- Brazil has accomplished tremendous gains over the past three, four years, yet they are under an incredible threat right now. What can this government and those institutions that we just talked about -- the IMF, the World Bank -- do to provide some sort of help support to Brazil? R. RUBIN: Well, the first step, has now been taken by President Cardoso himself, who about two weeks ago gave a speech in which he said he was going to make fiscal discipline and Social Security reform the centerpiece of his next term -- very important in terms of dealing with Brazil's challenges.

I think probably what I -- the most I ought to say at that point, Lou -- and I have said before -- is that Brazil is very important to the economic well being of the region -- the United States. And all of us are very much focused -- the international community is very much focused on seeing how we can be helpful if need be.

DOBBS: But is this management -- this leadership of the International Monetary Fund, at this point -- they have been criticized, they've understated the crisis in Asia. They have understated the crises in Russia. Today Yevgeny Primikov threatened the Soviet style controls -- the Russian economy should (UNINTELLIGIBLE) more than four billion dollars not be delivered by the IMF. Give us your judgment of this leadership and its track record.

R. RUBIN: I don't agree with the, what is in effect the premise of your question, Lou. The IMF is faced dealing with, what really in many ways are -- as you correctly said -- unprecedented problems and exceedingly complex problems. I think on balance they have made the right judgment, although there are no sure, no easy answers. Once they put a program in place -- and these programs are very carefully tailored to the circumstance in each country -- they then have adjusted the program as circumstances have warranted.

But they are dealing with an extremely complex set of problems that have developed over many, many years. I think as one thinks about it, one has to think of limiting the damage as the world works its way through a very difficult period. Clearly, I might add, I do believe there will be very substantial reform in the IMF and needs to be.

DOBBS: And the U.S. markets are severely challenged, particularly over the past two months -- give us your best judgment on the state of the U.S. economy -- the state of the markets. I want to ask you to lay out a course for interest rates -- but give us your best characterization?

R. RUBIN: I think, Lou, we still, as the most likely scenario going forward, have solid growth and low inflation. But I think it is also equally clear that this international crisis is affecting some sectors significantly and is creating a greater risk for the overall economy. The two most significant things that could happen in the world in terms of our economic well being, are, number one, for Japan to get back on track because of the enormous importance that would have for the rest of the world.

And secondly, something we can do, which is to provide funding for the International Monetary Fund. The United States has not yet committed to provide the funding the president requested over a year ago. And the rest of the world is waiting for that action. Once that happens, the whole world will make their contributions and the IMF will then again have the resources they need to deal with the kind of crises that so affect our economic interests.

DOBBS: The bailed out orchestrated by the Federal Reserve -- before Capitol Hill in testimony there, you offered some cautionary words. Give us your judgment about the bail out?

RUBIN: You're talking about LTCM?

DOBBS: The Long-Term Capital -- yes.

RUBIN: I don't think it was a bail out, Lou.

DOBBS: Well, it's a bail out in the sense that capital was provided from a number of firms to Long-Term Capital, which would not have had sufficient capital to stay in business. And that was arranged and encouraged by the Federal Reserve. It was not a bail out by the Federal Reserve.

RUBIN: There was no public money. It seems to me the Federal Reserve Board of New York provided a useful function. They made a judgment that there were possible systemic risks. I'm not close enough to know whether those judgments are right or wrong, but I have enormous respect for the people who made those judgments. And once they made those judgments they then convened the creditors, but the creditors made their own decisions as to what was in their economic self-interests.

DOBBS: Is it your judgment that there is sufficient surveillance of -- and oversight of bank lending to hedge funds at this point?

RUBIN: I think there are two areas there that need focus. One are hedge funds themselves. We actually will have -- actually have under way now a study in the financial markets working group which is a group that has Alan Greenspan, myself, and Arthur Levin (ph), and others on it. We have a focus on the implications of LTCM and more generally issues with respect to hedge funds to determine whether or not there is regulation that would be appropriate. In terms of the banks themselves, I think there what we need is far greater supervisory focus on proper and effective risk evaluation and credit extension.

DOBBS: As always, it is great to talk with you, Treasury Secretary, Robert Rubin.

RUBIN: Good to be with you, Lou, thank you.

DOBBS: We will continue in just one moment. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: The all but total failure of Long-Term Capital Management and its dramatic takeover, highlight the fragility of the global financial system. It's also raised news, somewhat troubling questions about largely unregulated pools of capital inhabited by Nobel Prize winners, the world's super rich and Wall Street legends such as John Merriweather, George Soris (ph), Julian Robertson and my guest tonight, Leon Cooperman of Omega Advisers.

Lee, good to have you with us.

LEON COOPERMAN, CHAIRMAN, OMEGA ADVISER: Nice to be with you.

DOBBS: I might say as well, not just hedge funds, but the legend of Wall Street itself. The hedge funds -- are they unfairly focused upon by the regulators, lawmakers right now, because of Long-Term Capital, in your judgment?

COOPERMAN: I believe so. I guess back in 1965 when Jack Nicklaus won the master's tournament, the great golfer Bobbie Jones observed that Jack Nicklaus plays a game of golf with which I'm not familiar with. Similarly, most of the people I know in the hedge fund business don't manage money in a way that would familiar to what goes on, what happened at Long-Term Capital.

DOBBS: Will leverage obviously, the principle story at Long-Term Capital. Give us an example of what is a more typical leverage.

COOPERMAN: It varies, you know whether you are running an equity fund, or you're running a fixed income fund…

DOBBS: A (UNINTELLIGIBLE) fund.

COOPERMAN: … whether you're specializing in convergence trades. In our own case, I think that the highest in the last three or four years, we have been roughly $3 of assets per dollar of equity.

DOBBS: And that is modest by even the classic understanding of what is a hedge fund. The suggestion, as we just heard from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission chairman, that there would be an appropriate road for them in looking over hedge funds.

What is your reaction to that?

COOPERMAN: Fine. I mean all the regulation they want to heap on us is fine. We're already, in my opinion, in my business very highly regulated. We have to adhere to Federal Reserve Board margin requirements. The brokers that we deal with -- they have in house rules regarding margin. We are registered investment advisers, so the SCC has jurisdiction over us.

DOBBS: Then how did Long-Term Capital happen?

COOPERMAN: That's my question. In my opinion, the question should not be directed towards to hedge funds, per se, but questions should be asked as to how the banks and the brokerage industry lent $116 billion to one borrower with $4 billion of equity.

DOBBS: And that's obviously the question now that Congressman Leach, chairing the House Banking Committee will be asking with his usual rigor and thoroughness. If it's your judgment that LTC was a loan in its position -- give us judgment about how treacherous this market is. I know that for (UNINTELLIGIBLE) fund for every fund, there has been -- these last two months have not been a lot of fun. Give us your past judgment about this market right now.

COOPERMAN: Well, I think we basically had a goldilocks market environment where the market was discounting perfection. And all of a sudden, the three bears got out of control. I think it was kind of a balloon looking for a pin and the pin turned out to be what happened in Russia. I think it's a very mixed picture at the current time. And I think frankly, where we had head from here is going to be very much a function what happens in the economy.

DOBBS: The economy itself, we are seeing earnings decline. We are seeing also at the same time, tremendous historic lows in terms of inflation and unemployment. What is your outlook then for the economy? I'm not letting you off that easy.

COOPERMAN: Basically three scenarios out there that are very plausible. For want of any better terminology, we talk in terms of soft landing, recession and something worse than recession. Essentially, I think if it's a soft landing, financial markets have more than adjusted to that, and I think the lows of august, early September will hold up as being the lows in the cycle. A recession, I think is not yet quite discounted. And something worse is not discounted in any of the financial markets. I think it's a period where one has to be very careful. I mean we have a lot of instability around the world. You look at Japan, every one of their long-term bonds yields less than 70 basis points. Short rates are 25 basis points. Asia is in a depression…

DOBBS: You are not cheering me up, Lee.

COOPERMAN: Look, there are positives out there. I mean we have good fiscal policy; we have a budget surplus. We have very low long- term low interest rates. But I think the low long-term interest rates are functions of the problems in the economy.

DOBBS: Do you believe the Fed has moved fast enough?

COOPERMAN: I think they will move fast enough. They are there to preserve order, and will do what they have to do. And I am quite confident with that view. I think the thing to watch here is the economy, Brazil and mutual fund cash flow.

DOBBS: Will do, as always. Lee, great to have you here on the "MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR" with us.

COOPERMAN: Nice to be here with you.

DOBBS: Leon Cooperman.

We'll continue in just a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: For tonight, that's the bottom line. Thanks for being with us. Good night from New York.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:57MB-X1V1-JBRC-V1C0-00000-00Stocks mixed after uneven reports aired2013-01-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1Stocks mixed after uneven reports airedAssociated Press Associated Press

U.S. stocks meandered between small gains and losses Monday, cooling off after a rally that had pushed the Standard & Poor's 500 index above 1,500 for the first time since December 2007. Encouraging news about manufacturing provided an early boost, but stocks fell later after a report on the pace of home sales fell short of expectations.

The government said before trading began that orders for long-lasting goods rose in December by 4.6 percent, helped by a 10 percent gain in orders for new aircraft. The report was a sign of strength for the manufacturing sector, a crucial driver of economic growth.

Heavy equipment maker Caterpillar said separately that its fourth-quarter net income exceeded analysts' expectations, after adjusting for the cost of a soured deal to buy a Chinese maker of roofing supports for mines. Caterpillar said it took a big charge in the quarter because the Chinese company had misrepresented its finances.

Caterpillar Inc.said it expects growth in China to improve without regaining the levels seen in 2010 or 2011. The stock was the biggest gainer in the Dow Jones industrial average, closing up $1.87, or 2 percent, at $97.45.

The Dow Jones transportation index, a proxy for future economic activity, edged higher, notching its tenth straight increase and its twelfth gain in the past 13 trading days.

A half-hour after trading began, the National Association of Realtors said that its index of pending home sales fell in December, suggesting that sales of previously occupied homes may slow in the coming months. The report, which was weaker than many economists had expected, helped push stocks lower for much of the morning. They were roughly flat by midday, and spent the afternoon swapping small bumps and dips.

The Dow closed down 14.05 points, or 0.1 percent, at 13,881.93. The S&P 500 fell 2.78, or 0.2 percent, to 1,500.18. The Nasdaq composite index added 4.59, or 0.2 percent, to 3,154.

The Dow and the S&P 500 are rapidly approaching their all-time closing highs, reached on Oct. 9, 2007. The Dow is about 282 points below its high of 14,164.53; the S&P 500 is 65 points shy of its record of 1,565.

Economic data may be less likely to boost the indexes because traders have become harder to impress as the data have strengthened in recent weeks, said Bill Stone, chief investment strategist with PNC Asset Management Group.

Among companies in the S&P 500 that reported earnings Monday, Biogen Idec Inc.said its fourth-quarter net income slipped nearly 3 percent because of a tax charge and higher expenses. Still, the biotech drug maker rose $3.79, or 2.6 percent, to $149.99.

Roper Industries Inc., which makes medical and industrial equipment, said its fourth-quarter net income rose 18 percent. But the company issued mixed guidance for the current quarter and full year 2013. It fell 33 cents to $118.50.

Oil company Hess Inc. was the biggest gainer in the S&P 500, adding 6.1 percent after the company said it plans to sell its U.S. terminal network, shutter its New Jersey refinery and continue shifting its focus to exploration and production. Hess also said that the hedge fund Elliott Associates plans to seek regulatory approval to buy a major stake in the company. Hess rose $3.58 to $62.48.

Several big tech companies reported their results after the market closed and saw big price swings in after-hours trading:

* Web portal Yahoo Inc. rose 81 cents, or 4 percent, to $21.12 after saying its fourth-quarter earnings topped analyst estimates as an upturn in its international investments helped end a three-year revenue slump.

* Hard disk maker Seagate Technology PLC said it beat analysts' estimates in its results for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 28. It rose 69 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $38.10 after hours.

* Cloud computing provider VMWare Inc. said its net income edged higher, but the company announced guidance that was far weaker than analysts had expected. VMWare lost $10.83, or 11 percent, to $87.49 after hours.

Strong corporate earnings helped push the S&P 500 through the 1,500 milestone Friday after several calm, relatively news-free weeks. In addition to companies' performance, traders have been encouraged by signals that housing market is improving steadily and hiring is picking up, albeit slowly.

There will plenty of fresh data to drive trading this week, including retail sales, economic growth and the government's report on hiring and employment in January, which is due out Friday. More than one-fifth of the companies in the S&P 500 will report fourth-quarter earnings this week.

Stone said stocks are trading sideways in part because many investors are awaiting economic reports later this week, especially the employment report. There is agreement among economists and analysts that the economy slowed in the fourth quarter, he said, and this week's numbers will help answer the question of "how slow, and how much did it impact employment."

The yield in the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 1.97 percent from 1.95 percent late Friday, reflecting lower demand for ultra-safe investments. After Monday's factory orders report, the yield rose briefly above 2 percent for the first time since April. A bond's yield rises as demand for it decreases.

urn:contentItem:60G3-GFW1-F07F-83VX-00000-00Stocks Open Slightly Higher Ahead Of Federal Reserve Decision2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisNEWSStocks Open Slightly Higher Ahead Of Federal Reserve DecisionSergei Klebnikov

TOPLINE The market opened slightly higher on Wednesday as investors closely watch for the Federal Reserve’s latest policy decision and a congressional hearing on antitrust in Big Tech later in the day. KEY FACTS The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.1%......

TOPLINE The market opened slightly higher on Wednesday as investors closely watch for the Federal Reserve’s latest policy decision and a congressional hearing on antitrust in Big Tech later in the day. KEY FACTS The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.1%...

TOPLINE The market opened slightly higher on Wednesday as investors closely watch for the Federal Reserve’s latest policy decision and a congressional hearing on antitrust in Big Tech later in the day. KEY FACTS The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.1%, nearly 50 points, at Wednesday’s open, while the S&P 500 rose 0.4% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite gained 0.8%. The Federal Reserve, which concludes its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at near zero to continue to support the economy through the coronavirus pandemic. The CEOs of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google-parent Alphabet are set to testify before the House Antitrust Subcommittee later on Wednesday, which may give investors insight into how Big Tech companies are handling challenges from regulators. While Big Tech companies are among the best-performing stocks so far this year, there are rising concerns on Wall Street that heavy market concentration in these handful of big names could pose downside risks. The busiest week of the second quarter earnings season continued, with shares of General Electric, Advanced Micro Devices, General Motors and Shopify all rising after the companies reported better-than-expected results. Boeing and Starbucks, meanwhile, posted wider-than-expected losses last quarter, but both stocks traded higher heading into the market open. Key background Investors also continued to assess the latest coronavirus relief bill unveiled by Senate Republicans late on Monday, titled the Heath, Economic Assistance, Liability Protection and Schools (HEALS) Act. The GOP proposal for the next round of federal coronavirus aid includes a second round of $1,200 stimulus checks and more funds for small business loans in the Paycheck Protection Program. The bill would also eliminate the $600-per-week federal unemployment supplement, which states stopped paying out this week, to be replaced with a 70% wage-replacement program. What to watch for The Federal Reserve will wrap up its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday: The last time Fed officials met in June, they decided to maintain the target range for the federal funds rate at 0% to 0.25%. On Tuesday, the central bank announced that it would extend loan programs through the end of 2020 as it continues to support the U.S. economy amid the pandemic. Full coverage and live updates on the Coronavirus

urn:contentItem:4238-MDH0-0094-7273-00000-00STOCKS PARE LOSSES WITH LATE COMEBACK2001-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisBUSINESS,STOCKS PARE LOSSES WITH LATE COMEBACKBloomberg News,Sun-Sentinel wire services

Bargain-hunters saved the market from another big tech selloff Monday, rescuing the Dow Jones industrials and the Nasdaq composite index from losses of more than 100 points each in the last hour of trading.

Stocks still finished lower, as Wall Street is waiting to see how much harm the slowing economy has had on earnings.

The Dow closed down 40.66 at 10,621.35. The Nasdaq fell 11.73 to 2,395.92 and the Standard & Poor's 500 index ended down 2.49 at 1,295.86. MONDAY

Aronex Pharmaceuticals Inc. (ARNX)

Shares fell $ 3.33, or 73 percent, to $ 1.23 and traded as low as $ 1. The drug developer said its leukemia drug Atragen was rejected for a second time by U.S. regulators, forcing the company to cut jobs.
 
Ciphergen Biosystems Inc. (CIPH)

Shares fell $ 3.56, or 31 percent, to $ 8.31 and traded as low as $ 7.63. The maker of laboratory tools for studying proteins said it had fourth-quarter revenue of about $ 3 million, as much as 15 percent below its expectations. The company made the announcement in a press release distributed by PR Newswire.
 
Drugstore.com Inc. (DSCM)

Shares rose 78 cents, or 63 percent, to $ 2.03 and traded as high as $ 2.81. The Internet drug-seller said fourth-quarter sales increased 90 percent to $ 35 million from a year ago. The company made the announcement in a press release distributed by Business Wire and couldn't immediately be reached for comment.
 
Internet Security Systems Inc. (ISSX)

Shares fell $ 12.19 to $ 48.50 and traded as low as $ 47.75. The maker of computer security software was downgraded to "outperform" from "buy" in a report by analyst Chris Hovis at Robinson-Humphrey Co. Inc.
 
Kronos Inc. (KRON)

Shares fell $ 2.06 to $ 33 and traded as low as $ 27.25. The maker of labor-management systems said it had revenue of $ 64 million to $ 65 million in its first quarter ended Dec. 30, which it said is below forecasts.
 
Leap Wireless International Inc. (LWIN)

Shares rose $ 4.06 to $ 36.50 and traded as high as $ 38.42. The telecommunications company ended last year with more than 190,000 subscribers to its Cricket service, a flat-rate wireless calling plan. That beat company goals and analysts' forecasts, Leap Wireless said.
 
Tut Systems Inc. (TUTS)

Shares fell $ 1.34, or 22 percent, to $ 5.84 and traded as low as $ 5.13. The maker of equipment that allows copper telephone lines to handle high-speed Internet access said it had fourth-quarter revenue of $ 6 million to $ 7 million, lower than $ 15 million to $ 18 million it had expected.
 
VerticalNet Inc. (VERT)

Shares fell $ 1.44, or 27 percent, to $ 3.88 and traded as low as $ 3.75. The manager of Web sites fell after its CEO resigned.
 
Today
 
I2 Technologies Inc. (ITWO)

Shares rose as high as $ 49 in after-hours trading Monday. It closed at $ 41.94. The software maker said it expects to report fourth-quarter revenue of more than $ 370 million. It was expected to have revenue of $ 343 million, the average estimate of seven analysts.
 
MiniMed Inc. (MNMD)

Shares fell as low as $ 24.63 in after-hours trading Monday. It closed at $ 33 in regular trading. The maker of diabetes-treatment products said it expects to report earnings of 17 cents a share for its fourth quarter ended Dec. 29. It was expected to earn 19 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call.
 
Airgas Inc. (ARG)

The industrial gas distributor said it expects to report earnings of 10 cents to 12 cents a share in its third quarter ended Dec. 31. It was expected to earn 15 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. Airgas on Monday rose 13 cents to $ 7.75.
 
Aztar Corp. (AZR)

The casino and hotel operator said it expects to report fourth-quarter earnings that are little changed from the 10 cents a share earned in the fourth quarter of 1999. It was expected to earn 14 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call. Aztar rose 13 cents to $ 11.38.

urn:contentItem:5S17-9251-DY2T-F194-00000-00Stocks Plummet Amid China'S Tariff Revenge; Big tech among big losers as investors are rattled by looming trade war, data privacy2018-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. B1 Stocks Plummet Amid China'S Tariff Revenge; Big tech among big losers as investors are rattled by looming trade war, data privacyMarley JayThe Associated PressNEW YORK

Stocks tumbled Monday after China raised import duties on a number of U.S. exports, bringing the two economic giants closer to a full-on trade conflict. Big technology companies, long investor favourites, suffered heavy losses.

The deepening worries over newly protectionist U.S. trade policies combined with blowback toward technology companies, including Facebook's ever-widening privacy scandal, have prompted investors to pull money out of the market. That has meant steep drops in former big winners including Netflix, Microsoft and Alphabet, Google's parent company.

Among other recent winners, Intel dove 6.1 per cent following a report in Bloomberg News that Apple plans to start using its own chips in Mac computers, and Amazon sank following more broadsides from U.S. President Donald Trump on Twitter.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 758 points, although major indexes regained some of their losses later in the afternoon. The Dow lost 458.92 points, or 1.9 per cent, to 23,644.19.

The S&;P 500 index gave up 58.99 points, or 2.2 per cent, to 2,581.88.

The Nasdaq composite slumped 193.33 points, or 2.7 per cent, to 6,870.12. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks fell 36.90 points, or 2.4 per cent, to 1,492.53.

Toronto's main stock index joined U.S. markets in a downward swing Monday as Chinese tariff action rattled investors after the holiday weekend.

The Toronto Stock Exchange's S&;P/TSX composite closed down 153.84 points at 15,213.45, led by declines in energy and health care.

Kate Warne, an investment strategist for Edward Jones, said the step by China is small but significant.

"The fact that a country has actually raised tariffs in retaliation is an important step in the wrong direction," she said. "The tariffs imposed by China today lead to greater worries that we will see escalating tariffs and the possibility of a much bigger impact than investors were anticipating last week. And that could be true for Mexico as well as for China."

Food maker Tyson dropped 6.2 per cent after China raised import duties on a US$3 billion list of U.S. goods in response to the tariffs on imported steel and aluminum that President Trump ordered last month.

Amazon fell another 5.2 per cent.

The online retailer has slumped with the market recently, although it's still up about 17 per cent in 2018. Trump has repeatedly criticized Amazon over issues including taxes and Amazon's shipping deals with the U.S. Postal Service.

Jack Ablin, chief investment officer of Cresset Wealth Advisors, said Amazon is just the latest company to falter after it drew scrutiny from the government, as Facebook and Alphabet have slumped recently on data privacy concerns.

"It seems like the long arm of the government is interfering with investors'expectations," he said. "Investors are pricing in an escalating trade war and regulation of tech companies."

Microsoft dropped three per cent and Alphabet, Google's parent company, shed 2.4 per cent.

After a month of public negotiations between the U.S. and several other countries, Monday marked the first time another country has placed tariffs on U.S. goods in response to the Trump administration's recent trade sanctions.

The price of gold climbed 1.2 per cent to US$1,343.60 an ounce and silver jumped two per cent to US$16.60 an ounce as some investors took money out of stocks and looked for safer investments.

Health insurer Humana was one of the market's few winners following more reports Walmart could buy the company or create a new partnership with it. Humana is a major provider of Medicare Advantage coverage for people 65 and older. Humana gained 4.4 per cent while Walmart slid 3.8 per cent.

Bond prices finished little changed. The yield on the 10-year Treasury stayed at 2.74 per cent after a sharp decline last week.

Energy companies skidded as benchmark U.S. crude lost US$1.93, or three per cent, to US$63.01 a barrel in New York. Brent crude, used to price international oils, slid US$1.70, or 2.5 per cent, to US$67.64 a barrel in London.

Wholesale gasoline dropped five cents to US$1.97 a gallon. Heating oil fell four cents to US$1.98 a gallon. Natural gas slid five cents to US$2.68 per 1,000 cubic feet.

Copper rose two cents to US$3.05 a pound.

The dollar declined to 105.85 yen from 106.50 yen. The euro edged up to US$1.23 from US$1.2306.

Trading in France, Germany and Britain was closed for Easter. Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 lost 0.3 per cent and South Korea's Kospi fell almost 0.1 per cent. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong was closed as well. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2018 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

It was a day of few winners as China fired back on U.S. trade sanctions by increasing import duties on U.S. goods, and big technology companies were caught in the blowback. The TSX also suffered a downward swing Monday.;

urn:contentItem:5S16-YXX1-JBKR-R0WK-00000-00Stocks Plummet Amid China'S Tariff Revenge; Big tech among big losers as investors are rattled by looming trade war, data privacy2018-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL POSTPg. C5Stocks Plummet Amid China'S Tariff Revenge; Big tech among big losers as investors are rattled by looming trade war, data privacyMarley JayThe Associated PressNEW YORK

Stocks tumbled Monday after China raised import duties on a number of U.S. exports, bringing the two economic giants closer to a full-on trade conflict. Big technology companies, long investor favourites, suffered heavy losses.

The deepening worries over newly protectionist U.S. trade policies combined with blowback toward technology companies, including Facebook's ever-widening privacy scandal, have prompted investors to pull money out of the market. That has meant steep drops in former big winners including Netflix, Microsoft and Alphabet, Google's parent company.

Among other recent winners, Intel dove 6.1 per cent following a report in Bloomberg News that Apple plans to start using its own chips in Mac computers, and Amazon sank following more broadsides from U.S. President Donald Trump on Twitter.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 758 points, although major indexes regained some of their losses later in the afternoon. The Dow lost 458.92 points, or 1.9 per cent, to 23,644.19.

The S&;P 500 index gave up 58.99 points, or 2.2 per cent, to 2,581.88.

The Nasdaq composite slumped 193.33 points, or 2.7 per cent, to 6,870.12. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks fell 36.90 points, or 2.4 per cent, to 1,492.53.

Toronto's main stock index joined U.S. markets in a downward swing Monday as Chinese tariff action rattled investors after the holiday weekend.

The Toronto Stock Exchange's S&;P/TSX composite closed down 153.84 points at 15,213.45, led by declines in energy and health care.

Kate Warne, an investment strategist for Edward Jones, said the step by China is small but significant.

"The fact that a country has actually raised tariffs in retaliation is an important step in the wrong direction," she said. "The tariffs imposed by China today lead to greater worries that we will see escalating tariffs and the possibility of a much bigger impact than investors were anticipating last week. And that could be true for Mexico as well as for China."

Food maker Tyson dropped 6.2 per cent after China raised import duties on a US$3 billion list of U.S. goods in response to the tariffs on imported steel and aluminum that President Trump ordered last month.

Amazon fell another 5.2 per cent.

The online retailer has slumped with the market recently, although it's still up about 17 per cent in 2018. Trump has repeatedly criticized Amazon over issues including taxes and Amazon's shipping deals with the U.S. Postal Service.

Jack Ablin, chief investment officer of Cresset Wealth Advisors, said Amazon is just the latest company to falter after it drew scrutiny from the government, as Facebook and Alphabet have slumped recently on data privacy concerns.

"It seems like the long arm of the government is interfering with investors'expectations," he said. "Investors are pricing in an escalating trade war and regulation of tech companies."

Microsoft dropped three per cent and Alphabet, Google's parent company, shed 2.4 per cent.

After a month of public negotiations between the U.S. and several other countries, Monday marked the first time another country has placed tariffs on U.S. goods in response to the Trump administration's recent trade sanctions.

The price of gold climbed 1.2 per cent to US$1,343.60 an ounce and silver jumped two per cent to US$16.60 an ounce as some investors took money out of stocks and looked for safer investments.

Health insurer Humana was one of the market's few winners following more reports Walmart could buy the company or create a new partnership with it. Humana is a major provider of Medicare Advantage coverage for people 65 and older. Humana gained 4.4 per cent while Walmart slid 3.8 per cent.

Bond prices finished little changed. The yield on the 10-year Treasury stayed at 2.74 per cent after a sharp decline last week.

Energy companies skidded as benchmark U.S. crude lost US$1.93, or three per cent, to US$63.01 a barrel in New York. Brent crude, used to price international oils, slid US$1.70, or 2.5 per cent, to US$67.64 a barrel in London.

Wholesale gasoline dropped five cents to US$1.97 a gallon. Heating oil fell four cents to US$1.98 a gallon. Natural gas slid five cents to US$2.68 per 1,000 cubic feet.

Copper rose two cents to US$3.05 a pound.

The dollar declined to 105.85 yen from 106.50 yen. The euro edged up to US$1.23 from US$1.2306.

Trading in France, Germany and Britain was closed for Easter. Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 lost 0.3 per cent and South Korea's Kospi fell almost 0.1 per cent. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong was closed as well. !@COPYRIGHT=© 2018 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

. Drew Angerer, Getty Images; A trader works on the floor on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday. It was a day of few winners as China fired back on U.S. trade sanctions by increasing import duties on U.S. goods, and big technology companies were caught in the blowback. The TSX also suffered a downward swing Monday;
