Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W2T-RYV1-DY0W-41T9-00000-00Stocks Poised To Open Lower In Black Friday Trade, Notch Weekly Loss of More than Three Percent; 'I Made a Tremendous Difference': Trump Heaps Thanksgiving Praise On Himself; Amazon Workers Strike; Black Friday Shopping; Fast Food Restaurants Hosting Hiring Parties; German Execs Invited To W.H.; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Vs. Mickelson Today; Live Action Lion King2018-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks Poised To Open Lower In Black Friday Trade, Notch Weekly Loss of More than Three Percent; 'I Made a Tremendous Difference': Trump Heaps Thanksgiving Praise On Himself; Amazon Workers Strike; Black Friday Shopping; Fast Food Restaurants Hosting Hiring Parties; German Execs Invited To W.H.; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Vs. Mickelson Today; Live Action Lion KingLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: It's the busiest shopping day of the year. Welcome to a special Black Friday edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, November 23th, your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern, time to go shopping. It's Black Friday more than 164 million people are expected to shop this weekend. Online sales are set to hit records. We'll keep an eye on retailers this morning like Amazon, Overstock, Macy's, these stocks have all been very hard hit, most of the retailers so far this month, can they turn around?

Amazon hit by a worker's strike in Germany and Spain today. Futures are showing this and the market action this morning. The losses across the board. The Dow futures are down 84 points. And, again, this is so far we're trying to turn around what has been a really, really awful week. We have losses of more than three percent at almost four percent loss on the NASDAQ Composite so far this week. In Europe, we have England, France, and Germany trading wide-open.

A slight loss on the Footsie 100 in England. Gains in France and Germany. The Asian markets closing lower overnight. The Nikkei was closed altogether. It never opened, but we have losses on the other three major markets there. The price of crude oil slipping this morning. We have oil prices now at the lowest level since late 2017 on abundance of supply. We break out what is going on. Telecom trouble, the U.S. warning that countries dealing with Chinese company Huawei Technologies ahead of this big meeting between President Trump and China's President Xi Jinping at the G20 Summit next week.

The concern is the use of Huawei Technology and potential infiltration on the U.S. military bases abroad. And then on to the border battle, President Trump threatening to shut down the entire Mexican border if immigration becomes uncontrollable. This is a group breaks off from the migrant caravan just 500 feet away from the U.S. border. The Trump administration reportedly wants to meet the heads of Volkswagen, BMW, and Daimler to discuss trade policy.

Reuters says that the invitation is to meet with Economic Advisor Larry Kudlow Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. Then the thriller on the green, Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson teeing off today in a special pay-per-view match in Las Vegas. Nine million dollars at stake. We have details. And Lion King goes live action. We can just listen to that all morning long. The trailer for the Lion King movie making its debut online and more of the amazing video coming up.

Here to break it all down this morning, Fox Business Network's Susan Li, Chief Market Strategist at Third Seven Advisors, Michael Block, and Republican strategist, former Trump surrogate, former Republican Convention Deputy Press Secretary Erin Elmore. Erin, I'm going to get to the president's tweet. I don't feel like I've talked to you enough this morning. So the president just tweeted and I'm going to get your reaction really quickly. Here's what the president says, really good criminal justice reform has a true shot at major bipartisan support.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer have a real chance to do something so badly needed in our country. Already passed with the big boat and House would be a major victory for all. He's seriously focused regardless of the Democrats' win in the House. He's seriously focused on getting things done.

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Right, because it's been so divisive. Right now, it's Republicans vote one way and Democrats vote another way, and there's really no sort of civility anymore. And I think he's really wants to get things accomplished in a bipartisan fashion because we haven't seen that in the last two years and I also think he's looking forward to 2020.

MCDOWELL: Well, I don't -- I will argue that the president based on just the language that he enjoys using sometimes. It's not about civility. It's about results. But it's not -- it's not about getting along in terms of not calling each other names. It's actually passing things that benefit all America.

ELMORE: Absolutely, because he has the best interests of the American people at heart whereas some these people in the Senate -- in the House that are so worried about their reelects and their elections and just sort of banging their fists on principle aren't so focused on those goals.

MCDOWELL: So instead of investigations in the House maybe we get actual things getting done and he's talking about the Senate, but --

(CROSSTALK)

ELMORE: Well, I think, you know, focusing on the Hillary Clinton stuff and dredging all that up again. Let's be more like the markets. Let's be forward looking, right? So I think that's what should be the big focus here Hillary Clinton stuff, it's old news and I think we have to move on from all of it.

MCDOWELL: Well, maybe she's going to run again.

ELMORE: I mean that would be -- that would be Christmas come early for the Republicans.

MCDOWELL: What a day. So we'll move on this Black Friday full swing -- in full swing. Shoppers scored deals ahead of the holidays. Hillary Vaughn is live from Garden City, New York with the very latest. Good morning, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen. Well, the Apple store just opened up. That's the big news here. There was a line all the way down this hallway. They opened up. Now, a lot of people looking to get good deals on new Apple products. But Apple is one of the stores where they're kind of offering a bonus gift card with any purchase - - some of the purchases for some of their new gear. Not necessarily discounting their prices.

But we have other long lines here. You have lines out the door for jewelry stores. I talked to a lot of these shoppers in line. They're looking to get some gifts for their mom, their sisters. Some guys in line looking to get gifts for their daughter or girlfriend. This is a store that's been pretty steady. A lot of people stacked up in line. We've seen a lot of young shoppers today. A lot of high schoolers out with their friends looking to cash in on the good deals and get those gifts, a lot of millennial shoppers.

So, you know, all this talk of people hopping on their phones staying at home doing everything online, well, we've seen young shoppers actually get into the holiday spirit. They like the idea of going out with their friends grabbing coffee early in the morning and coming here, and making a day of it. So a lot of hustle and bustle here people cashing in getting into holiday spirit, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Hillary, thank you for that. Hillary Vaughn for us at -- on Long Island. President Trump touting his administration's economic successes yesterday as the United States kicks off its annual holiday shopping season. The commander-in-chief commenting on what he's thankful for.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What are you most thankful for Mr. President?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: For having a great family and for having made a tremendous difference in this country. I've made a tremendous difference in the country. This country is so much stronger now than it was when I took office that you wouldn't believe it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Here now fashion and retailer trend analyst Charcy Evers. Charcy, your take on the holiday shopping season kicking off so far? What should we be watching?

CHARCY EVERS, FASHION AND RETAIL TREND ANALYST: We are all about experience at retail right now and that's what's drawing people into the stores. I keep saying that Black Friday is back and that's what customers are coming in for the experience and we're seeing that across, you know, all the big box stores as well as smaller retailers --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: What kind of experience other than just the elbows and showing from the crowds because you're talking about things that the retailers have really planned to really push and to get people -- get -- to produce foot traffic?

EVERS: Right, exactly. And it's part of much larger shift in retail in general this idea of creating experience centers in touch points because we all know that we can all buy everything online. So what's going to give me a reason to come into a store? Target for example has over 25,000 hours of retail experience planned throughout the holiday season. They have hours of play for kids really kind of taking advantage of the hole in the market that Toys"R"Us left inviting children in and having play dates with them and actually letting them use toys before you're even buying them.

So it's really creating a way to get them into the stores. Wal-Mart the same thing. They're having actual play dates with children really inviting them in. They've also created a digital playground online where you can use your tablet or your computer to try the toys out before, so that's just one the ways that these retailers are having people, you know, getting them into the store and making it like enjoyable.

MCDOWELL: Because it's hard to get consumers in the store especially if you can shop online and that's why it's hard to compete also with Amazon's discount. You really have to slice a lot of your pricing, right?

EVERS: Right. And I think we all know that, you know, to -- the holidays is a perfect time to kind of come up with a new experiential strategy as a retailer because it's, you know, we -- the idea of Black Friday or the holidays in general is like let's go and sit on Santa's lap and take a picture. That's always kind of, you know, it's bringing back that nostalgia of going in and creating tradition and Black Friday for many families is a tradition of going shopping --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: What about pricing though?

ELMORE: I mean (INAUDIBLE) get competitive when you have to give door busters and you basically cut your prices to extraordinary levels.

EVERS: I think that retailers are really trying to take -- get away from that stigma that Black Friday has of like people fighting over T.V.'s at the door and making it more of a kind of feel good family experience. There's always -- we know we're going to get the best prices online. We know that the deals are out there. But it's kind of, again, as I said, it's part of this larger shift in retail in general of creating an experience in the holidays really lend itself well to that --

(CROSSTALK)

ELMORE: -- this holiday season?

EVERS: Target for sure. I know their earnings will let you know was not a good Tuesday for them. But, you know, they've really put -- they've reinvested in their company. They put money back into the stores and really, you know, built-up their e-commerce business. So I think we will be surprised to see them. I think they'll have a good holiday season.

MCDOWELL: It might --

(CROSSTALK)

MICHAEL BLOCK, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: So, Charcy, you talked about Kohl's, and Target, and Kohl's, you talked about investing more in their business perhaps some more in these experiences, what about the mall operators? They've been under a lot of fire as, you know --

(CROSSTALK)

BLOCK: -- retail investment in kinds of places, is there any talk amongst the mall operators about how to provide more experiences?

EVERS: Oh, absolutely. I think that that's why, you know, we were talking a lot -- we talked a lot about retailer apocalypse and I always say it's actually retail renaissance. It's a much needed renaissance and rebirth of retail and it has caused the mall developers to really look at how they're using their space, right? So Roosevelt Mall for example has an area where shops are just pop-ups. So rather than going into these long-term leases which are really difficult for retailers to sustain, you know, and it's a risk in having overhead inventory.

Having pop-ups gives me a reason like I know when in one a month, it's going to be a different store there, so I'm going to go back into the mall and I'm going to go check out what's new with the pop-ups. So it's a little bit of novelty. There's also, you know, Westfield does a great job of incorporating experience in terms with theater, with entertainment, with restaurants, you know, they will become more experiential hubs.

And going back to Wal-Mart, they've really create -- they're doing new things with their stores and creating what they call town centers. And, actually, using the space around them, you know, the parking lots, the empty stores around them and creating these experiential centers that are really drawing consumers in, so --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: And don't -- because, again, I feel like some retail success stories get lumped in with the mall problems which had been going clearly 30 years in this country because I keep bringing this up, but Aerie which is a division of American Eagle was -- if you watched Aerie, that store literally -- it pulled you in you as a --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- shopper that they have such great inexpensive like lounge wear. If you were watching Aerie versus Victoria's Secret, you would know even two years ago that Victoria's Secret was in trouble and that Aerie was on the rise.

EVERS: Oh, yes. I talked a lot about that. Don't get me started Victoria's Secret. I think that --

(CROSSTALK)

EVERS: -- they missed out on the roller trend, you know, and they're also --

(CROSSTALK)

EVERS: -- very early and they did it and they did it well, and Victoria's Secret just needs, you know, come with the top -- like lived up in the times, you know, they didn't shift when the consumer shifted. We're with at leisure out there and more athletic apparel and stuff. The bras don't need to be under wired. We're not into push-up bras. We're not into that image of a woman any more, you know, it's about physical -- it's about being comfortable and --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- was the management at Victoria's Secret living in that they wouldn't know that it was about this -- there's not one standard of beauty anymore and it doesn't weigh 100 pounds and is six feet tall and --

(CROSSTALK)

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: -- the primetime lingerie show. I mean --

(CROSSTALK)

EVERS: -- but when you -- when you think about the comments of the CMO made about the Victoria's Secret Show, you really see that it's better than the culture. This ideology that's outdated.

MCDOWELL: That CMO has been running that fashion show as long as they've been doing it and kind of begs the question of like why is that dude still there?

EVERS: Right --

(CROSSTALK)

BLOCK: -- as my wife would say some man must have thought of that --

(CROSSTALK)

EVERS: Think about it. It's not the zeitgeist the more -- it's all about a male fantasy and an image that they're banking off as opposed to like me too women's power like get with day --

(CROSSTALK)

BLOCK: -- make money.

MCDOWELL: I'm glad I got you started on that really quickly, who do you think will be the big winner this weekend retail wise?

EVERS: I think Macy's is doing a great job. Nordstrom is doing a great job. Macy's is doing pop-ups with Facebook. You know, this idea of integrating online and off-line, I also talked a lot about retail -- it's just retail, right? It does not have to online, off-line. The customer is shopping now on their mobile. It has to be seamless. There's no distinction between the two.

MCDOWELL: Charcy, great to see you. Come back.

EVERS: I will.

MCDOWELL: And we'll talk about everything, Charcy Evers. Stay tuned we'll be right back everybody.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Border battle, President Trump threatening to shut down the U.S.-Mexico border if troops cannot get a handle on the migrants looking to cross into this country. Edward Lawrence is live from the White House with the very latest. Good morning, Edward.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Dagen. And not only is the president willing to shut down the entire border, but it's allowing the military to forcibly stop any illegal immigrant who gets out of control. This is an escalation of his position on the caravan. Now, this president says that criminals have infiltrated this caravan and they're already started to cause problems in Tijuana. He made these comments while the nation has celebrated Thanksgiving.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's not like normal innocent people. These are people you talk to. I mean they start a fistfight. I don't that in this country, OK?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. President, what about the idea that the military may use lethal force against these migrants?

TRUMP: They have to. They're going to use lethal force.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: And he wants Mexico to do more to secure their side of the border. The president is saying that if things get out of control as a last resort, he will close the entire border. No crossings at all. The State Department says that $1.7 billion worth of goods and services crosses that Mexican border daily. Now, all of this is tied to the funding of the border wall. The president tweeting about 20 minutes ago saying that Republicans and Democrats need to come together with a package that will include funding for the wall.

The president is saying he will partially shut down the government if he does not get funding for that border wall. Now, on this subject, Hillary Clinton interviewed with the Guardian newspaper backtracking a little bit what she campaigned on in 2016. She said that Europe cannot offer -- open borders because it's giving rise to these right-wing populist groups. Hillary Clinton goes on to say that Europe must put a position out there.

Now, that they will not have -- they will not continue to refuge or support unlimited refugees. Back to you, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: That it went too far in terms of the asylum-seekers and the migrants coming in particularly from Syria. It went too far in Germany. You've seen that in -- with Angela Merkel in Germany and I pointed this out earlier, Edward, it was -- I said two years ago. It was actually three years ago. There were mass sexual assaults in Cologne, Germany related to this very problem, so Hillary Clinton is essentially saying that this went too far in Europe --

(CROSSTALK)

LAWRENCE: Yes, exactly.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- and it's -- she's saying that after a lot of other people know that.

LAWRENCE: Exactly. And not just Germany but also Greece and Italy had a massive problem with this influx. Now, the numbers have cut down since 2015. But, again, they're still having those issues and seeing more and more people coming in.

MCDOWELL: Edward, thank you so much. Happy Thanksgiving belatedly.

LAWRENCE: You too.

MCDOWELL: Edward Lawrence. Coming up, crude awakening, we're watching oil prices and oversupply concerns. And The Lion King is back, a sneak peek of the live action reboot later this hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Futures are pointing to a lower ahead of the open where a little more than an hour away from the opening bell. A 115-point loss on the Dow futures right now. And let's not forget what happened on Wednesday. It's been a really terrible week for stocks. But gains were wiped out in the final hours of trading on Wednesday. So even when you -- maybe we can see a bounce back. If we see a flip around in the futures maybe we get gains as we head into the close at 1:00 p.m. Eastern today.

Joining us now is the Head of Global Research at Bulltick Capital Markets, Kathryn Rooney Vera. Kathryn, always great to see you. What you are you watching today in terms of the market action? Are investors going to be paying attention to any incline we get about retail sales?

KATHRYN ROONEY VERA, HEAD, GLOBAL RESEARCH, BULLTICK CAPITAL MARKETS: Yes. I think retail sale definitely comes into play, Dagen. There's been a lot of talk about recession that seems kind of comical at this point when you see Black Friday sales already pointing to a double-digit year-over-year increase. So I mean I think that retail sales are going to come out strong. I think we're in a strong economic swing and I don't see recession on the near-term horizon at all.

MCDOWELL: What people -- when people talked about recession what they're worried about is this broad downdraft in a whole host of asset classes. It's not just technology stocks. It was retail stocks earlier in the week like sever double-digit losses on some of these retail names. It's even Bitcoin. You have a yield curve that is flattening that, you know, people are very worried about shorter term interest rates being higher than longer term interest rates.

You -- even the downdraft in oil, so -- but you don't see a recession here, so does that mean that we get a rebound in the market?

VERA: Dagen, none of these trends are new, not one. I would say that what I'm expecting is a near term near impetus to change this negative trend. It's momentum driven. It's sentiment driven. Guys talk about recession, Dagen, when the -- when we get a correction in the markets. It's a direct correlation between drops in markets and talk of recession. So one does not necessarily mean imply the other. What I will say is that I think that the Xi and Trump meeting is the most near term potential of near tern potential for that bounce in sentiment.

So if we get anything on this front, anything verbal a handshake, any concession from the Chinese, I'll bet you got stocks fly.

BLOCK: What do you see other than, Kathryn, you know, in terms of emerging markets? We haven't heard a lot about Brazil and Mexico (INAUDIBLE) what do you -- what's your outlook there?

VERA: Look, I think, you know, if we get a risk on sentiment then emerging markets definitely disproportionately benefit because it's a high beta place. So if you have risk on which means that investors rush in looking for those higher yields higher than what you get in treasuries then the emerging markets will certainly benefit. But what we do need to see what we have to see is some, you know, some melting of the icy tensions with China and the U.S.

So I think that's going to be near term stimulus if we get the emerging markets do even better.

ELMORE: Headwinds, a strong dollar higher interest rates. I assume you're pricing in the fed to move into December and possibly more next year.

VERA: Yes. The fed I think has largely -- the hikes have been largely discounted if you look at fed funds futures which is something that we in the market look at in terms of where the fed is going to be putting rates or the terminal rate by end of next year. I would say it's largely priced in, Erin. And the market would be surprised if the fed were to hike disproportionately more. There's a real risk however that the feds applies on the opposite side that they don't hike in December.

That could be another near term impetus for the market to change this negative trajectory.

MCDOWELL: Kathryn, great to see you. Happy Thanksgiving. Thanks for taking some of your Black Friday morning out and joining us. Kathryn Rooney Vera down in -- where it's a lot warmer than it is here in Florida.

VERA: Thank you so much.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, questions for James Comey, the latest development as the former FBI Director is vowing to fight a subpoena he received from House Republicans. Plus, a legendry face-off, the nine million dollar showdown between Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: Welcome back to a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA: BLACK FRIDAY.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. Black Friday is here! All eyes on retailers, more than 164 million people are expected to shop this weekend. A record-setting number of online shoppers set to grab some deals. Futures are showing this in the markets. Can we get a turn around? We had one in the making on Wednesday, and as we got near the close, markets flipped around. Dow down 119 points on the Futures right now, it's been a bruising week for stocks. Markets close early today at 1:00 p.m. Eastern Time. Fox Business has you covered until 2:00 in the afternoon. So, all day past the close at 1:00. And we're looking at losses of more than three percent on all three major market gauges so far this week. And we've had like double-digit losses on some of these retail stocks.

In Europe, we have losses on the FTSE 100, and the CAC Quarante in France to report although slight. And in Asia overnight, it was losses across the board, as well. Except for the Nikkei which was closed for trading this Friday. The price of crude oil in the red again this morning. Oil prices at their lowest level since late 2017. We have cost of crude trading at $51.00 a barrel at the moment.

Car conference, the Trump administration reportedly wants to meet the heads of German automakers next week to discuss trade policy. Does that mean getting rid of tariffs? Europe's import tariffs on our cars. How about our import tariffs on light trucks coming in from other nations? We will dig into that.

And former -- and subpoenaed former FBI Director, Jim Comey, is meeting -- is meeting with House Judiciary Committee next month. He's been subpoenaed, Comey says, I'm going to -- you know, I don't want to do it behind closed doors, I want do it in public. Let's see what happens. This is, of course, before the Democrats take over the House in January.

It's Tiger versus Phil, golf greats Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson team off today in a special pay-per-view match in Las Vegas. A lot riding on the game including a $9-million prize and a side bet from Mickelson himself.

And the circle of life goes live action, the trailer for the new "Lion King" movie making its debut online, more of this incredible coming attraction, coming up.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You can't get enough, can you?

MCDOWELL: I cannot get enough.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Cannot.

MCDOWELL: I watched it I don't know how many times yesterday.

Outrage for Amazon workers, employees striking in Germany and Spain during Black Friday. Kristina Partsinevelos is live from the New York Stock Exchange with the details. Hey, Kristina.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Yes. Good morning, Dagen. As you can see, it's kind of quiet here today. A lot of people haven't come into the office, but what we're hearing from Amazon, you're actually seeing some pre-market volume going on with that stock right now, but like you mentioned, there is a strike going on in Germany, about 650 employees walked off the job. They're expected to also walk off in Spain tomorrow, so they're going to have a walk-off and then strike on Saturday. The company claims that this won't affect Black Friday orders, nonetheless, the employees chose to do -- this moment in time to negotiate hire pay.

But since we're talking about Amazon such a giant, I wanted to switch over the Best Buy and start talking about that company because Wedbush analyst put out a note raising their target on Best Buy. Right now, it's at $62.00, they believe it can climb higher at $65.00 because they believe Best Buy has done a great job when it comes to electronics and competing the prices against Target. And if we're going to -- against Amazon, sorry. If we're going to end on Wal-Mart and target, I just heard both companies right now, if you go into their stores for Black Friday, you have a wireless thing, you don't have to wait in line, they'll come and find you to buy your products.

MCDOWELL: They're finally doing what Apple has been doing for how many years?

PARTSINEVELOS: Exactly. Exactly.

MCDOWELL: So, I saw that story and I thought --

PARTSINEVELOS: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they should have been doing that at Whole Foods yesterday because that was a horror show here in New York City on Thanksgiving Day. At least they were open, but nevertheless, it was kind of in disarray. I leave it at that. Kristina Partsinevelos, thank you.

PARTSINEVELOS: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: It's good to see you. Joining us now, former McDonald's USA CEO, former Famous Dave's BBQ CEO, Fat Brands International Chairman, Ed Rensi. Ed, what's your outlook for the holiday shopping season?

ED RENSI, CHAIRMAN, FAT BRANDS INTERNATIONAL: I think it's fantastic. Trump has driven this economy largely with these tax reductions, so people have got a lot more money to spend, there's a joyous attitude, too, because a lot of people are back to work, the wages are good, I think, it's a good holiday season, I think it's a good economic story for the average Joe walking the street. I think it's great.

MCDOWELL: So, maybe the people in politics on the left need to stop talking down the economy, and trying to convince everybody that things are lousy simply because they hate President Trump.

RENSI: Well, President Trump is clearly cheerleader in chief. You ask him how he's doing, he's doing AAA. You ask him how the country is doing, it's AAA, he can't find anything wrong anywhere except for the Democrats bad behavior on the border. So, I think we ought to be optimistic. I think as all citizens, my whole family belonged to the Democratic Party, they were in unions, those are the people that built this great country of ours. It's time to get off their back and celebrate the hard work of men and women all across the country.

MCDOWELL: Ed, just to be clear, the quote from President Trump -- I -- because I wrote it down from the Chris Wallace interview earlier in the week. Look, when he asked how he would grade things, look, I late to do it, but I will do it, I would give myself an A+. Is that enough? Can I go higher than that? So, that's the quote which I will be using as the weekend wears on. Susan Li has a question for you, Ed.

LI: Yes, just about wages, Ed, because we know that this holiday shopping season, a lot of retailers have had to raise their wages. It's a tight labor market, you're going to compete for workers, but what does that mean for profit margins in the bottom line?

RENSI: Well, the fact of the matter is when you have a labor shortage which we're suffering in the hospitality industry, people are doing amazing things to recruit for restaurants, and hotels, and what have you. LI: It's a growth stock though. That's a growth sector. That's kind of how they're valued, aren't they? You know, we --

PAYNE: Right.

LI: We actually had Facebook, admitting, going into the holiday, later on Wednesday, that they did hire definers. That was -- they did that on purpose, so that we would miss the headlines on Thursday. But, they admitted to hiring definers, Sheryl Sandberg admitted to actually knowing that they hired this opposition research team.

So, what about Facebook, in particular? What about the reputational risk, regulatory risk priced in?

PAYNE: I (INAUDIBLE) priced in. We had a lot of panic already. And anecdotally, I work the retail investor. And invariably, the retail investor is always wrong. So, when they start to panic -- you know, I think, when they start to panic, you're starting to see some panic in here, that's actually very bullish for the markets.

You didn't see that before and we had a big selloff in the end of October, and we kind of hit those lows again, this past week. No, no one's really panicking, that always concerned me, but now you're starting to see a little bit of panic in there, which makes me think we're probably even closer to some kind of bottom in here.

MCDOWELL: You know what -- you know what, I think our viewers, based on their comments on Twitter, are quite smart about the markets, when what's part -- a part of what's causing this downdraft, it's the smart money. It's the smart money getting put out of business because they have been so wrong. Talk about that.

BLOCK: Yes. Well, what's been going on, is Q3 was hard for one, the hedge funds, they've got whipsawed by a lot these, moves higher in the big tech stocks, and then, right when they -- right when they bought into that, it traded down. It was a rough October, rough November.

There's a lot of blood out there. There's a lot of liquidation. I'm reading about somebody's energy focus funds. There's an energy fund that's down 15.7 percent, month to date, right now, and around, so there's a lot going on.

Your clients, you do have -- you know, you claim retail investors aren't smart, but you know, of course, yours are the smartest, and what are they saying? Like, are they excited about the market? Are they apprehensive? What's your biggest concern right now?

PAYNE: When was the retail investor not smart? But they tend to be very emotional, right? And that emotional Litmus test. Then, you know, we can argue, is the smart money really that smart? Hedge funds have not done that well in the last couple of years.

Just the fact they're selling, they might not -- they might be indicative of making a bad decision as opposed to good decision.

BLOCK: They're Mike Tyson-smart. They're geniuses until they get punched in the face.

MCDOWELL: Jonas Ferris used that very quote on Wednesday, by the way.

BLOCK: Great minds think alike.

MCDOWELL: So you were -- no, you were watching, is what --

BLOCK: Hi, Jonas.

MCDOWELL: No, I'm just kidding. Ryan Payne, good to see you.

PAYNE: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Thanks so much. Stay tuned. Our special Black Friday on Fox Business, we're here until 2:00 p.m. Eastern. And coming up, he's urging for transparency, former FBI Director James Comey, issuing -- issued a subpoena by the House Judiciary Committee, over the Hillary Clinton E-mail scandal.

Plus, showdown on the links, Phil Mickelson and Tiger Woods set to duke it out today, in Vegas, with a $9 million purse.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Weird song. Virgin Atlantic reportedly in talks to by Flybe. Cheryl Casone has more. Hey, Cheryl.

CASONE: That's weird. All right, here's the news: Sky News says the Britain's Virgin Atlantic is going to acquire regional airline, Flybe. This comes a week after Flybe announced in talks to sell itself. Virgin Atlantic owned by Richard Branson's Virgin Group and Delta Airlines. Flybe has got a market cap of about 27 million. Last month, Flybe has shared a proper warning, though; they said a weak demand and a weaker British Pounds. So, we'll see if Virgin Atlantic gets the deal.

Former FBI Director, James Comey says that Republicans have subpoenaed him to testify at a closed-door meeting of the House Judiciary Committee early next month. In a Thanksgiving Day tweet, Comey says, that he would be happy to answer the committee's questions but would resist doing it behind closed doors for that his testimony will be leaked and distorted. The subpoena part of a congressional inquiry into allegations of anti-Trump bias that led to the opening of the Russia investigation.

Well, the head-to-head matchup between two of the biggest names in golf takes place today. Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson is going to hit the links in Las Vegas, the much-hyped $9 million winner take all match. Organizers are hoping to recoup the money from fans willing to pay $19.99 for pay-per-view. Woods and Mickelson are also putting up their own cash and side bets that eventually, of course, is all going to charity. Teatime is set for 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time. Dagen, place your bet.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, a Disney classic reborn. The first trailer for the live-action "Lion King" wowing people; it basically broke the Internet yesterday. Coming up, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ralph, what is wrong you?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Start churning butter and put on your church shoes little sister because we're about to blast off.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ralph, what is it you're trying to say?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We're going to the Internet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: What?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That was a clip from the new animated film "Ralph Breaks the Internet"; the sequel to Disney's "Wreck It Ralph," it premiers on Wednesday. Joining me now: "IN THE FOX LIGHT" Host, Michael Tammero.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The microphone is off?

MCDOWELL: What is your take on "Ralph Breaks the Internet," is he going to break the box office?

MICHAEL TAMMERO, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST AND VICE PRESIDENT FOR MARKETING: It's going to break all sorts of records this weekend, looking probably about $100 million. You know, this is a big weekend for the box office every year; and so far, box office is up over 10 percent this year over last year, with an -- attendance is up which is even a bigger story right now. It's not just, you know, the fact that tickets are more expensive, but attendance is up about seven percent so far this year. And this weekend, looks to push those numbers even higher. The Ralph, critics are loving him and audiences are loving him as well and it about A- cinema score.

MCDOWELL: What else is opening this weekend or is in competition --

TAMMERO: We have "Creed 2," follow up to the big 2016 hit, Michael B. Jordan -- what a year this guy has had. He started the year with "Black Panther" which grossed over $700 million. "Creed 2" is getting also sorts of critical acclaim; and who knows it could push him to an Oscar coming down, an award season, you just never know with these things.

MCDOWELL: All right, so what broke yesterday, can we just watch it?

TAMMERO: Oh, my God, yes!

MCDOWELL: "The Lion King" live-action trailer, the very first one. Roll it. Do we have it?

TAMMERO: Or not?

MCDOWELL: There we go.

TAMMERO: Oh my god.

MCDOWELL: That's not all of it. I'm just going to sit here (INAUDIBLE) --

TAMMERO: Over and over again. Look, this formula has been really successful for Disney: Bringing these animated movies to live-action movies. A lot of -- how is this going to look? This broke yesterday. People are going nuts. I was driving home watching it from mother-in-law and I said, oh my god, this look so good. And my husband was like, enough with "The Lion King."

MCDOWELL: No, no, no.

TAMMERO: We've seen the Broadway show ten times, the movie, but guess what? Guess who was watching it last night and all of a sudden oh my god, this looks incredible. I'm like, see?

MCDOWELL: You caught your husband when you were in the other room watching the trailer on his phone.

TAMMERO: Sold. He is sold, Jon Favreau is directing, Beyonce plays Nala, Donald Glover is in this -- Darth Vader, I can't think of his name -- James Earl Jones is in this as well plays Mufasa.

MCDOWELL: I actually -- because I'm such a nerd as Adam Driver but it wasn't Adam Driver. But it's -- the James Earl Jones does the voiceover for the film.

TAMMERO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: What is it about? Is it this movie? I know that they've really brought back some iconic Disney films through this new live-action technology but there's something about "The Lion King:" It's the music and it's the story and the fact that it had life as an animated film and then as a Broadway show -- which so many people have seen.

TAMMERO: It's a great story and the music is fantastic. This is going to have a whole remade score from Hans Zimmer, that we'd get to look forward to. And it's also -- it's the way they do these movies now; it's so incredible. When you think about the motion capture and the CGI tech -- watching this last night, I kept thinking: Wow, animation is no longer the only execution to create a world; now it's just going to be a style of execution. When you can do things like this, you really don't need to know the animation, this looks real.

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE), from "Swingers." What an incredible -- but what an amazing career as a director when a lot of people just thought he would just be an actor.

TAMMERO: He's responsible for Disney's "The Jungle Book" which made hundreds of dollars last year at the box office. I cannot wait.

MCDOWELL: It looks --

TAMMERO: 2019 cannot come soon enough.

MCDOWELL: But now, Jon Favreau, you have to deliver. It has to be as good as the trailer. It better be better than the trailer. Happy Thanksgiving. Loved your whole family; loved your husband, Michael Tammero.

TAMMERO: Happy Thanksgiving. Good to see you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, everybody, still ahead, it's the busiest shopping day of the year and we're just getting started, the best Black Friday deals more on the markets next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, November 23rd.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TV0-DSC1-DY0W-454X-00000-00Stocks Poised To Open Lower In Black Friday Trade, Notch Weekly Loss of More than Three Percent; 'I Made a Tremendous Difference': Trump Heaps Thanksgiving Praise On Himself; Amazon Workers Strike; Black Friday Shopping; Fast Food Restaurants Hosting Hiring Parties; German Execs Invited To W.H.; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Vs. Mickelson Today; Live Action Lion King2018-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks Poised To Open Lower In Black Friday Trade, Notch Weekly Loss of More than Three Percent; 'I Made a Tremendous Difference': Trump Heaps Thanksgiving Praise On Himself; Amazon Workers Strike; Black Friday Shopping; Fast Food Restaurants Hosting Hiring Parties; German Execs Invited To W.H.; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Vs. Mickelson Today; Live Action Lion KingLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ANNOUNCER: It's the busiest shopping day of the year. Welcome to a special Black Friday edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, November 23th, your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern, time to go shopping. It's Black Friday more than 164 million people are expected to shop this weekend. Online sales are set to hit records. We'll keep an eye on retailers this morning like Amazon, Overstock, Macy's, these stocks have all been very hard hit, most of the retailers so far this month, can they turn around?

Amazon hit by a worker's strike in Germany and Spain today. Futures are showing this and the market action this morning. The losses across the board. The Dow futures are down 84 points. And, again, this is so far we're trying to turn around what has been a really, really awful week. We have losses of more than three percent at almost four percent loss on the NASDAQ Composite so far this week. In Europe, we have England, France, and Germany trading wide-open.

A slight loss on the Footsie 100 in England. Gains in France and Germany. The Asian markets closing lower overnight. The Nikkei was closed altogether. It never opened, but we have losses on the other three major markets there. The price of crude oil slipping this morning. We have oil prices now at the lowest level since late 2017 on abundance of supply. We break out what is going on. Telecom trouble, the U.S. warning that countries dealing with Chinese company Huawei Technologies ahead of this big meeting between President Trump and China's President Xi Jinping at the G20 Summit next week.

The concern is the use of Huawei Technology and potential infiltration on the U.S. military bases abroad. And then on to the border battle, President Trump threatening to shut down the entire Mexican border if immigration becomes uncontrollable. This is a group breaks off from the migrant caravan just 500 feet away from the U.S. border. The Trump administration reportedly wants to meet the heads of Volkswagen, BMW, and Daimler to discuss trade policy.

Reuters says that the invitation is to meet with Economic Advisor Larry Kudlow Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. Then the thriller on the green, Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson teeing off today in a special pay-per-view match in Las Vegas. Nine million dollars at stake. We have details. And Lion King goes live action. We can just listen to that all morning long. The trailer for the Lion King movie making its debut online and more of the amazing video coming up.

Here to break it all down this morning, Fox Business Network's Susan Li, Chief Market Strategist at Third Seven Advisors, Michael Block, and Republican strategist, former Trump surrogate, former Republican Convention Deputy Press Secretary Erin Elmore. Erin, I'm going to get to the president's tweet. I don't feel like I've talked to you enough this morning. So the president just tweeted and I'm going to get your reaction really quickly. Here's what the president says, really good criminal justice reform has a true shot at major bipartisan support.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer have a real chance to do something so badly needed in our country. Already passed with the big boat and House would be a major victory for all. He's seriously focused regardless of the Democrats' win in the House. He's seriously focused on getting things done.

ERIN ELMORE, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Right, because it's been so divisive. Right now, it's Republicans vote one way and Democrats vote another way, and there's really no sort of civility anymore. And I think he's really wants to get things accomplished in a bipartisan fashion because we haven't seen that in the last two years and I also think he's looking forward to 2020.

MCDOWELL: Well, I don't -- I will argue that the president based on just the language that he enjoys using sometimes. It's not about civility. It's about results. But it's not -- it's not about getting along in terms of not calling each other names. It's actually passing things that benefit all America.

ELMORE: Absolutely, because he has the best interests of the American people at heart whereas some these people in the Senate -- in the House that are so worried about their reelects and their elections and just sort of banging their fists on principle aren't so focused on those goals.

MCDOWELL: So instead of investigations in the House maybe we get actual things getting done and he's talking about the Senate, but --

(CROSSTALK)

ELMORE: Well, I think, you know, focusing on the Hillary Clinton stuff and dredging all that up again. Let's be more like the markets. Let's be forward looking, right? So I think that's what should be the big focus here Hillary Clinton stuff, it's old news and I think we have to move on from all of it.

MCDOWELL: Well, maybe she's going to run again.

ELMORE: I mean that would be -- that would be Christmas come early for the Republicans.

MCDOWELL: What a day. So we'll move on this Black Friday full swing -- in full swing. Shoppers scored deals ahead of the holidays. Hillary Vaughn is live from Garden City, New York with the very latest. Good morning, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Dagen. Well, the Apple store just opened up. That's the big news here. There was a line all the way down this hallway. They opened up. Now, a lot of people looking to get good deals on new Apple products. But Apple is one of the stores where they're kind of offering a bonus gift card with any purchase - - some of the purchases for some of their new gear. Not necessarily discounting their prices.

But we have other long lines here. You have lines out the door for jewelry stores. I talked to a lot of these shoppers in line. They're looking to get some gifts for their mom, their sisters. Some guys in line looking to get gifts for their daughter or girlfriend. This is a store that's been pretty steady. A lot of people stacked up in line. We've seen a lot of young shoppers today. A lot of high schoolers out with their friends looking to cash in on the good deals and get those gifts, a lot of millennial shoppers.

So, you know, all this talk of people hopping on their phones staying at home doing everything online, well, we've seen young shoppers actually get into the holiday spirit. They like the idea of going out with their friends grabbing coffee early in the morning and coming here, and making a day of it. So a lot of hustle and bustle here people cashing in getting into holiday spirit, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Hillary, thank you for that. Hillary Vaughn for us at -- on Long Island. President Trump touting his administration's economic successes yesterday as the United States kicks off its annual holiday shopping season. The commander-in-chief commenting on what he's thankful for.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What are you most thankful for Mr. President?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: For having a great family and for having made a tremendous difference in this country. I've made a tremendous difference in the country. This country is so much stronger now than it was when I took office that you wouldn't believe it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Here now fashion and retailer trend analyst Charcy Evers. Charcy, your take on the holiday shopping season kicking off so far? What should we be watching?

CHARCY EVERS, FASHION AND RETAIL TREND ANALYST: We are all about experience at retail right now and that's what's drawing people into the stores. I keep saying that Black Friday is back and that's what customers are coming in for the experience and we're seeing that across, you know, all the big box stores as well as smaller retailers --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: What kind of experience other than just the elbows and showing from the crowds because you're talking about things that the retailers have really planned to really push and to get people -- get -- to produce foot traffic?

EVERS: Right, exactly. And it's part of much larger shift in retail in general this idea of creating experience centers in touch points because we all know that we can all buy everything online. So what's going to give me a reason to come into a store? Target for example has over 25,000 hours of retail experience planned throughout the holiday season. They have hours of play for kids really kind of taking advantage of the hole in the market that Toys"R"Us left inviting children in and having play dates with them and actually letting them use toys before you're even buying them.

So it's really creating a way to get them into the stores. Wal-Mart the same thing. They're having actual play dates with children really inviting them in. They've also created a digital playground online where you can use your tablet or your computer to try the toys out before, so that's just one the ways that these retailers are having people, you know, getting them into the store and making it like enjoyable.

MCDOWELL: Because it's hard to get consumers in the store especially if you can shop online and that's why it's hard to compete also with Amazon's discount. You really have to slice a lot of your pricing, right?

EVERS: Right. And I think we all know that, you know, to -- the holidays is a perfect time to kind of come up with a new experiential strategy as a retailer because it's, you know, we -- the idea of Black Friday or the holidays in general is like let's go and sit on Santa's lap and take a picture. That's always kind of, you know, it's bringing back that nostalgia of going in and creating tradition and Black Friday for many families is a tradition of going shopping --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: What about pricing though?

ELMORE: I mean (INAUDIBLE) get competitive when you have to give door busters and you basically cut your prices to extraordinary levels.

EVERS: I think that retailers are really trying to take -- get away from that stigma that Black Friday has of like people fighting over T.V.'s at the door and making it more of a kind of feel good family experience. There's always -- we know we're going to get the best prices online. We know that the deals are out there. But it's kind of, again, as I said, it's part of this larger shift in retail in general of creating an experience in the holidays really lend itself well to that --

(CROSSTALK)

ELMORE: -- this holiday season?

EVERS: Target for sure. I know their earnings will let you know was not a good Tuesday for them. But, you know, they've really put -- they've reinvested in their company. They put money back into the stores and really, you know, built-up their e-commerce business. So I think we will be surprised to see them. I think they'll have a good holiday season.

MCDOWELL: It might --

(CROSSTALK)

MICHAEL BLOCK, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: So, Charcy, you talked about Kohl's, and Target, and Kohl's, you talked about investing more in their business perhaps some more in these experiences, what about the mall operators? They've been under a lot of fire as, you know --

(CROSSTALK)

BLOCK: -- retail investment in kinds of places, is there any talk amongst the mall operators about how to provide more experiences?

EVERS: Oh, absolutely. I think that that's why, you know, we were talking a lot -- we talked a lot about retailer apocalypse and I always say it's actually retail renaissance. It's a much needed renaissance and rebirth of retail and it has caused the mall developers to really look at how they're using their space, right? So Roosevelt Mall for example has an area where shops are just pop-ups. So rather than going into these long-term leases which are really difficult for retailers to sustain, you know, and it's a risk in having overhead inventory.

Having pop-ups gives me a reason like I know when in one a month, it's going to be a different store there, so I'm going to go back into the mall and I'm going to go check out what's new with the pop-ups. So it's a little bit of novelty. There's also, you know, Westfield does a great job of incorporating experience in terms with theater, with entertainment, with restaurants, you know, they will become more experiential hubs.

And going back to Wal-Mart, they've really create -- they're doing new things with their stores and creating what they call town centers. And, actually, using the space around them, you know, the parking lots, the empty stores around them and creating these experiential centers that are really drawing consumers in, so --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: And don't -- because, again, I feel like some retail success stories get lumped in with the mall problems which had been going clearly 30 years in this country because I keep bringing this up, but Aerie which is a division of American Eagle was -- if you watched Aerie, that store literally -- it pulled you in you as a --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- shopper that they have such great inexpensive like lounge wear. If you were watching Aerie versus Victoria's Secret, you would know even two years ago that Victoria's Secret was in trouble and that Aerie was on the rise.

EVERS: Oh, yes. I talked a lot about that. Don't get me started Victoria's Secret. I think that --

(CROSSTALK)

EVERS: -- they missed out on the roller trend, you know, and they're also --

(CROSSTALK)

EVERS: -- very early and they did it and they did it well, and Victoria's Secret just needs, you know, come with the top -- like lived up in the times, you know, they didn't shift when the consumer shifted. We're with at leisure out there and more athletic apparel and stuff. The bras don't need to be under wired. We're not into push-up bras. MCDOWELL: Take a look at futures today. We've got a market that's down three percent or more so far this week. There -- Monday and Tuesday being horrible days in the stock market.

Moving on to the border showdown, President Trump threatening to shut down the United States border with Mexico if things cannot get under control.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If we find that it's -- it gets to a level where we are going to lose control, or where people are going to start getting hurt, we will close entry into the country for a period of time until we can get it under control.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You mean entire border of the country?

TRUMP: The whole border. I mean the whole border.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This coming after reports that a small group separated from the major migrant caravan within 500 feet of the U.S. border yesterday.

Joining us now, "Weekly Standard" Deputy Editor Kelly Jane Torrance. What do you make of what the President was talking about there?

KELLY JANE TORRANCE, DEPUTY EDITOR, WEEKLY STANDARD: Yes. You know, it's really coming to a showdown, isn't it, Dagen? And I have mixed feelings.

I mean you don't want to close the border to people who do have real problems and who are seeking asylum, but at the same time, a lot of these people are coming specifically for a showdown.

And, you know, the President says talking about closing down border, but what he's not mentioning is actually the government knows about the caravan and has been preparing for it for months now.

And what's interesting is the administration is actually implementing what they call a Remain in Mexico plan, which is if you can show that you have worries for your life, you need to get out of Mexico, you will be let into the United States while your asylum claim is being processed.

But if you can't, you're going to actually wait in Mexico while that claim is being processed.

And, you know, President Trump has been complaining for a while about the, you know, what he calls the, you know, detainee program now, and complaining about people being released.

Well, if they're going to have to wait in Mexico, it might actually stop some people from coming to United States who think, "Well, I can get here, I can get to the United States. And once they let me go, I can do what I want."

So there's a lot going on here that the President isn't talking about that's going on behind the scenes.

MCDOWELL: Erin.

ELMORE: Yes. Hi, Kelly. Erin Elmore here. Good morning. We know that immigration is a huge issue for the Trump voter and the Trump base.

TORRANCE: Yes.

ELMORE: What do you think the right play is here? We know 9th Circuit is trying to control the situation, but what do you think the right play is? What do you tell the President to do?

TORRANCE: Yes, and, you know what, everyone's complaining about Donald Trump talking about the politicized core, but let's face it, you had --

Okay, so this is not the 9th Circuit, but it's the district court that things go to the 9th Circuit. The District Court of Northern California complained that the President cannot make immigration law and it stopped, you know, his recent laws.

But let's face it, that same court actually thought that it was okay for Obama, President Obama to make immigration law with DACA, with the, you know, the DREAM Act.

And so then it was like, "Oh, it's okay for the president to say --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

TORRANCE: -- that we're going to have this DREAM Act in young people who are here. They had no problem with the President making immigration law then they have a problem with Donald Trump doing it.

So I mean, you know, you don't want to criticize courts too much, you want to let them do their job, but I think in this case, Donald Trump actually has a point.

And you say, you know, look at and it's like, "Well, hey, we're -- Donald Trump can't make immigration law but Barack Obama can." He has a good point there.

ELMORE: So he's not relying on his own precedent, is what you're saying basically. And that's -- the beauty of courts is that their precedent shows you what they're going to likely do in the future.

And in this case, they're not relying on their own precedent and it is politics.

TORRANCE: Exactly. I mean I agree with the court, actually, that it's Congress who should be making immigration law.

But we -- of course we know that Congress has been trying since the George W. Bush years to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill and it's not going to happen.

Let's face it, it's just never going to happen and that's why presidents have been using executive orders to do things that they want and, yes.

MCDOWELL: What -- well, I want to point out that one very well-known Democrat, Hillary Clinton, weighed in on immigration.

TORRANCE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: The Former Presidential candidate urging Europe to get a handle on the migrant crisis there.

This is in an interview with "The Guardian."

Hillary Clinton said this, "I admire the very generous and compassionate approaches that were taken particularly by leaders like German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, but I think it is fair to say Europe has done its part and must send a very clear message."

"We're not going to be able to continue to provide refuge and support because we don't deal with the immigration issue. We'll continue to roil the body politic."

Your reaction to that. Again, it's -- she's talking about Europe, but why not the United States?

TORRANCE: Well -- and, of course, one of the reasons that Europe has this crisis is because Angela Merkel actually welcomed migrants to come to Germany.

People forget that the reason that you have this migrant crisis, one of the reasons, is that Angela Merkel said, "Hey, you guys need asylum? Come here."

And, of course, people listen. But let's face it, why do we -- why does Europe have that migrant crisis? It's because of the war in Syria.

And, you know, honestly, if we got rid of the terrible regime in Iran, that's propping up Bashar al-Assad and making it impossible to live in Syria, for regular Syrians who are facing, you know, terrible situations, they wouldn't be doing that.

So, yes, let's look at the root causes of why people are leaving and I think -- no, that's one of the things that Donald Trump is tried -- sort of said is like, hey, we need to look at what's happening in Central America and maybe help people at the source, so they don't feel they need to leave.

MCDOWELL: She -- Hillary Clinton did say that you need to handle the immigration crisis if you want to stop the rise of right wing populist, in the region. But I'll point out.

Remember the mass sexual assaults in Cologne, Germany that were virtually not covered by the news media, here in the United States? In large part, because of this immigration crisis that Hillary Clinton is talking about and I think that was two years ago, maybe, just to point that out.

TORRANCE: It's not even just it wasn't covered here, it was actually not covered in Germany so much, because police in Cologne actually wouldn't -- didn't want people to know about what was happening because they didn't want people angry at the government that -- you know, welcome those people to come.

MCDOWELL: Thank you Kelly Jane, Kelly Jane Torrance, this morning, Happy Thanksgiving.

TORRANCE: Happy Thanksgiving.

Amazon , Google parent Alphabet , Apple and Facebook reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings Thursday. Five pros break down the company earnings and why they don't see the gains ending anytime soon. Howard Ward, CIO of growth equities at GAMCO, ap... Amazon , Google parent Alphabet , Apple and Facebook reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings Thursday. Five pros break...

Amazon , Google parent Alphabet , Apple and Facebook reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings Thursday. Five pros break down the company earnings and why they don't see the gains ending anytime soon. Howard Ward, CIO of growth equities at GAMCO, ap...

Amazon , Google parent Alphabet , Apple and Facebook reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings Thursday. Five pros break down the company earnings and why they don't see the gains ending anytime soon. Howard Ward, CIO of growth equities at GAMCO, applauds Amazon for its long-term focus. "When you look at Amazon in particular, Amazon is a stock that people that use valuation as a reason not to own Amazon ever since it went public, and that didn't work out very well. It worked out very well for Jeff Bezos , on the other hand, to become the richest person in the world using a management philosophy of forgoing short-term profits. I think that has turned out very well for him, and I think there's a lesson in there not only for other companies and their approach to managing their businesses, but it's a lesson for investors as well, because investors that took that long-term ride with Jeff Bezos have done very well." Alan Patricof, founder of Greycroft, sees the threat of regulation lingering over these companies. "I think it's inevitable that there's going to be more deep observation of all these companies, and everybody's going to face up to the fact that they are basically utilities. You can't survive today really without Facebook, you can't survive without Google. Google represents 90% of the searches. Think about that. No matter what you do, if you're sitting there, you want to find some information, you have to go with Google ... Anything that people are so dependent on is something that becomes a utility, a public utility, which means something has to be done to make sure that our public utility doesn't take advantage of the public in one way or another. That, to me, it's inevitable there's going to be some regulation." Ann Winblad, managing partner at Hummer Winblad Venture Partners, says these reports highlighted how tech is evolving to meet the challenges of the pandemic. "I'm surprised how well Facebook actually did in their advertising revenue. I had high expectations of cloud revenue for the enterprise for Amazon and Google, and Google is making great progress on cloud revenue. Apple was stunning. All of these companies, first of all, demonstrated that ... they can operate in extraordinary circumstances. For all companies operating long term, this way is going to be really challenging — to maintain talent, to maintain innovation." Mark Mahaney, lead internet analyst at RBC, sees promise in Facebook's report. "I think Facebook showed that its ad model currently is more resilient than Google's. There are two interesting numbers that came out of the Facebook print — one is that they disclosed that they now have 9 million advertisers; their last disclosure was 8 million. And the second one is that they've disclosed that their top 100 advertisers accounted for only 16% of their total revenue; last time they disclosed that it was 20%. So they are diversifying their advertiser base and they're dramatically increasing it." Jim Cramer , host of CNBC's " Mad Money ," is in awe of Amazon's results. "Every conference call last night, with the exception of Google, was incredible. The power of these companies is extraordinary ... Brian Olsavsky, he's the CFO of Amazon, when he talks about the idea that basically, 'We didn't know we were going to make billions of dollars more than we did — not tens of millions, not hundreds of millions — billions.' What a juggernaut, the most impressive of last night." Disclaimer

urn:contentItem:5FVC-C9P1-JBVR-3200-00000-00Stocks rise on big tech earnings; Nasdaq composite adds to record;Stocks rise on tech earnings; Nasdaq adds to record2015-04-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisBUSINESSStocks rise on big tech earnings; Nasdaq composite adds to recordStocks rise on tech earnings; Nasdaq adds to recordKen SweetThe Associated Press

NEW YORK - Stock indexes edged higher Friday, helped by gains in big technology companies including Google, Amazon and Microsoft.

KEEPING SCORE: The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose five points, or 0.3 per cent, to 2,118 as of 2:20 p.m. Eastern. The Nasdaq composite added 37 points, or 0.7 per cent, to 5,093 and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 22 points, or 0.1 per cent, at 18,082.

BIG GAINS IN BIG TECH: Microsoft, Amazon and Google all rose sharply after the releasing their quarterly results. Amazon jumped $56.66, or 15 per cent, to $446.55. While the company reported a quarterly loss, investors were encouraged the growth in some of Amazon's other businesses, including Amazon's cloud computing division.

Microsoft rose $4.12, or 10 per cent, to $47.48. The software giant had results that beat expectations, and like Amazon, showed promising growth in new businesses like cloud computing. Google rose $17.72, or 3 per cent, to $564.72. The search and advertising company missed analysts' expectations; the company had strong growth in mobile advertising.

PIVOTING: Investors have been looking for Google, Microsoft and Amazon to show promise outside their bread-and-butter businesses. Microsoft cannot solely rely on PC sales to drive its profits, Amazon has very low profit margins on the products it sells and Google is heavily exposed to desktop computer advertising while the world is shifting to mobile.

"I think we are starting to see actual evidence that their strategies are working, especially at Microsoft and Amazon," said Dan Morgan, a portfolio manager at Synovus Trust Company, who owns shares of all three companies.

GREECE: A meeting between Greece and its creditors ended without a deal. A top official said "significant" progress is still needed. The lack of a deal keeps uncertainty over Greece, which is forecast to have enough money only for another few weeks.

WALK AWAY: Time Warner Cable and Comcast rose after the companies called off their $45 billion merger following pressure from regulators. Comcast rose 61 cents to $59.85 and Time Warner Cable rose $7.71, or 5 per cent, to $156.49.

Shares of Time Warner Cable rose after The Wall Street Journal reported that Charter Communications, another cable company, was looking at making a bid for Time Warner Cable now that Comcast pulled out. Charter was up $1.16, or 1 per cent, to $184.48.

NASDAQ RECORD: On Thursday the Nasdaq composite rose to 5,056.06 points, beating the record of 5,048.62 it set on March 10, 2000 at the height of the dot-com boom.

ENERGY: Benchmark U.S. crude oil fell 59 cents to close at $57.15 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

CURRENCIES, BONDS: The dollar fell to 118.89 yen from 119.62 yen. The euro was little changed at $1.0865. U.S. government bond prices rose. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell to 1.92 per cent from 1.96 per cent late Thursday.

METALS: Gold fell $19.30 to $1,175 an ounce, silver fell 19 cents to $15.64 an ounce and copper rose five cents to $2.75 a pound.

NEW YORK — Stock indexes edged higher in late-afternoon trading Friday, helped by gains in big technology companies including Google, Amazon and Microsoft.

KEEPING SCORE: The Standard & Poor’s 500 index rose four points, or 0.2 percent, to 2,117 as of 3:20 p.m. Eastern. The Nasdaq composite added 35 points, or 0.7 percent, to 5,091 and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 11 points, or 0.1 percent, at 18,070.

BIG GAINS IN BIG TECH: Microsoft, Amazon and Google all rose sharply after the releasing their quarterly results. Amazon jumped $56.32, or 14 percent, to $446.33. While the company reported a quarterly loss, investors were encouraged the growth in some of Amazon’s other businesses, including Amazon’s cloud computing division.

Microsoft rose $4.41, or 10 percent, to $47.75. The software giant had results that beat expectations, and like Amazon, showed promising growth in new businesses like cloud computing. Google rose $17.98, or 3 percent, to $564.95. The search and advertising company missed analysts’ expectations; the company had strong growth in mobile advertising.

PIVOTING: Investors have been looking for Google, Microsoft and Amazon to show promise outside their bread-and-butter businesses. Microsoft cannot solely rely on PC sales to drive its profits, Amazon has very low profit margins on the products it sells and Google is heavily exposed to desktop computer advertising while the world is shifting to mobile.

“I think we are starting to see actual evidence that their strategies are working, especially at Microsoft and Amazon,” said Dan Morgan, a portfolio manager at Synovus Trust Company, who owns shares of all three companies.

GREECE: A meeting between Greece and its creditors ended without a deal. A top official said “significant” progress is still needed. The lack of a deal keeps uncertainty over Greece, which is forecast to have enough money only for another few weeks.

WALK AWAY: Time Warner Cable and Comcast rose after the companies called off their $45 billion merger following pressure from regulators. Comcast rose 35 cents to $59.59 and Time Warner Cable rose $7.57, or 5 percent, to $156.32.

Shares of Time Warner Cable rose after The Wall Street Journal reported that Charter Communications, another cable company, was looking at making a bid for Time Warner Cable now that Comcast pulled out. Charter was up 84 cents, or 0.5 percent, to $184.27.

NASDAQ RECORD: On Thursday the Nasdaq composite rose to 5,056.06 points, beating the record of 5,048.62 it set on March 10, 2000 at the height of the dot-com boom.

ENERGY: Benchmark U.S. crude oil fell 59 cents to close at $57.15 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Brent crude rose 43 cents to close at $65.28 a barrel in London.

CURRENCIES, BONDS: The dollar fell to 118.89 yen from 119.62 yen. The euro was little changed at $1.0865. U.S. government bond prices rose. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell to 1.92 percent from 1.96 percent late Thursday.

METALS: Gold fell $19.30 to $1,175 an ounce, silver fell 19 cents to $15.64 an ounce and copper rose five cents to $2.75 a pound.

urn:contentItem:5WF7-BYG1-DY0W-43PN-00000-00Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep 2-Day Selloff; Alabama Mall Shooting Leaves Two Injured, Gunman Dead; Border Shutdown; Hillary Clinton Weighs In On European Migrant Crisis; Holiday Shopping is in Full Swing Today; Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep Two-Day Selloff; Virgin Atlantic Launches Surprise Bid To Buy Flybe; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Versus Mickelson Today; 'Ralph Breaks The Internet' Rumbles Into Theaters; 'Creed 2' Expected To Take In $45M It's Opening Weekend; Live Action 'Lion King'2018-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks See a Bounce Back After Steep 2-Day Selloff; Alabama Mall Shooting Leaves Two Injured, Gunman Dead; Border Shutdown; Hillary Clinton Weighs In On European Migrant Crisis; Holiday Shopping is in Full Swing Today; Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep Two-Day Selloff; Virgin Atlantic Launches Surprise Bid To Buy Flybe; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Versus Mickelson Today; 'Ralph Breaks The Internet' Rumbles Into Theaters; 'Creed 2' Expected To Take In $45M It's Opening Weekend; Live Action 'Lion King'LanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, November 23rd.

Get ready for shopping, and your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern. That frenzy already underway. It is Black Friday. Shoppers have already started to hit the stores in person and online.

When the dust settles, online sale set to hit a record level. We'll keep an eye on retailers this morning like -- Amazon will see if some holiday shopping can put -- turn that stock around. It's down in premarket trading so far.

The futures are showing this in market action. Loses across the board, in fact. The Dow Futures are down 132 points in what has been a rough week so far the -- for the markets.

This is end of the week that's seen all three major market gauges down. You can take a look at this. This is 11/19 close as a rough, rough time for stocks.

In Europe let's take look at trading in England, France, and Germany, some mixed market action there, but just slight losses and gains of those three, the FTSE-100 down ever so slightly.

The Asia markets closing lower overnight. The Nikkei was not trading for the day. The Shanghai shedding two and a half percent.

The price of crude oil slipping this morning. Oil prices now at their lowest level since late 2017 on an abundance of supply. A five percent lose on the cost of crude as we speak.

And telecom trouble, the U.S. warning countries about dealing with Chinese company Huawei Technologies. This, ahead of the big meeting between President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 Summit next week.

Mortar battle. President Trump threatening to shut down the entire Mexican border if immigration becomes uncontrollable.

This is a group breaks off from the migrant caravan just 500 feet away from the U.S. border.

Been the thriller on the green. Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson teeing off today in a special pay-per-view match in Las Vegas with more than nine million dollars at stake. We have the details.

And Lion King goes live action. The trailer for the new Lion King movie making its debut online, more of this incredible video coming up. I've already watched it about 10 times so far.

That was how I spent my Thanksgiving.

All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox Business Network's Susan Li, Chief Market Strategist at Third Seven Advisors, Michael Block, and Republican Strategist, Former Trump Surrogate, Former -- and Former Republican Convention Deputy Press Secretary, Erin Elmore.

Great to see you one and all. Hope you had a lovely --

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Black Friday.

MCDOWELL: I know. I hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, but we're back to business.

LI: Yes, we are.

ERIN ELMORE, FORMER REPUBLICAN CONVENTION DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And some of these retailers were open yesterday.

LI: Well, you can get your deals online already yesterday. I know. I was sifting through all -- full transparency here, but it's going to be a blowout shopping season.

A trillion dollars for the first time should be spent.

MCDOWELL: And the question is, can that turn the market around?

Two words. You get two words, yes or no? May be. May be's two words.

MICHAEL BLOCK, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: Sneaking up.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Michael. We're going to get -- dig into all of this as the morning wears on.

Retail, the Super Bowl was officially here. Black Friday shoppers braving the cold, gearing up for major deals.

Hillary Vaughn is live in Garden City, New York, where shoppers are scoring some bargains. Hey, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Dagen. Well, one to know, this mall was open all of Thanksgiving until about 2:00 a.m., and then they closed for a few hours, and now they're opening their doors again to daytime Black Friday shoppers.

We're seeing this happen all over the country where retailers are not only rolling out early deals online, but also in stores and malls opening up on Thanksgiving Day.

So, people really don't have to wait late at night outside in the cold for the mall to open before they're able to cash in on really good deals.

So, we've a lot of people starting to trickle in and walk around. Some of them already have bags of things that they bought.

So, we're looking at some early sales data. The mall here says that they saw -- basically are expecting to at least have the same turnout in sales that they had last year at this time, the same number of people, and possibly purchase or even beat those estimates.
