LI: We actually had Facebook, admitting, going into the holiday, later on Wednesday, that they did hire definers. That was -- they did that on purpose, so that we would miss the headlines on Thursday. But, they admitted to hiring definers, Sheryl Sandberg admitted to actually knowing that they hired this opposition research team.

So, what about Facebook, in particular? What about the reputational risk, regulatory risk priced in?

PAYNE: I (INAUDIBLE) priced in. We had a lot of panic already. And anecdotally, I work the retail investor. And invariably, the retail investor is always wrong. So, when they start to panic -- you know, I think, when they start to panic, you're starting to see some panic in here, that's actually very bullish for the markets.

You didn't see that before and we had a big selloff in the end of October, and we kind of hit those lows again, this past week. No, no one's really panicking, that always concerned me, but now you're starting to see a little bit of panic in there, which makes me think we're probably even closer to some kind of bottom in here.

MCDOWELL: You know what -- you know what, I think our viewers, based on their comments on Twitter, are quite smart about the markets, when what's part -- a part of what's causing this downdraft, it's the smart money. It's the smart money getting put out of business because they have been so wrong. Talk about that.

BLOCK: Yes. Well, what's been going on, is Q3 was hard for one, the hedge funds, they've got whipsawed by a lot these, moves higher in the big tech stocks, and then, right when they -- right when they bought into that, it traded down. It was a rough October, rough November.

There's a lot of blood out there. There's a lot of liquidation. I'm reading about somebody's energy focus funds. There's an energy fund that's down 15.7 percent, month to date, right now, and around, so there's a lot going on.

Your clients, you do have -- you know, you claim retail investors aren't smart, but you know, of course, yours are the smartest, and what are they saying? Like, are they excited about the market? Are they apprehensive? What's your biggest concern right now?

PAYNE: When was the retail investor not smart? But they tend to be very emotional, right? And that emotional Litmus test. Then, you know, we can argue, is the smart money really that smart? Hedge funds have not done that well in the last couple of years.

Just the fact they're selling, they might not -- they might be indicative of making a bad decision as opposed to good decision.

BLOCK: They're Mike Tyson-smart. They're geniuses until they get punched in the face.

MCDOWELL: Jonas Ferris used that very quote on Wednesday, by the way.

BLOCK: Great minds think alike.

MCDOWELL: So you were -- no, you were watching, is what --

BLOCK: Hi, Jonas.

MCDOWELL: No, I'm just kidding. Ryan Payne, good to see you.

PAYNE: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Thanks so much. Stay tuned. Our special Black Friday on Fox Business, we're here until 2:00 p.m. Eastern. And coming up, he's urging for transparency, former FBI Director James Comey, issuing -- issued a subpoena by the House Judiciary Committee, over the Hillary Clinton E-mail scandal.

Plus, showdown on the links, Phil Mickelson and Tiger Woods set to duke it out today, in Vegas, with a $9 million purse.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Weird song. Virgin Atlantic reportedly in talks to by Flybe. Cheryl Casone has more. Hey, Cheryl.

CASONE: That's weird. All right, here's the news: Sky News says the Britain's Virgin Atlantic is going to acquire regional airline, Flybe. This comes a week after Flybe announced in talks to sell itself. Virgin Atlantic owned by Richard Branson's Virgin Group and Delta Airlines. Flybe has got a market cap of about 27 million. Last month, Flybe has shared a proper warning, though; they said a weak demand and a weaker British Pounds. So, we'll see if Virgin Atlantic gets the deal.

Former FBI Director, James Comey says that Republicans have subpoenaed him to testify at a closed-door meeting of the House Judiciary Committee early next month. In a Thanksgiving Day tweet, Comey says, that he would be happy to answer the committee's questions but would resist doing it behind closed doors for that his testimony will be leaked and distorted. The subpoena part of a congressional inquiry into allegations of anti-Trump bias that led to the opening of the Russia investigation.

Well, the head-to-head matchup between two of the biggest names in golf takes place today. Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson is going to hit the links in Las Vegas, the much-hyped $9 million winner take all match. Organizers are hoping to recoup the money from fans willing to pay $19.99 for pay-per-view. Woods and Mickelson are also putting up their own cash and side bets that eventually, of course, is all going to charity. Teatime is set for 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time. Dagen, place your bet.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, a Disney classic reborn. The first trailer for the live-action "Lion King" wowing people; it basically broke the Internet yesterday. Coming up, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ralph, what is wrong you?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Start churning butter and put on your church shoes little sister because we're about to blast off.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ralph, what is it you're trying to say?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We're going to the Internet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: What?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That was a clip from the new animated film "Ralph Breaks the Internet"; the sequel to Disney's "Wreck It Ralph," it premiers on Wednesday. Joining me now: "IN THE FOX LIGHT" Host, Michael Tammero.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The microphone is off?

MCDOWELL: What is your take on "Ralph Breaks the Internet," is he going to break the box office?

MICHAEL TAMMERO, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST AND VICE PRESIDENT FOR MARKETING: It's going to break all sorts of records this weekend, looking probably about $100 million. You know, this is a big weekend for the box office every year; and so far, box office is up over 10 percent this year over last year, with an -- attendance is up which is even a bigger story right now. It's not just, you know, the fact that tickets are more expensive, but attendance is up about seven percent so far this year. And this weekend, looks to push those numbers even higher. The Ralph, critics are loving him and audiences are loving him as well and it about A- cinema score.

MCDOWELL: What else is opening this weekend or is in competition --

TAMMERO: We have "Creed 2," follow up to the big 2016 hit, Michael B. Jordan -- what a year this guy has had. He started the year with "Black Panther" which grossed over $700 million. "Creed 2" is getting also sorts of critical acclaim; and who knows it could push him to an Oscar coming down, an award season, you just never know with these things.

MCDOWELL: All right, so what broke yesterday, can we just watch it?

TAMMERO: Oh, my God, yes!

MCDOWELL: "The Lion King" live-action trailer, the very first one. Roll it. Do we have it?

TAMMERO: Or not?

MCDOWELL: There we go.

TAMMERO: Oh my god.

MCDOWELL: That's not all of it. I'm just going to sit here (INAUDIBLE) --

TAMMERO: Over and over again. Look, this formula has been really successful for Disney: Bringing these animated movies to live-action movies. A lot of -- how is this going to look? This broke yesterday. People are going nuts. I was driving home watching it from mother-in-law and I said, oh my god, this look so good. And my husband was like, enough with "The Lion King."

MCDOWELL: No, no, no.

TAMMERO: We've seen the Broadway show ten times, the movie, but guess what? Guess who was watching it last night and all of a sudden oh my god, this looks incredible. I'm like, see?

MCDOWELL: You caught your husband when you were in the other room watching the trailer on his phone.

TAMMERO: Sold. He is sold, Jon Favreau is directing, Beyonce plays Nala, Donald Glover is in this -- Darth Vader, I can't think of his name -- James Earl Jones is in this as well plays Mufasa.

MCDOWELL: I actually -- because I'm such a nerd as Adam Driver but it wasn't Adam Driver. But it's -- the James Earl Jones does the voiceover for the film.

TAMMERO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: What is it about? Is it this movie? I know that they've really brought back some iconic Disney films through this new live-action technology but there's something about "The Lion King:" It's the music and it's the story and the fact that it had life as an animated film and then as a Broadway show -- which so many people have seen.

TAMMERO: It's a great story and the music is fantastic. This is going to have a whole remade score from Hans Zimmer, that we'd get to look forward to. And it's also -- it's the way they do these movies now; it's so incredible. When you think about the motion capture and the CGI tech -- watching this last night, I kept thinking: Wow, animation is no longer the only execution to create a world; now it's just going to be a style of execution. When you can do things like this, you really don't need to know the animation, this looks real.

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE), from "Swingers." What an incredible -- but what an amazing career as a director when a lot of people just thought he would just be an actor.

TAMMERO: He's responsible for Disney's "The Jungle Book" which made hundreds of dollars last year at the box office. I cannot wait.

MCDOWELL: It looks --

TAMMERO: 2019 cannot come soon enough.

MCDOWELL: But now, Jon Favreau, you have to deliver. It has to be as good as the trailer. It better be better than the trailer. Happy Thanksgiving. Loved your whole family; loved your husband, Michael Tammero.

TAMMERO: Happy Thanksgiving. Good to see you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, everybody, still ahead, it's the busiest shopping day of the year and we're just getting started, the best Black Friday deals more on the markets next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, November 23rd.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TV0-DSC1-DY0W-454J-00000-00Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep 2-Day Selloff; Alabama Mall Shooting Leaves Two Injured, Gunman Dead; Border Shutdown; Hillary Clinton Weighs In On European Migrant Crisis; Holiday Shopping is in Full Swing Today; Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep Two-Day Selloff; Virgin Atlantic Launches Surprise Bid To Buy Flybe; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Versus Mickelson Today; 'Ralph Breaks The Internet' Rumbles Into Theaters; 'Creed 2' Expected To Take In $45M It's Opening Weekend; Live Action 'Lion King'2018-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks See a Bounce Back After Steep 2-Day Selloff; Alabama Mall Shooting Leaves Two Injured, Gunman Dead; Border Shutdown; Hillary Clinton Weighs In On European Migrant Crisis; Holiday Shopping is in Full Swing Today; Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep Two-Day Selloff; Virgin Atlantic Launches Surprise Bid To Buy Flybe; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Versus Mickelson Today; 'Ralph Breaks The Internet' Rumbles Into Theaters; 'Creed 2' Expected To Take In $45M It's Opening Weekend; Live Action 'Lion King'LanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, November 23rd.

Get ready for shopping, and your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern. That frenzy already underway. It is Black Friday. Shoppers have already started to hit the stores in person and online.

When the dust settles, online sale set to hit a record level. We'll keep an eye on retailers this morning like -- Amazon will see if some holiday shopping can put -- turn that stock around. It's down in premarket trading so far.

The futures are showing this in market action. Loses across the board, in fact. The Dow Futures are down 132 points in what has been a rough week so far the -- for the markets.

This is end of the week that's seen all three major market gauges down. You can take a look at this. This is 11/19 close as a rough, rough time for stocks.

In Europe let's take look at trading in England, France, and Germany, some mixed market action there, but just slight losses and gains of those three, the FTSE-100 down ever so slightly.

The Asia markets closing lower overnight. The Nikkei was not trading for the day. The Shanghai shedding two and a half percent.

The price of crude oil slipping this morning. Oil prices now at their lowest level since late 2017 on an abundance of supply. A five percent lose on the cost of crude as we speak.

And telecom trouble, the U.S. warning countries about dealing with Chinese company Huawei Technologies. This, ahead of the big meeting between President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 Summit next week.

Mortar battle. President Trump threatening to shut down the entire Mexican border if immigration becomes uncontrollable.

This is a group breaks off from the migrant caravan just 500 feet away from the U.S. border.

Been the thriller on the green. Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson teeing off today in a special pay-per-view match in Las Vegas with more than nine million dollars at stake. We have the details.

And Lion King goes live action. The trailer for the new Lion King movie making its debut online, more of this incredible video coming up. I've already watched it about 10 times so far.

That was how I spent my Thanksgiving.

All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox Business Network's Susan Li, Chief Market Strategist at Third Seven Advisors, Michael Block, and Republican Strategist, Former Trump Surrogate, Former -- and Former Republican Convention Deputy Press Secretary, Erin Elmore.

Great to see you one and all. Hope you had a lovely --

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Black Friday.

MCDOWELL: I know. I hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, but we're back to business.

LI: Yes, we are.

ERIN ELMORE, FORMER REPUBLICAN CONVENTION DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And some of these retailers were open yesterday.

LI: Well, you can get your deals online already yesterday. I know. I was sifting through all -- full transparency here, but it's going to be a blowout shopping season.

A trillion dollars for the first time should be spent.

MCDOWELL: And the question is, can that turn the market around?

Two words. You get two words, yes or no? May be. May be's two words.

MICHAEL BLOCK, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: Sneaking up.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Michael. We're going to get -- dig into all of this as the morning wears on.

Retail, the Super Bowl was officially here. Black Friday shoppers braving the cold, gearing up for major deals.

Hillary Vaughn is live in Garden City, New York, where shoppers are scoring some bargains. Hey, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Dagen. Well, one to know, this mall was open all of Thanksgiving until about 2:00 a.m., and then they closed for a few hours, and now they're opening their doors again to daytime Black Friday shoppers.

We're seeing this happen all over the country where retailers are not only rolling out early deals online, but also in stores and malls opening up on Thanksgiving Day.

So, people really don't have to wait late at night outside in the cold for the mall to open before they're able to cash in on really good deals.

So, we've a lot of people starting to trickle in and walk around. Some of them already have bags of things that they bought.

So, we're looking at some early sales data. The mall here says that they saw -- basically are expecting to at least have the same turnout in sales that they had last year at this time, the same number of people, and possibly purchase or even beat those estimates.

But some people are also, that have shopped online, are having trouble getting online. Walmart and Lululemon had some website access issues, which is concerning some shoppers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I like being able to see what it is that I'm buying versus having wait and see when it comes, like, in the mail. But --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And sometimes, I've had it crash, or have the websites just, like, there's so many people on at the same time.

So, to be able to still get the deals and not have to worry about if something sells out or crashes or whatever.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: And for the first time ever, half of those shoppers online were shopping on their phone, Dagen. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Hillary. We will check back in next hour.

Hillary Vaughn out on Long Island for us.

Staying on the Trump economy, President Trump touting his administration's economic success yesterday as this country kicks off its annual holiday shopping season.

The Commander-in0Chief commenting on what he is thankful for.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What are you most thankful for, Mr. President?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: For having a great family and for having made a tremendous difference in this country. I've made a tremendous difference in the country.

This country is so much stronger now than it was when I took office that you wouldn't believe it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now, Wall Street Global Economic Senator, Jon HILSENRATH. I'm thankful for myself.

JON HILSENRATH, CHIEF ECONOMICS CORRESPONDENT, WALL STREET JOURNAL: So I'm thankful for myself, yes.

MCDOWELL: Come on, we -- that's funny. That did make them laugh.

HILSENRATH: Did that make it around the table last night when you all said what you were thankful for?

MCDOWELL: I've got a great --

HILSENRATH: Thankful for what I've done for everybody around.

MCDOWELL: I'm going to grade myself. I give myself an A plus. Can I give myself a higher grade than that? Is that possible?

Jon, what do you make of the U.S. economy right now?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, we're seeing some signs that it -- it's slowing down a little bit. We had numbers earlier this week on investment durable goods orders.

And they were soft and it was a little troubling after a third quarter in which business investment numbers were kind of soft.

You all were talking earlier about retail sales. I mean we're in a moment right now where the consumer has so much power, with unemployment so low.

And the benefits of these tax cuts that this might be a quarter, the fourth quarter, where it's really the consumer driving thing more than anything else.

MCDOWELL: Is that enough to turn the markets around, though?

HILSENRATH: Well, you asked Michael yes or no question, I'm going to say no.

You know, it does look like the economy is slowing, it does look like earnings growth going into 2019 is slowing down.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HILSENRATH: So I think, you know, there's a lot this market has to be worried about right now.

BLOCK: So Jon, with all that, what is the fed thinking here? You know, you -- if you go back even a month, everyone was -- it was near certainty that they were going to raise rates again on -- in December.

You know, now we're looking at a scenario where suddenly we're starting to see blanks. We've talked about it on this program.

And the futures markets are starting to price in that this isn't a given anymore.

What is the fed thinking about right now? What's most important to them?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, the fed is thinking that it's going to go in December, so, you know, we had John Williams, New York Fed President, out speaking last week. Jay Powell has been out there talking in the last few weeks, and they haven't sent any signals that suggest they're wavering.

You know, when they see the market volatility like this, they say, "All right, that's part of the going back to normal in an economy. It's having a market that has ups and downs."

And so I think they're going to look through what -- the volatility we're seeing right now and go ahead and raise rates in December.

LI: I think they have to go in December at this point, because if you don't, it looks like you're kowtowing to the White House.

HILSENRATH: To the President.

LI: You're supposed to be an independent institution, right?

Four times that year, that's questionable to me. That's what Goldman Sachs is pricing in.

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean it's interesting because the President has really been on Jay Powell, the Fed Chairman, about raising rates.

And he's kind of put the fed into position where if it doesn't raise rates, which is what the President wants to happen, then it looks like the fed is getting political --

LI: Right.

HILSENRATH: -- and bending to the White House will. So it's counter -- you could argue that it's counterproductive, but I think from the fed's point of view, you have unemployment at a 50-year low.

Their model show that inflation should pick up when inflation gets this low. Powell isn't completely convinced of that, but we have seen inflation pick up. It's around two percent now.

So, I think they're going to go ahead in December and then see how things play out next year. The big question's what happens in 2019, and when they meet next month, the big question is going to be how the forecast change their forecast for 2019 come down.

But I wouldn't expect them to back away from a December move at this point.

MCDOWELL: Let's stay on the fed really quickly.

The President, though, is -- many people think he's right to talk about interest rates in the sense of that that is a concern that people are worried about, the Fed Reserve overdoing it.

We heard that from the economist, from the National Association of Retail - - excuse me, Realtors, existing home sales were up for the first time in six months thankfully, but they're worried about the -- about rising interest rates.

HILSENRATH: Well, we -- I mean it's interesting because the fed's been -- I'm sorry, the President has been talking about this for months.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: And just now the markets are starting to come around to his view that maybe the fed is being too aggressive.

And the other thing that's interesting about the President's comments is, you know, he's very vocal about his unhappiness with what Jerome Powell is doing.

But he really isn't interfering personally with what the fed has been up to. He hasn't talked to Powell since before he was nominated.

MCDOWELL: But this is --

HILSENRATH: So he's not -- you know, like we saw with LBJ back in the 1960s and President Nixon, they personally intervened with fed leaders and say -- and said, "Don't do this. Don't do this to me."

And with Powell -- I'm sorry, with the President, he's speaking publicly about it, but he isn't personally intervening with Jay Powell and telling him to stop.

MCDOWELL: Do you think anything changes with their balance sheet reduction that something that Greg Ip was writing about, about the removal of quantitative easing in Europe.

LI: That's quantitative tightening as well.

MCDOWELL: And -- well --

HILSENRATH: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- in Europe and Bank -- and the Bank of Japan and here in the United States.

HILSENRATH: Right. Well -- so the fed built up this four and half trillion dollar balance sheet. They bought all these treasury bonds, all these mortgage-backed securities, to try to hold down --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HILSENRATH: -- long-term interest rates and boost markets in the economy.

You know, they've been -- they've been at this for many months now, and they said they were going to do it more than a year ago.

It shouldn't be a surprise to markets. Markets are supposed to be forward- looking, and price in all of this activity.

LI: But why do they need to do -- couldn't they hold these bonds to maturity?

I mean, you don't necessarily have to un-want the balance sheet and sell off a bit --

MCDOWELL: Well, that's what they -- that's what the --

HILSENRATH: Well, they -- they're not -- they're not selling -- they're not selling any of the bonds.

MCDOWELL: You know, that's what they are doing now.

HILSENRATH: The --

MCDOWELL: Right? They're not actively selling.

HILSENRATH: They're allowing them -- they're allowing them -- when they mature, they're just allowing them to retire.

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

HILSENRATH: -- and they're not recycling them into new bonds.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: But the point I was trying to make is, like, the market should know this. This shouldn't be a surprise. So, the -- it shouldn't give be an on --

In theory, it shouldn't be an ongoing headwind to the market because it should have been priced in a long time ago.

MCDOWELL: But --

HILSENRATH: But a lot people would argue that it is because there's just all the supply coming out of that.

MCDOWELL: We're -- but we're assuming that investors are really smart.

HILSENRATH: Right. Yes, exactly.

MCDOWELL: And always make really good decisions looking ahead.

I want to talk about china.

HILSENRATH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: There's a lot of cover in this. But President Trump is expected to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping next week at the G20 Summit in Argentina.

The President sounding confident on his trade strategy ahead of the much anticipated meeting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I can say this China wants to make a deal very badly.

MCDOWELL: But now, Jon Favreau, you have to deliver. It has to be as good as the trailer. It better be better than the trailer. Happy Thanksgiving. Loved your whole family; loved your husband, Michael Tammero.

TAMMERO: Happy Thanksgiving. Good to see you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, everybody, still ahead, it's the busiest shopping day of the year and we're just getting started, the best Black Friday deals more on the markets next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, November 23rd.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TT6-8GR1-JB20-G4YM-00000-00Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep 2-Day Selloff; Alabama Mall Shooting Leaves Two Injured, Gunman Dead; Border Shutdown; Hillary Clinton Weighs In On European Migrant Crisis; Holiday Shopping is in Full Swing Today; Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep Two-Day Selloff; Virgin Atlantic Launches Surprise Bid To Buy Flybe; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Versus Mickelson Today; "Ralph Breaks The Internet" Rumbles Into Theaters; "Creed 2" Expected To Take In $45M It's Opening Weekend; Live Action "Lion King"2018-11-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:36ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTMichael Block, Erin Elmore, Jon Hilsenrath, Kelly Jane Torrance, Ryan PayneNEWSFinancial112301cb.231Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep 2-Day Selloff; Alabama Mall Shooting Leaves Two Injured, Gunman Dead; Border Shutdown; Hillary Clinton Weighs In On European Migrant Crisis; Holiday Shopping is in Full Swing Today; Stocks See a Bounce Back After Steep Two-Day Selloff; Virgin Atlantic Launches Surprise Bid To Buy Flybe; Comey Is Subpoenaed; Tiger Versus Mickelson Today; "Ralph Breaks The Internet" Rumbles Into Theaters; "Creed 2" Expected To Take In $45M It's Opening Weekend; Live Action "Lion King"Dagen McDowell, Susan Li, Cheryl Casone, Hillary Vaughn, Michael Tammero

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Friday, November 23rd.

Get ready for shopping, and your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern. That frenzy already underway. It is Black Friday. Shoppers have already started to hit the stores in person and online.

When the dust settles, online sale set to hit a record level. We'll keep an eye on retailers this morning like -- Amazon will see if some holiday shopping can put -- turn that stock around. It's down in premarket trading so far.

The futures are showing this in market action. Loses across the board, in fact. The Dow Futures are down 132 points in what has been a rough week so far the -- for the markets.

This is end of the week that's seen all three major market gauges down. You can take a look at this. This is 11/19 close as a rough, rough time for stocks.

In Europe let's take look at trading in England, France, and Germany, some mixed market action there, but just slight losses and gains of those three, the FTSE-100 down ever so slightly.

The Asia markets closing lower overnight. The Nikkei was not trading for the day. The Shanghai shedding two and a half percent.

The price of crude oil slipping this morning. Oil prices now at their lowest level since late 2017 on an abundance of supply. A five percent lose on the cost of crude as we speak.

And telecom trouble, the U.S. warning countries about dealing with Chinese company Huawei Technologies. This, ahead of the big meeting between President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 Summit next week.

Mortar battle. President Trump threatening to shut down the entire Mexican border if immigration becomes uncontrollable.

This is a group breaks off from the migrant caravan just 500 feet away from the U.S. border.

Been the thriller on the green. Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson teeing off today in a special pay-per-view match in Las Vegas with more than nine million dollars at stake. We have the details.

And Lion King goes live action. The trailer for the new Lion King movie making its debut online, more of this incredible video coming up. I've already watched it about 10 times so far.

That was how I spent my Thanksgiving.

All of that and so much more coming up this morning.

Fox Business Network's Susan Li, Chief Market Strategist at Third Seven Advisors, Michael Block, and Republican Strategist, Former Trump Surrogate, Former -- and Former Republican Convention Deputy Press Secretary, Erin Elmore.

Great to see you one and all. Hope you had a lovely --

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Black Friday.

MCDOWELL: I know. I hope you had a lovely Thanksgiving, but we're back to business.

LI: Yes, we are.

ERIN ELMORE, FORMER REPUBLICAN CONVENTION DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: And some of these retailers were open yesterday.

LI: Well, you can get your deals online already yesterday. I know. I was sifting through all -- full transparency here, but it's going to be a blowout shopping season.

A trillion dollars for the first time should be spent.

MCDOWELL: And the question is, can that turn the market around?

Two words. You get two words, yes or no? May be. May be's two words.

MICHAEL BLOCK, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: Sneaking up.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Michael. We're going to get -- dig into all of this as the morning wears on.

Retail, the Super Bowl was officially here. Black Friday shoppers braving the cold, gearing up for major deals.

Hillary Vaughn is live in Garden City, New York, where shoppers are scoring some bargains. Hey, Hillary.

HILLARY VAUGHN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Dagen. Well, one to know, this mall was open all of Thanksgiving until about 2:00 a.m., and then they closed for a few hours, and now they're opening their doors again to daytime Black Friday shoppers.

We're seeing this happen all over the country where retailers are not only rolling out early deals online, but also in stores and malls opening up on Thanksgiving Day.

So, people really don't have to wait late at night outside in the cold for the mall to open before they're able to cash in on really good deals.

So, we've a lot of people starting to trickle in and walk around. Some of them already have bags of things that they bought.

So, we're looking at some early sales data. The mall here says that they saw -- basically are expecting to at least have the same turnout in sales that they had last year at this time, the same number of people, and possibly purchase or even beat those estimates.

But some people are also, that have shopped online, are having trouble getting online. Walmart and Lululemon had some website access issues, which is concerning some shoppers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I like being able to see what it is that I'm buying versus having wait and see when it comes, like, in the mail. But --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And sometimes, I've had it crash, or have the websites just, like, there's so many people on at the same time.

So, to be able to still get the deals and not have to worry about if something sells out or crashes or whatever.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAUGHN: And for the first time ever, half of those shoppers online were shopping on their phone, Dagen. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you, Hillary. We will check back in next hour.

Hillary Vaughn out on Long Island for us.

Staying on the Trump economy, President Trump touting his administration's economic success yesterday as this country kicks off its annual holiday shopping season.

The Commander-in0Chief commenting on what he is thankful for.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What are you most thankful for, Mr. President?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: For having a great family and for having made a tremendous difference in this country. I've made a tremendous difference in the country.

This country is so much stronger now than it was when I took office that you wouldn't believe it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now, Wall Street Global Economic Senator, Jon HILSENRATH. I'm thankful for myself.

JON HILSENRATH, CHIEF ECONOMICS CORRESPONDENT, WALL STREET JOURNAL: So I'm thankful for myself, yes.

MCDOWELL: Come on, we -- that's funny. That did make them laugh.

HILSENRATH: Did that make it around the table last night when you all said what you were thankful for?

MCDOWELL: I've got a great --

HILSENRATH: Thankful for what I've done for everybody around.

MCDOWELL: I'm going to grade myself. I give myself an A plus. Can I give myself a higher grade than that? Is that possible?

Jon, what do you make of the U.S. economy right now?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, we're seeing some signs that it -- it's slowing down a little bit. We had numbers earlier this week on investment durable goods orders.

And they were soft and it was a little troubling after a third quarter in which business investment numbers were kind of soft.

You all were talking earlier about retail sales. I mean we're in a moment right now where the consumer has so much power, with unemployment so low.

And the benefits of these tax cuts that this might be a quarter, the fourth quarter, where it's really the consumer driving thing more than anything else.

MCDOWELL: Is that enough to turn the markets around, though?

HILSENRATH: Well, you asked Michael yes or no question, I'm going to say no.

You know, it does look like the economy is slowing, it does look like earnings growth going into 2019 is slowing down.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HILSENRATH: So I think, you know, there's a lot this market has to be worried about right now.

BLOCK: So Jon, with all that, what is the fed thinking here? You know, you -- if you go back even a month, everyone was -- it was near certainty that they were going to raise rates again on -- in December.

You know, now we're looking at a scenario where suddenly we're starting to see blanks. We've talked about it on this program.

And the futures markets are starting to price in that this isn't a given anymore.

What is the fed thinking about right now? What's most important to them?

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, the fed is thinking that it's going to go in December, so, you know, we had John Williams, New York Fed President, out speaking last week. Jay Powell has been out there talking in the last few weeks, and they haven't sent any signals that suggest they're wavering.

You know, when they see the market volatility like this, they say, "All right, that's part of the going back to normal in an economy. It's having a market that has ups and downs."

And so I think they're going to look through what -- the volatility we're seeing right now and go ahead and raise rates in December.

LI: I think they have to go in December at this point, because if you don't, it looks like you're kowtowing to the White House.

HILSENRATH: To the President.

LI: You're supposed to be an independent institution, right?

Four times that year, that's questionable to me. That's what Goldman Sachs is pricing in.

HILSENRATH: Well, I mean it's interesting because the President has really been on Jay Powell, the Fed Chairman, about raising rates.

And he's kind of put the fed into position where if it doesn't raise rates, which is what the President wants to happen, then it looks like the fed is getting political --

LI: Right.

HILSENRATH: -- and bending to the White House will. So it's counter -- you could argue that it's counterproductive, but I think from the fed's point of view, you have unemployment at a 50-year low.

Their model show that inflation should pick up when inflation gets this low. Powell isn't completely convinced of that, but we have seen inflation pick up. It's around two percent now.

So, I think they're going to go ahead in December and then see how things play out next year. The big question's what happens in 2019, and when they meet next month, the big question is going to be how the forecast change their forecast for 2019 come down.

But I wouldn't expect them to back away from a December move at this point.

MCDOWELL: Let's stay on the fed really quickly.

The President, though, is -- many people think he's right to talk about interest rates in the sense of that that is a concern that people are worried about, the Fed Reserve overdoing it.

We heard that from the economist, from the National Association of Retail - - excuse me, Realtors, existing home sales were up for the first time in six months thankfully, but they're worried about the -- about rising interest rates.

HILSENRATH: Well, we -- I mean it's interesting because the fed's been -- I'm sorry, the President has been talking about this for months.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: And just now the markets are starting to come around to his view that maybe the fed is being too aggressive.

And the other thing that's interesting about the President's comments is, you know, he's very vocal about his unhappiness with what Jerome Powell is doing.

But he really isn't interfering personally with what the fed has been up to. He hasn't talked to Powell since before he was nominated.

MCDOWELL: But this is --

HILSENRATH: So he's not -- you know, like we saw with LBJ back in the 1960s and President Nixon, they personally intervened with fed leaders and say -- and said, "Don't do this. Don't do this to me."

And with Powell -- I'm sorry, with the President, he's speaking publicly about it, but he isn't personally intervening with Jay Powell and telling him to stop.

MCDOWELL: Do you think anything changes with their balance sheet reduction that something that Greg Ip was writing about, about the removal of quantitative easing in Europe.

LI: That's quantitative tightening as well.

MCDOWELL: And -- well --

HILSENRATH: Right.

MCDOWELL: -- in Europe and Bank -- and the Bank of Japan and here in the United States.

HILSENRATH: Right. Well -- so the fed built up this four and half trillion dollar balance sheet. They bought all these treasury bonds, all these mortgage-backed securities, to try to hold down --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HILSENRATH: -- long-term interest rates and boost markets in the economy.

You know, they've been -- they've been at this for many months now, and they said they were going to do it more than a year ago.

It shouldn't be a surprise to markets. Markets are supposed to be forward- looking, and price in all of this activity.

LI: But why do they need to do -- couldn't they hold these bonds to maturity?

I mean, you don't necessarily have to un-want the balance sheet and sell off a bit --

MCDOWELL: Well, that's what they -- that's what the --

HILSENRATH: Well, they -- they're not -- they're not selling -- they're not selling any of the bonds.

MCDOWELL: You know, that's what they are doing now.

HILSENRATH: The --

MCDOWELL: Right? They're not actively selling.

HILSENRATH: They're allowing them -- they're allowing them -- when they mature, they're just allowing them to retire.

MCDOWELL: Right. Right.

HILSENRATH: -- and they're not recycling them into new bonds.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: But the point I was trying to make is, like, the market should know this. This shouldn't be a surprise. So, the -- it shouldn't give be an on --

In theory, it shouldn't be an ongoing headwind to the market because it should have been priced in a long time ago.

MCDOWELL: But --

HILSENRATH: But a lot people would argue that it is because there's just all the supply coming out of that.

MCDOWELL: We're -- but we're assuming that investors are really smart.

HILSENRATH: Right. Yes, exactly.

MCDOWELL: And always make really good decisions looking ahead.

I want to talk about china.

HILSENRATH: Yes.

MCDOWELL: There's a lot of cover in this. But President Trump is expected to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping next week at the G20 Summit in Argentina.

The President sounding confident on his trade strategy ahead of the much anticipated meeting.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I can say this China wants to make a deal very badly.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Do you think it's going to happen?

TRUMP: Because of the tariffs. Because right now on $250 billion, they'll be paying, as of January 1st, 25 percent.

And in many cases, they're already paying 205 percent. On the rest that they're not, they're paying 10, but the 10 percent goes to 25 percent on January 1st.

China is right now paying us. Right now paying us billions of dollars a month. That's never happened before. And soon, they're going to be paying us many, many billions of dollars a month.

But China wants to make a deal. If we can make a deal, we will.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: And then on china, Jon, you guys have one major breaking story every day, multiple stories a day, in fact.

And today, it's the U.S. government has initiated an extraordinary outreach campaign to foreign allies trying to persuade wireless and internet providers from avoiding the Chinese telecom equipment maker, Huawei Technologies.

HILSENRATH: Right.

MCDOWELL: Again, we're putting the hammer down on China in many ways, not just the tariff and the trade fight.

HILSENRATH: But it's -- we're doing it in ways that are kind of inconsistent and hard to read. On one hand --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HILSENRATH: -- you know, we're trying to convince Germany and Japan not to buy equipment from Huawei because we're afraid that they're going use that to spy, not only on Germany and Japan, but at our military installations.

MCDOWELL: Right.

HILSENRATH: But on the other hand, you know, we had this band on U.S. equipment sales, chip sales, to ZTE and then we reversed it.

So, it's kind of hard to tell where we're going in this battle. But, it, you know, when you look at it, you kind of think, you know, are we going to do a deal with the Chinese next week and then all of a sudden everything is fine?

And you know economic relations are kind of back to normal with the Chinese I don't think so. I think this is a very long run -- confrontation that we've got with China on its economic might and its technological might.

BLOCK: You know, to President Trump's credit, this is deliberately hard to read.

You know, the whole point here is exert pressure at various random points in order to say -- in order to get dialogue going within China --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BLOCK: -- and back channel saying, "Hey, this guy is going after us. Now we need to step down and make a deal, and I can tell you from my personal checks that that's feeling in China right now.

But there is also this optimism that deals are going to get done with the midterms out of the way going into the New Year.

When Wilbur Ross said, "Wait until next year," he wasn't kidding. There's things happening.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, final word, Jon.

HILSENRATH: I think next week, with Xi Jinping and President Trump, this is going to get a lot of attention. I don't expect a big breakthrough.

I mean maybe they keep talking going into 2019. But the President just -- and that hit didn't sound like he was ready for a deal.

He said the Chinese want to do a deal. He didn't say he's ready to do the one himself.

MCDOWELL: But that's yesterday and then there's today. So, maybe we'll get a tweet in the next 45 minutes that's incredibly optimistic. You just never know.

HILSENRATH: Keep watching. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Happy Thanksgiving, Jon.

HILSENRATH: Happy Thanksgiving to all of you.

MCDOWELL: Take care. Come back soon. Jon Hilsenrath, Wall Street Journal. Stay tuned, our special Black Friday market coverage on Fox Business.

Markets close at 1:00, we're here until 2:00.

And then coming up, border battle. President Trump threatening to shut down the entire U.S.-Mexico border if troops cannot get a handle on the migrants looking to cross into this country.

MCDOWELL: Dozens killed in a mosque blast in Afghanistan. Cheryl Casone has more details. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Dagen. We're just getting some new details on this story.

Here's what we know. This was an explosion at a mosque in the Eastern Afghan Province of Coast.

The mosque was inside of an army base, this was evening prayers. At least 26 people are dead, 50 wounded. The victims, of course, had gathered there to pray.

No word on what caused that explosion, though. We're going to, of course, be updating this story throughout the morning for you.

Another headlines this morning, Black Friday shopping turning violent in an Alabama mall last night.

Police fatally shooting a suspected gunman who they say opened fire inside a mall crowded with shoppers. Two people, including a 12-year-old girl, were injured.

The gunshots sent shoppers scurrying for cover and several were seen with their guns drawn.

The gunfire started just before 10 p.m. at the Riverchase Galleria in Hoover. That's about 10 miles from Birmingham.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It was crazy in every direction. And I just started praying and praying that God would give the police wisdom and accuracy of shot, protect the victims.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The suspect has not yet been identified.

Well, dozens were hurt after a charter bus overturned on an icy road in Washington State.

That bus was carrying the University of Washington Marching Band and it flipped on its side.

They were on their way to tonight's Apple Cup came against Washington State.

Nearly 40 of the 56 people onboard were injured, but none of those injuries, luckily, are serious.

Well, Nissan's Board voting unanimously to oust Chairman Carlos Ghosn from his post.

The Japanese automaker claims Ghosn used company money to buy personal homes, including a condominium in Rio de Janeiro.

Nissan also says that Ghosn uses subsidiary in the Netherlands to make multiple payments totaling thousands of dollars to his older sister for consulting.

Shares of the company are down about 14 percent so far this year, Dagen.

And there is the year-to-date with chart. A lot of pressure and a lot of news coming out on Nissan as well.

Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl. I'm reading "The Wall Street Journal's" story that the auto -- Nissan found that Carlos Ghosn used a subsidiary in the Netherlands, which Cher was talking about, to spend $18 million, buying, renovating personal homes.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It wasn't just a condo in Rio, but it was a home in Beirut that his sister received 60,000 commission for advising on the housing in Rio.

LI: Wow.

MCDOWELL: But found no evidence that the sister actually performed such work.

LI: And he underreported his $44 million in earnings as well according to these allegations in Japanese court.

And so, yes, Japan doesn't take this lightly, as I mentioned to you. It's a very insular domestic oriented economy. And when you're a foreign CEO heading up one of the largest companies in the country, you know, that doesn't look good for you, especially for a legacy.

Someone like Carlos Ghosn who's been -- his tenure has been over 10 years at the helm of Nissan.

MCDOWELL: Well, they save Nissan -- he essentially saved Nissan from bankruptcy.

LI: Avoided, 2008. Yes.

BLOCK: That's -- then becomes a corporate rock star, and now this happens. Unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: Well they wanted to -- independence, I guess. And now --

LI: But it took a while for them to actually kick him out because they needed Renault's support in order to oust him as chairman and they finally got it, so.

MCDOWELL: What happens to the alliance, guys?

LI: I think it stays in place because it's been intact for so long. It's been successful. I think they -- they're -- bringing in new people obviously, new blood to front the new entity.

MCDOWELL: So you don't have to be a rock star to actually know how to run a company or series of companies. I'll just point that out.

BLOCK: It's more --

LI: Maybe --

MCDOWELL: Boring is better sometimes.

LI: Maybe stars only shine so long, I think that's the lesson.

MCDOWELL: Yes, that's right.

BLOCK: You're a rock star, and don't steal.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, caravan crisis, more asylum seekers gaining ground near the U.S.-Mexico border, as President Trump threatens to shut it down entirely.

Plus subpoena sent, FBI Director James Comey urging for transparency, set to answer house judiciary questions over the Clinton email investigation.

MCDOWELL: Take a look at futures today. We've got a market that's down three percent or more so far this week. There -- Monday and Tuesday being horrible days in the stock market.

Now you have 124 point loss on the Dow Futures right now. We'll be looking into this, digging into this as the morning moves on.

Markets close today shortened trading session. Close at 1 p.m. Eastern Time.

Moving on to the border showdown, President Trump threatening to shut down the United States border with Mexico if things cannot get under control.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If we find that it's -- it gets to a level where we are going to lose control, or where people are going to start getting hurt, we will close entry into the country for a period of time until we can get it under control.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You mean entire border of the country?

TRUMP: The whole border. I mean the whole border.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This coming after reports that a small group separated from the major migrant caravan within 500 feet of the U.S. border yesterday.

Joining us now, "Weekly Standard" Deputy Editor Kelly Jane Torrance. What do you make of what the President was talking about there?

KELLY JANE TORRANCE, DEPUTY EDITOR, WEEKLY STANDARD: Yes. You know, it's really coming to a showdown, isn't it, Dagen? And I have mixed feelings.

I mean you don't want to close the border to people who do have real problems and who are seeking asylum, but at the same time, a lot of these people are coming specifically for a showdown.

And, you know, the President says talking about closing down border, but what he's not mentioning is actually the government knows about the caravan and has been preparing for it for months now.

And what's interesting is the administration is actually implementing what they call a Remain in Mexico plan, which is if you can show that you have worries for your life, you need to get out of Mexico, you will be let into the United States while your asylum claim is being processed.

But if you can't, you're going to actually wait in Mexico while that claim is being processed.

And, you know, President Trump has been complaining for a while about the, you know, what he calls the, you know, detainee program now, and complaining about people being released.

Well, if they're going to have to wait in Mexico, it might actually stop some people from coming to United States who think, "Well, I can get here, I can get to the United States. And once they let me go, I can do what I want."

So there's a lot going on here that the President isn't talking about that's going on behind the scenes.

MCDOWELL: Erin.

ELMORE: Yes. Hi, Kelly. Erin Elmore here. Good morning. We know that immigration is a huge issue for the Trump voter and the Trump base.

TORRANCE: Yes.

ELMORE: What do you think the right play is here? We know 9th Circuit is trying to control the situation, but what do you think the right play is? What do you tell the President to do?

TORRANCE: Yes, and, you know what, everyone's complaining about Donald Trump talking about the politicized core, but let's face it, you had --

Okay, so this is not the 9th Circuit, but it's the district court that things go to the 9th Circuit. The District Court of Northern California complained that the President cannot make immigration law and it stopped, you know, his recent laws.

But let's face it, that same court actually thought that it was okay for Obama, President Obama to make immigration law with DACA, with the, you know, the DREAM Act.

And so then it was like, "Oh, it's okay for the president to say --

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

TORRANCE: -- that we're going to have this DREAM Act in young people who are here. They had no problem with the President making immigration law then they have a problem with Donald Trump doing it.

So I mean, you know, you don't want to criticize courts too much, you want to let them do their job, but I think in this case, Donald Trump actually has a point.

And you say, you know, look at and it's like, "Well, hey, we're -- Donald Trump can't make immigration law but Barack Obama can." He has a good point there.

ELMORE: So he's not relying on his own precedent, is what you're saying basically. And that's -- the beauty of courts is that their precedent shows you what they're going to likely do in the future.

And in this case, they're not relying on their own precedent and it is politics.

TORRANCE: Exactly. I mean I agree with the court, actually, that it's Congress who should be making immigration law.

But we -- of course we know that Congress has been trying since the George W. Bush years to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill and it's not going to happen.

Let's face it, it's just never going to happen and that's why presidents have been using executive orders to do things that they want and, yes.

MCDOWELL: What -- well, I want to point out that one very well-known Democrat, Hillary Clinton, weighed in on immigration.

TORRANCE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: The Former Presidential candidate urging Europe to get a handle on the migrant crisis there.

This is in an interview with "The Guardian."

Hillary Clinton said this, "I admire the very generous and compassionate approaches that were taken particularly by leaders like German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, but I think it is fair to say Europe has done its part and must send a very clear message."

"We're not going to be able to continue to provide refuge and support because we don't deal with the immigration issue. We'll continue to roil the body politic."

Your reaction to that. Again, it's -- she's talking about Europe, but why not the United States?

TORRANCE: Well -- and, of course, one of the reasons that Europe has this crisis is because Angela Merkel actually welcomed migrants to come to Germany.

People forget that the reason that you have this migrant crisis, one of the reasons, is that Angela Merkel said, "Hey, you guys need asylum? Come here."

And, of course, people listen. But let's face it, why do we -- why does Europe have that migrant crisis? It's because of the war in Syria.

And, you know, honestly, if we got rid of the terrible regime in Iran, that's propping up Bashar al-Assad and making it impossible to live in Syria, for regular Syrians who are facing, you know, terrible situations, they wouldn't be doing that.

So, yes, let's look at the root causes of why people are leaving and I think -- no, that's one of the things that Donald Trump is tried -- sort of said is like, hey, we need to look at what's happening in Central America and maybe help people at the source, so they don't feel they need to leave.

MCDOWELL: She -- Hillary Clinton did say that you need to handle the immigration crisis if you want to stop the rise of right wing populist, in the region. But I'll point out.

Remember the mass sexual assaults in Cologne, Germany that were virtually not covered by the news media, here in the United States? In large part, because of this immigration crisis that Hillary Clinton is talking about and I think that was two years ago, maybe, just to point that out.

TORRANCE: It's not even just it wasn't covered here, it was actually not covered in Germany so much, because police in Cologne actually wouldn't -- didn't want people to know about what was happening because they didn't want people angry at the government that -- you know, welcome those people to come.

MCDOWELL: Thank you Kelly Jane, Kelly Jane Torrance, this morning, Happy Thanksgiving.

TORRANCE: Happy Thanksgiving.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, Black Friday madness. It's the biggest shopping day of the year. We'll see if retail stocks get a boost or even the overall market. And live action Lion King, a sneak peek at the latest trailer from Disney and all of the talent that comes along with it.

ANNOUNCER: Welcome back to a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA, Black Friday.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, November 23rd, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern. Black Friday is here. More than 164 million people are expected to go shopping this weekend, that, according to the National Retail Federation.

Checking out market actions this morning, Futures are pointing way, way lower, 126-point loss on the Dow Futures. Markets close at 1:00 p.m. Eastern time, today. But so far, in this shortened holiday week, the Dow, S&P and NASDAQ are all down more than three percent. NASDAQ Composite down nearly four percent. That's the worst week in eight months, for the NASDAQ.

In Europe, markets have shown some mixed moves. So far, we have green across the screen, at the moment, slight gains in England, France and Germany, and in Asia overnight, markets moving lower. The Nikkei was closed for trading, but the Hang Seng, Shanghai and KOSPI in South Korea, all to the downside.

Crude awakening, we're watching oil prices amid oversupply concerns, we have a four percent loss on the cost of crude this morning, the cost of oil, at $52.32 a barrel.

Question for James Comey, the latest developments as the former FBI director is vowing to fight a subpoena he received from House Republicans before they pass the baton to the Democrats.

It's sky-high bid, the details as Virgin Atlantic reportedly discusses purchasing struggling budget airline, Flybe. Plus, a legendary face-off, $9 million showdown between Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, that's ahead. And the Lion King is back. A sneak peek at the live-action reboot, later this hour. We will play this trailer over and over and over again.

But to our top story this half hour, Futures are heading lower on the busiest shopping day of the year, joining us now, Payne Capital Management President, Ryan Payne. Can -- do investors need to see even better-than- expected sales, this weekend? Is that enough to turn this market around?

RYAN PAYNE, PRESIDENT, PAYNE CAPITAL MANAGEMENT: Well, it wasn't earlier in the weeks, so we had, you know, a couple big new retailers report earnings on Tuesday. You know, you got Kohl's report, you got Target report, and they had great sales, and they sold off pretty unmercifully, I would say.

LI: But it's profit margins because people are thinking ahead, thinking when (INAUDIBLE) a bite, when do supply chains get too expensive and when do shoppers stop shopping when interest rates go up.

PAYNE: And I think that is a big one. I think everyone is worried, like, has the consumer peaked here? Is this as good as it going to get? And I think that's kind of been the overhang on the market. Like, do we really believe the economy is getting stronger? At some point here, it's all going to collapse.

MCDOWELL: Well, if you look at this, I want to stay on retail before we move on, but if you look at these retail stocks, the only of this major list of retail stocks that we follow, including Kohl'sNordstrom, Penney's, Macy's, you name it, the only one up, so far this month, is --

Well, you know, because I asked my (INAUDIBLE) about it. It's Fred's. Fred's is up on, but it's up 9-1/2 percent, but you've got an 18 percentage point loss, almost 19 percent, like Abercrombie and Fitch, these are deep, deep, deep losses for these retail stocks.

BLOCK: We were watching T.V. earlier about Black Friday, and there was a woman who was sitting at the mall and she was interviewed, and she said, yes, I was getting 60 to 70 percent off at Aeropostale. What does that mean for an Abercrombie? It's definitely difficult.

You know, one thing I'm looking at here is, earlier this year, we talk about wage costs, freight costs. Those are allegedly going to hit the retail. But what happened was, retailers were able to keep raising their prices and they actually turned out decent margins.

With the Kohl's and Target reports earlier this week, we saw, A, there is some concern about freight costs, both companies mentioned that, but also, B -- you know -- B, there's also -- there are some issues with the price. You know, what could save these stocks here? What could help them?

PAYNE: Well, I think at this point (INAUDIBLE) as an overall lifted market, right? They also sold off just because a whole market there is capitulating in the short term, which I would argue it's probably a good buying opportunity because now, valuations are even more reasonable.

And, you know, our belief in Payne Capital Management is, you know, the retailer -- the retail investors are strong right now. Consumer is strong and it's going to continue to get stronger. So, as long as the consumers in good shape, I think it's going to be very good for those stocks, long term.

MCDOWELL: Well, that argument about, I can find some bargains now. People have been saying that about technology and big technology stocks, and you've continued to see a downdraft in all of these big names, and Apple, really, putting pressure on the market, specifically, earlier in the week.

PAYNE: Yes, you live by a (INAUDIBLE) right? I mean, tech, has had a huge move up, and now we've seen this, you know, huge move down. So, at some point, I think you have to find some kind of ground here where the market says OK.

You know, valuations are reasonable. I mean, techs never going to get reasonable here. I mean, you're still trading at like, 20 times forward earnings, which is a premium to the market.

LI: It's a growth stock though. That's a growth sector. That's kind of how they're valued, aren't they? You know, we --

PAYNE: Right.

LI: We actually had Facebook, admitting, going into the holiday, later on Wednesday, that they did hire definers. That was -- they did that on purpose, so that we would miss the headlines on Thursday. But, they admitted to hiring definers, Sheryl Sandberg admitted to actually knowing that they hired this opposition research team.

So, what about Facebook, in particular? What about the reputational risk, regulatory risk priced in?

PAYNE: I (INAUDIBLE) priced in. We had a lot of panic already. And anecdotally, I work the retail investor. And invariably, the retail investor is always wrong. So, when they start to panic -- you know, I think, when they start to panic, you're starting to see some panic in here, that's actually very bullish for the markets.

You didn't see that before and we had a big selloff in the end of October, and we kind of hit those lows again, this past week. No, no one's really panicking, that always concerned me, but now you're starting to see a little bit of panic in there, which makes me think we're probably even closer to some kind of bottom in here.

MCDOWELL: You know what -- you know what, I think our viewers, based on their comments on Twitter, are quite smart about the markets, when what's part -- a part of what's causing this downdraft, it's the smart money. It's the smart money getting put out of business because they have been so wrong. Talk about that.

BLOCK: Yes. Well, what's been going on, is Q3 was hard for one, the hedge funds, they've got whipsawed by a lot these, moves higher in the big tech stocks, and then, right when they -- right when they bought into that, it traded down. It was a rough October, rough November.

There's a lot of blood out there. There's a lot of liquidation. I'm reading about somebody's energy focus funds. There's an energy fund that's down 15.7 percent, month to date, right now, and around, so there's a lot going on.

Your clients, you do have -- you know, you claim retail investors aren't smart, but you know, of course, yours are the smartest, and what are they saying? Like, are they excited about the market? Are they apprehensive? What's your biggest concern right now?

PAYNE: When was the retail investor not smart? But they tend to be very emotional, right? And that emotional Litmus test. Then, you know, we can argue, is the smart money really that smart? Hedge funds have not done that well in the last couple of years.

Just the fact they're selling, they might not -- they might be indicative of making a bad decision as opposed to good decision.

BLOCK: They're Mike Tyson-smart. They're geniuses until they get punched in the face.

MCDOWELL: Jonas Ferris used that very quote on Wednesday, by the way.

BLOCK: Great minds think alike.

MCDOWELL: So you were -- no, you were watching, is what --

BLOCK: Hi, Jonas.

MCDOWELL: No, I'm just kidding. Ryan Payne, good to see you.

PAYNE: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Thanks so much. Stay tuned. Our special Black Friday on Fox Business, we're here until 2:00 p.m. Eastern. And coming up, he's urging for transparency, former FBI Director James Comey, issuing -- issued a subpoena by the House Judiciary Committee, over the Hillary Clinton E-mail scandal.

Plus, showdown on the links, Phil Mickelson and Tiger Woods set to duke it out today, in Vegas, with a $9 million purse.

MCDOWELL: Weird song. Virgin Atlantic reportedly in talks to by Flybe. Cheryl Casone has more. Hey, Cheryl.

CASONE: That's weird. All right, here's the news: Sky News says the Britain's Virgin Atlantic is going to acquire regional airline, Flybe. This comes a week after Flybe announced in talks to sell itself. Virgin Atlantic owned by Richard Branson's Virgin Group and Delta Airlines. Flybe has got a market cap of about 27 million. Last month, Flybe has shared a proper warning, though; they said a weak demand and a weaker British Pounds. So, we'll see if Virgin Atlantic gets the deal.

Former FBI Director, James Comey says that Republicans have subpoenaed him to testify at a closed-door meeting of the House Judiciary Committee early next month. In a Thanksgiving Day tweet, Comey says, that he would be happy to answer the committee's questions but would resist doing it behind closed doors for that his testimony will be leaked and distorted. The subpoena part of a congressional inquiry into allegations of anti-Trump bias that led to the opening of the Russia investigation.

Well, the head-to-head matchup between two of the biggest names in golf takes place today. Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson is going to hit the links in Las Vegas, the much-hyped $9 million winner take all match. Organizers are hoping to recoup the money from fans willing to pay $19.99 for pay-per-view. Woods and Mickelson are also putting up their own cash and side bets that eventually, of course, is all going to charity. Teatime is set for 3:00 p.m. Eastern Time. Dagen, place your bet.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, a Disney classic reborn. The first trailer for the live-action "Lion King" wowing people; it basically broke the Internet yesterday. Coming up, stay with us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ralph, what is wrong you?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Start churning butter and put on your church shoes little sister because we're about to blast off.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Ralph, what is it you're trying to say?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We're going to the Internet.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: What?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: That was a clip from the new animated film "Ralph Breaks the Internet"; the sequel to Disney's "Wreck It Ralph," it premiers on Wednesday. Joining me now: "IN THE FOX LIGHT" Host, Michael Tammero.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The microphone is off?

MCDOWELL: What is your take on "Ralph Breaks the Internet," is he going to break the box office?

MICHAEL TAMMERO, FOX NEWS CHANNEL HOST AND VICE PRESIDENT FOR MARKETING: It's going to break all sorts of records this weekend, looking probably about $100 million. You know, this is a big weekend for the box office every year; and so far, box office is up over 10 percent this year over last year, with an -- attendance is up which is even a bigger story right now. It's not just, you know, the fact that tickets are more expensive, but attendance is up about seven percent so far this year. And this weekend, looks to push those numbers even higher. The Ralph, critics are loving him and audiences are loving him as well and it about A- cinema score.

MCDOWELL: What else is opening this weekend or is in competition --

TAMMERO: We have "Creed 2," follow up to the big 2016 hit, Michael B. Jordan -- what a year this guy has had. He started the year with "Black Panther" which grossed over $700 million. "Creed 2" is getting also sorts of critical acclaim; and who knows it could push him to an Oscar coming down, an award season, you just never know with these things.

MCDOWELL: All right, so what broke yesterday, can we just watch it?

TAMMERO: Oh, my God, yes!

MCDOWELL: "The Lion King" live-action trailer, the very first one. Roll it. Do we have it?

TAMMERO: Or not?

MCDOWELL: There we go.

TAMMERO: Oh my god.

MCDOWELL: That's not all of it. I'm just going to sit here (INAUDIBLE) --

TAMMERO: Over and over again. Look, this formula has been really successful for Disney: Bringing these animated movies to live-action movies. A lot of -- how is this going to look? This broke yesterday. People are going nuts. I was driving home watching it from mother-in-law and I said, oh my god, this look so good. And my husband was like, enough with "The Lion King."

MCDOWELL: No, no, no.

TAMMERO: We've seen the Broadway show ten times, the movie, but guess what? Guess who was watching it last night and all of a sudden oh my god, this looks incredible. I'm like, see?

MCDOWELL: You caught your husband when you were in the other room watching the trailer on his phone.

TAMMERO: Sold. He is sold, Jon Favreau is directing, Beyonce plays Nala, Donald Glover is in this -- Darth Vader, I can't think of his name -- James Earl Jones is in this as well plays Mufasa.

MCDOWELL: I actually -- because I'm such a nerd as Adam Driver but it wasn't Adam Driver. But it's -- the James Earl Jones does the voiceover for the film.

TAMMERO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: What is it about? Is it this movie? I know that they've really brought back some iconic Disney films through this new live-action technology but there's something about "The Lion King:" It's the music and it's the story and the fact that it had life as an animated film and then as a Broadway show -- which so many people have seen.

TAMMERO: It's a great story and the music is fantastic. This is going to have a whole remade score from Hans Zimmer, that we'd get to look forward to. And it's also -- it's the way they do these movies now; it's so incredible. When you think about the motion capture and the CGI tech -- watching this last night, I kept thinking: Wow, animation is no longer the only execution to create a world; now it's just going to be a style of execution. When you can do things like this, you really don't need to know the animation, this looks real.

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE), from "Swingers." What an incredible -- but what an amazing career as a director when a lot of people just thought he would just be an actor.

TAMMERO: He's responsible for Disney's "The Jungle Book" which made hundreds of dollars last year at the box office. I cannot wait.

MCDOWELL: It looks --

TAMMERO: 2019 cannot come soon enough.

MCDOWELL: But now, Jon Favreau, you have to deliver. It has to be as good as the trailer. It better be better than the trailer. Happy Thanksgiving. Loved your whole family; loved your husband, Michael Tammero.

TAMMERO: Happy Thanksgiving. Good to see you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, everybody, still ahead, it's the busiest shopping day of the year and we're just getting started, the best Black Friday deals more on the markets next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Friday, November 23rd.

And so did a number of companies that got in trouble with the government, shares of for-profit trade schools, for instance. And Johnson and Johnson, the medical products maker, they had some regulatory ...

urn:contentItem:51V6-HGK1-DY2S-N0YX-00000-00Stocks Set To End 2010 on an Upbeat Note2010-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisMorning Edition10:00 AM ESTNPRStocks Set To End 2010 on an Upbeat Note

RENEE MONTAGNE, host:

This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News. I'm Renee Montagne.

Despite some ups and downs, the stock market had a good year in 2010. To find out why and what it portends for the economy, we turn to Dave Wessel now. He's economics editor of The Wall Street Journal.

Good morning.

Mr. DAVID WESSEL (Economics Editor, The Wall Street Journal): Good morning, Renee.

MONTAGNE: David, how good was this year for stocks?

Mr. WESSEL: Well, it was pretty good. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up nearly 11 percent in 2010, on top of a 15 percent rise in 2009. It's basically put the stock market, more than two years after the disaster of Lehman Brothers in the fall of 2008, its back to where it was before we had that calamity.

We have this great chart in The Wall Street Journal today, that shows that nearly all the stocks in the S&P 500 were down in 2008, 425 of them were up in 2009, 392 were up this year. And the same is true in most of the foreign stock markets - Germany, Canada, Britain.

It seems that investors think that, well, corporate profits are doing pretty well and investors have decided that the worst is behind us - that the risk of a double dip recession has faded. Capital gains taxes are not going to go up in the U.S. next year, as some had feared. And they seem to think the economy will get better - maybe slowly - but will get better from here.

MONTAGNE: Which sounds like good times are coming, but how good a predictor is the stock market for the rest of the economy?

Mr. WESSEL: Not great. The late economist, Paul Samuelson, once joked that the stock market predicted nine out of the last five recessions. If there's some bad news on the economy, some surprise in oil markets or tension in the Middle East, or in North Korea or something, the stock market could dive again.

But it does suggest some optimism, that, about the durability of the economic recovery. And there's one thing that really does matter: higher stock prices mean that people have more money - at least the ones who own stocks.

The value of the stock market, of the whole stock market, is up about $2 trillion over the year. Now, even though most people's assets are in houses in America - and house prices are not going up - still, there's more money in the stock market than there is in the housing market. And so, the more money people have and the better businessmen feel about the stock market, the more likely they are to spend.

MONTAGNE: Give us a little scorecard. Which industries and stocks did best this year, and which ones lagged?

Mr. WESSEL: Well, as I said, most did better. Commodity prices are up a lot and that help the shares of companies that produce them, or help produce them. Caterpillar had a great year, the equipment maker. DuPont, which makes chemicals and sells agricultural seeds, was up roughly 50 percent. In general, smaller companies did better than big ones.

As consumers began to spend again, companies that sell to them had a good year in the stock market: Ford, Abercrombie & Fitch, Amazon, Apple was up 50 percent, Netflix was up 227 percent.

And one of the biggest winners of all, ironically, was AIG - the insurance company that was bailed out by the government - its shares nearly doubled in 2010, although they're still not worth anything like they were before the crisis.

On the down side, some of the big tech companies, Hewlett Packard and Cisco had lousy years. And so did a number of companies that got in trouble with the government, shares of for-profit trade schools, for instance. And Johnson and Johnson, the medical products maker, they had some regulatory issues and they were down for the year, as well.

MONTAGNE: But very briefly, David, unemployment is close to 10 percent still. I mean back to that question of the economy and the stock market. How can companies prosper when their customers aren't?

Mr. WESSEL: That's a good question. The first thing is they can't for long. The second is that those people who have money are spending. The third thing is that companies are getting a lot of productivity out of their existing workers, which means they're making more profit out of each worker.

And finally, nearly half the revenue of the companies in the S&P 500, come not from selling to Americans but to selling from abroad. And a number of foreign economies, particularly in Asia, are doing quite well.

MONTAGNE: David, thanks very much and a happy New Year to you.

Mr. WESSEL: You're welcome, Renee, and happy New Year to you.

MONTAGNE: David Wessel is economics editor of The Wall Street Journal.
