BARTIROMO: The -- and the President is tweeting -- wait. Governor, the President just tweeting this morning --

RICHARDSON: I don't know what poll you're reading. It was significant damage to the President.

BARTIROMO: The President is tweeting this morning. Let me tell you what he says. He says, "Democrats are becoming the party of late-term abortion, high taxes, open borders, and crime. Your reaction.

RICHARDSON: Oh, I mean this -- you know, he's into his campaign mode. This is like when he says to his intelligence people that we spend over $20 billion in intelligence, CIA, NSA, Department of Defense --

BARTIROMO: So is that -- is that tweet incorrect?

RICHARDSON: -- all of North Korea, they're my -- they're my buddies.

BARTIROMO: Is that -- is that tweet inaccurate? Wait, is that tweet inaccurate?

RICHARDSON: Totally inaccurate. Totally inaccurate.

BARTIROMO: What's inaccurate? What's inaccurate?

RICHARDSON: The whole thing. The whole thing.

BARTIROMO: Wait, late term abortion?

RICHARDSON: It's like the President's saying to his intelligence fee --

BARTIROMO: -- higher taxes? Which one? Later term abortion?

RICHARDSON: Totally inaccurate. Totally -- no.

BARTIROMO: Open borders? Wait, which one?

RICHARDSON: You know, this is -- this is --

BARTIROMO: What's inaccurate, governor?

RICHARDSON: This is ridiculous. No. Open borders? That's ridiculous. All of that is ridiculous. There should be serious negotiations right now. And it's not happening. And the President's not helping with these tweets.

RICHARDSON: You know the thing is? I mean I know that a lot of your colleagues say that they're for border security, but they didn't vote for Kate's law, they didn't vote to end Sanctuary Cities, they didn't vote for a border wall, so how can you say you're for border security when you actually haven't done so in terms of your voting record?

RICHARDSON: Well, look at what the Democrats are proposing for this showdown, one, more border patrol agents, two, more Coast Guard assistance, three, more drones, four, all kinds of new technologies that will work.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think they voted for a wall before?

RICHARDSON: A border wall is not going to work.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think they vote --

RICHARDSON: It doesn't work.

BARTIROMO: Why did Nancy Pelosi vote for a wall before?

RICHARDSON: That -- perhaps that wall she voted for on her border. All I'm saying is --

BARTIROMO: But why is that not immoral?

RICHARDSON: -- let's make this work. Let's make this work.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

RICHARDSON: But not threaten border shutdowns, not end the government working, that's what the President is saying.

BARTIROMO: Bill Richardson --

RICHARDSON: "If I don't get my way, I'm going to shut down the government.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

RICHARDSON: All right. All right.

BARTIROMO: Bill Richardson joining us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Facebook reporting a record profit. The stock is soaring this morning. Joining me now the host of "VARNEY & CO." Stuart Varney to weigh in. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi, good morning, Maria. You know, I wasn't looking at that profit report for the profit number or profit margin, I was looking at it to see how many active monthly users they've got. When I saw that number come over, 2.7 billion, I figured that Facebook was out of the woods. Think of all the scandal, all the bad publicity, all the privacy questions that have been leveled against Facebook in the last, what, year or six months? It--- it's not touched their business. I thought that the scandal may have reduced the number of monthly users, active users on the -- on the base, but it didn't. They've actually increased. And that's why I think Facebook is up so much this morning, 11 percent gain for a stock like that is absolutely enormous. My bottom line is this, all the scandal did not touch its financial business. The heart of its business was not touched by all the political goings-on around it. Facebook, 167. Who would have thought?

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's pretty incredible. You're right, Stu.

VARNEY: It really is.

BARTIROMO: Great analysis. I know you have a lot more in about 12 minutes' time.

VARNEY: Sure.

BARTIROMO: So we'll see you top of the hour.

VARNEY: You got it.

BARTIROMO: Thank so much. "Varney & Co." begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, a raging fire tears through Newark Airport, torching at least a dozen cars. We've got all the details. We will take you there. Then Goodell speaks out, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell breaks his silence on the controversial no call that knocked The Saints off the path of the Super Bowl. All next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news. More than a dozen cars catching fire at Newark Liberty International Airport this morning. Lauren Simonetti with headlines now. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi, Maria. The fire broke out in a parking lot around 7:00 a.m. this morning. Firefighters quickly responded. They put it out amid this freezing cold temperatures, flights are not affected, the cause of the fire under investigation.

Apple is reportedly planning 3-D cameras for its 2020 iPhone. Bloomberg reporting that Apple wants to launch the new 3-D camera as soon as they can as it moves deeper into augmented reality. Maybe you'll spend a lot of for that phone. I don't know. Shares looking this morning, up two-thirds of one percent.

Former Starbucks CEO impossible 2020 independent hopeful Howard Schultz says he's surprised being attacked for being rich.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HOWARD SCHULTZ, FORMER STARBUCKS CEO: This interesting phenomenon in the last week or so where I have this moniker now of being, you know, I'm a billionaire and so don't trust him because he's a successful person. I grew up literally in public housing in the projects. And I have succeeded in America I always thought that was something to be celebrated, that my success should not be something that is punitive. My success is living proof of the promise of the country. I can't find the answers why people are all of a sudden chastising me for being successful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Many Democrats are caffeinated against him, criticizing Schultz over his potential presidential run saying he will only help to reelect President Trump. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Listen, I'm looking at this. We are celebrating throwback Thursday this morning. We're showing you our best looks from the 80s, that's next stay, with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: It is throwback Thursdays here on the MORNINGS WITH MARIA set. Here's me from circa 19857. I was working in a photo lab, printing pictures.

MCDOWELL: I told you, Sophia Loren.

BARTIROMO: Care-free days. I don't even know that I was thinking about what stock to buy. I don't even know that I was thinking about me being a journalist.

MCDOWELL: Look at this complexion. This is even before -- well, it's before the internet really, but the no photo filters, you're glowing.

BARTIROMO: Let's see yours, Dagen McDowell. Come on.

MCDOWELL: No. I told you I'm really ugly.

BARTIROMO: Throwback Thursday.

MCDOWELL: Do they have it?

BARTIROMO: Wait, Governor Huckabee with his daughter. OK.

MCDOWELL: Oh, there I am.

BARTIROMO: There's Dagen.

HUCKABEE: There's Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I jumped in a swimming pool fully clothed right after that was taken. And I am not making that up.

BARTIROMO: And this is about 1980 --

MCDOWELL: 88.

BARTIROMO: 88.

MCDOWELL: It was the summer after my freshman year in college.

BARTIROMO: Governor Huckabee with your daughter, White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders. Aww. That is too cute.

HUCKABEE: That's about 1984. She was about two years old at that time. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So great. That's beautiful shot. And lastly, the photo James Freeman gave us.

FREEMAN: Yes, so this is me. You asked for a throwback --

BARTIROMO: Come on, James.

FREEMAN: -- Thursday photo of James Freeman. Apparently, this is the Reverend James Freeman. Apparently, he was an outstanding preacher. Governor, you might want to grade his performance, I don't know, but very influential in Boston. My kids ran across this a few weeks ago while sightseeing, so --

BARTIROMO: You couldn't find any shots of yourself as a baby.

FREEMAN: I -- well, I did -- if you give me more time, I'll try and find it. But I told you, I never went with the mullet. My great regret, so I don't know if we're going to have really fun 80s photos, but I'll do my best.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday.

FREEMAN: OK. Deal.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday, we'll do another throwback Thursday, how's that?

MCDOWELL: OK. You got to let me know in advance and so we I can dig some photos out of my -- well --

BARTIROMO: All right. So we have a week.

MCDOWELL: -- drawer.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, we didn't even talk about this. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell spoke publicly for the first time about that blatant non-call in the NFC Championship game. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER GOODELL, NFL COMMISSIONER: Technology is not going to solve all those issues. The game is not officiated by robots. It's not going to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: God, you're lucky the game has been great in the last year, Goodell, because you're terrible and people hate you. No more than --

BARTIROMO: Oh, God.

MCDOWELL: No, people hate him.

BARTIROMO: Tell us how you really feel.

HUCKABEE: What do you really think?

MCDOWELL: No, let's call some folks down in New Orleans and ask them how they feel. Anyway. No, they do, people don't -- excuse me, they don't like him.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day everybody. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away. Hey, you've got a neat throwback Thursday shots you want to share, Stu?

END

Plants Halt Production; NJ Paper Plant Destroyed; Schultz Takes On Trump; Vets Suing 3M; G.E. Rev Beats Estimates: $33.28 Billion (ACT) Versus $32.61 Billion (EST); Mueller Report Decision; Daily Caller: Trump Says He Will Leave the Mueller Report Decision to DOJ; Sen. Paul Awarded Over $580K; Goodell on Blow Call; Deadly Polar Vortex2019-01-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks Surge After Fed Says It Will Be Patient Raising Rates; Amazon Super Bowl Ad; G.M. Plants Halt Production; NJ Paper Plant Destroyed; Schultz Takes On Trump; Vets Suing 3M; G.E. Rev Beats Estimates: $33.28 Billion (ACT) Versus $32.61 Billion (EST); Mueller Report Decision; Daily Caller: Trump Says He Will Leave the Mueller Report Decision to DOJ; Sen. Paul Awarded Over $580K; Goodell on Blow Call; Deadly Polar VortexLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies, thank you so much. And good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday, it is Thursday, January 31st. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the east coast. Busy morning on earnings this morning. We will hear from UPS, General Electric, both ahead of the open this morning. Big technology still in focus, Facebook reporting last night after the close, big quarter for Facebook, Amazon will be the one to watch today after the close tonight.

Meanwhile, the arctic blast turns deadly. Temperatures across the Midwest falling to their lowest levels in decades. We will take you to the Minneapolis region this morning, where the negative 24 degrees is having a real impact. The push to tax the wealthy, J.P. Morgan's CEO Jamie Dimon reportedly saying that the richest Americans can afford to pay higher taxes, but there's a catch. Then, Roger Goodell breaking his silence, what he said about the infamous no-call during the NFC championship game coming up later this hour. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

And we kick it off with markets this morning. Let's check Futures showing a mixed opening this morning after a huge day yesterday. Dow Industrials expected to be down 15 points at the open. The S&P and the NASDAQ up fractionally right now after a solid day of trading that all stock surged yesterday after the Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell signaled that the Central Bank may pause interest rate hikes for now. The Fed on pause.

Technology giant, Facebook, meanwhile also reporting fourth-quarter earnings. Look at that market yesterday, up 434 points at the close, it was a big day. And that, by the way, was off of the highs of the day after the Fed meeting. Facebook earnings beat expectations posting a record profit for what has been a difficult year for the social media company. Take a look at Facebook shares this morning, up 11-1/3 percent right now, 167 and change. Earnings season rolling on today with Amazon reporting after the bell tonight. Take a look at all the names that we're expecting today in what is really the busiest week -- one of the busiest weeks for the fourth quarter.

Here now, the founder of Disruptive Technology Research Lou Basenese. Lou, it's good to see you.

LOU BASENESE, FOUNDER, DISRUPTIVE TECH RESEARCH: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: First, on Facebook, your reaction to the quarter last night.

BASENESE: Look, I am just shocked and disappointed in this rally. I mean, I think this is really putting forward that investors and management favor profit growth over ethics. I mean, look, this week, we had -- I think one of the -- just biggest disappointments in privacy protection with the Facebook research app. I mean, just total disregard for Apple's wishes, total disregard for teenage users' privacy, and yet, investors are cheering profit growth. So, look, I can't argue with the fundamental numbers. I mean, the stock is reasonably valued, you've seen growth come back in the U.S. as the key market, and advertisers just don't have any other outlet, any other alternative to reach 2 billion potential viewers. So, it's one of those things, it's a toxic investment, to me. So, I --

BARTIROMO: So, you wouldn't touch it?

BASENESE: I wouldn't touch it. Look, I think there's a lot of risk embedded there. What's the next privacy scandal that's going to come to light? Facebook, over the years, has really made more excuses than changes to what they're doing.

BARTIROMO: All right, let's talk about the Fed -- the Fed essentially on hold yesterday saying it's on hold, indicating that more dovish stance when it comes to interest rate hikes. What was your reaction to what the Fed said in particular also saying that the balance sheet unwind is also a way that they could pull back and perhaps stop the 50 billion sales a month.

BASENESE: Yes, I don't think I can remember in my lifetime just a more dramatic turn of sentiment at the Fed. I mean, in October, they were saying that we're a long way from neutral and now, yesterday's statement said that we're within range. I mean, they went from playing hardball with the President to playing patty cake, and you know, investors love that. So, you know, more easy monetary policy coming. I think they gave themselves some flexibility on unwinding the balance sheet. Not that they didn't say that they were going to be data dependent before, but now they just made that much more of a point to communicate to the markets that there's not going to be a fast and hard unwind.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, we were sort of expecting this in the last couple of months, that's for sure. But would this be a signal for you to put new money to work in stocks?

BASENESE: I think absolutely. Look, the Fed has been supportive of stock prices. I mean, there's a lot of people that would argue this bull market would not be around without the Fed. So, with the Fed being very accommodative, I think it's time to come back into the market, we're going to see that. You've seen a dramatic reversal even in the more speculative areas of the market. And I think I pointed out before in another appearance that the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index, tremendous bounce off the lows, up almost 20 percent, and about to breakthrough to the 200-day moving average. So, yes, it's risk on again. At least to the Fed.

BARTIROMO: All right. Two more things on stocks, we've got earnings, obviously, the middle in -- we're in the middle of a very busy period. DowDupont just reported they beat on earnings per share at $0.88 a share but they missed on revenue at 20.1 billion versus an estimate of 20.9 billion, how would you characterize the earnings season so far, and what does that telling you about the backdrop?

BASENESE: Look, it's a mixed bag. We haven't really seen a huge beat rate on the earnings on the bottomline. I think the top like is being less impressive. So, on DuPont's report, it's epitomizing it, right? We're seeing some earnings growth but the demand on the top line is not there. So, look, I think we're in more of a stock picker's market. It points more towards active management and really trying to find those companies that are overcoming the China hangover that are finding strength despite some pockets of weakness.

BARTIROMO: How much of a focus is economic data for you? We've got the January job's report out Friday morning, tomorrow morning 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We are expecting 165,000 jobs added to the economy last month with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.9 percent. We had the ADP numbers earlier this week, they were strong.

BASENESE: Yes. No, they're very strong. Look, I'm a tech guy first, but I'd love to see tailwinds and the job's market supporting that. I think many people thought we might have a slowdown just because of the government shutdown, and just that extreme volatility in December that might have put some businesses a little uneasy about hiring. But the ADP Report like you mentioned this week, pointing to just continued strength, so another positive for the markets.

BARTIROMO: It sounds like you're thinking we're going to get a pretty good year, 2019.

BASENESE: As of now -- look, a lot can change, I mean, look what happened in December. So, I don't want to go on the record and say it's a -- it's a foregone conclusion 2019 is going to be great, but --

BARTIROMO: But you've got put money to work either way, so what do you do?

RICHARDSON: Totally inaccurate. Totally -- no.

BARTIROMO: Open borders? Wait, which one?

RICHARDSON: You know, this is -- this is --

BARTIROMO: What's inaccurate, governor?

RICHARDSON: This is ridiculous. No. Open borders? That's ridiculous. All of that is ridiculous. There should be serious negotiations right now. And it's not happening. And the President's not helping with these tweets.

RICHARDSON: You know the thing is? I mean I know that a lot of your colleagues say that they're for border security, but they didn't vote for Kate's law, they didn't vote to end Sanctuary Cities, they didn't vote for a border wall, so how can you say you're for border security when you actually haven't done so in terms of your voting record?

RICHARDSON: Well, look at what the Democrats are proposing for this showdown, one, more border patrol agents, two, more Coast Guard assistance, three, more drones, four, all kinds of new technologies that will work.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think they voted for a wall before?

RICHARDSON: A border wall is not going to work.

BARTIROMO: Why do you think they vote --

RICHARDSON: It doesn't work.

BARTIROMO: Why did Nancy Pelosi vote for a wall before?

RICHARDSON: That -- perhaps that wall she voted for on her border. All I'm saying is --

BARTIROMO: But why is that not immoral?

RICHARDSON: -- let's make this work. Let's make this work.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

RICHARDSON: But not threaten border shutdowns, not end the government working, that's what the President is saying.

BARTIROMO: Bill Richardson --

RICHARDSON: "If I don't get my way, I'm going to shut down the government.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

RICHARDSON: All right. All right.

BARTIROMO: Bill Richardson joining us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Facebook reporting a record profit. The stock is soaring this morning. Joining me now the host of "VARNEY & CO." Stuart Varney to weigh in. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi, good morning, Maria. You know, I wasn't looking at that profit report for the profit number or profit margin, I was looking at it to see how many active monthly users they've got. When I saw that number come over, 2.7 billion, I figured that Facebook was out of the woods. Think of all the scandal, all the bad publicity, all the privacy questions that have been leveled against Facebook in the last, what, year or six months? It--- it's not touched their business. I thought that the scandal may have reduced the number of monthly users, active users on the -- on the base, but it didn't. They've actually increased. And that's why I think Facebook is up so much this morning, 11 percent gain for a stock like that is absolutely enormous. My bottom line is this, all the scandal did not touch its financial business. The heart of its business was not touched by all the political goings-on around it. Facebook, 167. Who would have thought?

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's pretty incredible. You're right, Stu.

VARNEY: It really is.

BARTIROMO: Great analysis. I know you have a lot more in about 12 minutes' time.

VARNEY: Sure.

BARTIROMO: So we'll see you top of the hour.

VARNEY: You got it.

BARTIROMO: Thank so much. "Varney & Co." begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, a raging fire tears through Newark Airport, torching at least a dozen cars. We've got all the details. We will take you there. Then Goodell speaks out, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell breaks his silence on the controversial no call that knocked The Saints off the path of the Super Bowl. All next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news. More than a dozen cars catching fire at Newark Liberty International Airport this morning. Lauren Simonetti with headlines now. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi, Maria. The fire broke out in a parking lot around 7:00 a.m. this morning. Firefighters quickly responded. They put it out amid this freezing cold temperatures, flights are not affected, the cause of the fire under investigation.

Apple is reportedly planning 3-D cameras for its 2020 iPhone. Bloomberg reporting that Apple wants to launch the new 3-D camera as soon as they can as it moves deeper into augmented reality. Maybe you'll spend a lot of for that phone. I don't know. Shares looking this morning, up two-thirds of one percent.

Former Starbucks CEO impossible 2020 independent hopeful Howard Schultz says he's surprised being attacked for being rich.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HOWARD SCHULTZ, FORMER STARBUCKS CEO: This interesting phenomenon in the last week or so where I have this moniker now of being, you know, I'm a billionaire and so don't trust him because he's a successful person. I grew up literally in public housing in the projects. And I have succeeded in America I always thought that was something to be celebrated, that my success should not be something that is punitive. My success is living proof of the promise of the country. I can't find the answers why people are all of a sudden chastising me for being successful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Many Democrats are caffeinated against him, criticizing Schultz over his potential presidential run saying he will only help to reelect President Trump. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Listen, I'm looking at this. We are celebrating throwback Thursday this morning. We're showing you our best looks from the 80s, that's next stay, with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: It is throwback Thursdays here on the MORNINGS WITH MARIA set. Here's me from circa 19857. I was working in a photo lab, printing pictures.

MCDOWELL: I told you, Sophia Loren.

BARTIROMO: Care-free days. I don't even know that I was thinking about what stock to buy. I don't even know that I was thinking about me being a journalist.

MCDOWELL: Look at this complexion. This is even before -- well, it's before the internet really, but the no photo filters, you're glowing.

BARTIROMO: Let's see yours, Dagen McDowell. Come on.

MCDOWELL: No. I told you I'm really ugly.

BARTIROMO: Throwback Thursday.

MCDOWELL: Do they have it?

BARTIROMO: Wait, Governor Huckabee with his daughter. OK.

MCDOWELL: Oh, there I am.

BARTIROMO: There's Dagen.

HUCKABEE: There's Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I jumped in a swimming pool fully clothed right after that was taken. And I am not making that up.

BARTIROMO: And this is about 1980 --

MCDOWELL: 88.

BARTIROMO: 88.

MCDOWELL: It was the summer after my freshman year in college.

BARTIROMO: Governor Huckabee with your daughter, White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders. Aww. That is too cute.

HUCKABEE: That's about 1984. She was about two years old at that time. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So great. That's beautiful shot. And lastly, the photo James Freeman gave us.

FREEMAN: Yes, so this is me. You asked for a throwback --

BARTIROMO: Come on, James.

FREEMAN: -- Thursday photo of James Freeman. Apparently, this is the Reverend James Freeman. Apparently, he was an outstanding preacher. Governor, you might want to grade his performance, I don't know, but very influential in Boston. My kids ran across this a few weeks ago while sightseeing, so --

BARTIROMO: You couldn't find any shots of yourself as a baby.

FREEMAN: I -- well, I did -- if you give me more time, I'll try and find it. But I told you, I never went with the mullet. My great regret, so I don't know if we're going to have really fun 80s photos, but I'll do my best.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday.

FREEMAN: OK. Deal.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday, we'll do another throwback Thursday, how's that?

MCDOWELL: OK. You got to let me know in advance and so we I can dig some photos out of my -- well --

BARTIROMO: All right. So we have a week.

MCDOWELL: -- drawer.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, we didn't even talk about this. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell spoke publicly for the first time about that blatant non-call in the NFC Championship game. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER GOODELL, NFL COMMISSIONER: Technology is not going to solve all those issues. The game is not officiated by robots. It's not going to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: God, you're lucky the game has been great in the last year, Goodell, because you're terrible and people hate you. No more than --

BARTIROMO: Oh, God.

MCDOWELL: No, people hate him.

BARTIROMO: Tell us how you really feel.

HUCKABEE: What do you really think?

MCDOWELL: No, let's call some folks down in New Orleans and ask them how they feel. Anyway. No, they do, people don't -- excuse me, they don't like him.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day everybody. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away. Hey, you've got a neat throwback Thursday shots you want to share, Stu?

END

Paul Awarded Over $580K; Goodell on Blow Call; Deadly Polar Vortex2019-01-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:35ZLexisNexisStocks Surge After Fed Says It Will Be Patient Raising Rates; Amazon Super Bowl Ad; G.M. Plants Halt Production; NJ Paper Plant Destroyed; Schultz Takes On Trump; Vets Suing 3M; G.E. Rev Beats Estimates: $33.28 Billion (ACT) Versus $32.61 Billion (EST); Mueller Report Decision; Daily Caller: Trump Says He Will Leave the Mueller Report Decision to DOJ; Sen. Paul Awarded Over $580K; Goodell on Blow Call; Deadly Polar VortexLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies, thank you so much. And good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday, it is Thursday, January 31st. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the east coast. Busy morning on earnings this morning. We will hear from UPS, General Electric, both ahead of the open this morning. Big technology still in focus, Facebook reporting last night after the close, big quarter for Facebook, Amazon will be the one to watch today after the close tonight.

Meanwhile, the arctic blast turns deadly. Temperatures across the Midwest falling to their lowest levels in decades. We will take you to the Minneapolis region this morning, where the negative 24 degrees is having a real impact. The push to tax the wealthy, J.P. Morgan's CEO Jamie Dimon reportedly saying that the richest Americans can afford to pay higher taxes, but there's a catch. Then, Roger Goodell breaking his silence, what he said about the infamous no-call during the NFC championship game coming up later this hour. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

And we kick it off with markets this morning. Let's check Futures showing a mixed opening this morning after a huge day yesterday. Dow Industrials expected to be down 15 points at the open. The S&P and the NASDAQ up fractionally right now after a solid day of trading that all stock surged yesterday after the Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell signaled that the Central Bank may pause interest rate hikes for now. The Fed on pause.

Technology giant, Facebook, meanwhile also reporting fourth-quarter earnings. Look at that market yesterday, up 434 points at the close, it was a big day. And that, by the way, was off of the highs of the day after the Fed meeting. Facebook earnings beat expectations posting a record profit for what has been a difficult year for the social media company. Take a look at Facebook shares this morning, up 11-1/3 percent right now, 167 and change. Earnings season rolling on today with Amazon reporting after the bell tonight. Take a look at all the names that we're expecting today in what is really the busiest week -- one of the busiest weeks for the fourth quarter.

Here now, the founder of Disruptive Technology Research Lou Basenese. Lou, it's good to see you.

LOU BASENESE, FOUNDER, DISRUPTIVE TECH RESEARCH: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: First, on Facebook, your reaction to the quarter last night.

BASENESE: Look, I am just shocked and disappointed in this rally. I mean, I think this is really putting forward that investors and management favor profit growth over ethics. I mean, look, this week, we had -- I think one of the -- just biggest disappointments in privacy protection with the Facebook research app. I mean, just total disregard for Apple's wishes, total disregard for teenage users' privacy, and yet, investors are cheering profit growth. So, look, I can't argue with the fundamental numbers. I mean, the stock is reasonably valued, you've seen growth come back in the U.S. as the key market, and advertisers just don't have any other outlet, any other alternative to reach 2 billion potential viewers. So, it's one of those things, it's a toxic investment, to me. So, I --

BARTIROMO: So, you wouldn't touch it?

BASENESE: I wouldn't touch it. Look, I think there's a lot of risk embedded there. What's the next privacy scandal that's going to come to light? Facebook, over the years, has really made more excuses than changes to what they're doing.

BARTIROMO: All right, let's talk about the Fed -- the Fed essentially on hold yesterday saying it's on hold, indicating that more dovish stance when it comes to interest rate hikes. What was your reaction to what the Fed said in particular also saying that the balance sheet unwind is also a way that they could pull back and perhaps stop the 50 billion sales a month.

BASENESE: Yes, I don't think I can remember in my lifetime just a more dramatic turn of sentiment at the Fed. I mean, in October, they were saying that we're a long way from neutral and now, yesterday's statement said that we're within range. I mean, they went from playing hardball with the President to playing patty cake, and you know, investors love that. So, you know, more easy monetary policy coming. I think they gave themselves some flexibility on unwinding the balance sheet. Not that they didn't say that they were going to be data dependent before, but now they just made that much more of a point to communicate to the markets that there's not going to be a fast and hard unwind.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, we were sort of expecting this in the last couple of months, that's for sure. But would this be a signal for you to put new money to work in stocks?

BASENESE: I think absolutely. Look, the Fed has been supportive of stock prices. I mean, there's a lot of people that would argue this bull market would not be around without the Fed. So, with the Fed being very accommodative, I think it's time to come back into the market, we're going to see that. You've seen a dramatic reversal even in the more speculative areas of the market. And I think I pointed out before in another appearance that the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index, tremendous bounce off the lows, up almost 20 percent, and about to breakthrough to the 200-day moving average. So, yes, it's risk on again. At least to the Fed.

BARTIROMO: All right. Two more things on stocks, we've got earnings, obviously, the middle in -- we're in the middle of a very busy period. DowDupont just reported they beat on earnings per share at $0.88 a share but they missed on revenue at 20.1 billion versus an estimate of 20.9 billion, how would you characterize the earnings season so far, and what does that telling you about the backdrop?

BASENESE: Look, it's a mixed bag. We haven't really seen a huge beat rate on the earnings on the bottomline. I think the top like is being less impressive. So, on DuPont's report, it's epitomizing it, right? We're seeing some earnings growth but the demand on the top line is not there. So, look, I think we're in more of a stock picker's market. It points more towards active management and really trying to find those companies that are overcoming the China hangover that are finding strength despite some pockets of weakness.

BARTIROMO: How much of a focus is economic data for you? We've got the January job's report out Friday morning, tomorrow morning 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We are expecting 165,000 jobs added to the economy last month with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.9 percent. We had the ADP numbers earlier this week, they were strong.

BASENESE: Yes. No, they're very strong. Look, I'm a tech guy first, but I'd love to see tailwinds and the job's market supporting that. I think many people thought we might have a slowdown just because of the government shutdown, and just that extreme volatility in December that might have put some businesses a little uneasy about hiring. But the ADP Report like you mentioned this week, pointing to just continued strength, so another positive for the markets.

BARTIROMO: It sounds like you're thinking we're going to get a pretty good year, 2019.

BASENESE: As of now -- look, a lot can change, I mean, look what happened in December. So, I don't want to go on the record and say it's a -- it's a foregone conclusion 2019 is going to be great, but --

BARTIROMO: But you've got put money to work either way, so what do you do?

BASENESE: I think -- I put money to work. Look, I like the semiconductor industry particularly companies like NXP, really undervalued at about 11 times earnings. And the chipmakers are going to make this world go, from here into the future. About a trillion semiconductors shipped last year. They go into every big growth trend that you can think of.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I guess. I mean, even more so with 5G on the way. Lou, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

BASENESE: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Lou Basanese joining us. Make sure you tune in tomorrow morning. We'll be bringing you live coverage of the January job's report beginning at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. We've got our "JOBS IN AMERICA" special where we identify where the jobs are right now. Meanwhile, Amazon earnings after the bell, the company poking fun in its own Alexa devices for going haywire in this year's Super Bowl ad. Dagen McDowell, good morning to you. Your take on that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I love Super Bowl ads, and Amazon is advertising during the big game for the fourth straight year, two spots including part of this one, we're going to show you a 90-second spot with some popular names. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: But trust me, there are a lot of fails.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Like what?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Like --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Alexa, play my podcast.

ALEXA: When you heard that, did that surprise (INAUDIBLE) that seems exciting.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We need an Alexa dog collar. Four dogs.

ALEXA: Ordering dog food, ordering dog food.

HARRISON FORD, ACTOR: You can bark all you want, I'm not paying for any more dog food.

ALEXA: Ordering gravy. Ordering sausages.

FORD: Hey, you better cancel that order.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Alexa hot tub sucked.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Alexa, play music. OK.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

I thought that the scandal may have reduced the number of monthly users, active users on the -- on the base, but it didn't. They've actually increased. And that's why I think Facebook is up so much this morning, 11 percent gain for a stock like that is absolutely enormous. My bottom line is this, all the scandal did not touch its financial business. The heart of its business was not touched by all the political goings-on around it. Facebook, 167. Who would have thought?

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's pretty incredible. You're right, Stu.

VARNEY: It really is.

BARTIROMO: Great analysis. I know you have a lot more in about 12 minutes' time.

VARNEY: Sure.

BARTIROMO: So we'll see you top of the hour.

VARNEY: You got it.

BARTIROMO: Thank so much. "Varney & Co." begins top of the hour, 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, a raging fire tears through Newark Airport, torching at least a dozen cars. We've got all the details. We will take you there. Then Goodell speaks out, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell breaks his silence on the controversial no call that knocked The Saints off the path of the Super Bowl. All next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news. More than a dozen cars catching fire at Newark Liberty International Airport this morning. Lauren Simonetti with headlines now. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi, Maria. The fire broke out in a parking lot around 7:00 a.m. this morning. Firefighters quickly responded. They put it out amid this freezing cold temperatures, flights are not affected, the cause of the fire under investigation.

Apple is reportedly planning 3-D cameras for its 2020 iPhone. Bloomberg reporting that Apple wants to launch the new 3-D camera as soon as they can as it moves deeper into augmented reality. Maybe you'll spend a lot of for that phone. I don't know. Shares looking this morning, up two-thirds of one percent.

Former Starbucks CEO impossible 2020 independent hopeful Howard Schultz says he's surprised being attacked for being rich.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HOWARD SCHULTZ, FORMER STARBUCKS CEO: This interesting phenomenon in the last week or so where I have this moniker now of being, you know, I'm a billionaire and so don't trust him because he's a successful person. I grew up literally in public housing in the projects. And I have succeeded in America I always thought that was something to be celebrated, that my success should not be something that is punitive. My success is living proof of the promise of the country. I can't find the answers why people are all of a sudden chastising me for being successful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Many Democrats are caffeinated against him, criticizing Schultz over his potential presidential run saying he will only help to reelect President Trump. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Listen, I'm looking at this. We are celebrating throwback Thursday this morning. We're showing you our best looks from the 80s, that's next stay, with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: It is throwback Thursdays here on the MORNINGS WITH MARIA set. Here's me from circa 19857. I was working in a photo lab, printing pictures.

MCDOWELL: I told you, Sophia Loren.

BARTIROMO: Care-free days. I don't even know that I was thinking about what stock to buy. I don't even know that I was thinking about me being a journalist.

MCDOWELL: Look at this complexion. This is even before -- well, it's before the internet really, but the no photo filters, you're glowing.

BARTIROMO: Let's see yours, Dagen McDowell. Come on.

MCDOWELL: No. I told you I'm really ugly.

BARTIROMO: Throwback Thursday.

MCDOWELL: Do they have it?

BARTIROMO: Wait, Governor Huckabee with his daughter. OK.

MCDOWELL: Oh, there I am.

BARTIROMO: There's Dagen.

HUCKABEE: There's Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I jumped in a swimming pool fully clothed right after that was taken. And I am not making that up.

BARTIROMO: And this is about 1980 --

MCDOWELL: 88.

BARTIROMO: 88.

MCDOWELL: It was the summer after my freshman year in college.

BARTIROMO: Governor Huckabee with your daughter, White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders. Aww. That is too cute.

HUCKABEE: That's about 1984. She was about two years old at that time. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So great. That's beautiful shot. And lastly, the photo James Freeman gave us.

FREEMAN: Yes, so this is me. You asked for a throwback --

BARTIROMO: Come on, James.

FREEMAN: -- Thursday photo of James Freeman. Apparently, this is the Reverend James Freeman. Apparently, he was an outstanding preacher. Governor, you might want to grade his performance, I don't know, but very influential in Boston. My kids ran across this a few weeks ago while sightseeing, so --

BARTIROMO: You couldn't find any shots of yourself as a baby.

FREEMAN: I -- well, I did -- if you give me more time, I'll try and find it. But I told you, I never went with the mullet. My great regret, so I don't know if we're going to have really fun 80s photos, but I'll do my best.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday.

FREEMAN: OK. Deal.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday, we'll do another throwback Thursday, how's that?

MCDOWELL: OK. You got to let me know in advance and so we I can dig some photos out of my -- well --

BARTIROMO: All right. So we have a week.

MCDOWELL: -- drawer.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, we didn't even talk about this. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell spoke publicly for the first time about that blatant non-call in the NFC Championship game. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER GOODELL, NFL COMMISSIONER: Technology is not going to solve all those issues. The game is not officiated by robots. It's not going to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: God, you're lucky the game has been great in the last year, Goodell, because you're terrible and people hate you. No more than --

BARTIROMO: Oh, God.

MCDOWELL: No, people hate him.

BARTIROMO: Tell us how you really feel.

HUCKABEE: What do you really think?

MCDOWELL: No, let's call some folks down in New Orleans and ask them how they feel. Anyway. No, they do, people don't -- excuse me, they don't like him.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day everybody. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away. Hey, you've got a neat throwback Thursday shots you want to share, Stu?

END

Plants Halt Production; NJ Paper Plant Destroyed; Schultz Takes On Trump; Vets Suing 3M; G.E. Rev Beats Estimates: $33.28 Billion (ACT) Versus $32.61 Billion (EST); Mueller Report Decision; Daily Caller: Trump Says He Will Leave the Mueller Report Decision to DOJ; Sen. Paul Awarded Over $580K; Goodell on Blow Call; Deadly Polar Vortex2019-01-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks Surge After Fed Says It Will Be Patient Raising Rates; Amazon Super Bowl Ad; G.M. Plants Halt Production; NJ Paper Plant Destroyed; Schultz Takes On Trump; Vets Suing 3M; G.E. Rev Beats Estimates: $33.28 Billion (ACT) Versus $32.61 Billion (EST); Mueller Report Decision; Daily Caller: Trump Says He Will Leave the Mueller Report Decision to DOJ; Sen. Paul Awarded Over $580K; Goodell on Blow Call; Deadly Polar VortexLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies, thank you so much. And good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday, it is Thursday, January 31st. Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the east coast. Busy morning on earnings this morning. We will hear from UPS, General Electric, both ahead of the open this morning. Big technology still in focus, Facebook reporting last night after the close, big quarter for Facebook, Amazon will be the one to watch today after the close tonight.

Meanwhile, the arctic blast turns deadly. Temperatures across the Midwest falling to their lowest levels in decades. We will take you to the Minneapolis region this morning, where the negative 24 degrees is having a real impact. The push to tax the wealthy, J.P. Morgan's CEO Jamie Dimon reportedly saying that the richest Americans can afford to pay higher taxes, but there's a catch. Then, Roger Goodell breaking his silence, what he said about the infamous no-call during the NFC championship game coming up later this hour. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

And we kick it off with markets this morning. Let's check Futures showing a mixed opening this morning after a huge day yesterday. Dow Industrials expected to be down 15 points at the open. The S&P and the NASDAQ up fractionally right now after a solid day of trading that all stock surged yesterday after the Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell signaled that the Central Bank may pause interest rate hikes for now. The Fed on pause.

Technology giant, Facebook, meanwhile also reporting fourth-quarter earnings. Look at that market yesterday, up 434 points at the close, it was a big day. And that, by the way, was off of the highs of the day after the Fed meeting. Facebook earnings beat expectations posting a record profit for what has been a difficult year for the social media company. Take a look at Facebook shares this morning, up 11-1/3 percent right now, 167 and change. Earnings season rolling on today with Amazon reporting after the bell tonight. Take a look at all the names that we're expecting today in what is really the busiest week -- one of the busiest weeks for the fourth quarter.

Here now, the founder of Disruptive Technology Research Lou Basenese. Lou, it's good to see you.

LOU BASENESE, FOUNDER, DISRUPTIVE TECH RESEARCH: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: First, on Facebook, your reaction to the quarter last night.

BASENESE: Look, I am just shocked and disappointed in this rally. I mean, I think this is really putting forward that investors and management favor profit growth over ethics. I mean, look, this week, we had -- I think one of the -- just biggest disappointments in privacy protection with the Facebook research app. I mean, just total disregard for Apple's wishes, total disregard for teenage users' privacy, and yet, investors are cheering profit growth. So, look, I can't argue with the fundamental numbers. I mean, the stock is reasonably valued, you've seen growth come back in the U.S. as the key market, and advertisers just don't have any other outlet, any other alternative to reach 2 billion potential viewers. So, it's one of those things, it's a toxic investment, to me. So, I --

BARTIROMO: So, you wouldn't touch it?

BASENESE: I wouldn't touch it. Look, I think there's a lot of risk embedded there. What's the next privacy scandal that's going to come to light? Facebook, over the years, has really made more excuses than changes to what they're doing.

BARTIROMO: All right, let's talk about the Fed -- the Fed essentially on hold yesterday saying it's on hold, indicating that more dovish stance when it comes to interest rate hikes. What was your reaction to what the Fed said in particular also saying that the balance sheet unwind is also a way that they could pull back and perhaps stop the 50 billion sales a month.

BASENESE: Yes, I don't think I can remember in my lifetime just a more dramatic turn of sentiment at the Fed. I mean, in October, they were saying that we're a long way from neutral and now, yesterday's statement said that we're within range. I mean, they went from playing hardball with the President to playing patty cake, and you know, investors love that. So, you know, more easy monetary policy coming. I think they gave themselves some flexibility on unwinding the balance sheet. Not that they didn't say that they were going to be data dependent before, but now they just made that much more of a point to communicate to the markets that there's not going to be a fast and hard unwind.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, we were sort of expecting this in the last couple of months, that's for sure. But would this be a signal for you to put new money to work in stocks?

BASENESE: I think absolutely. Look, the Fed has been supportive of stock prices. I mean, there's a lot of people that would argue this bull market would not be around without the Fed. So, with the Fed being very accommodative, I think it's time to come back into the market, we're going to see that. You've seen a dramatic reversal even in the more speculative areas of the market. And I think I pointed out before in another appearance that the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index, tremendous bounce off the lows, up almost 20 percent, and about to breakthrough to the 200-day moving average. So, yes, it's risk on again. At least to the Fed.

BARTIROMO: All right. Two more things on stocks, we've got earnings, obviously, the middle in -- we're in the middle of a very busy period. DowDupont just reported they beat on earnings per share at $0.88 a share but they missed on revenue at 20.1 billion versus an estimate of 20.9 billion, how would you characterize the earnings season so far, and what does that telling you about the backdrop?

BASENESE: Look, it's a mixed bag. We haven't really seen a huge beat rate on the earnings on the bottomline. I think the top like is being less impressive. So, on DuPont's report, it's epitomizing it, right? We're seeing some earnings growth but the demand on the top line is not there. So, look, I think we're in more of a stock picker's market. It points more towards active management and really trying to find those companies that are overcoming the China hangover that are finding strength despite some pockets of weakness.

BARTIROMO: How much of a focus is economic data for you? We've got the January job's report out Friday morning, tomorrow morning 8:30 a.m. Eastern. We are expecting 165,000 jobs added to the economy last month with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.9 percent. We had the ADP numbers earlier this week, they were strong.

BASENESE: Yes. No, they're very strong. Look, I'm a tech guy first, but I'd love to see tailwinds and the job's market supporting that. I think many people thought we might have a slowdown just because of the government shutdown, and just that extreme volatility in December that might have put some businesses a little uneasy about hiring. But the ADP Report like you mentioned this week, pointing to just continued strength, so another positive for the markets.

BARTIROMO: It sounds like you're thinking we're going to get a pretty good year, 2019.

BASENESE: As of now -- look, a lot can change, I mean, look what happened in December. So, I don't want to go on the record and say it's a -- it's a foregone conclusion 2019 is going to be great, but --

BARTIROMO: But you've got put money to work either way, so what do you do?

BASENESE: I think -- I put money to work. Look, I like the semiconductor industry particularly companies like NXP, really undervalued at about 11 times earnings. And the chipmakers are going to make this world go, from here into the future. About a trillion semiconductors shipped last year. They go into every big growth trend that you can think of.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I guess. I mean, even more so with 5G on the way. Lou, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much.

BASENESE: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Lou Basanese joining us. Make sure you tune in tomorrow morning. We'll be bringing you live coverage of the January job's report beginning at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. We've got our "JOBS IN AMERICA" special where we identify where the jobs are right now. Meanwhile, Amazon earnings after the bell, the company poking fun in its own Alexa devices for going haywire in this year's Super Bowl ad. Dagen McDowell, good morning to you. Your take on that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I love Super Bowl ads, and Amazon is advertising during the big game for the fourth straight year, two spots including part of this one, we're going to show you a 90-second spot with some popular names. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: But trust me, there are a lot of fails.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Like what?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Like --

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Alexa, play my podcast.

ALEXA: When you heard that, did that surprise (INAUDIBLE) that seems exciting.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We need an Alexa dog collar. Four dogs.

ALEXA: Ordering dog food, ordering dog food.

HARRISON FORD, ACTOR: You can bark all you want, I'm not paying for any more dog food.

ALEXA: Ordering gravy. Ordering sausages.

FORD: Hey, you better cancel that order.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Alexa hot tub sucked.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Alexa, play music. OK.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: So, that's just a little bit of a snippet of that ad, Maria. Harrison Ford, Forest Whitaker among the well-known celebrities in that ad. Just that 90-second spot will set Amazon back more than $15 million, $5 million per 30-second spot for Super Bowl ads. This is a little ironic because Amazon has really ramped up spending on national television advertising, you know, a real innovator in terms of online advertising, streaming video, but Amazon spends every year now on national T.V. advertising, $680 million a year, that's about doubled from 2015. It spends more than Toyota and even McDonalds every year on T.V. ads. Why the Super Bowl? Do we even need to tell you, more than 100 million people are going to watch this, and it has a very diverse viewing base, about 47 percent of the viewers last year ladies.

BARTIROMO: Do we watch for the commercials or do we watch for the game?

MCDOWELL: The game. The game always.

BARTIROMO: Both, I'm both. That commercial really resonated though with the dog ordering everything.

MCDOWELL: And who doesn't love Harrison Ford.

BARTIROMO: Love it. Love it. Thank you. We will keep watching that.

Meanwhile, a deadly polar vortex sweeping through the Midwest. Lauren Simonetti with the details on that. Lauren, it is cold there.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: It is cold. And speaking of Amazon, they're not delivering in some Midwest cities because it is so cold, but at least -- this is deadly, at least nine people have died in causes related to the historic -- this historic arctic blast when 18-year-old college student found dead outside of a building on the University of Iowa campus. Windchill temperatures falling to minus 50 degrees in Chicago. And near minus 70 across parts of the upper Midwest.

According to FlightAware, since yesterday, there have been more than 21,000 flight delays and more than 6,000 cancellations. Seven people stranded in an ice shack, safely rescued without injuries despite brutally cold temperatures in Wisconsin. Former Starbucks CEO impossible 2020 independent hopeful Howard Schultz says he's surprised being attacked for being rich.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HOWARD SCHULTZ, FORMER STARBUCKS CEO: This interesting phenomenon in the last week or so where I have this moniker now of being, you know, I'm a billionaire and so don't trust him because he's a successful person. I grew up literally in public housing in the projects. And I have succeeded in America I always thought that was something to be celebrated, that my success should not be something that is punitive. My success is living proof of the promise of the country. I can't find the answers why people are all of a sudden chastising me for being successful.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: Many Democrats are caffeinated against him, criticizing Schultz over his potential presidential run saying he will only help to reelect President Trump. Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Listen, I'm looking at this. We are celebrating throwback Thursday this morning. We're showing you our best looks from the 80s, that's next stay, with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: It is throwback Thursdays here on the MORNINGS WITH MARIA set. Here's me from circa 19857. I was working in a photo lab, printing pictures.

MCDOWELL: I told you, Sophia Loren.

BARTIROMO: Care-free days. I don't even know that I was thinking about what stock to buy. I don't even know that I was thinking about me being a journalist.

MCDOWELL: Look at this complexion. This is even before -- well, it's before the internet really, but the no photo filters, you're glowing.

BARTIROMO: Let's see yours, Dagen McDowell. Come on.

MCDOWELL: No. I told you I'm really ugly.

BARTIROMO: Throwback Thursday.

MCDOWELL: Do they have it?

BARTIROMO: Wait, Governor Huckabee with his daughter. OK.

MCDOWELL: Oh, there I am.

BARTIROMO: There's Dagen.

HUCKABEE: There's Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I jumped in a swimming pool fully clothed right after that was taken. And I am not making that up.

BARTIROMO: And this is about 1980 --

MCDOWELL: 88.

BARTIROMO: 88.

MCDOWELL: It was the summer after my freshman year in college.

BARTIROMO: Governor Huckabee with your daughter, White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders. Aww. That is too cute.

HUCKABEE: That's about 1984. She was about two years old at that time. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So great. That's beautiful shot. And lastly, the photo James Freeman gave us.

FREEMAN: Yes, so this is me. You asked for a throwback --

BARTIROMO: Come on, James.

FREEMAN: -- Thursday photo of James Freeman. Apparently, this is the Reverend James Freeman. Apparently, he was an outstanding preacher. Governor, you might want to grade his performance, I don't know, but very influential in Boston. My kids ran across this a few weeks ago while sightseeing, so --

BARTIROMO: You couldn't find any shots of yourself as a baby.

FREEMAN: I -- well, I did -- if you give me more time, I'll try and find it. But I told you, I never went with the mullet. My great regret, so I don't know if we're going to have really fun 80s photos, but I'll do my best.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday.

FREEMAN: OK. Deal.

BARTIROMO: Next Thursday, we'll do another throwback Thursday, how's that?

MCDOWELL: OK. You got to let me know in advance and so we I can dig some photos out of my -- well --

BARTIROMO: All right. So we have a week.

MCDOWELL: -- drawer.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, we didn't even talk about this. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell spoke publicly for the first time about that blatant non-call in the NFC Championship game. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGER GOODELL, NFL COMMISSIONER: Technology is not going to solve all those issues. The game is not officiated by robots. It's not going to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: God, you're lucky the game has been great in the last year, Goodell, because you're terrible and people hate you. No more than --

BARTIROMO: Oh, God.

MCDOWELL: No, people hate him.

BARTIROMO: Tell us how you really feel.

HUCKABEE: What do you really think?

MCDOWELL: No, let's call some folks down in New Orleans and ask them how they feel. Anyway. No, they do, people don't -- excuse me, they don't like him.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day everybody. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away. Hey, you've got a neat throwback Thursday shots you want to share, Stu?

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60TM-6RP1-JCMN-Y4WC-00000-00Stocks swing as Wall Street's tumultuous week comes to close2020-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks swing as Wall Street's tumultuous week comes to close

Sep 11, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) In this July 9, 2020 file photo, signage is shown at the New York Stock Exchange, in New York. Stocks are rising modestly in early trading on Wall Street as a bumpy, holiday-shortened week of trading winds down. The S&P 500 was up 0.4% in the early going Friday, Sept. 11. (AP Photo/Mark Lennihan, File)NEW YORK (AP) — Stocks keep swinging between gains and losses on Wall Street Friday, as a tumultuous week of abrupt stops and starts comes to a close.

The S&P 500 was down 0.1% in afternoon trading, after a roller-coaster day where it careened from a gain of 0.9% to an equivalent loss. Momentum has been lightning-quick to shift on Wall Street recently, and a similar morning gain for the S&P 500 on Thursday gave way to a 1.8% loss for its fourth drop in five days. The Nasdaq composite, which includes many of the superstar tech stocks that have been the focus of the market's recent selling, was down 0.7% after flip-flopping earlier between gains and losses. It has swung at least 1.3% in each of the last five days, with four of those down. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 105 points, or 0.4%, at 27,639, as of 2:46 p.m. Eastern time. Analysts expect swings to continue to rattle markets for weeks, if not months, as investors wait for more clarity on several key issues. At the head of the list of uncertainties, for now at least, is what to do with Big Tech stocks. Apple, Amazon and others soared through the pandemic as their businesses boomed despite the recession. The coronavirus accelerated a shift to online life that's benefited them, and a pile-on of investors into Big Tech sent their share prices soaring to levels that critics said were simply too high. Apple had a nearly irrepressible run this summer where it rose in 13 out of 14 weeks. Zoom Video Communications surged above $450 per share earlier this month after starting the year at less than $70. That all came to an abrupt halt last week. Worries that the stocks had gotten overheated helped send the S&P 500 to its worst three-day run in nearly three months, and the Nasdaq composite slid 10%. Tech stocks and the market broadly recovered a bit on Wednesday, and they seemed to regain their stride Thursday morning, only for an afternoon swoon to batter them again. (Ad) Access our premier research platform that includes MarketBeat Daily Premium, portfolio monitoring tools, stock screeners, research tools, a real-time news feed, email and SMS alerts, the MarketBeat Idea Engine, proprietary brokerage rankings, extended data export tools and much more. On Friday, tech stocks again swung from gains to losses. The fluctuations came even after Oracle reported stronger profit for its latest quarter than analysts expected. It also gave a forecast for profits in the current quarter that topped Wall Street's expectations. After leaping as much as 7.9% in the morning, its stock was virtually flat. Big Tech and the high-growth area of the stock market "just got ahead of itself,' said Jason Pride, chief investment officer of private wealth at Glenmede. 'It doesn't matter how it got there, it matters that it got there and now we're kind of deflating that overvaluation a little bit.' The S&P 500 is on track for a loss of 2.6% this week. That would be its second weekly loss in a row, something that hasn't happened for nearly four months. After rising as much as 1.5% shortly after trading began, Apple fell back to a loss of 1.3%. Apple is on pace for a loss of 7.4% this week, which would be its worst since March, when the market was still plummeting on worries about the recession caused by the pandemic. Movements for it and other Big Tech stocks matter more than ever for broad market indexes because their immense size means they can influence the S&P 500 almost by themselves. Five Big Tech companies make up nearly 23% of the index's entire value. One big factor that remains in the stock market's favor is the Federal Reserve, which continues to pump aid into the economy. It has slashed short-term interest rates to record lows and bought up all kinds of bonds to support markets. It also said recently it will keep delivering stimulus even if inflation rises above its target level, as long as inflation had been well under it before then. A report on Friday showed that inflation remains low, though it was higher than economists expected. Consumer prices rose 1.3% in August from a year earlier, a shade above the 1.2% that investors were expecting. Following the report, the yield on the 10-year Treasury gave up an earlier gain. It was at 0.66%, down from 0.68% late Thursday. Unprecedented amounts of aid from Congress, along with the Federal Reserve, also helped the stock market halt its nearly 34% plummet in late March. But it looks less likely by the day that Congress will approve more support for the limping economy before the November elections, even though investors say such stimulus is crucial after unemployment benefits and other stimulus has expired. Senate Democrats on Thursday shot down a scaled-back package proposed by Republicans, saying it shortchanged too many needs. Investors are also worried about all the uncertainty that elections bring generally, which can result in big changes for tax laws and regulations that affect corporate profits. Concerns are likewise high about trade tensions between the United States and China, among other major economies, and whether the expectations building for a coming COVID-19 vaccine prove to be too optimistic. European stock markets made modest moves. The German DAX was close to flat, and the French CAC rose 0.2%. The FTSE 100 in London rose 0.5% after data showed the British economy recouped further lost ground during July after a swath of coronavirus restrictions on businesses were lifted. Asian markets were stronger. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.7%, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong climbed 0.8% and stocks in Shanghai added 0.8%. The Kospi in South Korea was close to flat. ___ AP Business Writer Yuri Kageyama contributed. 8 Pharmaceutical Companies Working on a Coronavirus Cure[1]We are living through interesting times. Not an hour goes by when Americans don't receive some reminder of the impact the coronavirus has on our lives. The race is on for an effective, FDA-approved treatment for the virus. Despite, vaccines being available for human trial in record time, we are many months away from having a viable vaccine. However, we may be somewhat closer in finding some antiviral treatments. And if you've watched the market closely this week, any news on that front tends to move the market in a positive direction. That brings up another truth of investing. There are some stocks that thrive from other stocks misery. And that's why we've put together this special report. If you're an investor who is looking to jump into this bear market, the pharmaceutical sector is a logical choice. A combination of big-name drug companies as well as smaller startup companies are working around the clock to develop vaccines or treatments that will target the infection caused by the novel coronavirus. View the "8 Pharmaceutical Companies Working on a Coronavirus Cure"[2]. [ 1]: https://www.marketbeat.com/slideshows/8-pharmaceutical-companies-working-on-a-coronavirus-cure/0.aspx?utm_source=BottomOfArticle&utm_medium=WebsiteInternal&utm_campaign=8-pharmaceutical-companies-working-on-a-coronavirus-cure [ 2]: https://www.marketbeat.com/slideshows/8-pharmaceutical-companies-working-on-a-coronavirus-cure/0.aspx?utm_source=BottomOfArticle&utm_medium=WebsiteInternal&utm_campaign=8-pharmaceutical-companies-working-on-a-coronavirus-cure

Apple is on pace for a loss of 7.4% this week, which would be its worst since March, when the market was still plummeting on worries about the recession caused by the pandemic. Movements for it and other Big Tech stocks matter more than ever for broad market indexes because their immense size means they can influence the S&P 500 almost by themselves. Five Big Tech companies make up nearly 23% of the index’s entire value. One big factor that remains in the stock market’s favor is the Federal Reserve, which continues to pump aid into the economy. It has slashed short-term interest rates to record lows and bought up all kinds of bonds to support markets. It also said recently it will keep delivering stimulus even if inflation rises above its target level, as long as inflation had been well under it before then. A report on Friday showed that inflationremains low, though it was higher than economists expected. Consumer prices rose 1.3% in August from a year earlier, a shade above the 1.2% that investors were expecting. Following the report, the yield on the 10-year Treasury gave up an earlier gain. It was at 0.66%, down from 0.68% late Thursday. Unprecedented amounts of aid from Congress, along with the Federal Reserve, also helped the stock market halt its nearly 34% plummet in late March. But it looks less likely by the day that Congress will approve more support for the limping economy before the November elections, even though investors say such stimulus is crucial after unemployment benefits and other stimulus has expired. Senate Democrats on Thursday shot downa scaled-back package proposed by Republicans, saying it shortchanged too many needs. Investors are also worried about all the uncertainty that elections bring generally, which can result in big changes for tax laws and regulations that affect corporate profits. Concerns are likewise high about trade tensions between the United States and China, among other major economies, and whether the expectations building for a coming COVID-19 vaccine prove to be too optimistic. European stock markets made modest moves. The German DAX was close to flat, and the French CAC rose 0.2%. The FTSE 100 in London rose 0.5% after data showed the British economy recouped further lost ground during July after a swath of coronavirus restrictions on businesses were lifted. Asian markets were stronger. Japan’s Nikkei 225 rose 0.7%, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong climbed 0.8% and stocks in Shanghai added 0.8%. The Kospi in South Korea was close to flat. ___ AP Business Writer Yuri Kageyama contributed.

urn:contentItem:60P9-FNT1-JCMN-Y2BD-00000-00Stocks tick up after Fed says rates may stay low for longer2020-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks tick up after Fed says rates may stay low for longer

Aug 27, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Marble sculptures occupy the pediment above the New York Stock Exchange signage, Tuesday Aug. 25, 2020, in New York. Stocks are pushing further into record heights on Wall Street Thursday, after the Federal Reserve made a major overhaul to its strategy, one that could keep interest rates lower for longer. (AP Photo/Bebeto Matthews)NEW YORK (AP) — Stocks are ticking further into record heights in afternoon trading on Wall Street Thursday after the Federal Reserve made a major overhaul to its strategy, one that could keep interest rates lower for longer.

The S&P 500 was 0.2% higher, after veering through jumbled trading earlier. Prices for stocks, bonds and gold made several U-turns after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave a highly anticipated speech, where he essentially said the Fed may continue efforts to prop up the economy even if inflation rises above its target level of 2%, as long as it had been weak before then. The change in the Fed's strategy is a huge deal for markets because the central bank has been the superhero repeatedly rescuing them from crises through the years, by slashing short-term interest rates and buying all kinds of bonds. The momentous announcement was widely expected on Wall Street, but trading was nevertheless erratic following it. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 198 points, or 0.7%, at 28,539, as of 1:30 p.m. Eastern time. It earlier had been up as many as 301 points. The Nasdaq composite, meanwhile, was down 0.4% after paring an earlier loss of 1%. The benchmark S&P 500 is coming off a five-day winning streak and has returned to a record level after the immense support of the Fed helped halt its free-fall earlier this year and erase its pandemic losses. Low rates often act like steroids for stocks, allowing their prices to rise faster than corporate profits. 'The era of easy money is here,' said Mike Loewengart, managing director of investment strategy at E-Trade Financial. Treasury yields fell immediately after Powell began talking, but then started bouncing up and down. The yield of the 10-year Treasury was at 0.73%, up from 0.68% late Wednesday. The 30-year yield climbed to 1.49% from 1.41%. Shorter-term Treasury yields were more subdued, with the two-year yield ticking up to 0.15% from 0.14%, and the widening gap between short- and longer-term yields could be an indication of higher expectations for the economy or inflation among investors. (Ad) Discover Why This Gold Stock Could Be The Biggest Trade of 2020 Gold was down 1.1% at $1,931.40 per ounce after initially spiking as high as $1,987.00 after Powell began talking. It mirrored the movements of the 10-year Treasury yield. Lower yields can drive demand for gold from investors seeking safety but not interested in the lower interest payments coming from bonds. Earlier in the morning, a report showed the pace of layoffs sweeping the country remains incredibly high but may be slowing. A little more than 1 million U.S. workers applied for unemployment benefits last week, which was a dip from the slightly more than 1.1 million the prior week. In another report, the government also said that the economy looks like it shrank at an annual rate of 31.7% in the spring quarter. That would be the sharpest quarterly drop on record, but it's not as bad as the Commerce Department's earlier estimate of 32.9%. Abbott Laboratories jumped 9.4% for one of the biggest gains in the S&P 500 after federal regulators gave emergency use authorization for its COVID-19 test, which can provide results in 15 minutes and will cost only $5. Stocks of companies that sorely need people feeling comfortable enough with the pandemic to get back to 'normal' life were also strong. Live Nation Entertainment rose 8.3%, Norwegian Cruise Line was up 5.3% and Alaska Air Group rallied 5.2%. Financial stocks had the biggest gain among the 11 sectors that make up the S&P 500, up 2%. A higher 10-year Treasury yield allows for higher rates on mortgages and other loans, which boosts profits for banks. JPMorgan Chase gained 3.4%, and Wells Fargo rose 2.5%. Counterbalancing those gains were losses for some big tech and internet companies, which gave back some of their slingshot, earlier gains. Apple slipped 1.3%. It's coming off four straight weeks where it rocketed up by 3% to 14.7%. In European stock markets, the German DAX lost 0.7%, and France's CAC 40 slipped 0.6%. The FTSE 100 in London was down 0.8%. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.4%, and South Korea's Kospi lost 1%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong fell 0.8%, and stocks in Shanghai rose 0.6%. Benchmark U.S. crude oil fell 0.9% to $43.00 per barrel. Brent crude, the international standard, lost 0.8% to $45.80 per barrel. Companies Mentioned in This Article Compare These Stocks[1] Add These Stocks to My Watchlist[2] 15 Healthcare Stocks that Analysts Love[3]There are more than 200 healthcare companies traded on public markets. Given the sheer number of pharmaceutical companies, medical research firms, hospital systems and other healthcare stocks, it can be hard to identify which healthcare companies are going to outperform the market. Fortunately, Wall Street's brightest minds have already done this for us. Every year, analyst issue approximately 3,000 distinct recommendations for healthcare companies. Analysts don't always get their "buy" ratings right, but it's worth taking a hard look when several analysts from different brokerages and research firm are giving "strong buy" and "buy" ratings to the same healthcare stock. This slide show lists the 15 healthcare companies that have the highest average analyst recommendations from Wall Street's equities research analysts over the last 12 months.View the "15 Healthcare Stocks that Analysts Love"[4].
