Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5PTS-BXS1-DXH2-641Y-00000-00Stocks Up On GDP Growth; Clintons In The Spotlight; Trump Blocks Some JFK Files; DOJ Lifts Gag Order On FBI Informant With Info Regarding Uranium One Deal; GOP Battle Over Taxes; IRS Targeted Conservatives; Trump Dossier Scandal; Spain To Take Control Of Catalonia After Vote For Independence2017-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisINTELLIGENCE REPORT2:00 PM ESTKeith Fitz-Gerald, Scott Martin, Paul Rosenzweig, Ned Ryun, Kimberley Strassel, Doug WeadNEWSFinancial102701cb.232Stocks Up On GDP Growth; Clintons In The Spotlight; Trump Blocks Some JFK Files; DOJ Lifts Gag Order On FBI Informant With Info Regarding Uranium One Deal; GOP Battle Over Taxes; IRS Targeted Conservatives; Trump Dossier Scandal; Spain To Take Control Of Catalonia After Vote For IndependenceTrish Regan, Nicole Petallides, Blake Burman, Connell McShane, Ashley Webster

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX NEWS HOST: Hey, Trish.

TRISH REGAN "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: Hey there, Neil. Thank you so much.

Breaking right now, everyone, we got stocks at all-time highs on strong earnings reports plus a gangbuster GDP report, that's the measurement of our overall economy showing that we grew a lot in 30 percent despite suffering two major hurricanes last month. This is some good news. I'm Trish Regan. Welcome everyone to "The Intelligence Report" on this Friday.

But the Nasdaq on pace for its biggest gain of the year during the strong tech earnings, and of course that much better than expected, economic growth, three percent. So just imagine what kind of growth we might actually get if Republicans manage to pass tax reform this year. We're on it.

Plus, three Obama era scandals in the spotlight today, the Russian's dossier, the Russian uranium deal, and now the IRS. Not a good week for President Obama and Hillary Clinton.

The "Wall Street Journal's" Kimberly Strassel is here and she is going to tell us about more bombshells that are on the way. She joins us straight ahead.

Plus, the National Archives refusing to publish some 300 records about the JFK assassination. What are they hiding? Presidential Historian Doug Wead has a theory. He has the Intel for you coming up.

But first, back to our top story here, third quarter GDP, three percent, how about it. Joining me right now, Money Map Press Chief Investment Strategist, Keith Fitz-Gerald. Our own Nicole Petallides down at floor in New York Stock Exchange.

And Keith, it's pretty good, I mean, especially considering we had a couple hurricanes in there.

KEITH FITZ-GERALD, CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, MONEY MAP PRESS: This is knock the leather off the ball time, you know, the thing that's surprising to me is that Wall Street is claiming they were surprised. Big tech has been the story, not just a story, the story, for a long time. And it will continue to change the world we live in.

REGAN: I love it. Nicole, down on the floor, are they surprised? I mean, I didn't get expectations have been tempered somewhat knowing that we clearly had gone through a lot in the past quarter with all the hurricanes and yet, a pretty stellar report.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX NEWSCORRESPONDENT: It really is. For the GDP, obviously, we saw that three percent gain. That was more than expected. You noted Hurricane Harvey and Irma. And we thought that could cut into it. But it didn't. And the big picture here is that earnings and employment have continued to boost optimism going forward and now with these tech earnings today, blowout.

REGAN: Yes. Hey, it's looking pretty good, as we said Nasdaq on pace to hit a record.

Joining me right now, Kingsview Asset Management as well CIO, Scott Martin. Scott, how much of this is attributable to just the sort of secular shift if you would, or cyclical shift rather in the economy? How much is attributable to the president?

SCOTT MARTIN, CIO, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT: I think a lot of it Trish, I mean, you guys were talking about the GDP numbers. You know a lot of pick up in GDP this quarter -- past quarter rather in this report was businesses, right? Because the consumers got hit with the hurricanes, but businesses picked up the slack, because Trish, as I like to say, gone is the -- you didn't build that message that was just delivered to the business community over and over again by President Obama.

And now it is, how can we help you, Mr. And Mrs. Businessman and woman, from D.C.? So that's why businesses are going out there confident, spending, and hiring workers, which is going to drive the S&P prices higher, because of the fact that businesses are back in this country.

REGAN: That's good stuff. I like the sound of that, Keith. It's -- you can't underestimate, Keith, how much psychology and sentiment plays? What kind of role it plays, when you're out there repealing regulations one after another. When you're out there promising lower taxes for business owners, for corporations and for individuals, what does that do to overall confidence levels?

FITZ-GERALD: It brings into play the most important word in the investment vocabulary, certainty, because CEOs want and need certainty to spend and gain customers. Customers need certainty because they know the companies that they're going to buy from are dependable, and the markets need certainty because it means there is stability.

So to me, this a win, win, win, all the way across the board. It's important political nonsense aside, because the CEOs are the ones who have to navigate this on behalf of their shareholders.

REGAN: All right, so Scott, assuming the tax reform happens, we're looking at a market that's 23,434 on the Dow right now. Where do we go?

MARTIN: Easy, Dow 25,000, Trish.

REGAN: Wow.

MARTIN: And it's probably relatively soon, you know, we'll get this, probably not. And maybe by the end of the year, maybe in 2018 which is OK, because that's about going forward that the market really wants to see. And so, I think you are easily going to see the Dow pop here as we're going in end of the year, especially given as you guys talked about. It's really amazingly strong earnings report that we're just seeing today from say, some of the Google and the Amazons of the world. Plus we got Facebook and Apple next week. So don't forget --

PETALLIDES: Yes.

MARTIN: -- we got another lift coming I think in matter of days too.

REGAN: Is that what you're hearing Nicole?

PETALLIDES: In Washington I mean, what you're seeing in Washington, you still see the ball rolling. I know we've been talking a lot about tax reform, budgets and that really still, well, on its way. Everybody bet on that. And you couple that with the great earnings this season that we've seen. And fundamentals, things have improved. I know it feels crazy in the run-up that we've seen, all-time highs, one record after another. And sure, everybody is always cautious and watching, but the feeling is still optimistic big picture, for the longer term. And what a day today with this tech earnings blowout numbers.

REGAN: Indeed. Well, thank you so much. Good to see you all, Keith, Scott, and Nicole.

The DOJ lifting a gag order everyone, on an FBI informant who could potentially blow the lid off this entire Uranium One scandal. He's going to be speaking to at least three Congressional committees who only now want to get to the bottom of why this deal was ever allowed in the first place.

Let's go to Blake Burman. He's live at the White House with the latest on this. Blake, there could be some pretty interesting stuff in his testimony.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWSCORRESPONDENT: Yes, and Trish, here is what we could tell you. That President Trump here at White House, last week, rather during a meeting made it clear that he thought it was appropriate for the Department of Justice to go forward to lift this gag order on this confidential informant. This informant was speaking with the FBI when it was looking several years back into possible bribery and extortion by Russian energy officials.

Now, that informant is going to be able to talk to Congressional investigators. That informant's attorney saying earlier today claiming that her client might be able to draw a link between the Clintons and the Uranium One deal.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VICTORIA TOENSING, ATTORNEY: We have the Clinton Foundation getting tens of millions of dollars from the same people involved in the deal. So you got it, right there, the quid pro quo. Now my client can put some meat on those bones and tell you what the Russians were saying during that time.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: OK, now it is --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The White House, though, is now forced to defend the president's involvement in this high-level decision. Here is Kellyanne Conway earlier today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO THE PRESIDENT: There are some reports that the president interfered, the president weighed in. Not unusual for a president to weigh in on any other topics, but remember, Chairman Grassley got that party started last week when he asked the Department of Justice to allow the FBI informant to speak.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Trish, one of the bottom line here is after months of this Russian investigation being put on President Trump and those within his orbit, the president and White House very clearly feel that they are now able to turn this headline around on to the other side. For example, the president tweeted out earlier today, and I quote here he said, "It is now commonly agreed after many months of costly looking that there was no collusion between Russia and Trump. Was collusion with H.C." Of course that being Hillary Clinton. Trish.

REGAN: All right. Well, we want to talk about this a little more. Blake Burman, thank you very much.

Joining me right now with his take former Deputy Secretary for Policy at the Department of Homeland Security, Paul Rosenzweig. Good, you here, Paul.

Given your background, given your background there at Homeland Security, are you surprised that a deal like this went through?

PAUL ROSENZWEIG, FMR DEPUTY SECY FOR POLICY, DHS: Not really. It was approved or rather it was not blocked by a committee -- the Committee of Foreign Investment in the United States, which actually has nine cabinet agencies sitting in it, as well as director of National Intelligence.

And in this case, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission look to the deal as well and approved it. As far as one can tell from looking at the historical record, there was really no dispute about it. And that's pretty unsurprising given that, yes, in many ways --

REGAN: Yes, OK, so but I heard and understand what you're saying here, sir, because you're saying, it's a little surprising that there is no dispute. And by the way, there was some dispute, not from members of CFIUS, the nine people that were sitting on CFIUS, including State Department and treasury, et cetera.

But there was concern, I mean, Chuck Grassley sending a note to Loretta Lynch at the time. We do know that there was an FBI investigation going into or delving into whether or not, Vladimir Putin was trying to gain undue (ph) influence in our atomic energy sector.

So by the way, when you got the Russian state energy company trying to purchase Uranium One in the United States of America, I would just think that that would send off some red flags.

ROSENZWEIG: Well, apparently not. The Nuclear Regulatory -- well, let's start with that. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved this because the ore that they purchased doesn't get exported. Uranium One didn't have an export license.

REGAN: OK.

ROSENZWEIG: And also amounted to no more than two percent --

REGAN: But it was exported?

ROSENZWEIG: No, it wasn't ma'am, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved the deal on the grounds that Uranium One did not have a --

REGAN: OK, so they approved it under assumption that it wouldn't actually be exported? But, Paul, let me share with you --

ROSENZWEIG: -- they are the ones who issues the licenses.

REGAN: It could get exported. For "The New York Times" --

ROSENWEIG: Right?

REGAN: Here's a quote "New York Times", 2015, April, where they were talking about how there was one particular individual there who was saying that --

ROSENWEIG: -- that he saw some of the yellowcake in this property going on.

(CROSSTALK)

REGAN: Yes.

ROSENWEIG: Right, he didn't say anything to that whether or not it was part -- it was owned by Uranium One and whether or not it was returned after processing right?

REGAN: If you would let me finish I will tell you exactly what "The New York Times" reported, "Asked about the commission, it confirmed that Uranium one has in fact, shipped yellowcake to Canada."

ROSENWEIG: Right.

REGAN: OK, so there you go. The commission confirmed that Uranium One has, in fact, shipped yellowcake to Canada, even though it does not have an export license. So if you try and tell me, none of their stuff left the country, well, that's just wrong.

ROSENZWEIG: Now, here's a good question for you. How much uranium does the United States consume every year?

REGAN: I don't know.

ROSENZWEIG: Fifty million-pound, roughly. How much do we make domestically?

REGAN: I don't know. Tell me.

ROSENZWEIG: About 10 percent of that, about 5 million. What's the uranium production from Uranium One?

REGAN: Twenty percent of the U.S. supply. Listen, I don't care.

ROSENZWIEG: Right. So 20 percent of --

REGAN: What you're trying to say is somehow this was OK that this deal happened. Because there are some just basic things --

(CROSSTALK)

REGAN: -- in the world. And that is that you do not allow the supply of uranium to go to the Russians. I mean, why would you allow that?

ROSENZWEIG: No. Not to go to the Russians. Not to go to the Russians. To be -- the mining contracts went -- were owned by the Russian Rosatom. But you don't know -- you've not told me anything about where the --

REGAN: Well, we just talked how the uranium went to Canada, Paul. We just talked about that and Uranium One confirming that. OK? So, you know, once it goes to Canada, I don't know where it goes from there.

But the point is that uranium is strategic resource, so why is it nobody at CFIUS, including Hillary Clinton, by the way, who is running State Department at that time even care.

Let me also ask you this Paul, why is it that that, by the way, during the Bush administration we were concerned about Russia. We really were, I mean, I cited a foreign affairs article the other day from the CFR where (INAUDIBLE) was talking about the threat of Vladimir Putin. It was the cover article back in 2007. I remember the lobster summit in Kennebunkport, which I covered in Maine.

A lot of concerns about Putin back then. And then suddenly Hillary Clinton becomes Secretary of State. And President Obama is there and suddenly we're approving deals like this while simultaneously $146 million is going to the Clinton Foundation?

ROSENZWEIG: Well, I don't know anything about the deals with the Clinton Foundation, except that most of the money went about two years before this deal was, went down.

So, you know, that -- I really don't have any information about that. What I do know is that CFIUS committee is charged with examining whether or not there is a --

REGAN: OK.

ROSENZWEIG: -- national security concern and they determined that there was not. And the reason there's not is because two percent of the U.S.'s uranium production is not a material concern to the United --

REGAN: That tells me that they're either incompetent or something else is going on, because uranium is --

ROSENZWEIG: No, I think they're exercising their best judgment, that you're second-guessing.

REGAN: -- should be giving that to a Russian state-controlled company.

ROSENZWEIG: Look, I think Hillary is liar in most instances. I spent most of my life trying to prosecute her, right, with the Whitewater investigation. So I'm not one to give her any credit at all. But when a committee of United States that is mostly run by career bureaucrats says that there's no problem, you know, to try and hang that on her without the least bit of evidence that she had any knowledge of it is kind of frivolous.

REGAN: -- because you know, it wasn't just Hillary Clinton. These were all Clintonites, actually, if you look at this list. You got Eric Holder there, you got Janet Napolitano. You got a whole bunch of people, Steven Chu, Tim Geithner that were close to Clinton, close to Obama. And I would only point out when you talk about the money that's changing hands. You said this money came in two years before this deal.

Well, $500,000 went to Bill Clinton in the weeks after over the first speaking event in Russia. And I get, I would just once again ask like, there's nobody think that's inappropriate? Does nobody think that's bizarre? A $146 million to the Clinton Foundation while she is Secretary of State from Russia and $500K for a gig speaking there from the Russians to Bill Clinton?

ROSENZWEIG: Nobody says that the Clinton Foundation should have been taking this money. They probably should not have been taking money from any foreign source as long as the past of -- she was Secretary of State. But to suggest the Uranium One deal is outside the bounds of normal procedure is really just to be indulging in with respect to conspiracy theories.

REGAN: No. No. You're wrong on that. I mean, we had a lot of concerns about Russia. We still have a lot of concerns about Russia. And I really question --

ROSENZWEIG: I agree with you. I have lots of concerns about Russia. I worry about the president's decision to try and lift sanctions.

REGAN: To the Russians.

ROSENZWIEG: That's the type of concern I have.

REGAN: So it tells me it's either incompetence on the part of our government or there's something else at play. Paul, thank you very much for joining us, thanks very much.

ROSENZWEIG: Thanks for having me. It's a great pleasure.

REGAN: Congress taking a major step forward in passing tax reform, but a battle is growing between Republicans from high-taxed states and those from low-taxed states. Are we heading for a showdown?

Plus, the IRS finally admitting it targeted conservative and Tea Party groups and the DOJ is paying out big time. Stay with me. I'm back in two.

REGAN: Here we are just days away from seeing the first text of the Republican tax form bill. Are you excited? The big question is going to be, is it going to get rid of state and local tax deductions? And look, I said this many times on this show, I like getting a state and local tax deduction. Heck, I live in New York City, right?

But the reality is those deductions that I'm allowed to take they aren't really entirely fair. Because while they benefit New York or California or New Jersey, they don't do much good for Texas or New Hampshire or Florida, because you don't have any state income tax there that you can deduct. So you see what's happening. Essentially, part of the country is helping to subsidize spending in these blue states. And the president is calling that out.

But Republican lawmakers from those blue states, because there are a few Republicans in the blue states, they say, they're not going to pass a bill that gets rids of these deductions. So is this turning into a massive showdown? We're going to Connell McShane for the latest. Hey Connell!

CONNELL MCSHANE. FOX NEWSCORRESPONDENT: Hey there, Trish. Yes, well, they might need the votes from those Republican lawmakers that you allude to. So they are working on a compromise for that, for the deduction issue. There's also a lot of interesting talk here in Washington today about 401(k) contributions. OK, so I'll get to that in a second. But since you brought up the deductions, so let's start with that.

We had 20 no votes on the budget yesterday in the House. And 11 of the 20 were New York and New Jersey representatives on the Republican side. So that really tells you how important this issue is. And leadership is talking to those members but he's trying to kind of work something out that maybe softens the blow. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

KEVIN BRADY, (R-TX), 8TH DISTRICT WAYS AND MEANS COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: We know as we're working with these lawmakers, that if you couple lower taxes, a bigger child tax credit and we work with, to find a compromise on state and local, we can help Americans in every bracket keep more of what they earn.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

MCSHANE: Well, you know, the other possibility is you have the deductions going away for some people but not for others. Maybe there's some sort of an upper income limit put on it, but again, a lot being talked about there.

Now on the 401(k) issue, you remember the president brought that up in a tweet. But that got very interesting earlier today as well. You just heard from Chairman Brady. I was speaking to him about this a little bit earlier the day and he has made a suggestion, in fact, he's told us that he talked to the president about this, where the limit on contributions to your 401(k) plan, they might actually increase of its 18,000 now, up to 20,000 plus. But there's a big catch.

All the money wouldn't be tax-free as part of this compromise. Some of that tax-free savings might go to the backs end rather than the front end. And that's to save money for the tax reform effort. Here's more of the rationale.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

BRADY: Those 401(k)'s most people are saving $200 or less a month. That won't do it in retirement. They're going to be in trouble.

So we're asking experts how we can help theses families save more. And so we're working to reach a good solution there. If not, we'll leave them as they are.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

MCSHANE: As they are. Now that's basically, Trish, where we are right now. I should tell you there is still a very ambitious timeline up here. I mean Chairman Brady has talked about this a number of times. But they want to get the bill introduced by next week and still talking about at getting it passed by Thanksgiving. But two issues, the deductions in the 401(k), still going to work something out.

REGAN: Thanks so much, Connell.

The IRS, everyone, finally admitting it did target conservatives and Tea Party groups. And The DOJ is paying out big time.

But will any heads roll over this blatant abuse of power? And finally what does this telling you about the Obama Administration? They passed a deal to allow the Russians to buy 20 percent of our uranium assets.

That's very skeptical. And now we're learning what they did, targeting, deliberately targeting conservatives and Tea Party activists. We're on it.

Plus "The Wall Street Journal" Kimberley Strassel is here. She's running about the so-called dirty dossier about President Trump, and she is warning right now that there are many Russian bombshells to come, if and when the bank records of who paid for this thing are actually uncovered. She's got a lot of Intel for you. Do not miss it. Stay with me.

REGAN: OK. We got another scandal to talk about today from the Obama era. As the Trump Justice Department is forced to settle two lawsuits that date back to the Obama administration. The IRS admitting in court documents that intentionally delayed tax-exempt status for Tea Party and conservative groups. Attorney General Jeff Sessions says there's no excuse for this conduct. And then on to President Trump, this abuse of power will not be tolerated.

Joining me with more, American majority CEO, Ned Ryun. Abuse of power, is that what it is?

NED RYUN, CEO, AMERICAN MAJORITY: Yes. Oh, Absolutely. I mean Trish we're not dealing -- we weren't dealing with just dozens of Tea Party and conservative groups. This is hundreds and hundreds almost 500.

By the time you add everything up. And I guess the question I would have for those watching is, do you really think the IRS of its own volition just decided to target Tea Party groups and conservatives? I mean IRS, bureaucrats acting of their own volition.

I think this went higher and it is kind of a microcosm of what a lot of us were concerned about with the Obama administration that it was weaponizing governments, the states against those that opposed it. And so, when you look at the IRS scandal, again it's just one of many things that concerned us during the Obama administration. People in D.C. and New York, still don't understand why 2016 happened and this is a microcosm of why it happened. People are losing trust in their institutions.

REGAN: And it leads you, of course, down the path of looking it what happened with that, now infamous dossier. And was the FBI --

RYUN: That's right.

REGAN: -- under President Obama using that in order to wiretap. Save that because I want to ask you something else and Kimberly Strassel is going to be on momentarily to talk about that. But I know you've been digging into the Uranium One story quite extensively.

RYUN: That's right.

REGAN: And, you know, we just heard from a guest who sat on homeland security who try to tell us, look, you know, this is no big deal. Absolutely no big deal at all that all --

RYUN: That's true.

REGAN: -- these people at CFIUS day signed off on it. And he also tried to say, Ned that none of this uranium left the country, when in fact we know that it went to Canada. And we know that in part because Uranium One confirmed it in April 2015 that this uranium went to Canada. And who knows what it happens to the uranium once it's out of the country.

RYUN: No. This is correct, Trish. And to say that this is no big deal, I'm sorry you had nine people, CFIUS members. Again, Hillary Clinton and Eric Holder, and Timothy Geithner, you can look on my Twitter feed and see all these names.

These people in expedited fashion, usually these things, Trish, 75 to 90 days they're looking at this deals started first part of August of 2010, and it was approved by October 22nd, 2010. It was expedited process. Most to this time when you're dealing with something such national security implications, usually 120 days.

REGAN: You know, I just want to point out. You're saying national security implications. And, you know, you're the guest who said, no, no, no national security. I would just say and I'm reading the name of this company that bought 51 percent stake in Uranium One, it's called ARMZ Uranium Holdings and it's from Russia, right?

So if that's not enough to kind of red flag some of this called Uranium Holdings. How about this? Guess who owns, ARMZ Uranium Holdings it's Rosatom which stands for --

RYUN: Rosatom.

REGAN: -- Russian State Atomic Energy Corporation. And no one cares?

RYUN: By the way, we're also helping Iran build these nuclear facilities and training Iranian nuclear scientists.

REGAN: Yes. And we knew that back in 2007.

RYUN: And the thing about it is, it wasn't as though Republicans weren't raising red flags. On October 5th, 2010, Republicans sent a letter to Timothy Geithner and said, we have real issues with this deal. And you know what they did? They went ahead signed off on it basically two weeks later and said this deal was fine to go forward.

There are a lot of questions, and I think the only way we get to bottom of this, Trish is we have all nine of those CFIUS voting members, brought to the Hill, put under oath in a public setting and asked, why did you approve this deal? Why did you do it in expedited fashion? And we get answers because I think we deserve answers.

Was this to help Russia come in on a terrible Iranian deal, or even worse, Trish, was this some sort of a payback to Democrat and Clinton Foundation donors as I thank you for all the support they've gotten? We deserve answers.

REGAN: You're hitting on something that I think is very interesting because as I've been telling the viewer and I remember covering Russia, the Ukraine elections, I covered the lobster --

RYUN: Right.

REGAN: -- summit in Kennebunkport. And during the Ukrainian elections it was very clear the Ukraine's were definitely warning about Russia as a real threat. As I've been citing (INAUDIBLE) -- cover article in 2007 in the foreign affairs journal from the CFR where she basically outlined exactly what Putin was up to and his imperialistic tendency. She talked about his support of those in Iran that were doing bad stuff. And she warned of everything.

We knew about this that Condoleezza Rice was there. And she was a Russian scholar. She knew exactly what was at stake. There was a lot of concern and yet, Ned, everything shifted, when President Obama came into office, Hillary Clinton was secretary of state, the last guest try to say, well, you know, that that money they went to the Clinton Foundation that happened two years before that deal was approved. But if you follow your logic, perhaps that was money well-spent as far as Russians go.

Now I'm not saying anything. I just think that say it looks awfully suspicious that we changed our policy tone towards Russia shortly after --

RYUN: Right.

REGAN: --in the years after all this money had been pouring into the Clinton Foundation. I mean, why you're going not to be -- not getting along with someone who's giving you so much money?

RYUN: That's right. There are a lot of questions. And again Trish, there are a lot of questions that still need to be answered. And you make a good point.

We knew who Russia was at this point. We also knew, the CFIUS board members, this voting board members knew that there was actually a bribery case taking place that the FBI uncovered and regards this uranium deal. And they also knew exactly what Russia was doing. It was trying to Annex Georgia this time. It was threatening Ukraine.

REGAN: Yes.

RYUN: It was also threatening Latvia and Lithuania and Estonia with small nuclear weapons. We knew exactly what was going on and we still approved this deal in expedited fashion. Bring these nine CFIUS voting members to the Hill. Put them under oath either in front of the House Intelligence Committee or the Senate Judiciary Committee to get answers.

REGAN: Yes. There are questions that need to be answer for sure. I mean they've --

RYUN: That's right.

REGAN: -- long needed to be answered. But now we know in fact the FBI was investigating Vladimir Putin for trying to have outsized reach in our atomic energy industry at the same time that they were approving this deal. So yes lots of questions. Ned Ryun good to see you. Thank you so much.

The "Wall Street Journal" Kimberley Strassel writing about the so-called dirty dossier on President Trump warning of, "The coming Russian Bombshells" if and when those bank records of those who paid for this whole thing are uncovered. She's here to explain what those bank records might reveal. Kimberly's here. She's next.

REGAN: New questions today over the controversial and unverified and largely discredited anti-Trump dossier. Top Democrats are passing the buck here, claiming they had no idea that the dirty document was ever being compiled, let alone that they have anything to do with paying for it. Of course now we have learned that the DNC and Hillary Clinton campaign were funneling money through a law firm in order to dig up all this disgusting stuff.

Joining me right now with more, "Wall Street Journal" writer, Kimberley Strassel. She says even more Russia-linked bombshells are on the way. Good to see you, Kimberley. What do you mean by that?

KIMBERLEY STRASSEL, WRITER, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Hi, Trish. So I think people need to ask themselves why it is that Fusion, this oppo research firm, finally came out and said who had hired it, the DNC and the Clinton campaign. They have resisted doing that for almost an entire year. They had Democrats and Congress helping them and then suddenly boom, they give the names.

And it's because there is something they want to hide even more than those names and that is their bank records. And I think they thought, or hoped that by putting these names out there, that maybe the House investigators would drop their subpoena is for the bank records. House investigators are not doing that. But it's very clear Fusion, which has taken then to court, does not want them to see what's in those bank records.

REGAN: So the bank records would tell us basically, who all their clients were, who was paying them?

STRASSEL: Well I think House investigators will probably be careful not to drag any of Fusion's clients out into the open that have nothing to do with this investigation. But let's just say we know, for instance, that Fusion in the past has had contacts and contracts with Russians. One of those Russians, Natalia Veselnitskaya, she worked for a company called Prevezon. You know, she was one that recently ended up in Donald Trump, Jr.'s office having a meeting with him.

Is she linked up with Fusion? Are they still working because if there was money coming from Russia simultaneous to the fact that they were working on this dossier, it brings up some questions about whether or not the Russians didn't know this dossier project was on going and sought to influence it.

REGAN: So, in other words, this was a disinformation campaign that Fusion GPS was putting together and your thinking on this might be that the Russians had a direct hand in this. That they somehow wanted to be involved in this disinformation.

STRASSEL: Well, what we do know from the dossier's author, he writes it in the dossier. Is that a lot of this, the allegation, which you said have been almost entirely disprove and -- were based off of tips and knowledge from anonymous Russian sources. So I think the question we have to ask ourselves is, was the Kremlin aware that this dossier was being put together? And they did they deliberately, yes, feed false information to this British intelligence officer to inject that into our political system.

REGAN: Well, hen, how on earth does the FBI fall for that, Kimberly? I mean, how is it that -- and by the way, I would just point out that most journalist organizations, this thing had been floating out there, and they found it discredited, so they never bothered published it, except for "BuzzFeed", and that certainly a whole other debate as to whether they even are a journalist organization. But no one published this, right?

And, yet the FBI, Kimberly, took this to heart. And said OK, now we're going to have to look into all these campaign folks and wiretapping, et cetera, et cetera?

STRASSEL: Yes. This is the other huge unanswered question here. I keep trying to remind people just to contemplate this one sentence. We had law enforcement agencies working for a government opposition party from one that's in now.

Basically, wiretapping in a presidential election campaign, which is a pretty astonishing thought when you think about it. Now add in the possibility that it was relying or justifying that investigation on the basis of a Democratic commissioned opposition research document that was sourced from anonymous Russians. And you just have to wonder, you know, who was in charge there?

Now, we still don't know the answers to that question. The dossier file in the FBI is supposed to go to Congress this next week, but then we may have a better sense of how much it was used.

REGAN: Wow. All right, well, Kimberly thanks you so much. Appreciate all your Intel on this and we'll keep talking to you about it. Thank you.

STRASSEL: Thanks.

REGAN: All right everyone, let's go to Spain for a minute because people are taking to the streets there after the Catalan parliament voted today in favor of independence from Spain. They want to break apart away from the rest of Spain, taking the country's deepening political crisis here into uncharted territory.

Spain is Europe's fifth largest economy and whatever happens there could certainly have major financial implications.

The U.S. is not wild about this, but I'll tell you having spent a lot of time in Barcelona, they have always had this separatist strain in their population and it's really coming to a head right now. So we'll go to Spain right after this, with more pictures.

REGAN: Breaking news right now. Can you imagine if Texas said, you know what, see you United States of America, we want to break off on to our own? That's effectively what's happening in Barcelona, Spain, right now. You see people celebrating there in the street.

The prime minister there in Spain is dissolving their Catalonia Parliament following the region's history vote declaring independent from Spain. In other words, the people there in Barcelona and Catalonia have said, see you to Spain, I guess see you to the E.U. but is that going to fly? Let's go to Ashley Webster who joins me with the latest now.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Absolutely not. There they are celebrating in Barcelona tonight. Huge dark cloud on the horizon is that no one recognizes Catalonia as an independent state, not the EU, not the UK, not the U.S., Germany, France have all pitched in and said we don't even recognize you. We do not believe you are an independent state.

Now, Catalonia says well, you know, we'd be happy to be still in the EU. EU says where you are because you're part of Spain. So the question now is, this has been going on and building and building a game of chicken and here we are, what happens next? Does this really descend into civil disobedience?

What happens when Madrid tries to dissolve the parliament? Maybe arrest those Catalonian leaders that held the vote in the first place? What do the Catalan police do? Are they loyal to Madrid or are they loyal to Catalonia? There's a lot of big questions here.

REGAN: I want to point again this is coming to us live from Spain right now from Barcelona. And this is something that has been going on for sometimes, I have shared with you, Ashley, the story when I was a young student over there in Spain studying Spanish. And I got to Spain, I was all excited. And they started speaking Catalan to me, so much for all my Spanish.

WEBSTER: Excuse me?

REGAN: But really you get into a taxicab and they speak Catalan, because it was so ingrained to them that they were Catalanian or Catalonian first - -

WEBSTER: Yes.

REGAN: And before they were Spanish back in the years of Franco, for example, they were not allowed to speak Spanish, forgive me Catalan. He made them speak Spanish

And so, this is been something that has been brewing for some time. And now there's a lot of economic components to it as well.

WEBSTER: Huge.

REGAN: Given how successful they are.

WEBSTER: Well, listen. We're in uncharted territory. What happens?

At least 1500 companies have already moved out of Catalonia. So, major banks have moved their headquarters out of Catalonia, very worried about what happens next. So there is a big economic hit. This is very rich region of Spain, 25 percent of the GDP comes out of this one region. It's upset --

REGAN: It is little like Greece and Germany?

WEBSTER: Pretty much. Catalonia believes it pays way too much in taxes and gets way too little back compared to the rest of the country. Now, all of the sudden we're going to have to basks in Spain and the Corsicans in France, in the Northern League in Italy, and the Bavarians in Germany. Then they will lose in Belgium. The EU is very concerned that they don't want cracks to stop forming in the union where there are cracks.

REGAN: And there are, I mean let's -- yes Brexit.

WEBSTER: Brexit.

REGAN: I mean Brexit is a great example.

WEBSTER: Scotland. What about Scotland Island? It's covering the Scottish independence. I mean, they covered that vote, there were large group of Catalonians in Edinburgh egging them on to vote for independence. That's how, you know, strong they are for their statehood.

REGAN: So, ultimately? We don't know.

WEBSTER: We don't know but I -- it's going to be an uphill battle for Catalonia to get their own statehood. Let's put it that way.

REGAN: Ashley, thank you very much.

WEBSTER: My pleasure

REGAN: We'll be right back.

REGAN: Interesting story, the national archives releasing some, but not all, of the long secret files relating to the 1963 assassination of President JFK. President Trump blocked the release of nearly 300 records on the urging of CIA, and the FBI, those files are going to be under review for another six months. Those that were released described how federal agents madly chased after tips, after rumors and leads worldwide.

But the fact that some were held back, well, you know, that's fueling a whole lot more speculation. And by the way, they were held back because of national security concerns. What does that mean?

Presidential historian Doug Wead is back with me. And Doug, you know, one of the interesting things in all of this, is that we have learned that Oswald went to Mexico City for a meeting at the Soviet embassy shortly before this all transpired. Does that lead you in any direction towards maybe the Soviets, the Soviets perhaps, and the Cubans combined had a hand in this?

DOUG WEAD, PRESIDENTIAL HISTORIAN: Absolutely.

REGAN: Yes. That was my thought.

WEAD: All of the conspiracy theories, all of them are alive, and there is a bunch more after we've seen these documents. It is truly, truly stunning.

REGAN: But I mean is there any one that sticks out more so than others given what we know thus far?

WEAD: Here is what sticks out to me, Trish, and that's the questions that the American people were asking, that the taxicab driver, the beautician asking. They were the right questions. And the elite media and the government tried to make us feel like we're idiots and conspiracy theorists, but, they themselves are asking this question.

Richard Helms, the director of the CIA, sends out a memo that's in these documents and says was he one of ours? Meaning Oswald, was he a CIA agent? So, this isn't some blogger from Tulsa. This is the director of the CIA asking that question.

And then there is LBJ, LBJ is quoted in here as saying, the reason John F. Kennedy was assassinated was because he himself assassinated Ngo Dinh Diem, the president of our ally, president of South Vietnam, who was a fellow catholic. I mean, this, again, is president of the United States making this allegation in these documents. No wonder they wanted to keep them hidden.

REGAN: So what is your suspicion? Do you question all of this as well? I mean do you think that there is more to this story than was ever presented to the public?

WEAD: Oh, obviously so here because the principals themselves thought that. Johnson thought that. Helms thought that.

You can -- we've got to apologize to all the conspiracy theorists. They may not have the right conclusions. We don't know those conclusions and maybe that's the lone gunman as many say. But they certainly had the right questions and the questions they were asking should have been asked and no one should have been shamed from talking about it.

REGAN: You know, Doug, I guess now the concern is national security, right? And I understand that, by the way. I kept saying, well the president surely must know what's in these documents before they get released because I would think that you run the risk of anyone maybe being named that was a spy for us, possibly still being a live and being put into jeopardy. And also he is citing national security concerns, which makes me wonder, if it was another country involved in this assassination, do we run the risk of flaring up a scenario and perhaps is the reason why they want to be more careful?

I don't fault them by the way for wanting to be more careful. Because it is all sensitive stuff and you don't want to find yourself in a situation where we're going into some World War III over something done that many years ago, Doug.

WEAD: I don't think that's the problem. I think it's political and it's personal. Trish, when I wrote the book, "All the President's Children," I had the Warren G. Harding family lobbying me not to include the story of his illegitimate daughter which is now proven by DNA. But that tells you the pressure that was on.

And one of the revealing moments in this documents that I read last night is when J Edgar Hoover tips off Bobby Kennedy and says there's book coming out next year bout you and Marilyn Monroe. Giving the Kennedy's time to issue other books to dilute that book and to get their answers ready, that tells me why these docs are really hidden from the public. There are people who would be embarrassed by them.

REGAN: Dough, thank you so much. Good to see you.

WEAD: Good to see you, Trish.

REGAN: All right. The White House briefing just wrapping up moments ago, our own Blake Burman was there and he has a very important question about the President 401K tax position. Let's listen. We got the question and the answer I believe. There we go.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Is the president considering dropping the amount of pre taxed contributions that Americans can put in to their 401(k) currently? That said about $18,000. It seems is that this whole issue is up for negotiation. Does the president support taking that $18,000 a level and potentially lowering that?

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: As I said earlier this week the president wants to continue to fight and push for protection of Americans retirement. And that hasn't changed, but I'm not making any - - negotiate any deals beyond that. But that's the president's position and that's the same today as it was earlier this week.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: You know, I tell you, there's lot of opportunity had as we look at the market that once again is looking at new a high. New high anyway on the Nasdaq, and we have got the Dow up 31 points right now as we head into the weekend.

I hope you do have a wonderful one but there's a lot more news coming your way right now in the final hour of trading. Liz Claman has you covered. Hey Liz!

urn:contentItem:5TWG-6RM1-JBHT-D063-00000-00Stocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On Cleats2018-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On CleatsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you. What a day yesterday. We are looking at a follow through this morning. Thank you so much.

Good morning, everyone. Happy Thursday. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it Thursday, November 29th.

BARTIROMO: So, what should the President do, Bob? I mean, you know the issues about the -- about the intellectual property.

HORMATS: Yes, I spent 10 days in China intellectual property, when I was in government, intellectual property issues, questions of partnership, subsidies, they all come up. There have been negotiations on them.

I think what's needed is, for the two presidents to agree that if they are going to move ahead in this relationship, they've got to take a much more determined view to get changes that are acceptable and level the playing field between foreign companies and Chinese companies.

BARTIROMO: or could this --

HORMATS: I think the Chinese understand something has to be done. I just think that the tariff escalation is probably so harmful to both sides that it's unlikely to be the way of getting real progress.

BARTIROMO: So, you say, the Chinese understand something needs to be done. What does that mean, though, I mean, we're talking about dictator for life, in President Xi?

HORMATS: I give you one example.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HORMATS: I gave keynote speech at the Shenzhen Technology (INAUDIBLE) high-tech products from China and all around the world.

Even the foreign companies that represented there, said the Chinese are developing intellectual property of their own, innovative stuff of -- on many levels in China, so they -- their entrepreneurs now have an interest in protecting their intellectual property, just as, of course, our companies do.

So, I think there's a greater chance now of getting some agreement on intellectual property protection that there might not have been five years ago when the Chinese were not developing their own intellectual property. That's an area where, I think, they're (INAUDIBLE) overlap some convergence, also subsidies.

BARTIROMO: Very good point.

HORMATS: The Chinese are trying to cut back on subsidies. Their big spending -- even though the reserves are substantial, their spending is substantial, as well. I think reducing subsidies in their interest and, of course, in the interest of avoiding unfair competition, would be something they might decide that they can do.

BARTIROMO: So, there's some room here. There's room for upside potential at this meeting, isn't there?

HORMATS: There is. And I think that it's not that if they're going to have a breakthrough in either or these or other items. But if they establish a process, whereby the leaders ask for their experts to sit together and work for, say, six months and report back to them, on two or three or four items, it won't be a whole list of the kind United States has proposed to try.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: But two or three items of particular significance that might be the way out of it and avoid further escalation of tariffs, which as you correctly point out, is going to be harmful, just because these economies are so interdependent.

And one point for Americans to bear in mind, most of the tariffs we've imposed so far, are intermediate goods, products that are components for American companies, which squeezes American companies to the next realm, if their new items added. They'll be on consumer goods, like --

BARTIROMO: Like the iPhone.

HORMATS: Exactly. And those --

BARTIROMO: Yes, which is why, Apple has been trading down.

HORMATS: Exactly, they're 10 percent or 25 percent that virtually goes right to the consumer.

BARTIROMO: But there's a potential, I think, I hear you saying, of a big rally, if we get any upside potential out of this, maybe markets get a relief rally --

HORMATS: I think they will.

BARTIROMO: if we see something --

HORMATS: For two reasons, one, they'll make progress or hopefully make progress on certain subsidy issues or other issues. And second, if it works or if it's the right kind of deal, can avoid further escalation, so both would be market movers on the positive side.

And I like to give through you my condolences, again, to his family, to his wife, ex-wife, and to his children, and to his family, because Jamal was a reformer, he was in no position at all and what took place in that Saudi consulate was clearly horrific, despicable and tragic and I believe that Saudi Arabia is going to get to the bottom of it.

HORMATS: Well, I think the problem the U.S. and other countries have is, first of all, they're appalled at what happened.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we all are.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: Third, they have opportunities to sell more things to Saudi Arabia, so their abhorrence at this event, is tempered by the fact that they have real economic interest, and the fact is that some of them also, want to work with the Saudis for strategic reasons in the gulf. So, they have to work this balance --

BARTIROMO: Right, but we know that Iran --

HORMATS: U.S. cannot walk away.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HORMATS: U.S. cannot walk away.

BARTIROMO: That was what I was getting at. But you mentioned oil. HORMATS: It's both. It's a weakening of the global economy, not a dramatic one, but a moderate one. And it's also a supply factor, and that goes to another Saudi point. Again, as much as we're appalled by what happened, the Saudis are the key members of OPEC.

So, if there's going to be a tightening of production, it's going to have to be led by Saudi Arabia. They have the most excess capacity and therefore, they would have to reduce output to help push prices up, if that's the objective of oil producers.

BARTIROMO: So, you expect that to happen?

HORMATS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What do you think oil -- I mean, what's your take on oil? If it goes much lower than this, you're going to have a problem with the Shell producers, as well, aren't you?

HORMATS: Well, see, this is the other part where the Saudis have had two objectives here. They don't want the price of oil to fall too much because they depend on it. On the other hand, a couple of years ago, the Saudis had a view, if they keep the prices down, because some of these Shell producers, in the U.S., and also (INAUDIBLE) have a lot of leverage.

They will push some of them out of the market or force them to cut back on productions. So, again, Saudi strategy plays a key role in that, as well, even though we're not so dependent on their oil. It's a global price and they have the biggest impact of anyone on that global price.

BARTIROMO: By the way, do you think with the slowdown on the horizon, economic slowdown, the Fed, obviously, yesterday, talked about how great things are going, but markets have been worried.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: on sales to China, if their economy slows, and it's slowing for other reasons, a bit, not a lot. But trade war would make it a lot slower.

BARTIROMO: Has a big impact.

HORMATS: And Asia gets impacted and that affects their finances because they have a lot of debt, so they have to earn money to pay off their debt.

BARTIROMO: I'm feeling coupled, coupling, remember that?

HORMATS: There is coupling. It's an interdependent world.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HORMATS: Once you do one thing, it affects a lot of other things.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: And sometimes, people don't think through the secondary effects.

BLACKBURN: What I would like to see happen is passage of the Browser Act which is privacy regulations. And Maria -- they have resisted this. What they wanted was to put all of the privacy regulation on the ISPs. That would have been the 2015 rules that the Obama administration had wanted to put in place. But it needs to be one set of rules for the ecosystem.

FREEMAN: Senator-Elect -- James Freeman here with the "Wall Street Journal".

WEBER: But that's exactly what Jay was pointing at. There are two issues that they face. First one is they need to contain inflation because with the economy doing well, there is a risk that inflation will go up. It's been pretty contained. The Fed was able in this cycle to raise rates, roughly at half the speed of what they did in the past, and they've traveled about half the distance.

And the real question is, I don't think that normalization of monetary policy will be completed in the current cycle. It will take another economic cycle to really go to neutral. Because after a very long period of very low interest rates, raising interest rates has happened very cautious, but the balance sheets are still very, very expanded. So they'll continue to reduce the balance sheet.

But my expectation is they won't even go back to where the Fed's balance sheet was before the crisis. Central banks have now become a much larger central counterparty in markets. And for that, I think structurally central bank balance sheets will be larger.

And I think there's good reasons to be cautious about normalizing monetary policy because we're coming out of a 10 year low interest rate environment and therefore you have to be cautious and you should not overshoot. You need to look at the economy where central bank support has been taken for granted for a decade, and weaning that off has to happen with some eyes on a really cautious normalization. It will no longer expand balance sheet. Central bank balance sheets globally will start to shrink and that is a new phenomenon. And then, you have to be a lot more specific in what stocks you pick in the growing market.

BARTIROMO: So, in terms of the growth and where is the growth within the growth sector, are you seeing any other real performance coming out of some of the growth equity portion of the firm?

KOUDOUNIS: We're seeing a huge internal cyclical move, where the FAANGs were leading the markets and it was the biggest percentage, we're starting to see other stocks, other -- whether it'd be tech, we feel that finance is still going to do really well in the FAANG stocks. So, we're seeing movement out of some into the others, not just from --

BARTIROMO: So, an allocation shift is going on.

KOUDOUNIS: Huge allocation shift, and we're not just seeing a pull, we're just seeing more of an allocation shift and a slowdown of growth in the --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Do you worry that rates are going to spoil the party that higher rates?

KOUDOUNIS: Look, there always going to be mistakes that are done, but I think Jay Powell is doing a great job, he knows what he's doing, he will be accommodative. They say three rate hikes, I don't believe it. Unless the market is so strong and growth is so strong that they will do those hikes, they will watch it, and it's not all the battering because of the current administration is saying. They may listen to that but I think they're looking at the data, and they know -- nobody does well if they choke the market by raising rates too quickly.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KOUDOUNIS: So, they're going to be very, very -- looking at all statistics and I think they're going to continue to be accommodative.

BARTIROMO: And there seems to be a better tone right now. I mean, the market is lower, Futures indicating a decline at the start of trading, but it's only 20 points, and this is after a powerful rally yesterday.

KOUDOUNIS: Sure.

BARTIROMO: Did it feel like you wanted to buy into that rally yesterday when things were moving up? Were you on the buy side or were you selling into the strength?

KOUDOUNIS: I think there's been a lot of cash on the sidelines.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KOUDOUNIS: And I think a lot of people were looking for this opportunity, and that's why we saw that big of a movement. And we -- the market kind of sensed that Powell was going to say some positive things for it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KOUDOUNIS: We saw it go up, and then we saw it double again, the increase after the speech.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's incredible, because as soon as the embargoed comments came out, markets shoots up and then stayed up 500 points while Mr. Powell was speaking. It's great to see you, John. Thank you so much.

KOUDOUNIS: It's great to see you. Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: John Koudounis joining us there, CEO of Calamos.

Coming up, battle at the border, the growing concerns of a potential health risks among the migrant caravan members. Then, President Trump on the world stage this weekend. Stuart Varney's expectations for the G20 summit. He's up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are watching by Buenos Aires this morning. President Trump is headed to the G20 summit in Argentina, this morning, as he prepares for the high-stakes dinner with China's President Xi Jinping. Joining us now to talk more about that is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney with some high expectations, Stu?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, let's compare and contrast, in all previous G20 meetings or whatever they call it, G10, G12 - - whatever -- they all appear for the photo-op wearing some strange costumes from the host country, then they get together and give this final communique which says absolutely nothing, it is totally meaningless. This time around, this G20, this one in Buenos Aires, is going to be radically different. This is a place where something is going to happen. And the headlines will be flowing thick and fast.

Number one, you've got Saturday night's dinner with Xi Jinping. Don't tell me there'll be no headline after that. Saturday morning or lunchtime I think it is, he meets with Putin. Putin has just set his navy on the Ukrainian Navy. Don't tell me that nothing's going to happen with that meeting. Theresa May and Angela Merkel, they're there, do you think he'll have something to say about Brexit? How about the leader of Japan and South Korea, do you think they'll have something to say about North Korea? I do. I think it's going to be a thick and fast flow of headlines, meaningful headlines, news will be made. And that's a wonderful thing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. Lots to cover on Sunday and Monday that's for sure.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Do you think these are going to be largely positive headlines?

BARTIROMO: I don't know. I mean, you're laughing at me because you know - - you know, it's going to --

(CROSSTALK) I think thick and fast

BARTIROMO: No, that's the wildcard. We'll see.

VARNEY: I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: But I'll guarantee that at the end of the dinner with Xi Jinping, they'll be a smile, there will be a handshake, but after that, I don't know.

BARTIROMO: There's a lot of potential for upside surprises, you know, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes, yes.

BARTIROMO: Because markets aren't expecting much on the China front, right.

VARNEY: Yes. Well, look at the Fed yesterday. And were we expecting that yesterday? We got it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was wild. Stu, thanks. We'll see you in about 10 minutes.

VARNEY: Sure thing.

BARTIROMO: I know you'll have a lot more at the top of the hour "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart and company, coming up.

But first, there's this, health concerns at the southern border. We are headed live to Mexico, next up. We'll get the latest on the caravan crisis. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Health problems now at the southern border. The undocumented immigrants from the caravan could potentially bring serious health concerns to the United States. Griff Jenkins is live this morning in Tijuana, Mexico. Here's more on this. Good morning to you, Griff.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria, good morning. Yes, we're getting really troubling and concerning members for this migrant caravan. There are 6,000 here in Tijuana, and the health officials here told me yesterday that this is what they're seeing out of the 2,267 people they've treated, over 60 percent have respiratory infections. There have been three confirmed cases of tuberculosis, four cases of HIV aids, and 101 cases of lice, as well as four cases of chicken pox, and they're very worried about hepatitis because of the unsanitary conditions. And also, because of the overcrowding. If you just look over here for one second, Maria, you see, over that fence line is 6,000 close people, packed into a space for 1,000.

Then, if you quickly look just down this way, you see that white tent and one truck, that is the Tijuana health officials, that is the only resources that is dealing with all of that overcrowding. There is a lot of coughing, a lot of spitting, there are signs that say "prohibido escupir" no spitting, because they're worried about the spread. And it is -- the migrants here that are under these conditions, they believe they're getting very exhausted, and they say, listen, we were lied to in the very beginning from organizers who said it was going to be easier, not this tough. And they worry of breaking points coming. This is immigrant Marco Munoz from Honduras. Take at a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARCO MUNOZ, IMMIGRANT FROM HONDURAS: They lied to us from the beginning. So, most of these people are disappointed, you know, and getting frustrated as time -- so as you can see, every day that come -- that passes, there's more and more people that are coming. So, there's going to be a point break, but they're just going to say, let's just -- let's rush in there, you know?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: So, you've got rain coming earlier today already, and it's expected throughout the day, that makes things even worse under these conditions, the migrants are wet, cold, and tired, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Griff, thank you so much. Griff Jenkins is live in Tijuana this morning.

Coming up, corporate patriots, how U.S. companies can do their part protecting intellectual property from China, one of the biggest issues today. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: We're taking a look at American companies doing their part. A new op-ed this morning calls for companies to do more, that's in today's Wall Street Journal. The headline reads this: "Where Are the Corporate Patriots?" And in it, the author writes: "Too many American companies have been too quick to sell out in exchange for access to the Chinese market. They are more than business decisions, they are matters of national security."

And, you know, James, I always go back to the Google decision, when Google decided we don't want to do evil, so we're not going to work with the Pentagon and we're not going to work with the U.S. government on anything regarding immigration, after parents were separated from their children. And, instead, Google turns around and they go to China, with all of the bad behavior in China from human rights to everything else, stealing of theft - - theft of technology. They are OK with censoring their search engine in China.

FREEMAN: Yes, it was outrageous. And I think this article -- I'm glad we were able to run this op-ed by Samantha Ravich who is on the Trump intelligence advisory board, also at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies. And it raises, I think, a big question here, which is we're watching obviously the President try to negotiate to change China's behavior, and she's saying, well, what responsibilities do companies have? Should they just refuse to share their technology? Should they refuse on the Google end to participate in the -- in the police state there? You know, are there options that companies have, and are there things they should be doing that they're not in terms of reporting intelligence back to the U.S. government?

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Dagen, Andrew Higgins is mentioned in the piece, who's of course, Higgins boat was instrumental in the D-Day invasion.

MCDOWELL: Right, I love that she reminds the American people where -- who made those boats and kind of partnership between private industry and the United States that help us win World War II, she points out that Higgins was paid tribute in 1944 in Eisenhower's Thanksgiving Day address. To that point, there is a responsibility that American corporations have to protecting what is ours, and doing right by everyone in this nation. And I think that more and more, we call out these individual companies as you have with Google, the more -- you know, the more power we might have over their businesses decision.

BARTIROMO: And I think they have a responsibility, it's this great country that made them strong, powerful, and rich, Mike Murphy.

MURPHY: Yes, they have a responsibility to an extent, but it's a different world now, it's a global economy that we live in, and these companies that are being -- their job -- you know, the CEOs of these public companies, especially, they have to do what's best for their shareholders. So --

BARTIROMO: Right. I shouldn't say this country made them rich, that's not right. It enabled them with our freedoms and our democracy.

MURPHY: Yes. So, I think --

BARTIROMO: It helped them do so.

MURPHY: Yes. And they see China as the biggest market in the world, and a great way for them to increase their company profits, and I think, really, what I bring this back to is the current issue that we have with the trade war and tariffs, and that's we -- what the President wants is fair trade across the globe. And I think if we get that, it's better for China, it's better for the United States, it's better for everyone in between (INAUDIBLE)

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: It raises a -- it raises a bigger issue, though, these companies -- it's their intellectual property that's getting stolen, $600 billion -- up to $600 billion a year. And so then, when there's trouble, then they turn to the government and want the government to fix what they needed to take charge of to begin with.

BARTIROMO: That's what Trump is doing right now.

MURPHY: That's what he wants. So --

FREEMAN: Yes. And I think, maybe, a hopeful part of this story is that I think a lot of businesses have realized, they went into China thinking huge long-term market, last few years, they're seeing this communist regime has become more communist, it's kind of reverted, become less open, not liberalizing anymore. I don't think China is getting the help from the American business community they thought they were going to get to pressure Donald Trump. I think they have found a lot of American companies saying, yes, Trump is right, we're getting a raw deal. So, I think that is maybe the hopeful sign here, and perhaps this op-ed will encourage more on that.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but the likes of Google, they say, if they're saying that at all, they're saying it privately and quietly because some of these liberal companies, they won't stand next to the President in agreement on him doing what is right for the entire nation and every worker in this country because they don't want to be associated with him.

BARTIROMO: No, that's just --

MCDOWELL: And that's just ridiculous.

BARTIROMO: We've thrown out -- I mean, the mainstream media, they've thrown out their ideals and values of what we deem so important to us, and that is freedom, due process because they hate Donald Trump. I mean, it's really disgusting.

Before we go, we've got a couple of seconds left. Mike, you're expecting a pretty good performance in markets, aren't you, after yesterday's big rally?

MURPHY: I think we get a rally after the G20, and I think it's a big rally.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Mike Murphy, James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, great to see everybody, have a great day. Thanks so much for joining us. That will do it for us. Go seize the day, "VARNEY &COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Oh, this is a day to be seized. Good morning, Maria.

END

END

urn:contentItem:5WVX-FV81-DY0W-41YY-00000-00Stocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On Cleats2018-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:35ZLexisNexisStocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On CleatsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you. What a day yesterday. We are looking at a follow through this morning. Thank you so much.

Good morning, everyone. Happy Thursday. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it Thursday, November 29th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are pulling back this morning after that huge rally yesterday.

Dow Industrials now down 81 points. We are following through on what led the market higher yesterday. It was a major rally on the street. The Dow and the S&P 500 now in positive territory for this month.

Stocks rallied on the comment -- this comment from Fed Chairman Jay Powell, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: Interest rates are still low by historical standards, and they remain just below the range of estimates of that level that would be neutral for the economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And with that, the markets shut up 600 points in Europe. This morning, there is some follow through.

The markets are higher across the board.

FT-100 up 45 points right now, two-thirds of one percent, CAC Quarante in Paris also up two-thirds of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up a fraction this morning, 21 points higher.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances. Hong Kong and China were lower, but Japan was higher by a fraction, as was the Korean KOSPI Index.

Deutsche Bank has been raided. Prosecutors alleging that the bank helped clients create tax havens and launder money.

What it means for the already struggling bank coming up.

And a new tariff threat, President Trump warning of new charges on vehicles following the G.M. layoffs.

Plus Volvo is slowing hiring plans here in the U.S. because of those tariffs. The fallout coming up this morning.

Honoring our heroes, Arizona Cardinals wide receiver, Larry Fitzgerald, pays tribute to Pat Tillman and Senator John McCain on his feet.

A closer look at his special cleats for Sunday's big game, that's coming up.

And it is beginning to look a lot like Christmas at Taco Bell. The fast- food giant unveiling a line of themed clothes, from socks to sweaters, even onesies.

We will tell you about it. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, "The Wall Street Journal's" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Rosecliff CEO/Managing Partner, Mike Murphy.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to Jay Powell yesterday?

WEBER: I think as a former central banker I would say there was nothing extraordinary he said. And I think the real issue for markets is they have been quite jibbery this year because three major expectation of what really supported equity markets in the past are starting to be questioned.

The first is will earning growth continue to be as strong as it has? And there's some doubt about that. The second one is really monetary policy that was a major supporter of equity, markets is starting to be at neutral, so it's less supportive, it may actually become restrictive. Are they going to be able to do that without tightening too much too fast?

WEBER: But that's exactly what Jay was pointing at. There are two issues that they face. First one is they need to contain inflation because with the economy doing well, there is a risk that inflation will go up. It's been pretty contained. The Fed was able in this cycle to raise rates, roughly at half the speed of what they did in the past, and they've traveled about half the distance.

And the real question is, I don't think that normalization of monetary policy will be completed in the current cycle. It will take another economic cycle to really go to neutral. Because after a very long period of very low interest rates, raising interest rates has happened very cautious, but the balance sheets are still very, very expanded. So they'll continue to reduce the balance sheet.

But my expectation is they won't even go back to where the Fed's balance sheet was before the crisis. Central banks have now become a much larger central counterparty in markets. And for that, I think structurally central bank balance sheets will be larger.

And I think there's good reasons to be cautious about normalizing monetary policy because we're coming out of a 10 year low interest rate environment and therefore you have to be cautious and you should not overshoot. You need to look at the economy where central bank support has been taken for granted for a decade, and weaning that off has to happen with some eyes on a really cautious normalization. It will no longer expand balance sheet. Central bank balance sheets globally will start to shrink and that is a new phenomenon. Part of what we're also very good at and what we're expanding is investment in sustainability.
