KOUDOUNIS: It's great to see you. Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: John Koudounis joining us there, CEO of Calamos.

Coming up, battle at the border, the growing concerns of a potential health risks among the migrant caravan members. Then, President Trump on the world stage this weekend. Stuart Varney's expectations for the G20 summit. He's up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are watching by Buenos Aires this morning. President Trump is headed to the G20 summit in Argentina, this morning, as he prepares for the high-stakes dinner with China's President Xi Jinping. Joining us now to talk more about that is the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney with some high expectations, Stu?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well, let's compare and contrast, in all previous G20 meetings or whatever they call it, G10, G12 - - whatever -- they all appear for the photo-op wearing some strange costumes from the host country, then they get together and give this final communique which says absolutely nothing, it is totally meaningless. This time around, this G20, this one in Buenos Aires, is going to be radically different. This is a place where something is going to happen. And the headlines will be flowing thick and fast.

Number one, you've got Saturday night's dinner with Xi Jinping. Don't tell me there'll be no headline after that. Saturday morning or lunchtime I think it is, he meets with Putin. Putin has just set his navy on the Ukrainian Navy. Don't tell me that nothing's going to happen with that meeting. Theresa May and Angela Merkel, they're there, do you think he'll have something to say about Brexit? How about the leader of Japan and South Korea, do you think they'll have something to say about North Korea? I do. I think it's going to be a thick and fast flow of headlines, meaningful headlines, news will be made. And that's a wonderful thing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right. Lots to cover on Sunday and Monday that's for sure.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Do you think these are going to be largely positive headlines?

BARTIROMO: I don't know. I mean, you're laughing at me because you know - - you know, it's going to --

(CROSSTALK) I think thick and fast

BARTIROMO: No, that's the wildcard. We'll see.

VARNEY: I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: But I'll guarantee that at the end of the dinner with Xi Jinping, they'll be a smile, there will be a handshake, but after that, I don't know.

BARTIROMO: There's a lot of potential for upside surprises, you know, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes, yes.

BARTIROMO: Because markets aren't expecting much on the China front, right.

VARNEY: Yes. Well, look at the Fed yesterday. And were we expecting that yesterday? We got it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was wild. Stu, thanks. We'll see you in about 10 minutes.

VARNEY: Sure thing.

BARTIROMO: I know you'll have a lot more at the top of the hour "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart and company, coming up.

But first, there's this, health concerns at the southern border. We are headed live to Mexico, next up. We'll get the latest on the caravan crisis. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Health problems now at the southern border. The undocumented immigrants from the caravan could potentially bring serious health concerns to the United States. Griff Jenkins is live this morning in Tijuana, Mexico. Here's more on this. Good morning to you, Griff.

GRIFF JENKINS, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria, good morning. Yes, we're getting really troubling and concerning members for this migrant caravan. There are 6,000 here in Tijuana, and the health officials here told me yesterday that this is what they're seeing out of the 2,267 people they've treated, over 60 percent have respiratory infections. There have been three confirmed cases of tuberculosis, four cases of HIV aids, and 101 cases of lice, as well as four cases of chicken pox, and they're very worried about hepatitis because of the unsanitary conditions. And also, because of the overcrowding. If you just look over here for one second, Maria, you see, over that fence line is 6,000 close people, packed into a space for 1,000.

Then, if you quickly look just down this way, you see that white tent and one truck, that is the Tijuana health officials, that is the only resources that is dealing with all of that overcrowding. There is a lot of coughing, a lot of spitting, there are signs that say "prohibido escupir" no spitting, because they're worried about the spread. And it is -- the migrants here that are under these conditions, they believe they're getting very exhausted, and they say, listen, we were lied to in the very beginning from organizers who said it was going to be easier, not this tough. And they worry of breaking points coming. This is immigrant Marco Munoz from Honduras. Take at a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARCO MUNOZ, IMMIGRANT FROM HONDURAS: They lied to us from the beginning. So, most of these people are disappointed, you know, and getting frustrated as time -- so as you can see, every day that come -- that passes, there's more and more people that are coming. So, there's going to be a point break, but they're just going to say, let's just -- let's rush in there, you know?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JENKINS: So, you've got rain coming earlier today already, and it's expected throughout the day, that makes things even worse under these conditions, the migrants are wet, cold, and tired, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Griff, thank you so much. Griff Jenkins is live in Tijuana this morning.

Coming up, corporate patriots, how U.S. companies can do their part protecting intellectual property from China, one of the biggest issues today. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: We're taking a look at American companies doing their part. A new op-ed this morning calls for companies to do more, that's in today's Wall Street Journal. The headline reads this: "Where Are the Corporate Patriots?" And in it, the author writes: "Too many American companies have been too quick to sell out in exchange for access to the Chinese market. They are more than business decisions, they are matters of national security."

And, you know, James, I always go back to the Google decision, when Google decided we don't want to do evil, so we're not going to work with the Pentagon and we're not going to work with the U.S. government on anything regarding immigration, after parents were separated from their children. And, instead, Google turns around and they go to China, with all of the bad behavior in China from human rights to everything else, stealing of theft - - theft of technology. They are OK with censoring their search engine in China.

FREEMAN: Yes, it was outrageous. And I think this article -- I'm glad we were able to run this op-ed by Samantha Ravich who is on the Trump intelligence advisory board, also at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies. And it raises, I think, a big question here, which is we're watching obviously the President try to negotiate to change China's behavior, and she's saying, well, what responsibilities do companies have? Should they just refuse to share their technology? Should they refuse on the Google end to participate in the -- in the police state there? You know, are there options that companies have, and are there things they should be doing that they're not in terms of reporting intelligence back to the U.S. government?

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Dagen, Andrew Higgins is mentioned in the piece, who's of course, Higgins boat was instrumental in the D-Day invasion.

MCDOWELL: Right, I love that she reminds the American people where -- who made those boats and kind of partnership between private industry and the United States that help us win World War II, she points out that Higgins was paid tribute in 1944 in Eisenhower's Thanksgiving Day address. To that point, there is a responsibility that American corporations have to protecting what is ours, and doing right by everyone in this nation. And I think that more and more, we call out these individual companies as you have with Google, the more -- you know, the more power we might have over their businesses decision.

BARTIROMO: And I think they have a responsibility, it's this great country that made them strong, powerful, and rich, Mike Murphy.

MURPHY: Yes, they have a responsibility to an extent, but it's a different world now, it's a global economy that we live in, and these companies that are being -- their job -- you know, the CEOs of these public companies, especially, they have to do what's best for their shareholders. So --

BARTIROMO: Right. I shouldn't say this country made them rich, that's not right. It enabled them with our freedoms and our democracy.

MURPHY: Yes. So, I think --

BARTIROMO: It helped them do so.

MURPHY: Yes. And they see China as the biggest market in the world, and a great way for them to increase their company profits, and I think, really, what I bring this back to is the current issue that we have with the trade war and tariffs, and that's we -- what the President wants is fair trade across the globe. And I think if we get that, it's better for China, it's better for the United States, it's better for everyone in between (INAUDIBLE)

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: It raises a -- it raises a bigger issue, though, these companies -- it's their intellectual property that's getting stolen, $600 billion -- up to $600 billion a year. And so then, when there's trouble, then they turn to the government and want the government to fix what they needed to take charge of to begin with.

BARTIROMO: That's what Trump is doing right now.

MURPHY: That's what he wants. So --

FREEMAN: Yes. And I think, maybe, a hopeful part of this story is that I think a lot of businesses have realized, they went into China thinking huge long-term market, last few years, they're seeing this communist regime has become more communist, it's kind of reverted, become less open, not liberalizing anymore. I don't think China is getting the help from the American business community they thought they were going to get to pressure Donald Trump. I think they have found a lot of American companies saying, yes, Trump is right, we're getting a raw deal. So, I think that is maybe the hopeful sign here, and perhaps this op-ed will encourage more on that.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but the likes of Google, they say, if they're saying that at all, they're saying it privately and quietly because some of these liberal companies, they won't stand next to the President in agreement on him doing what is right for the entire nation and every worker in this country because they don't want to be associated with him.

BARTIROMO: No, that's just --

MCDOWELL: And that's just ridiculous.

BARTIROMO: We've thrown out -- I mean, the mainstream media, they've thrown out their ideals and values of what we deem so important to us, and that is freedom, due process because they hate Donald Trump. I mean, it's really disgusting.

Before we go, we've got a couple of seconds left. Mike, you're expecting a pretty good performance in markets, aren't you, after yesterday's big rally?

MURPHY: I think we get a rally after the G20, and I think it's a big rally.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Mike Murphy, James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, great to see everybody, have a great day. Thanks so much for joining us. That will do it for us. Go seize the day, "VARNEY &COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

VARNEY: Oh, this is a day to be seized. Good morning, Maria.

END

END

urn:contentItem:5TWG-6RM1-JBHT-D066-00000-00Stocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On Cleats2018-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On CleatsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you. What a day yesterday. We are looking at a follow through this morning. Thank you so much.

Good morning, everyone. Happy Thursday. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it Thursday, November 29th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are pulling back this morning after that huge rally yesterday.

Dow Industrials now down 81 points. We are following through on what led the market higher yesterday. It was a major rally on the street. The Dow and the S&P 500 now in positive territory for this month.

Stocks rallied on the comment -- this comment from Fed Chairman Jay Powell, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: Interest rates are still low by historical standards, and they remain just below the range of estimates of that level that would be neutral for the economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And with that, the markets shut up 600 points in Europe. This morning, there is some follow through.

The markets are higher across the board.

FT-100 up 45 points right now, two-thirds of one percent, CAC Quarante in Paris also up two-thirds of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up a fraction this morning, 21 points higher.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances. Hong Kong and China were lower, but Japan was higher by a fraction, as was the Korean KOSPI Index.

Deutsche Bank has been raided. Prosecutors alleging that the bank helped clients create tax havens and launder money.

What it means for the already struggling bank coming up.

And a new tariff threat, President Trump warning of new charges on vehicles following the G.M. layoffs.

Plus Volvo is slowing hiring plans here in the U.S. because of those tariffs. The fallout coming up this morning.

Honoring our heroes, Arizona Cardinals wide receiver, Larry Fitzgerald, pays tribute to Pat Tillman and Senator John McCain on his feet.

A closer look at his special cleats for Sunday's big game, that's coming up.

And it is beginning to look a lot like Christmas at Taco Bell. The fast- food giant unveiling a line of themed clothes, from socks to sweaters, even onesies.

We will tell you about it. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, "The Wall Street Journal's" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Rosecliff CEO/Managing Partner, Mike Murphy.

Great to see you this morning.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Good morning. I'll wear the onesie on T.V.

BARTIROMO: Taco Bell clothing --

MURPHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- here we come. Big move yesterday in the markets, huh?

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: It is a big move, and the oil dipping blow, 50 bucks a barrel, suggests the argument Mr. Powell was making has been bolstered this moment.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it sure has. And yesterday, I was -- I was at The New York Economic Club --

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- and everyone was waiting, will Jay Powell make comments about the interest rate story.

He did a lot about financial stability --

FREEMAN: Right. .

BARTIROMO: -- in his speech. It wasn't until he said, "Look, we're still at low levels," which we all knew and yet the market saw that as a reason to run up, Mike.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think, really, the main thing that they got was six week ago, he said that, "We're nowhere near neutral on rates."

MCDOWELL: A long way.

FREEMAN: Which is why there was a long --

MCDOWELL: A long way was --

FREEMAN: Sorry, a long way.

And now he's saying we're a lot closes to that, which implies there'll be less rate hikes, which the market likes, that's why he saw the rally yesterday.

BARTIROMO: So that was the change in --

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That one word usually tells it, right?

FREEMAN: I've --

MCDOWELL: So The Wall Street Journal Editorial Page --

FREEMAN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: -- James Freeman, where you work, don't know if you had your hands in this, says that this is a welcome rethink.

But as "The Journal" does point out that we have a market, a global market, and a world that is grappling with global slowing growth, bad trade policy that's deterring investment, and a fed that is also still gradually reducing this unprecedented bond portfolio.

And we have no way of knowing what the knock-on effects of that are or will be, so this is a very welcome, at least, reasonable approach to hiking short-term interest rates.

I paraphrase.

FREEMAN: Thank you. And just the editorial also adds those Vice Chairman -- Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida comments from earlier in the week saying the fact that you've got a lot of people working doesn't automatically lead to inflation.

That's a -- that's a welcome sign from the fed.

Personally, I kind of like going a bit higher. I don't think the fed funds rate ought to be equal to the rate of inflation.

But again, this oil news this morning, if you want to be dovish, if you want to say inflation is very restrained, you have a better case today.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you sure do. We're going to check markets this morning.

Take a look at oil, sitting right at $50.00 a barrel right now, what a selloff in the last month and a half.

Then another half a percent this morning with light sweet crude at $50.02 a barrel.

Joining the conversation this morning is the Chairman of UBS, Axel Weber is with us this morning in an exclusive interview talking about markets and investing capital today.

The CEO of Calamos Investments, John Koudounis, is joining us as well.

Almost looking at the backdrop for stocks.

Patron Spirits Founder, John Paul Mitchell Co-Founder, John Paul DeJoria is here as well.

Along with Wisconsin Congressman and House Financial Services Subcommittee Chairman, Sean Duffy.

Plus Tennessee Senator Elect, Marsha Blackburn with us.

A lot to talk about with the Senator Elect, so stay with us. We got a big three hours coming up.

HORMATS: There's no question about that, and for good reason. The second question, though, is they, a lot of these countries need Saudi oil, we don't really depend so much on Saudi oil, a lot of the other countries in the G20, do.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: Third, they have opportunities to sell more things to Saudi Arabia, so their abhorrence at this event, is tempered by the fact that they have real economic interest, and the fact is that some of them also, want to work with the Saudis for strategic reasons in the gulf. So, they have to work this balance --

BARTIROMO: Right, but we know that Iran --

HORMATS: that's the problem.

BARTIROMO: Iran is the problem. The Saudis have been a partner of the United States not just for oil but against Iran, so can the U.S. walk away?

HORMATS: U.S. cannot walk away.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HORMATS: U.S. cannot walk away.

BARTIROMO: That was what I was getting at. But you mentioned oil. Take a look at crowd oil now, below $50.00 yesterday, sitting right at $50.00, we're back below $50.00 this morning, first time in over a year, Bob, that we're seeing below $5.000, ahead of this OPEC meeting, which is happening next week.

Is this telling us something about the global economy, that things have weakened, is that why oil is selling off or is this more about oversupply? What do you think?

HORMATS: It's both. It's a weakening of the global economy, not a dramatic one, but a moderate one. And it's also a supply factor, and that goes to another Saudi point. Again, as much as we're appalled by what happened, the Saudis are the key members of OPEC.

So, if there's going to be a tightening of production, it's going to have to be led by Saudi Arabia. They have the most excess capacity and therefore, they would have to reduce output to help push prices up, if that's the objective of oil producers.

BARTIROMO: So, you expect that to happen?

HORMATS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What do you think oil -- I mean, what's your take on oil? If it goes much lower than this, you're going to have a problem with the Shell producers, as well, aren't you?

HORMATS: Well, see, this is the other part where the Saudis have had two objectives here. They don't want the price of oil to fall too much because they depend on it. On the other hand, a couple of years ago, the Saudis had a view, if they keep the prices down, because some of these Shell producers, in the U.S., and also (INAUDIBLE) have a lot of leverage.

They will push some of them out of the market or force them to cut back on productions. So, again, Saudi strategy plays a key role in that, as well, even though we're not so dependent on their oil. It's a global price and they have the biggest impact of anyone on that global price.

BARTIROMO: By the way, do you think with the slowdown on the horizon, economic slowdown, the Fed, obviously, yesterday, talked about how great things are going, but markets have been worried.

HORMATS: I think the slowdown is modest, I don't think it's a plunge. I do think escalation of a trade war does slow the world economy down, not just for the United States and China, but a lot of other countries depend, for instance, in East Asia --

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: on sales to China, if their economy slows, and it's slowing for other reasons, a bit, not a lot. But trade war would make it a lot slower.

BARTIROMO: Has a big impact.

HORMATS: And Asia gets impacted and that affects their finances because they have a lot of debt, so they have to earn money to pay off their debt.

BARTIROMO: I'm feeling coupled, coupling, remember that?

HORMATS: There is coupling. It's an interdependent world.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HORMATS: Once you do one thing, it affects a lot of other things.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: And sometimes, people don't think through the secondary effects.

BARTIROMO: It is great to see you this morning. Thank you so much.

HORMATS: Pleasure to be with you, Maria, as always. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Always a pleasure to get your insights, Bob Hormats. Tune in tomorrow on FOX Business, Liz Claman will be in Argentina. She's anchoring Countdown to the Closing Bell, live, from the G20 summit, in Argentina. She will be in Buenos Aires, beginning at 3:00 p.m. Eastern, tomorrow, so join Liz for her special coverage.

But first, President Trump just tweeted this, he wants to talk about G.M. He says, General Motors is very counter to what other auto and other companies are doing. Big Steel is opening and renovating plants all over the country. Auto companies are pouring into the U.S., including BMW, which just announced a major new plant. The USA is booming, writes the President, this morning.

We will take a short break. When we come back, running with the heroes, the Cardinals, Larry Fitzgerald's touching tribute to Pat Tillman and John McCain, showing up on his cleats, we'll tell you more about that, coming up.

And then, a spicy Christmas, that's for sure, Taco Bell rolls out a holiday apparel line, featuring sweaters, blankets, even onesies, back in a minute

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. As you saw, markets are pulling back this morning after that 600-plus-point rally yesterday. We are expecting a lower opening this morning for the broader averages. Stormy Daniels calling out her attorney, Michael Avenatti. Cheryl Casone with this story and headlines, Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right, Maria. In an interview with The Daily Beast, Daniels claims that Avenatti filed a defamation lawsuit against President Trump without her permission. Last month, the federal judge threw out that lawsuit and ordered Daniels to pay Trump's legal fees, which are estimated to be $350,000. Daniels also said she had no idea Avenatti started a second crowd-funding site for her legal expenses. Avenatti says, he's always been with Daniels and says he started the fund-raising to cover his legal fees. Because most of the money so far has gone to her security.

Well, outdoor gear company, Patagonia, donating the $1o million it saved from President Trump's tax cuts to non-profit environmental groups. Patagonia says, the donation is an addition to one percent of sales it gives to environmental groups every year. The new GOP tax law cut corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 21 percent, you may remember. Patagonia CEO called Trump's tax cuts "irresponsible" for taking away from environmental services.

Well, Taco Bell waste no time getting into the Christmas spirit. The company rolling out festive sweaters, they've also got blankets. Take a look at all of these onesies that look like Taco Bell hot sauce packets, because who doesn't need that? But the clothing and other gifts don't come as cheap as Taco Bell food. Sweaters are $59.00 each. The onesie, Maria, $78.00. Shares of Taco Bell's parent, Yum! Brands, up nine percent so far this year. I dare somebody on the panel to wear that one day on television.

BARTIROMO: Yes, somebody with six kids.

(LAUGHTER)

MURPHY: I'm in. Set me up.

MCDOWELL: You need the onesie --

MURPHY: I'm on for the onesie. I don't know if $78.00 is actually expensive for a onesie or if that's -- I don't know about the onesie mark.

MCDOWELL: It's not cheap. You need the onesie to hide -- that you're fat from eating at Taco Bell all the time. And I say that from personal experience, Nachos BellGrande every day and I was at least 40 pounds heavier than I am right now. So, there you go.

BARTIROMO: Nacho Grande every day?

MCDOWELL: Nacho -- yes, Nachos BellGrande and a beer, that was college.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE). All right, we'll take a break. When we come back, a hero's honor; the Cardinal's Larry Fitzgerald pays tribute to Pat Tillman and John McCain with some eye-catching cleats next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Here's a change, NFL ratings are up; Jared Max, why are ratings turning around here?

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: Maybe, Maria, good morning, it's record scoring, more legalized gambling. You know, some betters will say, I'm only interested to watch if I have action on the game. Oh, and have you noticed, we have not been talking about players kneeling for the national anthem, maybe some who were turned away are coming back.

Let's take a look at the numbers -- keep in mind, this is strictly Nielsen T.V. rating not streaming. Average audience for games this season at 15.8 million, five percent higher than last year's average, but still noticeably behind 2016 and 2015. Expect good numbers tonight on Fox, 8:20 Eastern. First place teams: Cowboys 6-5, tied with Washington to top the NFC East, host the 10-1 Saints, New Orleans, has won 10 in a row. And what we'll notice tonight, the Cowboys wearing the alternate white color rush uniforms; Saints will be in all black. Teams don't have to wear the color rush on Thursdays as they did in the past but the Cowboys elected to do so.

And hey, fashion goes hand-in-hand this week, week 13 of NFL, is my cause for my cleats' week -- an initiative began by Larry Fitzgerald around 500 players set to show case their cleats for charitable foundations. Now, the cleats that the players are going to be wearing, Arizona Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald wears these to honors the late Pat Tillman, who joined the army after 9/11, died in friendly fire in 2004. Camouflage design, we see Tillman's face, his foundation provides scholarships to veterans and their families.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY FITZGERALD, FOOTBALL PLAYER, ARIZONA CARDINALS: Every game day in Arizona, we remember Pat Tillman's sacrifice, his legacy lives on through the Pat Tillman foundation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Larry Fitzgerald's cleats also honor his old friend, the late Senator John McCain, you recall Fitzgerald spoke at McCain's memorial service. Megan McCain writing on Twitter: "This is so special -- thank you, Larry Fitzgerald, my father would have loved this. Thank you for your continued love and friendship for my father and for the amazing hero, Pat Tillman. Maria.

BARTIROMO: That's very nice. Thank you, Jared.

MURPHY: And we should really focus, if the NFL wants their ratings going up, they should focus on guys like Larry Fitzgerald and things like this that they're doing because it's an awesome story.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and look at the reaction that you get when you actually see the guys playing football.

MURPHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And not focused on politics.

FREEMAN: It's the great American game and you're right, once the off-the- field stuff is not the focus, people want to watch.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you.

MURPHY: 52-51 scores help also.

BARTIROMO: Jared's sports reports on Fox News 24/7 or Sirius Radio XM 115. Still ahead, the A.I. mini car; Amazon's new venture into self-driving cars, wait until you see this. It's powered by artificial intelligence, right here, next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5TVG-3KF1-JB20-G3SB-00000-00Stocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On Cleats2018-11-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:35ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTJames Freeman, Mike Murphy, Michael Sonnenfeldt, Bob HormatsNEWSFinancial112901cb.231Stocks Up on Powell Remarks; Deutsche Bank Offices Raided In Money Laundering Probe; Microsoft Overtakes Apple; Auto Tariff Threat; Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman Arrives in Argentina for G20 Summit; Crude Oil Slides Below $50.00 For First Time in over One Year; Stormy Calls Out Avenatti; Patagonia Donates Tax Cuts; Taco Bell Christmas Outfits; Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald Honors Pat Tillman and John McCain On CleatsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti, Cheryl Casone, Jared Max

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you. What a day yesterday. We are looking at a follow through this morning. Thank you so much.

Good morning, everyone. Happy Thursday. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it Thursday, November 29th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are pulling back this morning after that huge rally yesterday.

Dow Industrials now down 81 points. We are following through on what led the market higher yesterday. It was a major rally on the street. The Dow and the S&P 500 now in positive territory for this month.

Stocks rallied on the comment -- this comment from Fed Chairman Jay Powell, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: Interest rates are still low by historical standards, and they remain just below the range of estimates of that level that would be neutral for the economy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And with that, the markets shut up 600 points in Europe. This morning, there is some follow through.

The markets are higher across the board.

FT-100 up 45 points right now, two-thirds of one percent, CAC Quarante in Paris also up two-thirds of a percent, and the DAX Index in Germany up a fraction this morning, 21 points higher.

In Asia overnight, mixed performances. Hong Kong and China were lower, but Japan was higher by a fraction, as was the Korean KOSPI Index.

Deutsche Bank has been raided. Prosecutors alleging that the bank helped clients create tax havens and launder money.

What it means for the already struggling bank coming up.

And a new tariff threat, President Trump warning of new charges on vehicles following the G.M. layoffs.

Plus Volvo is slowing hiring plans here in the U.S. because of those tariffs. The fallout coming up this morning.

Honoring our heroes, Arizona Cardinals wide receiver, Larry Fitzgerald, pays tribute to Pat Tillman and Senator John McCain on his feet.

A closer look at his special cleats for Sunday's big game, that's coming up.

And it is beginning to look a lot like Christmas at Taco Bell. The fast- food giant unveiling a line of themed clothes, from socks to sweaters, even onesies.

We will tell you about it. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, "The Wall Street Journal's" Assistant Editorial Page Editor, James Freeman, and Rosecliff CEO/Managing Partner, Mike Murphy.

Great to see you this morning.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Good morning. I'll wear the onesie on T.V.

BARTIROMO: Taco Bell clothing --

MURPHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- here we come. Big move yesterday in the markets, huh?

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: It is a big move, and the oil dipping blow, 50 bucks a barrel, suggests the argument Mr. Powell was making has been bolstered this moment.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it sure has. And yesterday, I was -- I was at The New York Economic Club --

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- and everyone was waiting, will Jay Powell make comments about the interest rate story.

He did a lot about financial stability --

FREEMAN: Right. .

BARTIROMO: -- in his speech. It wasn't until he said, "Look, we're still at low levels," which we all knew and yet the market saw that as a reason to run up, Mike.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think, really, the main thing that they got was six week ago, he said that, "We're nowhere near neutral on rates."

MCDOWELL: A long way.

FREEMAN: Which is why there was a long --

MCDOWELL: A long way was --

FREEMAN: Sorry, a long way.

And now he's saying we're a lot closes to that, which implies there'll be less rate hikes, which the market likes, that's why he saw the rally yesterday.

BARTIROMO: So that was the change in --

FREEMAN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That one word usually tells it, right?

FREEMAN: I've --

MCDOWELL: So The Wall Street Journal Editorial Page --

FREEMAN: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: -- James Freeman, where you work, don't know if you had your hands in this, says that this is a welcome rethink.

But as "The Journal" does point out that we have a market, a global market, and a world that is grappling with global slowing growth, bad trade policy that's deterring investment, and a fed that is also still gradually reducing this unprecedented bond portfolio.

And we have no way of knowing what the knock-on effects of that are or will be, so this is a very welcome, at least, reasonable approach to hiking short-term interest rates.

I paraphrase.

FREEMAN: Thank you. And just the editorial also adds those Vice Chairman -- Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida comments from earlier in the week saying the fact that you've got a lot of people working doesn't automatically lead to inflation.

That's a -- that's a welcome sign from the fed.

Personally, I kind of like going a bit higher. I don't think the fed funds rate ought to be equal to the rate of inflation.

But again, this oil news this morning, if you want to be dovish, if you want to say inflation is very restrained, you have a better case today.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you sure do. We're going to check markets this morning.

Take a look at oil, sitting right at $50.00 a barrel right now, what a selloff in the last month and a half.

Then another half a percent this morning with light sweet crude at $50.02 a barrel.

Joining the conversation this morning is the Chairman of UBS, Axel Weber is with us this morning in an exclusive interview talking about markets and investing capital today.

The CEO of Calamos Investments, John Koudounis, is joining us as well.

Almost looking at the backdrop for stocks.

Patron Spirits Founder, John Paul Mitchell Co-Founder, John Paul DeJoria is here as well.

Along with Wisconsin Congressman and House Financial Services Subcommittee Chairman, Sean Duffy.

Plus Tennessee Senator Elect, Marsha Blackburn with us.

A lot to talk about with the Senator Elect, so stay with us. We got a big three hours coming up.

We kick it off right here with this top story, and that is the stock market comeback. Check out these numbers, the Dow, the S&P 500, and the NASDAQ surged yesterday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell's comments on interest rates.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

POWELL: Interest rates are still low by historical standards, and they remain just below the range of estimates of that level that would be neutral for the economy.

That is neither speeding up nor slowing up growth.

My FOMC colleagues and I, as well as many private sector economists are forecasting continued solid growth, low unemployment, and inflation remaining near two percent.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is TIGER 21 Chairman, Michael Sonnenfeldt.

Michael, it is good to see you. Thank so much for joining us.

MICHAEL SONNENFELDT, CHAIRMAN, TIGER 21: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: How's the sentiment in terms of your members?

SONNENFELDT: I -- our members are trying to have the discipline that when the market went down 600, they didn't overreact and when it goes up 600, but clearly interest rates and tariffs are the story of the day.

Are the tariffs really hurting the economy and what's going to happen with the exploding deficit and will we get some infrastructure? These are the bigger stories they are dealing with across the country.

BARTIROMO: Are they impacting things, the tariffs right now?

I mean look we've news this morning in terms of companies making moves in the auto sector as a result of these tariffs.

SONNENFELDT: Yes. There's no question that auto, for sure, particularly with the news around G.M. and what's going on, tariffs are having a huge impact on the auto industry.

We have members in our Detroit group who are clearly worried because with the closings of G.M. that has an impact, real estate prices are probably still too high.

That group is waiting for prices to come down and they've taken some real estate off the table in the last quarter.

FREEMAN: I'm trying to get a sense of how you think your members, investors generally might react to any news we get out of this weekend's G20 meeting.

Obviously both the U.S. and the Chinese side have kind of downplayed hopes for a solution to the trade dispute, but what if at the dinner Xi Jinping and Donald Trump solve it?

What if we have an agreement or maybe a framework to get to an agreement?

SONNENFELDT: Sure. So I would say that that would be a very important news, but when our members meet in groups every month, there are a load of struggling like what's the really important news and what's going to happen.

And they try to have a All-Weather portfolio, so when I was talking to a member recently, he was saying -- it was an interesting thing, he's shorting hundred-year bonds.

Why? Because if interest rates come up a little, those bonds are going to be a great stabilizer as they fall.

The Australian markets way overheated, American real estate somewhat overheated sector by sector, so our members in the last quarter took -- last two quarters have taken about 10 percent of their holdings off of the table.

MURPHY: So when you talk to your members, I'm kind of talking my own book here because we invest venture capital private equity.

So much focus on unicorns right now in the market. How do your members see that and do they want to be involved in the private space?

SONNENFELDT: Totally. The largest shift over the last decade in our membership is private equity, grown from 10 percent to 24, all-time high.

So as real estate is coming down, all-time high to private equity now exceeding even public equity 23 percent, private equity 24 percent.

Why? Because in venture and in private, you have these scalable businesses given our technology, that's where the action is, not as passive investors.

Our members were the great entrepreneurs who built businesses, so when they sell their business, what they can do is invest in another business where they can be on the board or they can actually kick the tires and understand really what's going on.

BARTIROMO: Does that tell you anything about where we are in terms of growth, this optimism about the unicorns?

SONNENFELDT: So what it tells you is when you see real estate coming down so quickly, that's the biggest sign that those markets are frothy.

But in total, our members are allocated over 73 percent of public equity, private equity in real estate, that's a pretty long-term bullish referendum on the U.S. economy.

So, I would say long-term optimism about the U.S., short-term, we're in choppy waters, but still sailing still fine.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Thursday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, November 29th, your top stories right now, 6:31 a.m. on the East Coast.

Futures showing the markets will pull back, this morning, at the opening of trading. Dow Industrials down 72 points right now, S&P 500 is down 9, and the NASDAQ down 40 points, that's two-thirds of one percent, lower, that after a powerful rally yesterday.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell, gave the economy a thumbs up, yesterday, in his 12:00 p.m. speech, it sent the market, shooting higher. The Dow, in fact, erasing the November decline, finishing higher on the session, by better than 600 points. Now, the Dow is in positive territory for 2018, with that huge rally of better than 2-1/2 percent.

In Europe this morning, we are not -- we are seeing some follow through there, in European indices, up 43 points, the CAC Quarante up 30 points right now, and the DAX Index in Germany, up 30 points, that's about a quarter percent higher, right now.

Markets were mixed, overnight, in Asia, meanwhile, Japan did well up a third of a percent, but the Hang Seng and the Shanghai, under pressure, overnight.

Trade troubles hitting the automakers, Volvo is cancelling its IPO. It is announcing a cutback and hiring plans, as well, all over increased tariffs from China.

Meanwhile, President Trump tweeting out that downsizing at General Motors may justify new tariffs. We'll tell you what the President has to say about that, as we break it all down.

Then, this, giving it away, Patagonia, deciding not to give its millions of dollars in tax cut savings, back to employees, why, we will tell you where they decided to send that money.

Then, honoring a hero, Arizona Cardinals wide receiver, Larry Fitzgerald, pays tribute to the late senator John McCain, with a special pair of cleats, the details, coming up.

And it is a Taco Bell Christmas. The fast food chain celebrates its own line of holiday clothing based on sauce packets, yes, we will tell you about that, coming up.

All those stories coming up, but first, our top story this half an hour, tensions are simmering, President Trump headed to Buenos Aires for the G20 summit, this morning, where he is expected to sit down with the President of China, Xi Jinping, for a crucial dinner, discussing the potential of a trade truce.

The administration floating the idea that a deal can be achieved, but also additional tariffs should the two companies not strike an agreement, joining me right now, is the Former Undersecretary of State for Economic Growth, Energy and the Environment, Bob Hormats, Bob, it's good to see you this morning.

BOB HORMATS, FORMER UNDERSECRETARY OF STATE: Good to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. What could come out of this meeting, in Argentina?

HORMATS: Well, hopefully, some kind of deal that's sufficient to stop the escalation in tariffs, which are harmful to China, but also harmful to the U.S., a lot of American companies are uncomfortable with this trade war with China, and the fact that it could get worse.

The probability, though, is that they are not going to have a breakthrough, because to have a breakthrough, a lot of work needs to be done, there has to be agreement on principles, neither of those have occurred at this point, so the best they can do is develop a process for moving forward with some broad outlines of objectives that both leaders support.

BARTIROMO: One of these -- one of the reasons for these tariffs against China, the President says, is because of China's behavior, the fact that it is stealing intellectual property. It is forcing the transfer of technology.

It is not opening its markets to foreign companies the way the rest of the world would like. And yet, there is another impact of these tariffs, look at the toll on automakers, as you mentioned. Volvo is slowing down hiring in its new assembly plans in Charleston, South Carolina, we learned, this morning.

It's citing the increased tariffs from the trade fight with China. The company also said it's calling off plans for an IPO, potentially where $30 billion as result of this dispute, follows General Motors plans to cut 14,000 jobs, shut down 5 U.S. factories next year. The President is now saying that G.M. closures may actually justify the auto tariffs.

So, how much longer can this go and how damaging will this be, do you think, to companies that are getting, sort of, caught up in this fight?

HORMATS: Well, it's going to be even more damaging if the President follows through and at the end of year, early next year, raises the tariffs from 10 percent to 25 percent, and adds a whole new swaff of items to the tariff list.

And the reason is, it does certainly hurt China, but it does hurt us because of the interdependence and relationship. We get a lot of --

BARTIROMO: So, what should the President do, Bob? I mean, you know the issues about the -- about the intellectual property.

HORMATS: Yes, I spent 10 days in China intellectual property, when I was in government, intellectual property issues, questions of partnership, subsidies, they all come up. There have been negotiations on them.

I think what's needed is, for the two presidents to agree that if they are going to move ahead in this relationship, they've got to take a much more determined view to get changes that are acceptable and level the playing field between foreign companies and Chinese companies.

BARTIROMO: or could this --

HORMATS: I think the Chinese understand something has to be done. I just think that the tariff escalation is probably so harmful to both sides that it's unlikely to be the way of getting real progress.

BARTIROMO: So, you say, the Chinese understand something needs to be done. What does that mean, though, I mean, we're talking about dictator for life, in President Xi?

HORMATS: I give you one example.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HORMATS: I gave keynote speech at the Shenzhen Technology (INAUDIBLE) high-tech products from China and all around the world.

Even the foreign companies that represented there, said the Chinese are developing intellectual property of their own, innovative stuff of -- on many levels in China, so they -- their entrepreneurs now have an interest in protecting their intellectual property, just as, of course, our companies do.

So, I think there's a greater chance now of getting some agreement on intellectual property protection that there might not have been five years ago when the Chinese were not developing their own intellectual property. That's an area where, I think, they're (INAUDIBLE) overlap some convergence, also subsidies.

BARTIROMO: Very good point.

HORMATS: The Chinese are trying to cut back on subsidies. Their big spending -- even though the reserves are substantial, their spending is substantial, as well. I think reducing subsidies in their interest and, of course, in the interest of avoiding unfair competition, would be something they might decide that they can do.

BARTIROMO: So, there's some room here. There's room for upside potential at this meeting, isn't there?

HORMATS: There is. And I think that it's not that if they're going to have a breakthrough in either or these or other items. But if they establish a process, whereby the leaders ask for their experts to sit together and work for, say, six months and report back to them, on two or three or four items, it won't be a whole list of the kind United States has proposed to try.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: But two or three items of particular significance that might be the way out of it and avoid further escalation of tariffs, which as you correctly point out, is going to be harmful, just because these economies are so interdependent.

And one point for Americans to bear in mind, most of the tariffs we've imposed so far, are intermediate goods, products that are components for American companies, which squeezes American companies to the next realm, if their new items added. They'll be on consumer goods, like --

BARTIROMO: Like the iPhone.

HORMATS: Exactly. And those --

BARTIROMO: Yes, which is why, Apple has been trading down.

HORMATS: Exactly, they're 10 percent or 25 percent that virtually goes right to the consumer.

BARTIROMO: But there's a potential, I think, I hear you saying, of a big rally, if we get any upside potential out of this, maybe markets get a relief rally --

HORMATS: I think they will.

BARTIROMO: if we see something --

HORMATS: For two reasons, one, they'll make progress or hopefully make progress on certain subsidy issues or other issues. And second, if it works or if it's the right kind of deal, can avoid further escalation, so both would be market movers on the positive side.

BARTIROMO: Interesting to note that the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia, Mohammed bin Salman, MBS, also arriving in Buenos Aires for the G20 summit, amid the outrage, over the murder of Jamal Khashoggi. I want to get your take on how he is going to be treated. I recently spoke with Prince Al- Waleed bin Talal, about this incident, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: A month ago, a brutal murder of Jamal Khashoggi, where his body was dismembered, is Mohammed bin Salman for real, or is he lying to us about this modernization plan?

PRINCE AL-WALEED BIN TALAL, MEMBER OF THE SAUDI ROYAL FAMILY: As for the Jamal Khashoggi incident, you know, you have to understand, Jamal was not only my friend. He was working with me. And his last job in Saudi Arabia, it was me and then Arab Channel.

And I like to give through you my condolences, again, to his family, to his wife, ex-wife, and to his children, and to his family, because Jamal was a reformer, he was in no position at all and what took place in that Saudi consulate was clearly horrific, despicable and tragic and I believe that Saudi Arabia is going to get to the bottom of it.

But please, you have to give us some time until the investigation is done and made public by the government of Saudi Arabia.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: You know, Bob, it's hard to know if Prince Al-Waleed was talking the party lines for Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the Crown Prince, trying to give back in his good graces. We know that Al-Waleed was jailed by MBS, and then he came out, or if, in fact, he is being honest in terms of saying, well, let's see what the investigation shows.

Your reaction to the Crown Prince's attendance and what the U.S. should do now in terms of its relationship with the Saudis?

HORMATS: Well, I think the problem the U.S. and other countries have is, first of all, they're appalled at what happened.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we all are.

HORMATS: There's no question about that, and for good reason. The second question, though, is they, a lot of these countries need Saudi oil, we don't really depend so much on Saudi oil, a lot of the other countries in the G20, do.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: Third, they have opportunities to sell more things to Saudi Arabia, so their abhorrence at this event, is tempered by the fact that they have real economic interest, and the fact is that some of them also, want to work with the Saudis for strategic reasons in the gulf. So, they have to work this balance --

BARTIROMO: Right, but we know that Iran --

HORMATS: that's the problem.

BARTIROMO: Iran is the problem. The Saudis have been a partner of the United States not just for oil but against Iran, so can the U.S. walk away?

HORMATS: U.S. cannot walk away.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HORMATS: U.S. cannot walk away.

BARTIROMO: That was what I was getting at. But you mentioned oil. Take a look at crowd oil now, below $50.00 yesterday, sitting right at $50.00, we're back below $50.00 this morning, first time in over a year, Bob, that we're seeing below $5.000, ahead of this OPEC meeting, which is happening next week.

Is this telling us something about the global economy, that things have weakened, is that why oil is selling off or is this more about oversupply? What do you think?

HORMATS: It's both. It's a weakening of the global economy, not a dramatic one, but a moderate one. And it's also a supply factor, and that goes to another Saudi point. Again, as much as we're appalled by what happened, the Saudis are the key members of OPEC.

So, if there's going to be a tightening of production, it's going to have to be led by Saudi Arabia. They have the most excess capacity and therefore, they would have to reduce output to help push prices up, if that's the objective of oil producers.

BARTIROMO: So, you expect that to happen?

HORMATS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What do you think oil -- I mean, what's your take on oil? If it goes much lower than this, you're going to have a problem with the Shell producers, as well, aren't you?

HORMATS: Well, see, this is the other part where the Saudis have had two objectives here. They don't want the price of oil to fall too much because they depend on it. On the other hand, a couple of years ago, the Saudis had a view, if they keep the prices down, because some of these Shell producers, in the U.S., and also (INAUDIBLE) have a lot of leverage.

They will push some of them out of the market or force them to cut back on productions. So, again, Saudi strategy plays a key role in that, as well, even though we're not so dependent on their oil. It's a global price and they have the biggest impact of anyone on that global price.

BARTIROMO: By the way, do you think with the slowdown on the horizon, economic slowdown, the Fed, obviously, yesterday, talked about how great things are going, but markets have been worried.

HORMATS: I think the slowdown is modest, I don't think it's a plunge. I do think escalation of a trade war does slow the world economy down, not just for the United States and China, but a lot of other countries depend, for instance, in East Asia --

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: on sales to China, if their economy slows, and it's slowing for other reasons, a bit, not a lot. But trade war would make it a lot slower.

BARTIROMO: Has a big impact.

HORMATS: And Asia gets impacted and that affects their finances because they have a lot of debt, so they have to earn money to pay off their debt.

BARTIROMO: I'm feeling coupled, coupling, remember that?

HORMATS: There is coupling. It's an interdependent world.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HORMATS: Once you do one thing, it affects a lot of other things.

BARTIROMO: Right.

HORMATS: And sometimes, people don't think through the secondary effects.

BARTIROMO: It is great to see you this morning. Thank you so much.

HORMATS: Pleasure to be with you, Maria, as always. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Always a pleasure to get your insights, Bob Hormats. Tune in tomorrow on FOX Business, Liz Claman will be in Argentina. She's anchoring Countdown to the Closing Bell, live, from the G20 summit, in Argentina. She will be in Buenos Aires, beginning at 3:00 p.m. Eastern, tomorrow, so join Liz for her special coverage.

But first, President Trump just tweeted this, he wants to talk about G.M. He says, General Motors is very counter to what other auto and other companies are doing. Big Steel is opening and renovating plants all over the country. Auto companies are pouring into the U.S., including BMW, which just announced a major new plant. The USA is booming, writes the President, this morning.

We will take a short break. When we come back, running with the heroes, the Cardinals, Larry Fitzgerald's touching tribute to Pat Tillman and John McCain, showing up on his cleats, we'll tell you more about that, coming up.

And then, a spicy Christmas, that's for sure, Taco Bell rolls out a holiday apparel line, featuring sweaters, blankets, even onesies, back in a minute

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. As you saw, markets are pulling back this morning after that 600-plus-point rally yesterday. We are expecting a lower opening this morning for the broader averages. Stormy Daniels calling out her attorney, Michael Avenatti. Cheryl Casone with this story and headlines, Cheryl.

CASONE: That's right, Maria. In an interview with The Daily Beast, Daniels claims that Avenatti filed a defamation lawsuit against President Trump without her permission. Last month, the federal judge threw out that lawsuit and ordered Daniels to pay Trump's legal fees, which are estimated to be $350,000. Daniels also said she had no idea Avenatti started a second crowd-funding site for her legal expenses. Avenatti says, he's always been with Daniels and says he started the fund-raising to cover his legal fees. Because most of the money so far has gone to her security.

Well, outdoor gear company, Patagonia, donating the $1o million it saved from President Trump's tax cuts to non-profit environmental groups. Patagonia says, the donation is an addition to one percent of sales it gives to environmental groups every year. The new GOP tax law cut corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 21 percent, you may remember. Patagonia CEO called Trump's tax cuts "irresponsible" for taking away from environmental services.

Well, Taco Bell waste no time getting into the Christmas spirit. The company rolling out festive sweaters, they've also got blankets. Take a look at all of these onesies that look like Taco Bell hot sauce packets, because who doesn't need that? But the clothing and other gifts don't come as cheap as Taco Bell food. Sweaters are $59.00 each. The onesie, Maria, $78.00. Shares of Taco Bell's parent, Yum! Brands, up nine percent so far this year. I dare somebody on the panel to wear that one day on television.

BARTIROMO: Yes, somebody with six kids.

(LAUGHTER)

MURPHY: I'm in. Set me up.

MCDOWELL: You need the onesie --

MURPHY: I'm on for the onesie. I don't know if $78.00 is actually expensive for a onesie or if that's -- I don't know about the onesie mark.

MCDOWELL: It's not cheap. You need the onesie to hide -- that you're fat from eating at Taco Bell all the time. And I say that from personal experience, Nachos BellGrande every day and I was at least 40 pounds heavier than I am right now. So, there you go.

BARTIROMO: Nacho Grande every day?

MCDOWELL: Nacho -- yes, Nachos BellGrande and a beer, that was college.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE). All right, we'll take a break. When we come back, a hero's honor; the Cardinal's Larry Fitzgerald pays tribute to Pat Tillman and John McCain with some eye-catching cleats next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Here's a change, NFL ratings are up; Jared Max, why are ratings turning around here?

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: Maybe, Maria, good morning, it's record scoring, more legalized gambling. You know, some betters will say, I'm only interested to watch if I have action on the game. Oh, and have you noticed, we have not been talking about players kneeling for the national anthem, maybe some who were turned away are coming back.

Let's take a look at the numbers -- keep in mind, this is strictly Nielsen T.V. rating not streaming. Average audience for games this season at 15.8 million, five percent higher than last year's average, but still noticeably behind 2016 and 2015. Expect good numbers tonight on Fox, 8:20 Eastern. First place teams: Cowboys 6-5, tied with Washington to top the NFC East, host the 10-1 Saints, New Orleans, has won 10 in a row. And what we'll notice tonight, the Cowboys wearing the alternate white color rush uniforms; Saints will be in all black. Teams don't have to wear the color rush on Thursdays as they did in the past but the Cowboys elected to do so.

And hey, fashion goes hand-in-hand this week, week 13 of NFL, is my cause for my cleats' week -- an initiative began by Larry Fitzgerald around 500 players set to show case their cleats for charitable foundations. Now, the cleats that the players are going to be wearing, Arizona Cardinals' Larry Fitzgerald wears these to honors the late Pat Tillman, who joined the army after 9/11, died in friendly fire in 2004. Camouflage design, we see Tillman's face, his foundation provides scholarships to veterans and their families.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY FITZGERALD, FOOTBALL PLAYER, ARIZONA CARDINALS: Every game day in Arizona, we remember Pat Tillman's sacrifice, his legacy lives on through the Pat Tillman foundation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Larry Fitzgerald's cleats also honor his old friend, the late Senator John McCain, you recall Fitzgerald spoke at McCain's memorial service. Megan McCain writing on Twitter: "This is so special -- thank you, Larry Fitzgerald, my father would have loved this. Thank you for your continued love and friendship for my father and for the amazing hero, Pat Tillman. Maria.

BARTIROMO: That's very nice. Thank you, Jared.

MURPHY: And we should really focus, if the NFL wants their ratings going up, they should focus on guys like Larry Fitzgerald and things like this that they're doing because it's an awesome story.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and look at the reaction that you get when you actually see the guys playing football.

MURPHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And not focused on politics.

FREEMAN: It's the great American game and you're right, once the off-the- field stuff is not the focus, people want to watch.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you.

MURPHY: 52-51 scores help also.

BARTIROMO: Jared's sports reports on Fox News 24/7 or Sirius Radio XM 115. Still ahead, the A.I. mini car; Amazon's new venture into self-driving cars, wait until you see this. It's powered by artificial intelligence, right here, next hour in MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5WN0-J3D1-JDJN-6396-00000-00Stocks - U.S. Futures Fall As DoJ Launches Probe into Big Tech2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks - U.S. Futures Fall As DoJ Launches Probe into Big Tech

Investing.com -

Investing.com - U.S. futures fell on Wednesday, dragged down by technology stocks after the U.S. Department of Justice announced an antitrust investigation into leading online platforms, raising fears that regulatory action could wreck the business model of some highly profitable companies.

The DoJ did not name which companies were under investigation, but said it would look at how they got their market power and whether they were engaging in best practices.

"The Department's review will consider the widespread concerns that consumers, businesses, and entrepreneurs have expressed about search, social media, and some retail services online," the agency said in its notice, which suggests that the likes of Google (NASDAQ:GOOGL), Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) will be investigated.

Google, Facebook and Amazon were all down over 1% in premarket trade.

Facebook was also hit with news that it is expected to settle with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million its disclosure of privacy practices and make a $5 billion settlement with the FTC.

Nasdaq 100 futures slumped 42 points or 0.5% by 6:41 AM ET (10:41 GMT), while Dow futures slipped 58 points or 0.2% and S&P 500 futures fell 8 points or 0.3%.

Earnings continued to be in focus, with Boeing (NYSE:BA), and others reporting before the bell, while Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA), Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) and Equifax (NYSE:EFX) release their earnings after the bell. AT&T (NYSE:T) slipped 0.3% despite its second-quarter earnings meeting analysts' forecasts.

Makers of semiconductors were higher, with Texas Instruments (NASDAQ:TXN) surging 6.6% after its earnings encouraged hopes that global demand for chips will pick up in the second half, while Micron (NASDAQ:MU) gained 0.4% and Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ:AMD) inched up 0.2%.

Social app Snap (NYSE:SNAP) jumped 10.6% after it said it added 13 million daily active users in the last quarter.

Elsewhere,

CannTrust

(TSX:TRST) fell 4.5% after reports that its top executives were informed in November of illegal cannabis growth, the Globe and Mail reported.

On the economic front, manufacturing and services PMIs are at 9:45 AM ET (13:45 GMT), already preceded by gloomy readings out of Japan and Europe. New home sales are due at 10:00 AM ET (14:00 GMT).

In commodities, crude oil gained 0.1% to $56.85 a barrel. Gold futures rose 0.3% to $1,425.75 a troy ounce, while the U.S. dollar index, which measures the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, was flat at 97.403.

urn:contentItem:5Y68-SVX1-F11P-X3XN-00000-00Stocks - U.S. Futures Point Higher as Virus Fears Ease2020-02-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks - U.S. Futures Point Higher as Virus Fears Ease

Investing.com -

By Peter Nurse

Investing.com - U.S. stocks are set to open higher Wednesday, continuing the recent positive trend as investors take heart from signs the coronavirus outbreak might be peaking.

At 7:30 AM ET (1230 GMT), futures for theS&P 500 traded 12 points, or 0.4%, higher, futures for the Nasdaq were up 49 points, or 0.5%, while the Dow Jones futures contract rose 125 points, or 0.4%.

The death toll from China's coronavirus, officially called Covid-19, now exceeds 1100, but there have been signs the outbreak may be peaking at the epicenter of the crisis.

Authorities in Hubei, the province where the outbreak likely originated, said there were an additional 1,638 confirmed cases of the virus Wednesday. That is almost one-third less than the previous day's new cases. However, reports from outside China suggest that this may be due more to changes in China's way of counting. China's National Health Commission said last week that it would no longer count new cases as confirmed until patients started showing symptoms of the disease. China's own studies suggest that people can remain asymptomatic for up to 24 days after catching the virus.

Both the S&P and Nasdaq again closed at record high levels Tuesday, posting gains in six of the last seven trading sessions and having their best months since June.

The large-cap tech companies, which have been behind a lot of the recent gains, will be in focus Wednesday following the announcement of a regulatory probe into previous deals by these firms. The move raised fears over a more aggressive regulatory crackdown on big tech.

Boeing (NYSE:BA) is also expected to be in the spotlight after the aircraft maker reported late Tuesday that it received no new orders for commercial jets in January. By contrast, its major rival Airbus (PA:AIR) received 274 orders.

Elsewhere, the U.S. earnings season may be coming to an end, but there are still some well-known names reporting.

Shares in

Lyft

(NASDAQ:LYFT) traded over 4% lower after hours despite reporting late Tuesday more than $1 billion in quarterly revenue. However, the ride-hailing company didn't move up its estimates for making a profit, a disappointment in the light of Uber's hopes of becoming profitable at an underlying level by the end of this year.

Shares in Bed Bath & Beyond (NASDAQ:BBBY) slumped 25% after announcing late Tuesday that same-store sales declined in December and January. The company, whose stock is heavily shorted, said it was facing inventory challenges and issues attracting customers to its stores.

CVS Health Corp (NYSE:CVS) reported fourth-quarter earnings that beat analysts' forecasts and revenue that topped expectations. These numbers may have impressed, but investors in CVS, as well as other stocks tied to healthcare, will be keeping an eye on developments in the Democratic primaries. This is especially with respect to Sen. Bernie Sanders, who won in New Hampshire on Tuesday and is running on a platform of single-payer health care.

Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) reports quarterly results after the bell Wednesday. The networking giant is expected to report a profit of 76 cents per share on revenue of about $12 billion, according to analysts' forecasts compiled by Investing.com.

The economic calendar is pretty bare Wednesday, but Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will be back on Capitol Hill for the second half of his semiannual Congressional testimony.

Powell will start speaking to the Senate Banking Committee at 10:00 AM ET (1500 GMT), after testifying before the House Financial Services committee Tuesday.

Elsewhere, the oil market has pushed higher Wednesday, rebounding a touch after recent losses. The U.S. government cut its forecast for world oil demand this year by 300,000 barrels a day, due to the virus outbreak, while the latest OPEC monthly report followed suit by cutting its forecast by 230,000 barrels a day..

The Energy Information Administration will report the latest weekly figures for U.S. oil supplies at 10:30 AM (15:30 GMT). Analysts are expecting the EIA to report a rise in inventories of about 3 million barrels, according to forecasts compiled by Investing.com.

Late Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute said that according to its measure crude stockpiles rose by 6 million barrels for the week ended Feb. 7.

AT 07:30 AM ET (1230 GMT), U.S. crude futures traded 1.7% higher at $50.77 a barrel and the international benchmark Brent contract rose 2.2% to $55.20. Additionally, gold futures fell 0.1% to $1,569.85/oz while EUR/USD traded at 1.0923, up 0.1%.

urn:contentItem:609D-XHH1-JCMN-Y2HK-00000-00Stocks worldwide slink back as virus dims recovery hopes2020-07-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:27:34ZLexisNexisStocks worldwide slink back as virus dims recovery hopes

Jul 07, 2020( MarketBeat: https://www.marketbeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) NEW YORK (AP) — Most of Wall Street is slipping in midday trading on Tuesday, giving back a slice of the big gains made the past couple weeks. More than three quarters of the stocks in the S&P 500 were dropping, and the index was down 0.1%, as of 11 a.m. Eastern time. Stocks sank more in France, Germany and elsewhere after the European Union's executive arm said this year's recession caused by the coronavirus pandemic will be deeper than forecast. It also said next year's expected rebound could be weaker than expected.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 176 points, or 0.7%, at 26,109, and stocks in Asia also fell following the big rally that swept markets worldwide on Monday. Big technology stocks were an outlier, though, with Microsoft, Apple and other titans pushing higher. Even though most stocks in the S&P 500 were lower, the tech titans' huge size gives them more sway over the index's direction, helping it momentarily erase all of its loss of 0.6% from earlier in the morning. They also helped lift the Nasdaq composite by 0.3%, extending its record set a day earlier. The U.S. stock market has been churning over the last month, with big daily moves up and down keeping it roughly in place. It's been a small-scale version of the market's movements since the start of the year, when a nearly 34% plunge on worries about the pandemic-caused recession quickly gave way to a tremendous rally that brought the S&P 500 nearly back to its record level. Pulling markets higher on one end are reports showing budding improvements in the economy. The job market, retail sales and other economic indicators are all still well below where they were before the pandemic struck. But they've stopped plummeting and have begun to grow again as governments relax restrictions meant to slow the spread of the coronavirus. That's combined with unprecedented amounts of aid from central banks and governments around the world to prop up markets. It also helped send the S&P 500 up 1.6% on Monday, following up on a 4% rise the prior week, which itself helped cap the best decade for the index since 1998. (Ad) In a form NS 43-101, two energy sector legends have told federal regulators that they may have found one of the world's biggest lithium discoveries - a massive 7 million tons near Tonopah, Nevada, worth around $70 billion. But pulling markets lower on the other end are worries that the optimism is overdone. The pandemic isn't going away, with infection levels worsening across wide swaths of the U.S. South and West, among other global hotspots. The concern is that could keep households and businesses nervous and scare them away from spending. In the worst-case scenario, it could force governments to bring back some of the restrictions that sent the economy into its sudden recession. Such worries spilled through markets Tuesday after the European Commission unveiled its more dour economic forecasts for 2020 and 2021. 'The road to recovery is still paved with uncertainty,' EU Economy Commissioner Paolo Gentiloni told reporters in Brussels. 'This is mostly linked to the epidemiological uncertainty.' The commission said the joint economy of the 27 nations in the European Union will shrink 8.3% this year, before growing 5.8% in 2021. In the previous forecasts released in May, it had forecast the economy would contract about 7.5% this year and bounce back 6% next year. Underscoring the fragility, a separate report showed that industrial production in Germany rebounded by less than economists expected in May, and remains far below levels from before the pandemic caused factories to close. Germany's DAX lost 1.1%, while France's CAC 40 fell 0.9%. The FTSE 100 in London dropped 1.6%. In Asia, Japan's Nikei 225 fell 0.4%, the Kospi in South Korea dropped 1.1% and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong slipped 1.4%. In the U.S. market, airlines and stocks of other companies that most need the economy to get closer to normal had the sharpest losses. United Airlines lost 6.2%, American Airlines slipped 5.8% and mall-owner Simon Property Group dropped 3.7%. Energy stocks fell 1.7% for the largest loss among the 11 sectors that make up the S&P 500. They've swung sharply with expectations for the economy's health and demand for oil. Devon Energy lost 5.1%, and National Oilwell Varo lost 4%. Benchmark U.S. crude slipped 0.1% to $40.60 per barrel. Brent crude, the international standard, rose 0.1% to $43.16 per barrel. On the winning end were the big tech-oriented companies that have been dominating the market for years. Investors have continued to pile into companies they believe are able to grow almost regardless of the economy and whether people are locked in quarantines. Microsoft rose 1.7%, Apple gained 1.1% and Google's parent company Alphabet added 1.1%. The yield on the 10-year Treasury slipped to 0.66% from 0.68% late Monday. It tends to move with investors' expectations for the economy and inflation. ___ AP Writers Yuri Kageyama and Samuel Petrequin contributed. Companies Mentioned in This Article 15 Healthcare Stocks that Analysts Love[1]There are more than 200 healthcare companies traded on public markets. Given the sheer number of pharmaceutical companies, medical research firms, hospital systems and other healthcare stocks, it can be hard to identify which healthcare companies are going to outperform the market. Fortunately, Wall Street's brightest minds have already done this for us. Every year, analyst issue approximately 3,000 distinct recommendations for healthcare companies. Analysts don't always get their "buy" ratings right, but it's worth taking a hard look when several analysts from different brokerages and research firm are giving "strong buy" and "buy" ratings to the same healthcare stock. This slide show lists the 15 healthcare companies that have the highest average analyst recommendations from Wall Street's equities research analysts over the last 12 months.View the "15 Healthcare Stocks that Analysts Love"[2].
